1100	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">BANGLADESH LAND HOLDING (LIMITATION) ORDER, 1972</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  7 BLD (AD) 210, 9 BLD (HCD) 1O. </p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  1972</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  BANGLADESH LAND HOLDING</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u style="text-underline: thick;">BANGLADESH LAND HOLDING (LIMITATION) ORDER (P.O. 98 OF 1972)</u></strong></p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>Article—3</strong></p><p>Pre-emption—Whether pre-emption can be allowed in favour of a person who owns more than 100 bighas of land violating provisions of Bangladesh Land Holding Limitation Order—When pre-emption was allowed in 1967 under section 26 F of the B.T. Act there was no question of land holding limitation upto 100 bighas—So limitation as to land holding under the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act is not attracted—In the absence of any objection regarding violation of land holding limitation at the time pre-emption was allowed—Such issue of fact cannot be raised for the first time in the Appellate Division.</p><p><strong><em>Azizur Rahman vs. Bhayetullah and another; 7 BLD (AD) 210.</em></strong></p><p>Ref. 52 C.W.N. 64.</p><p> </p><p><strong>Articles—7, 9 and 10</strong></p><p><strong>Vesting of land in Government</strong>—When there cannot be the vesting—There has been no selection of excess land by the revenue officer nor has he passed any order accepting any excess land or forfeiting any land—In the absence of such order the excess land, if any, held by the plaintiff cannot vest in the Government.</p><p><strong><em>Chan Juri Talukder and another Vs. Ching Neshay Magni and others; 9 BLD (HCD) 1O.</em></strong></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
1101	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">BANGLADESH LEGAL PRACTITIONERS AND BAR COUNCIL ORDER &amp; RULES, 1972</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  1 BLD (HCD) 428,  8 BLD (HCD) 216.</p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  1972</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  BANGLADESH LEGAL PRACTITIONERS AND BAR COUNCIL</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p><strong> </strong></p><p align="center"><strong>BANGLADESH LEGAL PRACTITIONERS AND BAR COUNCIL ORDER (P.O. 46 OF 1972) AND BANGLADESH LEGAL PRACTITIONERS AND BAR COUNCIL RULES, 1972</strong></p><p><strong>Articles—33, 34 and 35</strong></p><p>Tribunal set up under Bangladesh Legal Practitioners and Bar Council Order is not a civil Court, but shall be so considered for some specific purposes mentioned in the Order—Although the Tribunal may have the trappings of a court—It is not really a Court of law which a civil court is.</p><p><strong><em>Fariduddin Ahmed Vs. Secretary Bangladesh Bar Council and another 1 BLD (HCD) 428.</em></strong></p><p> </p><p><strong>Articles—34 and 35</strong></p><p>Stay proceedings before the Tribunal—. An application for stay of a proceeding before a Tribunal pending disposal of a suit between the same parties over the same matter is mis- conceived and not maintainable—Code of Civil Procedure (V of 1908),</p><p><strong><em>Fariduddin Ahmed Vs. Secretary, Bangladesh Bar Council and another, 1 BLD (HCD) 428.</em></strong></p><p><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p><strong>Articles—34 and 36</strong></p><p>Legal Practitioners and Bar Council Order—Disciplinary proceeding against an Advocate—Suspensioñ of sanad under Rule 51 pending enquiry is not a punishment under Article 32 of the Order—Notice to show cause why sanad shall not be suspended pending enquiry is not an order under Article 34 and therefore not appealable under Article 36 of the Order.</p><p><strong><em>Fariduddin Ahmed Vs. Secretary, Bangladesh Bar Council and another; 1 BLD (HCD) 428.</em></strong></p><p><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p><strong>Article—32(1)</strong></p><p>Punishment for professional misconduct—Question of severity of punishment— considering that the appellant was of fairly advanced age and was in bruised health the Tribunal decided to award him the intermediate punishment of suspension for 8 years—We do not find any reason why the intermediate punishment should now be relegated to the softest one—The appellant has no regrets, no remorse—He has chalked out a path of self justification—We find no extenuating circumstances to reduce the sentence.</p><p><strong><em>Harun-Ar-Rashid Talukdar Vs. District Manager, Pubali Bank, Jainalpur Branch and another, 8 BLD (HCD) 216.</em></strong></p><p><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p><strong>Clause (1) Chapter II</strong></p><p><strong>Professional misconduct</strong> — Advocate’s conduct with regard to his client—The appellant (Advocate) sought to create a title in him by purchasing the suit property under attachment at a time when he was the engaged Advocate of the Bank conducting the execution case—To acquire an interest adverse to the interest of the client amounts to professional misconduct. <strong><em>   Ibid. </em></strong></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>

Faizul Huq and others; 1 BLD (HCD) 177.</em></strong></p><p><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p><strong>Article—3</strong></p><p>Arbitrator—Whether he is excluded the definition of ‘Court’ —An arbitrator does not adjudicate and he does not sit as a Tribunal—He is not bound by the technicalities of the Evidence Act—His function is like - that of conciliator—He is neither a Court nor a Tribunal and his award is not a judgment, decree or order of any Court or Tribunal within the meaning of Article 3 of the President’s Order No. 12 of 1972.</p><p><strong><em>Begum Khadija Akhtar Banu and another Vs. Government of Bangladesh; 4 BLD (HCD) 199.</em></strong></p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>Article—2</strong></p><p>Abatement of suit challenging the taking over of fishery of the debuttar by the Government—Whether injunction can be granted restraining the Government?—The plaintiffs wanted to question the acquisition of the fishery indirectly under the garb of challenging the lease to the defendants on the plea that compensation assessment roll has not been prepared—P.O. 90 of 1972 prohibits such oblique challenge and a such suit shall abate— When the principal has gone into possession by operation of law, the agency is terminated and the agent cannot seek any injunction because there is hardly anything that needs protection.</p><p><strong><em>Samir Kuinar Roy Chowdhury and others Vs. 1106	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">BANGLADESH POWER DEVELOPMENT BOARD (EMPLOYEES) SERVICE RULES, 1982</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  7 BLD (HCD) 61</p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  1982</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  BANGLADESH POWER DEVELOPMENT BOARD </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u style="text-underline: thick;">BANGLADESH POWER DEVELOPMENT BOARD (EMPLOYEES) SERVICE RULES, 1982</u></strong></p><p style="line-height: 115%;"> </p><p><strong>Rule—21(b)</strong></p><p>Whether non graduation is a bar for promotion to the post of Deputy Director—Deputy Directorship is non-selection post—Meritcum-seniority is the criterion for promotion to this. post—Up to the ranks of Superintending Engineer and Director promotion is subject to the examination and test provided for in the Rules, themselves—Promotions have not been made subject to possession of requisite academic qualifications for each post—Each employee claiming merit and seniority and passing examination and test can rise up to the ranks of Superintending Engineer and Director.</p><p><strong><em>M. M. Ismail Vs. Bangladesh Power Development Board and others; 7 BLD (HCD) 61.</em></strong></p><p><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p><strong>Power Board cannot use an extra legal document</strong>—Whether the Directory published in 1969 setting for the uniform standard of qualification to be followed at the time of appointment and promotion of the personnel of the erstwhile authority can be used. by the Power Board in the same manner as it used to do before the framing of the Rules in 1982— This directory is not a Rule or a Circular or an office order—It has never been formally adopted by the Power Board at any time nor it has any statutory force—The Power Board cannot use an extra legal document which it has not adopted after the framing of Rules in 1982.</p><p><strong><em>M. M. Ismail Vs. Bangladesh Power Development Board and others; 7BLD (HCD) 61.</em></strong></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
1107	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">BANGLADESH RED CRESCENT SOCIETY ORDER, 1973</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  1O BLD (AD) 267</p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  1973</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  BANGLADESH RED CRESCENT SOCIETY</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p><strong> </strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u style="text-underline: thick;">BANGLADESH RED CRESCENT SOCIETY ORDER (P.O. NO. 26 OF 1973)</u></strong></p><p style="line-height: 115%;"> </p><p><strong>Sections—2(Ka), 4 and 7(6)</strong></p><p>Right to form an association not flowing from Article 38 of the Constitution—(a) Whether such right can be protected there under, (b) whether a statutory right under P.O. 27 of 1973 can be protected under Article 102 of the Constitution and (c) whether such statutory right can be amended by the legislature?</p><p>Held, (a) No.—as the appellants right does not flow from his right to form an association he cannot claim any right or protection under Article 38.</p><p>The right under Article 38 implies that several individuals having a community of interest can join together to form a voluntary association for furtherance of a common lawful object.</p><p>Article 38 cannot be invoked for support or substance or fulfillment of every object of an association.</p><p>(a)  Yes, — whatever right he (appellant) has as a member of the society Red (Crescent) has been given under P.O. 26 of 1973 and he can legitimately claim protections under Article 102 of the Constitution for enforcement of his statutory right.</p><p>(b)  Yes, — But he (appellant) cannot claim that his right under the statute cannot be modified, altered or affected by an amendment of P.O. 26 of 1973, validity passed by the legislature.</p><p>Whatever right the appellant has under P.O. 26 of 1973 can be modified, regulated or taken away by an amendment of that Order— There is no dispute as to the principle that the legislature can, subject to the provisions of the Constitution, take away a vested right by an express enactment.</p><p><strong><em>Md. Asaduzzaman Vs. Bangladesh, represented by the Secretary, Ministry of Law and Justice and others; 1O BLD (AD) 267.</em></strong></p><p>Ref.  A.I.R.  1962(SC) 171.</p><p> </p><p><strong>Distinguishing features of the Red Crescent Society from other voluntary society and associations</strong></p><p>There are certain features which distinguish the Red Crescent Society from other voluntary societies or associations—The society is a body corporate and the definitions of the term ‘Corporation’ or a ‘body corporate’ are:</p><p>It is clear that though the society is an association of persons it is an association sui generis—Though membership to the society is open to all the citizens of Bangladesh, who comply with the terms and conditions laid down in the rules framed under the order, no one has the right to form a similar society.</p><p>Unlike other associations the Society cannot be dissolved except by law made for the purpose (Article 24 of P.O. 26 of 1973).</p><p>No valid analogy can be drawn between a District Board and the Society, because the National Society being a component of the lnter9ational League of Red Cross and Red Crescent Movement is and must necessarily by an independent, impartial, voluntary, autonomous association of members.</p><p>The analogy or similarly between the District Board and Red Crescent Society is no doubt striking, but in both the cases the rights of the members flow from a statute and not from the fundamental right of association that citizens enjoy on their own.</p><p><strong><em>Md. Asaduzzanzan Vs. Bangladesh, represented by the Secretary, Ministry of Law and Justice and others; IOBLD (AD) 267.</em></strong></p><p>Ref. A.I.R. l952 (SC)196; PLDI964 (SC) 63 :A .I.R, 1971 (SC)966; A.I.R. 1952 (Cal) 90 1.</p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>

1111	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">BANGLADESH SHILPA BANK (DIRECT SALE OF MORTGAGED PROPERTY) RULES, 1980</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  10 BLD (AD) 226</p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  1980</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  BANGLADESH SHILPA BANK</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u style="text-underline: thick;"><span style="text-decoration: none;"><br/> </span></u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u style="text-underline: thick;">BANGLADESH SHILPA BANK (DIRECT SALE OF MORTGAGED PROPERTY) RULES, 1980</u></strong></p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>Rule—7(3)</strong></p><p>Bank jurisdiction to sell mortgaged property of the borrower directly under Article 34 of the B.S.B Order and Rules—The Bank has jurisdiction to sell the mortgaged property of the borrower directly under Article 34 of P.O. 129 of 1972—The power of the Bank to take over the management and administration of the industrial concern and to sell its property have been set out in Article 34 (1) with the conjunction ‘and’ which are undoubtedly independent and alternative powers to enforce repayment of the loan—This is the true import of sub-article (1)—Practical reasons however necessitate taking over of the industrial concern before putting it to sale but that does not mean that taking cannot take place afterwards before completion of sale.</p><p>Mere irregularity in holding the sale by public tender does not divest the Bank of its power to sell the property by private negotiation—According to Rules 4 and 5 of the procedure for selling by public auction or by calling public tender or otherwise are alternative methods and any defect in one procedure does not vitiate the transaction. The High Court Division has rightly interpreted the rules.</p><p>The Bank did not go for selling the vessels all at once but. gave due notice and other opportunities to the petitioners to settle the outstanding dues—The Banks, even in its letter offered to examine the petitioner’s proposal for replacement of over dues/loan outstanding subject to payment of specified sums by a certain date—But the petitioners made no response to the same—The High Court Division upon a scrutiny of the correspondence clearly found that there was neither any malafide nor arbitrariness on the part of the Bank—Bangladesh Shilpa Bank Order, 1972 (P.O. 129 of 1972), Article 34.</p><p><strong>Fairtech Limited and others Vs Bangladesh Shilpa Bank Ltd. and others; 10 BLD (AD) 226.</strong></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
1112	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">  BANGLADESH SHILPA BANK ORDER</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  7 BLD (HCD) 239, 10 BLD (AD) 226.</p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  1972</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  BANGLADESH SHILPA BANK </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p><strong> </strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u style="text-underline: thick;">BANGLADESH SHILPA BANK ORDER (P.O. 129 OF 1972)</u></strong></p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>Article—34(5)</strong></p><p>Injunction—Injunction to restrain Shilpa Bank from taking over or transfering of industrial concern indebted to the Bank— Whether the Bank can be restrained from taking over or transferring such industrial concern—No Court shall issue, make or pass any order of ad-interim or temporary injunction or any other order prohibiting or restraining the bank or any of its officers from such taken over or transferring the industrial concern—Even when the Shilpa Bank has not taken over the management and administration of any industrial concern the Court cannot issue, make or pass any order of ad- interim or temporary injunction or any other order prohibiting or restraining the Shilpa Bank or any of its officers from such taking over or from making such transfer—Code of Civil Procedure (V of 1908) or 39 RI.</p><p><strong><em>Moon Light Silk Mills Ltd. Vs. Bangladesh Shilpa Bank; 7 BLD (HCD) 239.</em></strong></p><p>Ref. 18 DLR (SC) 354</p><p> </p><p><strong>Article—34</strong></p><p>Bank’s jurisdiction to sell mortgaged property of the borrower directly under Article 34 of P.O. 129 of 1972—The power of the Bank to take over the management and administration of the industrial concern and to sell its property have been set out in Article 34(1) with the conjunction ‘and’ which are undoubtedly independent and alternative powers to enforce repayment of the loan— This is the true import of sub—article (1)— Practical reasons however necessitate taking over of the industrial concern before putting it to sale but that does not mean that taking cannot take place afterwards before completion of sale.</p><p>The bank did not go for selling the vessels all at once but gave due notice and other opportunities to the petitioners to settle the outstanding dues—The Bank, even in its letter offered to examine the petitioner’s proposal for replacement of over dues/10 am outstanding subject to payment specified sum by a certain date—But the petitioner’s made no response to the same—The High Court Division upon a scrutiny of the correspondence clear found that there was neither any malafide nor arbitrariness on the part of the Bank—Bangladesh Shilpa Bank (Direct Sale of Mortgaged Property) Rules, 1980—Rule 743).</p><p><strong><em>Fairtech Limited and others vs. Bangladesh Shilpa Bank Ltd. and others; 10 BLD (AD) 226.</em></strong></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
1113	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">BANGLADESH SHILPA RIN SANGSTHA ORDER</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  7 BLD (AD) 169, 7BLD (AD) 169</p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  1972</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  BANGLADESH SHILPA RIN SANGSTHA</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u style="text-underline: thick;">BANGLADESH SHILPA RIN SANGSTHA ORDER (P.O. 128 OF 1972)</u></strong></p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>Article—2(t)</strong></p><p>Clause (t) of Article 2of the P.O. 128 of N72: ‘Loan’ includes guarantee or indemnity which the Sangstha may give on behalf Of an intestinal concern and any liability which the Sangstha may to incur on behalf of an industrial concern—Whether the amount paid by shilpa Rin Sangstha to the appellant for construction of coaster vessel on behalf of the debtor of the Sangstha according to the terms the tripartite agreement could be viewed as n—In defining the term ‘Loan’ the clause</p><p>has not employed the word ‘means’ but has instead employed the word ‘includes’ does not exclude other possible meanings besides what have been expressly mentioned in the clause—By providing the inclusive definition of the term ‘Loan’, the clause has only enumerated one, or two transactions or matters such as ‘guarantee” or “indemnity” and “any liability” but not all kinds of transactions or matters—The term ‘Loan’ may, therefore be extended to such transaction as had arisen under the tripartite agreement.</p><p><strong><em>Dira Duckyard and Engineers Ltd. and others Vs. Bangladesh Shilpa Rin Sangstha and others; 7 BLD (AD) 169.</em></strong></p><p><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p><strong>Article—33</strong></p><p>Summary procedure for recovery of the loan granted by Shilpa Rin Sangstha— Whether Sangstha can take recourse to such summary procedure for recovery of the amount paid by it to the appellant for construction of the coaster vessel on behalf of the borrower under a tripartite agreement or the amount is to be recovered by money suit—The amount paid by the Sangstha to the appellant for the purpose mentioned in the agreement is a liability which has been incurred by the Sangstha on account of the borrower—The amount paid to the appellant under the tripartite agreement is or becomes part of the loan granted to the borrower— Once the amount so paid to the appellant becomes ‘loan’ as defined in the Shilpa Rin Sangstha Order 1972 not only the borrower to whom the loan was granted but also the appellant who has received a part of that loan becomes liable for payment of that loan— When there is any breach of any condition of the agreement the Sangstha may proceed to recover the loan according to the summary procedure laid down in Article 33—If it can be established that somebody else also received part of the loan under some legal agreement such person becomes liable for payment of that loan and is also amenable to the procedure for recovery of such loan.</p><p><strong><em>Dira Dockyard and Engineers Ltd. and others vs. Bangladesh Shil-pa Rin Sangstha and others; 7BLD (AD) 169</em></strong></p><p>Ref: PLD 1966 (SC) 738.</p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
1114	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">BANGLADESH TEXTILE MILLS CORPORATION (SERVICE) REGULATION, 1981</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  9 BLD (HCD) 383</p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  1981</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  BANGLADESH TEXTILE MILLS CORPORATION </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u style="text-underline: thick;">BANGLADESH TEXTILE MILLS CORPORATION (SERVICE) REGULATION, 1981</u></strong></p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>Clause—69(3) (e)</strong></p><p>Service matter—Second show cause notice without enquiry report whether violates principle of natural justice—The second show cause notice is not an idle formality—In order to be meaningful it has to be accompanied with or followed by the report of the Enquiry Officer—Whether or not the rules provide for the report to be given to the employee, rules of natural justice require that along with the second show cause notice the employee should be furnished with the same.</p><p>Inflicting higher punishment than the one recommended—Question of assigning some reason—When the appointing authority takes a different view from the Enquiry Officer and decides to inflict a higher punishment than the one recommended by the Enquiry Officer, then the appointing authority has to assign some reason—When no reason has been given the order is not immune from attack being violative of the principle of natural justice.</p><p><strong><em>Md. Torab Ali Vs. Bangladesh Textile Mills Corporation and another, 9 BLD (HCD) 383.</em></strong></p><p>Ref. 32DLR (AD)  46.</p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>

<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  7 BLD (HCD) 89</p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  1982</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  BANGLADESH WATER DEVELOPMENT BOARD </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u style="text-underline: thick;">BANGLADESH WATER DEVELOPMENT BOARD (EMPLOYEES) SERVICE RULES, 1982</u></strong></p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>Rule—20(1)</strong></p><p>Whether an employee shall be deemed to have been promoted to a higher post from the fact that he was allowed to hold a higher post for long 14 months without specification as to whether he was holding the same on a current charge or on an officiating basis—Promotion is an act of volition—A matter of positive action to be taken by the appropriate authority—It must be achieved by a process of selection, nomination and communication as per rules—One cannot import a legal fiction in a service matter.</p><p><strong><em>Monirul Huq Vs. Government of the People’s Republic of Bangladesh, through the Secretary, Ministry of Irrigation, Water Development and Flood Control and others; 7 BLD (HCD) 89.</em></strong></p><p><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p><strong>RuIe—33(e</strong>)</p><p><strong>Status of an additional post</strong>—What happens to an employee when he is allowed to hold current charge of an additional post for a period exceeding three months—In the absence of any consequences provided for in the Rule the Court allow the status of a post to undergo a radical transformation—After the expiry of three months the additional post shall neither be deemed to be a substantive post nor that the employee holding current charge of an additional post shall be deemed to be promoted to the additional post.</p><p><strong><em>Monirul Huq Vs. Government of the People’s Republic of Bangladesh, through the Secretary, Ministry of Irrigation, Water Development and Flood Control and others; 7 BLD (HCD) 89.</em></strong></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>

1118	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">BANKING COMPANIES ACT, 1991</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  11 BLD (HCD) 484</p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  1991</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  BANKING COMPANIES</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p><strong> </strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u style="text-underline: thick;">BANKING COMPANIES ACT, 1991 (XIV OF 1991)</u></strong></p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>Section—37</strong></p><p>Bangladesh Bank, whether is not entitled to publish the statement regarding the position of dues of an account—holder as on 31 St December, 1990, which is the last day of 2nd half of the year, 1990.</p><p><strong>Held</strong>—The argument that since the Banking Companies Act, 1991, came into force on 24th February, 1991, the Bangladesh Bank is not entitled to publish the statement regarding the position of outstanding dues of an account—holder as on 31st December, 1990, has no substance, as section 37, without putting any time limit, has clearly empowered the Bangladesh Bank to publish any such information obtained by it in a consolidated form in the public interest.</p><p><strong><em>M/s. Paul and Co. Narayanganj Vs. Bangladesh Bank, represented by its Governor and others; 11 BLD (HCD) 484.</em></strong></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
1119	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">BANKING COMPANIES ORDINANCE, 1962</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  10 BLD (HCD) 392, 1 BLD (HCD) 251, 1 BLD (HCD) 96, 10 BLD (HCD) 354, 10 BLD (HCD) 35, 1 BLD (AD) 421, 5 BLD (AD) 150, 1 BLD (AD) 431.</p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  1962</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  BANKING COMPANIES</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p><strong> </strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u style="text-underline: thick;">BANKING COMPANIES ORDINANCE (LVII OF 1962)</u></strong></p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>Sections—2, 60, 61 and 62</strong></p><p><strong>Section 2, 60, 61 and 62</strong> of the Banking Companies Ordinance are read with those of section 171 of the Companies Act and the provision section 7 read with Rule 6 of Schedule II of the P.D.R. Act—It appears that the provisions of Banking Companies Ordinance shall be effective in addition to and not in derogation of the Companies Act or any other law for the time being in force, excepting the provisions which are specifically made in the Ordinance—So, the provisions as provided in the aforesaid laws shall be read together harmoniously.</p><p><strong><em>The Official Liquidator, East Bengal Commercial Bank Ltd. (In Liquidation) Vs. Mrs. Jahura Khatun and others; 10 BLD (HCD) 392.</em></strong></p><p><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p><strong>Sections—60, 61 and 63</strong></p><p><strong>Banking Companies Ordinance</strong>—Property attached by the Company Judge—District Judge held auction on the direction of the Company Judge—District Judge not competent to question the attachment and to set aside the auction sale-—Code of Civil Procedure (V of 1908) Ss. 38, 42, 47, 151 and Or. 21 R.90.</p><p><strong><em>In re Kumud Ranjan Sarker and others; 1 BLD (HCD) 251.</em></strong></p><p>Ref. 1 BLD 96.</p><p> </p><p><strong>Sections—60, 63(3) (9)</strong></p><p>Execution of decree passed by Company Judge under section 63(3) of Banking Corn- pan ies Ordinance—Subordinate Court in execution cannot question the legality of the decree—Section 63 (9) of the Ordinance empowers Company Judge to entertain application under section 63(3) beyond the statutory period of limitation—Code of Civil procedure (V of 1908), S. 47.</p><p><strong><em>Tripura Modern Bank Ltd. Vs. Shuva Karan Rajgharia; 1 BLD (HCD) 96.</em></strong></p><p> </p><p><strong>Section—61</strong></p><p>Investigation of claims and objections to attachment of attached property—Objector filing objection before Executing Court (Subordinate Judge) claiming title thereunder—High Court Division having exclusive jurisdiction to entertain and decide any claim made by or against Banking Company while in Liquidation—Whether objection application maintainable and hit by section 61 of Banking Companies Ordinance, 1962?</p><p>Section 61 of the Banking Companies Ordinance meant for speedy disposal of a winding up proceeding, confers upon the High Court Division exclusive jurisdiction to entertain and decide any claim of a Banking Company in liquidation.</p><p>It, therefore, appears that the Banking Companies Ordinance 1962 which came into effect on 7th of June, 1962 male special provision for Banking Companies when they are in liquidation and in a case of Banking Company in liquidation, the law has empowered only the High Court Division giving exclusive jurisdiction to entertain and decide any claim made by or against a Banking Company which is wound up.</p><p><strong><em>Md. Bazlul Ghani Vs. The Pioneer Bank Ltd. Comilla; 10 BLD (HCD) 354.</em></strong></p><p>Ref. PLD 1964 (Dhaka) 741(1964) 16 DLR 656.</p><p> </p><p><strong>General statutes and Special statutes</strong></p><p>Conflict between—non obstante clause— harmonious construction.</p><p>The special statute prevails over general statute—If the provision of section 171 of the Companies Act comes into conflict with the provision of section 61 of the Banking Companies Ordinance, then, the provision of section 61 of the Ordinance would prevail— Therefore, though Banking Companies Ordinance, 1962 is in addition and not in derogation of the Companies Act or any other law for the time being in force, Section 60 of the said Banking Company Ordinance by the non-obstante clause has made the provisions of section 61 of the Banking Companies Ordinaries along with other provisions following thereafter, to prevail over any other provision of the Companies Act, or the provisions of the Code of Civil Procedure or Code of Criminal Procedure or any other law for the time being in force.</p><p><strong><em>Md. Bazlul Ghani Vs. The Pioneer Bank Ltd. Comilla; 10 BLD (HCD) 35.</em></strong></p><p><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p><strong>Section—62</strong></p><p><strong>Banking Companies Ordinance</strong>—winding up order made—Transfer of a pending case from civil Court to the Company Judge is not a matter of course—A matter pending before the High Court Division or Appellate Division on appeal cannot be transferred to the Company Judge.</p><p><strong><em>Kanak Chandra Das and others Vs. Basiruddin Khan  and another; 1 BLD (AD) 421.</em></strong></p><p><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p><strong>Section—65</strong></p><p>Claim for recovery of money by a Banking Company whether can be decreed in the absence of any evidence as to actual payment the amount—In view of the fact title deeds were deposited with the bank along with all other usual documents, executed by the predecessor of defendant the Company and gu1ar entries in the ledger and clean cash of the Bank in respect of the loan the claim is established—There is also admission x the Managing Director of defendant the company as to the liability to the Bank- Moreover there is presumption under the Neon able Instruments Act, Bankers Books of Evidence Act and Banking Companies Ordinance—Negotiable Instruments Act (XXV of ‘s I) S. 11 8—Bankers Book of Evidence Act XVIII of )891)S.4.</p><p><strong><em>Planters (Bangladesh) Ltd. Vs. Mahalaxmi Bank Limited and others; 5 BLD (AD) 150.</em></strong></p><p><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p><strong>Sections—66 and 72</strong></p><p><strong>Banking Companies Ordinance</strong>—Appeal—No appeal lies against an order not covered by section 72(1X2) of the Ordain e—Order under section 66(9) upon an application under section 66(1) not being covered by section 72(l)(2) is not appeal able— order passed on an application under non 66(1) cannot be held to be an order pass on an application under section 196(1) ii of Companies Act—Companies Act (VII 4i 1913) Ss. 196 and 202.</p><p><strong><em>Bangladesh Bank Vs. Debendra Nath Dutta; 1 BLD (AD) 431.</em></strong></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>

1122	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">BENGAL TENANCY ACT, 1885</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  6 BLD (AD) 70, 3 BLD (AD) 209, 3 BLD (AD) 1, 4 BLD (7KD) 282, 11 BLD (HCD) 433, 5 BLD (A.D) 282, 12BLD (HCD) 460, 1BLD (AD) 367, 8 BLD (AD) 189, 4 BLD (HCD) 309 </p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  1885</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  BENGAL TENANCY </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u style="text-underline: thick;">BENGAL TENANCY ACT (VIII of 1885)</u></strong></p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>Section 3(17)</strong></p><p><strong>Bargader or Adhiar</strong>—When acquires the status of a tenant—He acquires the status of a tenant if he is admitted as a tenant by the landlord in any document executed by him or if he has been held by a civil Court to be a tenant.</p><p><strong><em>Shafiullah and others Vs. Sultan Ahmad Mir being dead his heirs; 6 BLD (AD) 70.</em></strong></p><p><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p><strong>Section—22</strong></p><p>Occupancy right of tenancy when merged with superior interest—A person holding occupancy right in a land does not lose it by subsequently becoming jointly interested in the land as proprietor or permanent tenure holder</p><p><strong><em>Shafiullah and others Vs. Sultan Ahmad Mir being his deal heirs; 6 BLD (AD) 70.</em></strong></p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>Section—22(2)</strong></p><p>Merger—Whether occupancy raiyati holding merged with the tenure by purchase of the same by the co-sharer under-tenure holder—On account of purchase by co-sharer under-tenure-holder the raiyati holding did not lose its character of an occupancy raiyati holding—Subsequent purchasers acquired the same interest and not an under-tenure holding.</p><p><strong><em>Mst. Noorjan Nessa Bewa and others Vs. Md. Mohsin Ali Talukder and others; 3 BLD (AD) 209.</em></strong></p><p><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p><strong>Section—26C</strong></p><p><strong>Oral gift by a Muslim</strong>—Whether such gift of agricultural land without a registered instrument valid—Completion of oral gift—It takes place as soon as .a declaration of gift by the donor and acceptance of the same by the donee are made and delivery of possession follows—This completion cannot be destroyed by the requirement of a registered instrument under section 26C of the B.T. Act.</p><p><strong><em>Jabed Ali Vs. Aba Sheikh, being dead his heirs Md. Naimuddin and others; 3 BLD (AD) 1.</em></strong></p><p>Ref: .A.I.R. 1941 (Cal) 266; AIR. 1927 (Cal) 197; A.I.R. 1963 (Pat) 229; IL.R. 15 Cal 684; A.I.R. 1927 (PC) 22; 17 DLR 112; 1968 S.C:M.R. 509.</p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>Section—26C</strong></p><p>Istafa (surrender) of tenancy of agricultural land to landlord—If registered document required—In case of oral surrender no question of registered instrument is necessary.</p><p><strong><em>Mast Sercztannessa and others Vs. Dii Mamud and others; 4BLD (7KD) 282</em></strong></p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>Section—26F</strong></p><p>Deed of Heba-bil-ewaz, whether can have the effect of destroying the right of preemption.</p><p><strong>Held</strong>: Deed of Heba-bil-ewaz cannot have the effect of destroying. the right of preemption nor can it affect right of pre-emption inasmuch as a party at his own will cannot suspend the operation of a statute.</p><p><strong><em>Aiesuddin Mondal Vs. Md. Toyezuddin Dewan; 11 BLD (HCD) 433.</em></strong></p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>Section—87</strong></p><p>Abandonment—Circumstances constituting abandonment—The Collector got hardly anything to do in the matter except causing a notice published in the prescribed manner—If the landlord entered upon the holding by serving a notice the rayat may file a suit for recovery of possession—The rayat did nOt file any such suit as she did never return from India—In the circumstances the High Court Division rightly refused to disturb the finding as to abandonment.</p><p><strong><em>Mrs. Maleka Khatun and others Vs. Md. Abdul Kashem and others; 5 BLD (A.D) 282.</em></strong></p><p> </p><p><strong>Section—87</strong></p><p>As per provision of section 87 of the Bengal Tenancy Act, raiyat or under raiyat can voluntarily abandon residence without notice to his land-lord and without arranging for payment of rent—A finding of fact when not based on evidence or is based on utterly inadequate evidence and/or inconsistent with the evidence on record—High Court is justified to interfere in such matters in revisional jurisdiction.</p><p><strong><em>Md. Abdur Rashid Khan Vs .Khudeza Bewa and others; 12BLD (HCD) 460</em></strong></p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>Sections—161 and 167</strong></p><p>B.T. Act—Encumbrance—Sub-lease created by an under-raiyat having no occupancy right is not an in cumbrance and need not be annulled, but sub-lease created by a raiyat having occupancy right is an encumbrance and requires to be annulled under section 167 of the Bengal Tenancy Act.</p><p><strong><em>Sunil Kumar Biswas Vs. Mohammad Idris and others; 1BLD (AD) 367</em></strong></p><p>Ref: 16 DLR 110.</p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>Capitalized Value</strong>—There is no definition provided to the expression ‘capitalized value’ in the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act—The submission that there are provisions for including future rents in compensations by way of capitalized value of the lands acquired under the Land Acquisition Act, Lands in the Bengal Tenancy Act, 1885 have no basis.</p><p><strong><em>Bangladesh Vs. MIs. Zeenath Textile Mills Limited and others; 8 BLD (AD) 189.</em></strong></p><p><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p><strong>BOARD OF INTERMEDIATE AND SECONDARY EDUCATION, JESSORE, RECOGNIZED NON-GOVERNMENT SECONDARY SCHOOL REGULATIONS, 1973</strong></p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>Section—15</strong></p><p>Removal of a teacher from service when valid—A teacher may be removed from service by holding a meeting within 7 days notice called for that purpose with the prior approval of the Board for removal of a Headmaster or a teacher of a secondary school as provided under the Board of Intermediate and Secondary Education, Jessore Regulations, 1973 as the same are mandatory—In its absence, the resolution, by the Managing Committee without complying with the same and without giving the teacher opportunity to be heard is in violation of the principles of natural justice and is bad in law and has no legal effect.</p><p><strong><em>Sardar Ahmed Au Vs. G. M. Au Baksha and others; 4 BLD (HCD) 309.</em></strong></p><p>Ref: 28 DLR 668.</p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>

But without any sanction, his building can be removed in exercise of section 3B of the Act.</p><p><strong><em>Md. Habibullah Chowdhury Vs. Rajdhani Unnayan Kartipakkha and another; 11 BLD (HCD) 173.</em></strong></p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>Section—12</strong></p><p>Whether injunction prohibiting further construction and directing demolition of ‘tructures already erected should be made or compensation should be granted when a building is constructed in violation of Building Construction Rules and sanctioned plan— Construction of a building in violation Building Construction Rules and sanctioned plan are punishable under the Town improvement Act—Similarly if violation touches the interest of the neighbors, they also actionable at the instance of the neighbors—A person may be criminally liable :r the wrong done under some law—He may well be liable for a civil action for the done a private person—If the injury is not of a grave nature injunction perpetual or mandatory with regard to the structures already erected and their upward elevation. should not be given and compensations shall be adequate remedy.</p><p><strong><em>Abdul Hakim Khan Vs. 1125	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">BURMESE BUDDHIST LAW</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  9BLD (HCD) 2, 9 BLD (HCD) 10, 12 BLD (AD) 253.</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  BURMESE BUDDHIST </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u style="text-underline: thick;">BURMESE BUDDHIST LAW</u></strong></p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>Burmese Buddhist Law of Inheritance</strong></p><p>The rule that inheritance should not ascend when it can descend does not operate in a competition between relations of the full blood and those of the half blood of the same degree of relationship to the deceased.</p><p><strong><em>Machafrue Mogni Vs. Seman Magni and others; 9BLD (HCD) 2</em></strong></p><p>Ref: A.I.R. 1938 (Rangoon) 74.</p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>Will by Burmese Buddhist</strong></p><p>Under the Burmese Buddhist Law of inheritance a Burmese Buddhist cannot make a will—That being the position the will in question is not admissibl&amp;in evidence.</p><p><strong><em>Chan Jun Talukder and another Vs. Ching Neshay Magni and others; 9 BLD (HCD) 10.</em></strong></p><p>Ref: 17 DLR (Dhaka) 649.</p><p> </p><p><strong>Family arrangement</strong></p><p>Validity of such arrangement by a Burmese Buddhist—The plaintiff was the sole heir of the property left by her husband—The defendants fQr whom her husband made the family arrangement are not his heirs and as such this arrangement is no arrangement in the eye of law.</p><p><strong><em>Chan Jun Talukder and another Vs. Ching Neshay Magni and others; 9BLD (HCD)1O</em></strong></p><p>Ref: 17 DLR (Dhaka) 649.</p><p><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p><strong>Burmese Buddhist Law</strong></p><p>Under the Burmese Buddhist Law, a Burmese Buddhist cannot make a will—Ext. B is therefore inadmissible as a will.</p><p>According to Burmese Buddhist law, only the widow of the deceased is the heir—Ext. B can hardly stand the test of a family arrangement.</p><p>Plaintiff was not a party to the award—The award itself has no legal standing—It is not binding on the plaintiff.</p><p><strong><em>Gaanjury Talukdar and another Vs. Chingneshay Magni and others; 12 BLD (AD) 253.</em></strong></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
1126	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">CANTONMENTS ACT, 1924 (ACT II OF 1924)</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  7 BLD (AD) 62</p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  1924</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  CANTONMENTS</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong>CANTONMENTS ACT, 1924 (ACT II OF 1924)</strong></p><p> </p><p><strong>Sections—2(XXa) 280 and 281</strong></p><p>Whether Deputy Commissioner is competent to sign and verify the written statement in a suit against the Government represented by the Military Estate Officer—Government by notification dated 14th December, 1985 authorised Military Estate Officer to sign and verify the plaint or written statement in a suit by or against the Government in respect of Military Lands and Cantonment service—The suit relates to a premises in the Cantonment Area, and as such, the Military Estate Officer is the person who has been specifically appointed to sign and verify a plaint or written statement on behalf of the Government in the ‘Ministry of Defence’—Code of Civil Procedure (V of 1908) Or. XXVII Rules I and 2— The Military Land Manual, R—1O in Appendix—C.</p><p>The Military Estate Officer, in view of the statutory provisions, is the only person authorised to sign and verify a written statement on behalf of the Government and the Deputy Commissioner got no locus standi to sign and verify any written statement—The impugned written statements signed and verified by him are not written statements in the eye of law—The view taken by the High Court Division is erroneous.</p><p><strong><em>Moqsod Alam Vs. The People’s Republic of Bangladesh, represented by the Military Estate Officer, Dhaka Canton-nient, Ministry of Defence and others; 7 BLD (AD) 62.</em></strong></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
1127	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">CHITTAGONG PORT ACT, 1914</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  1BLD(AD) 373, 9 BLD (HCD) 1, 3 BLD (AD) 338, 5 BLD (HCD) 115</p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  1914</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  CHITTAGONG PORT </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u style="text-underline: thick;">CHITTAGONG PORT ACT (V OF 1914)</u></strong></p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>Section—109(2)</strong></p><p>Suit against Chittagong Port Trust for short delivery—Suit to be filed within six months of accrual of right to sue in accordance with section 109(2) of Chittagong Port Act which prescribes a special law of limitation—Article 115 of Limitation Act not applicable—Limitation Act (IX of 1908) S. 29 and Art. 115.</p><p><strong><em>Chittagong Port Authority Vs. Sadharan Bima Corporation and others; 1BLD(AD) 373</em></strong></p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>Section—109(2)</strong></p><p><strong>Accrual of right to sue</strong>—Right to sue for compensation for short delivery accrues against Port Trust on the date plaintiff gets definite knowledge that the Port Trust was responsible for the shortage.</p><p><strong><em>Chittagong Port Authority Vs. Sadharan Bima Corporation &amp; others; 1 BLD (AD) 373.</em></strong></p><p>Ref: PLD 1959 Kar 364.</p><p> </p><p><strong>Section—109(2)</strong></p><p>Suit against ‘Port Turst’—Plai ntiff entitled to add the period of notice under section .109 (1) of Chittagong Port Act in computing the period of limitation.</p><p><strong><em>Chittagong Port Authority Vs. Sadharan Bima Corporation &amp; others; 1 BLD (AD) 373.</em></strong></p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>Section—50B</strong></p><p>Removal of goods from port area—Section 50B of Chittagong Port Act providing that Port Trust shall not be responsible for goods if not removed from port area within 5 days of landing—Section 50B not applicable when Port Trust denies receipt of goods in its custody.</p><p><strong><em>Chittagong Port Authority Vs. Sadharan Bima Corporation and others; 1 BLD (AD) 373.</em></strong></p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>Section—50A</strong></p><p>Liability of delivering goods as bailee— When Chittagong Port Authority is absolved of such liability—Where the goods could be found and thern consignee was given notice to clear up the goods after ascertaining the same out of the goods landed under nil mark, the Port Authority is absolved of the liability— Contract Act (IX of 1872) Ss. 161, l52 and 161.</p><p><strong><em>Chittagong Port Authority Vs. MIs. Hong Kong Shipping Lines and others; 9 BLD (HCD) 1.</em></strong></p><p><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p><strong>Sections—50, 40A and 63</strong></p><p>Liability of the Port authority to pay compensation for non-delivery of goods—When the Shipping Company had delivered the goods the port authority must be deemed to be the agent for the consignee—The liability of the Port authority must be deemed to be of the agent for the consignee—The liability of the port authority is that of a bailee—They would be liable in the absence of proof that they took as much care of the goods as a man of ordinary prudence would in similar circumstances take—A suit based on non-delivery is really based on a breach of the duty—Contract Act (IX of 1872) Ss. 151, 152 and 161.</p><p><strong><em>The Chittagong Port Authority Vs. Md. Ishaque and others; 3 BLD (AD) 338.</em></strong></p><p>Ref: AIR. 1959 (Mad)367; A.I.R. 1928 (Lab) 774; 1895 A.C 632; (1911) 2 K.B. (C.A.)291;(1919) I K.B.(C.A.) 443.</p><p> </p><p><strong>Section—50A</strong></p><p><strong>Onus of proof</strong>—B ailee’s onus under the Chittagong Port Ordinance—It is well settled that onus is on the Bailee to show that missing, loss etc. happened because of factor beyond the control of the Bailee—The statutory Bailee having failed to take proper measure for protection of the goods cannot avoid liability for the loss—Here it is not the case that the consignee having failed to clear the goods after notice the port authority is absolved of the liability—It is a clear case of non- delivery—Contract Act (IX of 1872) Ss. 151, 152 and 161.</p><p><strong><em>The Turstees of the Port of Chittagong Vs. Khandkar Mahbub Hossain and others; 5 BLD (HCD) 115.</em></strong></p><p>Ref: A.I.R. 1957 (Myssore) 55; 17 DLR 582; 35 DLR (AD)364.</p><p> </p><p><strong>Section—109(2)</strong></p><p><strong>Limitation</strong>—Period of limitation under the Chittagong Port Act—Right to sue accrues from the actual date of knowledge of loss— The plaintiff will also be entitled to add the notice period.</p><p><strong><em>The Trustees of the Port of Chittagong Vs. Khandkar Mahbub Hossain and others; 5 BLD (HCD) 115.</em></strong></p><p>Ref: 35 DLR (AD) 364; 2 BCR (SC) 4.</p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>

1129	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">CINEMATOGRAPH ACT, 1918</h2>

Aktarul alias Md. Nipu Vs. The State; 11 BLD (HCD) 392.</em></strong></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>

1131	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">CIVIL COURTS ACT, 1887</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  1 BLD (HCD) 25, 3 BLD (HCD) 161, 6 BLD (HCD) 361, 1O BLD (HCD) 94, 6 BLD (AD) 303, 11 BLD (AD) 294.  .</p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  1887</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  CIVIL COURTS </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u style="text-underline: thick;">CIVIL COURTS ACT (XII OF 1887)</u></strong></p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>Sections—3, 6, 7, 8, 18, 19, 20 and 21</strong></p><p>District Judge has no revisional jurisdiction over a matter in respect of which he has no appellate jurisdiction.</p><p>A Court which cannot exercise jurisdiction over a matter in appeal is not intended to exercise its revisional jurisdiction—It is inconsistent with scheme of the Code of Civil Procedure and the Civil Courts Act to invest the District Judge with concurrent revisional jurisdiction in matters where no appeal lies before the District Judge—The District Judge’s revisional jurisdiction under section 115(2) is restricted by his appellate jurisdiction as presided under section 21(1) of the Civil Courts Act.—Code of Civil Procedure (V of 1908) Ss. 6,98 and 115, or. XLIII, R.1</p><p><strong><em>Nurul Islam and others Vs. Md. Abdur Rvzshid; 1 BLD (HCD) 25.</em></strong></p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>Section—8</strong></p><p>Jurisdiction of the District Judge to try the suit—The suit was properly filed before the Curt of the District Judge—There is no lack i jurisdiction on the part of the Additional 1k$rict Judge to hear the matter after it has been transferred to his Court.</p><p><strong><em>Md. Younus Ali and another Vs. Dr. Muslimuddin; 3 BLD (HCD) 161</em></strong> .</p><p>Ref: 11 DLR (Dacca) 414; 25 DLR 225.</p><p><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p><strong>Section—21(1)</strong></p><p>Jurisdiction of the Court to hear a mat?er— Whether inherent lack of jurisdiction of the Court to hear the matter will be cured when the order was passed without any objection as to jurisdiction—Whether District Judge can hear an appeal valued above 1k. 70,000/— District Judge has no jurisdiction to entertain appeal valued above Tk. 70,000/- —Consent of the parties or failure to raise any objection cannot invest the Court with jurisdiction Order passed by the District Judge in such appeal is null and void.</p><p><strong><em>Naresh Chandra Shaha and others Vs. Karizannessa and others; 6BLD (HCD) 361.</em></strong></p><p>Ref: 131.A.l44; 141.A.160; A.I.R. 1918 (Cal) 925; A.I.R. 1954(SC) 340; 36DLR(AD) 179; AIR. I 962(SC) 199; A.I.R. 191 8CaI 435;</p><p> </p><p><strong>Section—22(1)</strong></p><p>Transfer of appeal—Whether a District Judge can transfer an appeal preferied to him from a decision of the Election Tribunal—The cumulative effect of the elevant provisions in the Code of Civil Procedure and the Civil Courts Act is that the District Judge as referred to in the Local Government Ordinance has ample authority to transfer such an appeal to any Court subordinate to him—The expression ‘any’ before the expression ‘appeal’ in section 24(1) of the Code gives the District Judges an unfettered power of transfer of such appeal to any Court subordinate to him except the Court of Assistant Judge.</p><p><strong><em>Muhammad Zulfikar Vs. Abul Kalam Chowdhury and others; 1O BLD (HCD) 94.</em></strong></p><p>Ref: 38 DLR (AD) 172; A.I.R. 1956(SC)391.</p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>Sections— 4 and 25</strong></p><p><strong>Small Cause Court—Jurisdiction of—</strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Whether small cause suits can be tried by the presiding officer of a Court without being specifically empowered by notification to exercise Small Cause Court jurisdiction—Whether Small Cause Court jurisdiction is automatically vested in a Court— Government has been empowered to invest Subordinate Judges and Munsifs with Small Cause Court jurisdiction but that has to be</span></p><p>donç expressly by notification mentioning the individual by names—The jurisdiction cannot be invested by taking the pecuniary jurisdiction as the criterion—It has to be conferred specifically by notification—Civil Courts (Amendment) Ordinance (II of 1983) S.4.</p><p><strong><em>Khalilur Rahman Vs. Md. Saidur Rahman; 6 BLD (AD) 303.</em></strong></p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>Civil Court Act</strong></p><p><strong>Jurisdiction of Civil Court</strong>—The jurisdiction of the Civil court, whether may be barred expressly or by necessary implication— Under what circumstances such implied ouster takes place.</p><p>The jurisdiction of the Civil Court may be expressly barred or it may be barred by necessary implication—Such implied ouster takes place when a special statute provides for a special forum for redress of the grievances, if any, and when the decision of that forum is declared to be final.</p><p><strong><em>Chand Miah and ohters Vs. Abdur Razzaque Mahmud Chowdhury and others; 11 BLD (AD) 294.</em></strong></p><p>Ref: 44 C.W.N. 709; 6 C.B.NS. 336(356) (1859); L.R. (1919) A.C.368; 42 DLR(AD) 137; IOBLD(AD)151.</p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
1132	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">CIVIL COURTS (AMENDMENT) ORDINANCE, 1983</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  9 BLD (HCD) 304, 6 BLD (AD) 303</p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  1983</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  CIVIL COURTS (AMENDMENT) </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p align="center"><strong><em> </em></strong> <strong><u style="text-underline: thick;"><br/> </u></strong></p><p align="center"><strong><u style="text-underline: thick;">CIVIL COURTS (AMENDMENT) ORDINANCE (II OF 1983)</u></strong></p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>Sections—2 and 3</strong></p><p><strong>Pending suit</strong>—Question of their transfer for disposal—Whether amendments raising their valuation small affect disposal by the Courts other than where they are pending— Had the amendment been to the effect that all the pending suits of the Subordinate Judge’s Courts shall stand transferred automatically to the Courts of the Assistant Judges after promulgation of the Ordinance the position would have been different—Here, it is the discretion of the District Judge to transfer pending proceedings—It is true, at the time of institution of the suits, the transferee Asstt. Judges were</p><p>not competent to try them, but now by virtue of the amendment they have become competent to try them—What is needed is that the transferee Court must be competent at the time when the transfer is ordered—The amendment in question is not all mandatory and in that view the impugned transfers have not occasioned any failure of justice—Code of Civil Procedure (V of 1908) S. 24.</p><p><strong><em>Md. Ebadal Ali Vs. Ismail Hossain Akhand and others; 9 BLD (HCD) 304.</em></strong></p><p>Ref: 16 DLR (FC) 54; 11 DLR (SC) 200; A,I.R. 1962 (All) 503.</p><p> </p><p><strong>Section—4</strong></p><p><strong>Small Cause Court</strong></p><p>Jurisdiction of—Whether Small Cause Suits can be tried by the presiding officer of a Court without being specifically empowered by notification to exercise Small Cause Court jurisdiction. The Government has been empowered to invest Sub-ordinate Judges and Münsif with Small Cause Court jurisdiction but that has to be done expressly by notification mentioning the individual by names—The jurisdiction cannot be invested by taking the pecuniary jurisdiction as the criterion—It has to be conferred specifically by notification— Civil Courts Act (XII of 1887)s. 25.</p><p><strong><em>Khalilur Rahinan Vs. Md. Saidur Rahman, 6 BLD (AD) 303.</em></strong></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
1133	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">CIVIL RULES AND ORDER</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  9 BLD (HCD) 7, 10 BLD (AD) 194, 11 BLD (AD) 274, 2 BLD (HCD) 114. </p><p><b>Subject:</b>  CIVIL</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u style="text-underline: thick;">CIVIL RULES AND ORDER</u></strong></p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>Vol. I Rule 70</strong></p><p>Rule 70 of the Civil Rules and Orders Vol. I provides for service of the summons in presence of at least “two independent local residents”—Service in presence of a resident of a different locality without any explanation about his competence is not certainly in accordance with the Rule—Under Rule 70 the process server is required whenever possible to obtain the signature of the mokabila witness—This implies that in the case of absence of signature of the mokabila witnesses the process server is required to explain in the report why it could not be possible to obtain the signatures.</p><p><strong><em>Athaj Abdul Aziz Vs. Kali Pada Das and others; 9 BLD (HCD) 7</em></strong></p><p>Ref: 25 DLR 91</p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>Rule—69</strong></p><p>Rule 69 of the Civil Rules and Order provides that ‘service should always be personal wherever practicable (Order 5 Rule 12) and the Court ought not in ex parte cases to act upon anything short of personal service until they are satisfied that personal service could not reasonably be affected.”</p><p><strong><em>Upendra Chandra Rishi and others’. Vs. Sufia Begum and others; 10 BLD (AD) 194.</em></strong></p><p><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p><strong>Rule—84(c)</strong></p><p>Rule 84(C) of the Civil Rules and Order provides that “where a person refuses to accept the process the grounds thereof, if any, and the names of the persons witnessing the refusal should be given”—It is, therefore. Obligatory upon the process server to mention in his report the name and address of the person. if any, by whom the house was identified and in whose presence the copy was affixed.</p><p><strong><em>Upendra Chandra Rishi and others Vs. Sufia Begum and others; 10 BLD (AD) 194.</em></strong></p><p><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p><strong>Rule—388(2)</strong></p><p>Rule 466(2) of the erstwhile High Court Civil Rules and Order was the same as present Rule 388(2) of the Civil Rules and Order. On Rule 466(2) C.J. Choudhury, observed in the case reported in 15 DLR 99 as follows:</p><p>“This Rule contemplates that if, on the date fixed, any important order is passed this order is to be signed by the pleader and endeavor should be made to get the signature f the pleader. But if an order is passed on an off date, in a case not appearing in the cause or on a date not fixed for a case, it is still more incumbent on the Court to see that the order is communicated,”</p><p>An order of the Court affecting one of the pillars of the suit, namely place of trial, cannot be meant for communication to the Pleader Commission only—It was meant for communication to all the parties involved— Since the Court order was not communicated and the course of the suit took an adverse turn to the prejudice of the defendant behind his back and without his knowledge, the suit was rightly restored by the High Court Division.</p><p><strong><em>M.A. Wahab and another Vs. Abul Kalam and another; 11 BLD (AD) 274.</em></strong></p><p>Ref: 15 DLR 99, 4 C.W.N. 237, 238; 33DLR 35; 36DLR 253; 35 DLR 345.</p><p> </p><p><strong>Rule—466 (2)</strong></p><p>Acceptance of the Commissioner’s report without giving opportunity to a party to file objection against the same and passing of the final decree on the basis of the same cannot stand—Order directing parties to file objection against the Commissioner ought to report to have been shown to the party or his Advocate.</p><p><strong><em>Jaherunnessa Vs. Safed Ali Bepari and others; 2 BLD (HCD) 114.</em></strong></p><p>Ref: PLD 1963 Dacca 987; AIR. 1929 Mad 492; AIR. 1920 Lower Burma 31.</p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
1134	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">CIVILIAN EMPLOYEES IN DEFENCE SERVICE (CLASSIFICATION, CONTROL AND APPEAL) RULES, 1961</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  2 BLD (HCD) 109.</p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  1961</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  CIVILIAN EMPLOYEES IN DEFENCE SERVICE</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p> </p><p align="center"><strong>CIVILIAN EMPLOYEES IN DEFENCE SERVICE (CLASSIFICATION, CONTROL AND APPEAL) RULES, 1961</strong></p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>Rules —8 and 9</strong></p><p>Service matter—Compulsory retirement is a major penalty and can only he imposed upon a full enquiry under the Rules—after reinstatement the petitioner being governed by the Civil Service Regulations. He cannot be made to retire normally only after 12 years of service.</p><p><strong><em>Mostafa Izzat Ali Chowdhury Vs. Government of Bangladesh and others; 2 BLD (HCD) 109.</em></strong></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>

R. 11.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Baitul Aman Co-operative Housing Society Ltd. and another Vs.
