1136	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">CODE OF CIVIL PROCEDURE, 1908 [ORDER I - VI]</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  5 BLD (AD) 115, 9 BLD29, 2 BLD (HCD) 160, 4 BLD (HD) 207, 1 BLD (AD) 279, IOBLD (AD) 17, 1BLD (AD) 77, 6 BLD (AD) 109, 6 BLD (HCD) 155, 9 BLD HCD) 10, IIBLD (HCD)99, 1 BLD (AD) 218, 2 BLD (HCD) 160, 4 BLD(HCD) 288, 5BLD (HCD) 57, 5 BLD (HCD) 223, 6 BLD (</p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  1908</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  CIVIL PROCEDURE</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u><br/> </u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>CODE OF CIVIL PROCEDURE, 1908</u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order 1 Rules 3 and 4</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Joinder of parties</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Plaintiff can join all persons as defendants against whom .any right to relief in respect of the same cause of action, arising against them involves, common questions of law and fact.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Bangladesh Railway Vs. MIs. Sinafracht Chartering and Shipbreaking Corporation through their local agents United Liner Agencies and others, 5 BLD (AD) 115</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order 1 Rule 3 and 4</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The terms proforma means for the sake of form only but this expression does not appear in the Code of Civil Procedure. A defendant might be a necessary party whose presence is a must or he may be a proper party w-ho though not a necessary party, yet a party whose presence before the Court may be required for proper adjudication of the matters in issue. If the proforma defendant is for the sake of form only, the decree would not bind him—A party</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">though described as a proforma in a suit would be bound by a decree passed in his presence after he has contested the suit by filing a written statement in which an adverse claim is made against the property in suit.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Power Development Board Vs. sonali Bank, 9 BLD29</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. A.I.R. 1947 (Bom) 217; A.I.R. 1960 (SC) 388—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order 1 Rule 3 and 10</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Necessary Party</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In a suit for declaration that a decree is null and void, none excepting the persons who are parties to the decree and who are parties in the suit in which the decree was passed and their legal representatives are necessary parties—.In such a suit abandoned property authority is not a necessary party.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Md. Hanif and others Vs. Akhtar Rahim and others, 2 BLD (HCD) 160.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order 1 Rule 3</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Defect of party</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Whether the suit suffers from nonimpleading the original contracting party—The Imperial Chemical Industries (Pakistan Ltd.) has no subsisting interest in the suit property and has also no subsisting obligation in the contract—It is therefore not a necessary party.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Imprial Chemical Industries (Bangladesh) Ltd. Vs. MIs. G. K Brothers, 4 BLD (HD) 207</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order 1 Rule 8</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Representative suit—Prior permission of the Court for filing such a suit is not necessary.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Md. Kutubuddin Chowdhury and others Vs. Rafiqul Islam &amp; ors., 1 BLD (AD) 279.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order 1 Rule 8 read.with Order 39 Rules.1 and 2</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Ad-interim injunction—Refusal of prayer for such injunction in a representative suit when justified</span></strong>—the proceedings. in such a suit known these days as public litigation do not partake of pre-determined private law litigation model and the need for judicial intervention may not arise even in those cases where the Courts jurisdiction is invoked, ii the administration takes curative measures meanwhile—In this view of the matter the petition for special leave to appeal against the refusal of interim injunction is dismissed.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Ziaul Huq and others Vs. Messers Business Resources Ltd. and others, IOBLD (AD) 17</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. A.I.R.1988 (SC) 2211; A.I.R.1987 (SC) 359; A.I.R. I 988(HP) 4(at page 9)—Cited</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order 1 Rule 9, 10 and 13</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Pre-emption—Provisions of section 96(2) regarding joinder of necessary parties is mandatory and not directory</span></strong>—Consequence of non-joinder of necessary parties in spite of objection taken is the same .in preemption proceeding as in suits—State Acquisition. and Tenancy Act, .1950 (XXVIII of 1951), S. 96.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Abdus Samad and others Vs. Md. Sohrab Ali and others, 1BLD (AD) 77</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order 1 Rule 9</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Defect of party in a partition suit</span></strong>— whether such a suit is maintainable without impleading co-sharers—In a partition suit, the established principle of law is that all co sharers shall be impleaded and that failure to implead any co-sharer shall render the suit liable for dismissal.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Mobinnessa and others Vs. Khalilur Rahman and others 6 BLD (AD) 109</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order 1 Rule 9</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Suit for permanent injunction and defect of partie</span></strong>s—No question of defect of parties in a suit for permanent injunction— only those who threaten the plaintiff with dispossession are necessary parties.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Pasharuddin Mir Vs. Ismail Mir and others, 6 BLD (HCD) 155</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 5DLR22; 11 C.W.N.5 17; 1 2DLR708; 4BLD (AD) 285—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order 1 Rule 9</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Defect of party</span></strong>—When a partition suit suffers from defect of party—The plaintiff holds .12 acres of land in Khatian No. 77 plot No. 699 along with other persons who also hold 35 acres in Khatian Nos. 154 and 190 in the same plot 699—In the light of the principles laid down in such facts the suit suffers from defect of parties.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Chan Jun Talukder and another Vs. Ching Nesha Magni and others, 9 BLD HCD) 10</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 7PLR(DA)6 19; 1 OPLR(DA)27 ;26DL R( HC)363 ;3 I DLR(AD)2 18 ;8 DLR(DA)645; 9 PLR (DA)6 19—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order 1 Rule 9</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Misjoinder and non-joionder of parties— Necessary parties—Suit for simple declaration of title to the land claimed by the contesting defendant—Plaintiff does not claim my relief against the transferees nor is it impossible to pass an effective decree in the suit in their absence—So they cannot be said to be necessary parties.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Tahain Gazi Vs. Promila Pramanik, IIBLD (HCD)99.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order 1 Rule 10</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Probate proceeding—Addition of. party—</span></strong>Person not claiming interest in the property through the testator is not entitled to added as a party—Succession Act, )925(XXXIX bf 1925), S. 283.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Sreeiliati Charmbala Sen Gupta being dead her substituted legatee Paresh Chandra 1kb Gupta Vs. Aba! Hashem and others, 1 BLD (AD) 218</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. A.I.R. 1959 (Pat) 570; 2IDLR 331— Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order 1 Rule 10 and 3</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Necessary Party</span></strong>—In a suit for declaration that a decree is null and void, none exepting the persons who are parties to the decree and who are parties in the suit in which t decree was passed and their legal representatives are necessary parties—In suci a suit abandoned property authority is not a necessary party.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Md. Hamf and others Vs. Akhtar Rahim and others, 2 BLD (HCD) 160</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order I Rule 10</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Addition of party</span></strong>—Whether in a suit filed by the vendors against the purchasers for a declaration that the transaction of sale was in fact benami, the pre-emptor may be added as party—In the event the plaintiff-opposite parties succeed in obtaining the decree prayed for, the pre-emptor-petitioner may be required to file another suit to set aside that decree—In the interest of justice and in order to avoid. multiplicity of proceedings it is proper that the petitioner be added as defendant in the suit.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Sreemati Joga Maya Debi and others Vs. Sree Din Dayal Sing Hazari. and others, 4 BLD(HCD)288</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order 1 Rule 10</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Addition of party</span></strong>—Whether addition of party can be made in revision ?—The applicants resigned from the Executive Committee—They have no locus standi to be added as party in the proceeding—They are not necessary and proper parties in the Rule.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Deputy Secretary, Ministry of Commerce Vs. Nizamuddin Haider, 5BLD (HCD) 57</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 21 DLR (SC) 50—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order 1 Rule 10</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Whether a person who has purchased the suit property subsequent to the agreement for specific performance of contract, for which the suit has been filed, should be added as a party—The petitioner apparently 1as succeeded in showing that he has got exiting title and possession in the suit property—To effectually and completely adjudicate the dispute once for all and to avoid multiplicity of proceedings the petitioner should be added as a party.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Abut Hashem Vs. Saleh Ahmed and others, 5 BLD (HCD) 223</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 16 DLR 239—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order 1 Rule 10</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Addition of party</span></strong>—Whether a person who is neither a necessary party nor a proper party in the suit can be impleaded—It is well settled that an order of addition of parties can be made only where they are either necessary or proper parties but where this is not so, no order for addition of parties can be made.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>The Board of Secondary and Higher Secondary Education, Dhaka and another Vs. Md. Nurul Islam and others, 6 BLD (AD) 189</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order 1 Rule 10</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Defect of party—Whether nonimpleading of all the Shebaits in a suit against the Deity makes the. suit bad ?</span></strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">— The question of impleading all the Shebaits could arise only if the Development Committee was not formed to manage the affairs of the temple—There is no proof that heirs of some of the Shebaits were in fact managing the affairs of the Deity—Failure to implead such, heirs does not render the suit not maintainable.</span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Shrish Chandra Das Vs. Sri Sri Chatteswari Debi Bigraha, represented by Shehaits: Chandra Sekhar Chakraborty and others, 6 BLD (AD) 291</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. A.I.R. 1979 (SC) 1682—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order 1 Rule 10</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Addition of party</span></strong>—Whether in a suit for ejectment of a monthly tenant by the landlord a third party claiming title is a necessary party—Whether addition of such a third party claiming title should be added as a party in the suit—Whether such addition of party would change the nature of the suit—If .a third party claiming title to the suit property is added as a ,defendant in an ejectment suit the character or very nature of’ the suit will be changed turning it into ‘a complicated title suit and the relief asked for in the suit will fall into insignificance—Such a third party is not a necessary party in the ejectment suit.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Md. Juranuddin Sheikh Vs. Abul Kalam and another, 6 BLD (HCD)164</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. A.I.R.1974 Pat.364; A.I.R.1977 Orissa 183—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order 1 Rule 10</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Addition of party</span></strong>—Whether a person</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">offering to purchase the suit property from the Government on payment of certain amount and the Government accepting his offer is a necessary party in a suit by another person claiming that the suit property is not an abandoned property—Relief claimed by the plaintiff-appellant is against the Government—If the Government cannot justify the legality of its decision to treat the property as abandoned property it will be so declared by the Court—It is not understood how the addition of the person against whom no relief has been claimed in the suit can be of any use or relevance—It is for the Government to justify the order and the added defendant has nothing to say in the matter.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Abdul Khaleque Bains and others Vs. Government of Bangladesh and others, 7 BLD (AD) 121</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order 1 Rule 10</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Addition of party</span></strong>—Wheh not allowed?</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—The owners interested in the ship are necessary parties and they ought to have been added as defendants in the suit—But since the application for addition or substitution has been made at a belated stage ‘and after completion of evidence, it is rejected.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Bangladesh Chemical Industries Corporation and another Vs. M.V. Kayo Akyon and others, 7 BLD (HCD) 1</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order 1 Rule 10(2)</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Whetheir lessees are necessary parties?</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Addition of parties</span></strong>—Whether a lesee who claims to be in possression of the disputed property is a proper party in a suit for permanent injunction—A lessee in possession has at least some interest which he is interested to safeguard—His presence also helps the plaintiffs in getting their claims effectively adjudicated and settled in presence of all parties concerned—He is a proper party.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Mosammat Aleya Begum and others Vs. K.M.A. Mahiuddin Manik and others; 7 BLD (HCD) 105</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 31 DLR (HCD) 107;—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order 1 Rule 10</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Necessary party</span></strong>—Lessee in a suit for declaration simpliciter—Whether lessee is a necessary party in a suit for mere declaration—The suit is for a declaration that the. suit land is not vested and non-resident property—The relief sought is against the Government that had leased out the Suit land— The act of leasing out has led to the creation of interest in the lessee—The creation of interest has cast an obligation on him to protect it—It may be necessary that the lessee may have more reasons to protect his interest in the suit land than the lessor—The interests of lessor and lessee may not always be the same so as to hold that the presence of the lessor as a defendant suffices and the lessee’s presence. may not be necessary.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Waliullah Munshi Vs. Ledu Mia Patwari and others, 8 BLD (AD) 218</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. (1881) 9Cal. L.R., 3IDLR 107— Cited. .</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order 1 Rule 10</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Addition of Party</span></strong>—Addition of party in a Probate Proceeding—Whether persons claiming title independently of the will and adversely to the testator are entitled to be added as parties in a probate proceeding?—In probate proceeding the Court is required only to consider whether the will is duly executed and it is not the concern of the Court to decide whether the testator had title to the property—The person claiming independently dthe will and adversely to the testator has no locus.standi to file an application for being added as party in the probate proceeding.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Md. Makbul Hosain and, others Vs. Sree Sibu Pada Dam, 8 BLD (HCD) 143</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 33DLR (AD) 254; 2IDLR 331— Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order 1 Rule 10</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Addition of Party</span></strong>—The law permits addition of parties such as the petitioner, claims title and possession in the suit land, which fact came to the knowledge of the plaintiff subsequent to the institution of the suit.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Nuruddin Ahmed Vs. Zafarullah Siddique and others, 8 BLD (HCD) 200</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order 1 Rule 10</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Addition of Party</span></strong>—Question of addition in a suit for declaration that the decree is null and void—In the instant case it transpires that the plaintiff has sought for a. declaration that the decrees in the two suits are void by reason of fraud and in none of the suits neither the opposite party nor her vendor vas a party—In such a position any person is.1not to be added as a party—Only the person who are parties to the decree and who were parties in the suit or their representations are the necessary parties in such a suit, the paramount question to be decided therein being whether fraud was practiced on the Court 14y the parties— Moreover, in view of the claim of the opposite party the impugned order for her addition as a party suffers from error of law.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Md. Mozammel Huq Vs. Sirin Rahman and others, 8 BLD (HCD) 410</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 2 BLD 160—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order 1 Rule 10</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Probate Proceeding</span></strong>—When it should be referred to the District Judge for adjudication?—Both the District Judge and the District Delegate may upon an application for grant for Probate or Letters of Administration issue criterions calling upon all persons claiming to have any interest in the estate of the deceased to come and see the proceedings—But it is only the District Judge who can dispose of an objector’s application— With his appearance the proceeding cases to be non-contentious—If the District Delegate then proceeds with the case he will exceed his jurisdiction—Whether the party opposing the proceeding has any locus standi or not will be decided not by him but by the District Judge—Succession Act, 1925. (XXXIX of 1925), Ss. 265; 268, 272, 283 and 286.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Kalpana Das Gupta Vs. Govt. of Bangladesh and another, 8 BLD (HCD)</em></strong> 4</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 1 BLD (AD) 2 18—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Order 1 Rule 10(2)</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Addition of party</em></strong>—When a party canaiot be added as a co-plaintiff—A party seeking to be added as a co-plaintiff and putting forward conflicting claims as to the title in the property in dispute should not be so added—He can be made defendant in the suit for the purpose of effective and complete adjudication of the issues which may be raised for decision.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Mohammad Idris alias Shelim and others Vs. Bazal Ahmed and others, 9 BLD (HCD) 114</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 1981 Patna 298; 1953 Bombay ‘202—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order 1 Rule 10</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Addition of party on the appellate stage—Addition at the appellate stage in a case of specific performance of contract</span></strong>— The appellative Court in a fit case has jurisdiction to add any person as defendant if his presence is necessary in order to dispose of the dispute effectively and completely—The power of addition by the appellate Court is sparingly, used in exceptional cases for the sake of justic—In the ii41ant case, the Court did not come to any finding as to whether the addition of Opposite Party No. I was necessary for effective adjudication—He passed the order as if it is a routine work—The addition of the party in the case at the appellate. stage will create an anomalous position—It will call for written statement resulting in fresh hearing of the suit—The plaintiff will have to face a party against whom no relief was prayed for and the application was not connected with the contract in question—So an error of law has been committed by allowing opposite party No. I to be added as a respondent. The impugned order is not sustainable.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Gopi Ballav Saha Vs. Abdur Rob Khan, 9 BLD (HCD) 134</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 35 DLR 60; 35 DLR 110; 6I.C. 912—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order I Rul 10</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Transposition of a party and withdrawal from such by a co-plaintiff</span></strong>—Transposition upon withdrawal from a suit—Position of a co-plaintiff wanting to withdrew—A co-plaintiff, if he has a separate cause of action can always be allowed to withdrew— When a plaintiff having the same cause of action wants towithdraw with liberty to sue afresh, consent of other co-plaintiffs is necessary—In the case of absence of such liberty, no consent is required but the withdrawing plaintiff needs to be transposed as a proforma-defendant in order to avoid the suit being dismissed for defect of parties— Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 (V of 1908), Order XXIII.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Suresh Majumder and others Vs. Government of Bangladesh and others, 9 BID (HCD) 180</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. A.I.R. 1943 (Cal)427—Cited. Order 1 Rule 10</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Power to add a party is discretionary— Addition of party—When prayer for addition should be refused?—</span></strong>If the petitioner is added as a party the plaint needs be amended introducing new facts and cause of action changing the nature and character of the suit—Such amendment at the belated stage would be unwarranted—Further, the petitioners having already filed a suit the decree that may be passed there would be binding onboth the parties—In the facts of the case the Court in rejecting the prayer for addition of party had not acted illegally or arbitrarily or fancifully—The power to add a party is discretionary and unless that power is exercised arbitrarily or fancifully, it cannot be interfered with—Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 Vof 1908), S. 115.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Ishaque Hossain Chowdhurv. Vs Mrs. Shsmsun Nahar be gum, 9 BLD (HCD) 194</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 30DLR (SC) 244—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order I Rule 10</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Effect of abatement—Principle of addition of party</span></strong>—When abatement of a suit takes place owing to non-substitution of heirs, the defendants acquire a vested right not to be proceeded against in the suit—The effect of abatement can be overcome only by satisfying The Court as to the cause preventing the : plaintiff from continuing the suit which he is under a legal obligation to do when the cause under challenge—It is never in the discretion of the Court to allow the application for substitution either in the interest of justice or r avoiding multiplicity of proceedings— T- principle relating to addition of party cannot be applied in the facts and circumstances of the present case—Code of Civil Procedure, l908(V of 1908), Or. XXII C 8(2)(3).</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Bhupati Biswas and others Vs. Niranjan Biswas and others, 9 BLD (HCD) 355</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 22 DLR 500; A.I.R. 1940 (PC)</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order1Rule10</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Addition of Party—Addition after abatement was recorded for non substitution</span></strong>—If for any reason the heirs of a cannot be substituted within time, Court may allow such heirs to be added as in the suit in the interest of justice— Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 (V of 1908), 22 Rule 9.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Ujjal Hossain (Minor) and others Vs. Firoza Khatun and others, 9 BLD (HCD) 407</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 22 DLR 500—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order 1 Rule 10</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Addition of party in appeal</span></strong>—Whether a party not impleaded in the suit can be added as a party in the appeal—Any party interested in the proceeding of an appeal though was not a party in the suit can be impleaded, under given circumstances, in the appeal to protect the interest of that party.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Exports India Vs. Rupashai Garments and others, 11 BLD (HCD) 65</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order 1 Rule 10(2)</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Proper Parties</span></strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">—The suit is for simple declaration of title to the land claimed by the contesting defendant—The plaintiff does not claim any relief against the transferees nor is it impossible to pass an effective decree in the suit in their absence—So they cannot be said to be necessary parties—But it cannot be denied that in the facts and circumstances of the case their presence is a matter of convenience to enable the Court to adjudicate upon and settle all questions involved in the suit more effectively and completely—Thus though not necessary parties, the transferees from Sunil and Nakul are proper parties in the suit and in such view of the matter, there is no error in the finding of the Courts below that the suit is bad for nonjoinder of parties.</span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Ta ham Gazi Vs. Promila Pramanik, 11BLD (HCD) 99</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order 1 Rule 10(2)</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Addition of party</span></strong>—At the revision stage—A Court may add a party even at the revision stage in a proper case and the minimum that is required to be found in such a case is that the presence of such a part is necessary within the meaning of Order I Rule 10(2) of C.P.C. or for the ends of justice</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Subash Chandra Halder and another Vs. Abdul Ban and others, 12 BLD (AD) 174</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order 1 Rule 10</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Addition of party</span></strong>—The order on the trial Court allowing the application under Order 1 Rule 10 C.P.C. is illegal and contrary to law inasmuch without setting aside the order of abatement the prayer for addition of parties is not maintainable in law.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Nader Ali Shah Vs. Badu Molla and others, 12BLD (HCD) 511</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order I Rule 13</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Objection regarding non-joinder of parties in revision</span></strong>—Objection regarding non-joinder of necessary parties has to be taken at the earliest opportunity, before the trial Court, and in appropriate case may be allowed to be taken in appeal, but not for the first time in revision.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Abdus Samad and others Vs. Md. Sohrab Ali and others, 1 BLD (AD) 77</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order I Rule 13</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Non-joinder of parties</span></strong>—Plea should be taken at the earliest opportunity—Failure of taking such objection at the earliest possible opportunity shall be deemed to have been waived—Pleas not raised in the trial Court nor mentioned in the, written statement cannot be allowed to be raised in second appeal.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Mst. Hematunnesa and others Vs. Bangladesh Rubber Industries and another Vs.. Begum Lutfunnessa and another, 3 BLD (AD) 220.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Order VI Rule 17</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Amendment of the plaint by substituting the original prayer for declaration of share and accounts of an unregistered firm by dissolution and ‘accounts whether maintainable?</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Whether such amendment will change the nature and character of the suit’?.—The .pr posed amendment was necessary for avoiding multiplicity of proceedings and for complete adjudication of the disputes between the parties on determination of the real question in controversy—The suit was originally for declaration of shares and accounts—By amending the prayer the plaintiff now also seeks dissolution firm—It is difficult to understand why the prayer for dissolution can- not proceed in combination with the original prayer in the plaint—If a partner of an unregistered firm can maintain a suit for dissolution and accounts, his prayer for declaration of his share may as well be tried prior to dissolving the firm—Whatever bar was imposed by the provisions of sub-section (i) and (2) of section 69 of the Partnership Act cannot stand in the way of combining the prayers—The prayer for. Amendment is allowed—Partnership Act, 1932 (IX of 1932), S. 69.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Radha Krishna Jogani (Agarwalla) Vs. Dwarka Das Agarwalla and others, 5 BLD(AD)85</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. (1 893) I.L.R.20(Cal)805; A.I.R. 1922 (PC)249;LL.R. 48 (Cal) 832; A.I.R. 1933 (Rangoon) 247; 29 DLR (SC) 311; I5DLR (SC) 120; 1979 BSCR 135; 11 M.I.A. 468; 63 C.W.N. 766;—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Order VI Rule 17</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Amendment of plaint</strong>—Whether prayer r declaration that the deed of partition is and by fraudulent and illegal can be amended By substituting prayer for cancellation of the deed of partition—Since the relief prayed for in the amendment petition appears to follow m the declaration prayed for in the plaint the contention that there was question of limitation does not appear to be acceptable— If the Court after taking evidence comes to hold that certain document is null and void being fraudulent, there is no reason why it cannot order its cancellation after granting the said declaration—Cancellation of a document seems to be a consequence of the declaration of the deed as null and void.—Specific Relief Act, 1877(1 of 1877) S. 42.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Jarina Khatun and others Vs. Pulin Chandra Das and others, 5BLD (AD)253</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. I7DLR 190; 29DLR (SC) 311; 1979 BSCRI35; 15 DLR (SC)120—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Order VI Rule 17</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Cancellation of written statement filed jointly with other defendants and acceptance of a separate written statement—Pleading may be struck out or cancelled at any stage of the proceeding—The trial Court committed illegalities in not allowing the prayer of the petitioner for cancellation of the written statement filed jointly in so far as it relates to her and acceptance of the written statement filed by her along with the petition.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Musammat Sakina Begum </em></strong><strong>Vs. Moharn <em>mad Ishaque, 5BLD (HCD) 13</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Order VI Rule 17</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Amendment</strong>—Amendment for preemption—The pre-emptor is seeking to amend the pleading with a new claim on the basis that he is a contiguous owner of the Kabala lands—The new claim is a different one based on the ground that he is a contiguous owner—Apart from the question of prejudice to the other side or that the claim is barred by limitation, the alteration of the basis of the claim has assumed a complexion wholly different from the original cause of action—The provisions of the C.P.C. do not contemplate amendment of a pleading when a legal right has accrued by lapse of time in favour of the other party.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Al-haj Moulvi Idris Miah Vs. Sree Shushil Ranjan Dutta, 5BLD (HCD) 30</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. PLD I 963(Dhaka) 87; 1960 PLD (Lahore) 975; 17 DLR (SC) 111; 15DLR (SC) 120; PLD1948 (PC) 73; 3IDLR (AD) 133; A.1.R.1973 (SC) 21 10—Cited</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Order VI Rule 17</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Amendment of plaint</strong>—Amendment would affect the question of limitation and the right allowed to the defendant by lapse of time—Such amendment cannot be allowed to be made.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Aminul Hoque Sowdagar Vs. Md. Abdur Rabban and others, 5BLD (HCD) 6I</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Order VI Rule 17</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Amendment of plaint</strong>—Suit for declaration of nullity of the alleged fraudulent decree and for an injunction—If the suit is maintainable the amendment of the plaint for recovery of possession of the suit land from which the plaintiff was dispossessed by violent means is also maintainable.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Kazi Hanif Siddique Vs.. Sheikh Nuruddin alias Nuruddin and others, 6BLD (AD) 54</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Order VI Rule 17</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Amendment of pleading</strong>—It is true that amendment can be allowed at any stage of the proceedings, but after an inordinate delay it will be inequitable to allow the prayer for amendment.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Md. Nurul Islam being dead his heirs Md. Shamsul Islam and others Vs. Abdul Malek, 6BLD (AD) 201</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 36 DLR (AD) 253—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Order VI Rule 17</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Amendment of pre-emption petition making a new claim on the basis of contiguous ownership will change the nature and character of the case specially when it is barred by limitation—No amendment is allowed where its effect will take away any legal tight accrued to the other party by lapse of time or if the amendment introduces a totally new and inconsistent case—The appellant claimed pre-emption either as a co-sharer Or as a tenant holding land contiguous to the land transferred—The is was necessary because the respondent took the plea that by mutation a separate Khatian had been created—In the present case no legal right has accrued to the pre emptee—Once- an amendment is made the amendment will relate back to the date of institution of the case—State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950 (XXVIII of 1951), S.96.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Sree Shushil Ranjan Dutta Vs. Al-haj - Moulvi Idris Mia, 6 BLD (AD) 221</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref... PLDI948 (P.C.) 73; 15DLR (SC) 120; BSCR (1979) 135—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Order VI Rule 17</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Amendment of the plaint</strong>—Whether the amendment of the plaint that a party in suit for partition is not an heir of the original owner can be allowed?—Amendment. of-the plaint changing the averment regarding a party will not change the nature and character of.the suit—A change in one of the links in the genealogy does not have the effect of changing the fundamental character of the plaint—Amendment of the plaint for getting out of the admission—Such amendment can be allowed if it is necessary for the discrimination of the real question of controversy between the parties. - -</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Shahiman Bewa Vs. Sharifuddin Ahmed and others, 6BLD (HCD) 58 - -</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 36 DLR (AD) 253; A.I.R. 1929 (Cal) 307: 35 C-.L.J. 530; 68 IC. 482; AIR. 1922 Cal 309; 30 D.L.R. (SC) 93—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Order VI Rule 17</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Amendment of plaint</strong>—Amendment for further relief—Even if the prayer for- further relief was not included in the plaint the Court got power to direct amendment of plaint so as to include such a prayer at any stage of the proceedings -if it is considered necessary in the interest of justice—The only condition for amendment of the plaint is that it will not take the defendant, by, surprise. by introducing an new case or any new cause of action altogether or it will not change the character of the suit—Though the law of limitation is to be followed in such matter, in an appropriate case the rigidity may be relaxed.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Sufia Khanain Chowdhury Vs. Faizun Nessa Chowdhury, 7BLD (AD) 55.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 15 DLR (SC) 120; AIR. 1967 (SC) 6—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Order VI Rule 17</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Amendment of plaint</strong>—Whether in a uit for specific performance of contract for .ale of property a prayer for amendment of the plaint by inclusion of a prayer for execution and registration of the sale deed also by the purchaser subsequent to the contract with the plaintiff should be allowed?—The suit is for specific performance of a contract which Order VI Rule 17 as executed on 22nd January 1981 on which date the purchaser defendant was not in the scene—The contract related to properties which then solely belonged to defendant No. 1—defendant No. 2 came into the• picture nearly eight months after—Unless he can claim ownership of the properties on and from this date how he can be compelled to execute the sale deed on the basis of such a contract?.—Since defendant No. 2 has already been implicated in the Suit, he being subsequent transferee will be bound by the decree the suit—The prayer for declaration that subsequent deed was void and fraudulent, if _lowed, the plaintiff will have no ground for more grievant—Rejection of prayer for _amendment of the plaint by the Courts below approved—Specific Relief Act, 1877 I of l7). S. 27. . .</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Nurul Amin and others Vs; Md. Faziul Huq and others, 7BLD (AD) 185</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Order VI Rule 17</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Amendment of election petition</strong>— Whether an election Tribunal has power to amend an election petition—An election Tribunal is no a civil Court constituted under</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">the Civil Court Act, 1887—The power of the Election Tribunal in deciding an election petition is that of a statutory Tribunal with limited jurisdiction—Though the Tribunal is not a Civil Court exercising all the powers under the Code of Civil Procedure, it may still exercise the power of amendment of pleadings—But it has no authority to give the amendment a retrospective effect from the date of filing bf the election petition.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Hosne Zaman Sarker Vs. Election Tribunal and Munsif and others, 7BLD (HCD) 84</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 29DLR 111; 27DLR 388; 28 DLR 375; 28DLR368; 1BLD298—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Order VI Rule 17</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Amendment of plaint</strong>—Whether the plaintiff can be allowed to amend the plaint for recovery of money based on dishonored cheques into a suit based on failure to pay price of goods?—In a suit for promissory notes, hands etc. since the plaintiff could have initially sued in the alternative upon the original consideration, there is no reason why the plaintiff should not be allowed to amend his plaint so as to base his suit only on the original consideration using the dishonored cheques as evidence of his outstanding dues from the defendant—The amendment does not in any. way have the effect of converting thorn suit into another suit of a different and inconsistent c:haracter—Cause of action is not being substituted nor the subject matter of thC suit changed nor ground of relief is being departed . from nor the order allowing amendment takes away from the defendant the teal right of limitation—The Court is empowered Wallow a any stage of the proceeding either party to alter or amend the pleadings for the 5urpose of determining the real questions in controversy.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>M.A. Majid Vs. MIs. Khalil and sons; 7BLD (HCD) 226</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. A.LR.1918 (PC) 146: A.I.R.1921 (PC) 50; I.L.R.1933 (Born.) 802; A.LR.1922 (PC) 249—Cited</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order VI Rule 17</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Amendment of plaint</span></strong>—Whether a suit for mesne profits can be amended to include prayer for declaration of title and recovery of possession—What the plaintiffs were wanting in the suit is to assert their title in the land and to go back to possession—Mere change in the relief prayed for does not change the nature of the suit—The prayer for amendment of the plaint has rightly been allowed—There is no scope for saying that the amendments have made any change in the nature and character of the suit or have taken away any right from any of the defendants—Code of Civil Procedure, 1908(V of 1908), Or.2 r.2.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Nuruddin Ahmed Vs. Zafarullah Siddique and others, 8BLD (HCD) 200</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. A.I.R. 1921 (PC)50; I 978BSCR(AD) 349: PLD1963 (SC) 191; I5DLR (SC) 120; ii M.LA.(PC) 468; 29DLR (SC) 311—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order VI Rule 17 V</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Maintainabilfty of suit</span></strong>—When payment of advelorem court fee. Itself does not make the suit maintainable—it cannot be said that. merely because the plaintiffs paid ad valorem court fees the suit in effect became a suit for’ title and possession—The Subordinate Judge’. has correctly foundthat the suit as framed is not maintainable is as much as no relief can be given as per negative, contradictory and vague prayer in the plaint.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Abdul Hafez and another Vs. L Meah and others, 8BLD (HCD) 497</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 2ODLR 332; 28DLR 18 1—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order VI Rule 17</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Ainendnient of plaint</span></strong>—Adding of prayers—.It is well settled that adding of prayers which are consequential in nature does not in any way change the nature and character of the suit.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Yakub Ltd. and others Vs. Md. Meah Mia, 8BLD (HCD) 524</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 15 DLR (SC) 520; 11 M.I.A. 468; A.I.R. 1921 (PC) 50; 29 DLR (AD) 311; PLD 1953 (SC) 19 1—Cited</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order VI Rule 17 read with section 151</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Amendment of written statement</span></strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">— Principle for such amendment—The governing consideration to amend, the written statement should be how far, if at all, the proposed amendment of the defence is necessary to determine the real controversy between the parties—Amendment of written statement should not be granted’ if it would convert the defence into another or a different and inconsistent character.</span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Major (Rtd) Mohammad Afsaruddin Vs. Karnal Rahinan, 9BLD (HCD) 380</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. (1885)31 Ch. D. 68; 26.DLR 205; A.I.R. I 953(CAI) 15—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order VI Rule 17 read with section 1.51.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Amendment of written statement</span></strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">— Whether it can be prayed at any stage—--lt can be legitimately argued by the plaintiff that the introduction of an alteinative defence at this stage of the suit when his case is closed and the defendant has been examined in part will  be highly prejudicial to him (plaintiff).</span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Major (Rtd) Mohammad Afsaruddin Vs. Kamal Rahman, 9BLD (HCD) 380</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order VI Rule 17</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Amendment of plaint</span></strong>—Extent of Courts power to allow amendment—Court is competent to allow the plaintiff to amend’ his plaint Cven after filing of the written statement—Amendment can be ‘allowed at any stage of the proceeding and the rules of procedure are meant to, do justice’ between the parties and. not to stand in its way—In order t’o allow amendment the true. test is whether the amendment is foreign to the ‘subject- matter and wh’ether it would be just to ‘allow it—’--Mere introduction of new facts without changing the subject-matter is no ground for refusal of amendment—Where the plaintiff seeks to alter the cause of action itself in the garb of amendment by introducing a1toether a new or inconsistent cause of action the Court will refuse such amendment.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">M.A. Jahangir and another Vs. Abdál Malek and others, 9BLD (HCD) 528</span></em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 12D.L.R. 704; 1977 Mad. 368;. 1978 (SC) 484;—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Order VI Rule 17</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Amendment of plaint</strong>—Amendment of the plaint may be made at any, stage of the proceeding even at the appellate stage without any change in the nature and character of the suit.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Jahangir Nagar University Co-operative Housing Society Vs. Md. Mujibar Rahman and others, 10BLD (HCD) 419</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 29 DLR (SC) 311; 28 DLR (HCD) 131; 13 DLR 871; 12 DLR 626—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Order VI Rule 17</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Amendment of plaint</strong>—The Court has no right to direct the amendment of plaint when it has no jurisdiction over the subject matter of the plaint.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The general rule in allowing amendment of plaint is that a party is not allowed by way of amendment to set up a new cause or a new cause of action particularly when the suit on• the new cause of action is barred.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">An amendment which involves a substaiitial alteration of the cause of action should not be permitted more specially when the suit was brought long after the period of limitation.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Md. Mansur Ali Vs. Janata Bank and others, 11 BLD (HCD) 23.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. A.I.R. 1967 (SC) 96; A.I.R. 1935 All) 842; AIR. I 936(Patna) 535;—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Order VI Rule 17</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Amendment of plaint</strong>—When amendment sought for, does not change the nature and character of the suit and the amendment is proper and just for effective adjudication of the issues between the parties, amendment is to be allowed.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Kutub Uddin Bhuiyan and others Vs. Sakhina Bibi and others, 11BLD (HCD) 33</span></em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Order VI Rule 17</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Court’s power .under Order VI Rule 17</strong>—the power of the Court under Order VI Rule 17 of the Code of Civil Procedure is no doubt discretionary but the same must be exercised in a judicial manner.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Mojibur Rahman Sarker and others Vs. Shafiqul Islam and ors., 11BLD (HCD) 314</span></em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Order VI Rule 17</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Courts power under Order VI Rule 17</strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">—It is well settled that power of the Court under Order VI Rule 17 is wide and discretionary’ but that power must be exercised judicially in the facts and circumstances of each case and not arbitrarily or whimsically—It is also well established that if the proposed amendment changes the nature and character of the suit, the Court will not generally allow such a prayer for amendment.</span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Moyezuddin Mondal Vs. Beena Das and others, 12 BLD (HCD) 231</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 25DLR62; 3DLR (PC)310; 4IDLR 389—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Order VI Rule 17</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Amendment of plaint</strong>—Before allowing any amendment or alteration of the pleading, the Court must come to a finding that such amendment or alteration is necessary for determining the real question in controversy between the parties and further that such amendment or alteration does not change the nature and character of the suit or the same is not inconsistent with the earlier pleadings or it does not substitute any cause of action of the suit.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Sree Kirtish Chandra Dev Vs. Begum Sufia Akhter and others, 12 BLD (HCD) 591.</em></strong></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
1137	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">CODE OF CIVIL PROCEDURE, 1908 [ORDER VII - IX]</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  11BLD (HCD) 124, 1OBLD (HCD) 392, 6BLD (HCD) 23, 8BLD (HCD) 473, 3BLD (AD) 195, 1OBLD (HCD) 100, 10BLD (H CD) 347, HBLD (HCD) 23, 128LD (HCD) 257, 1BLD (AD) 3O7, 1BLD (HCD) 361, 2BLD (HCD) 160, 2BLD(HCD)201, 3BLD (AD) 195, 3BLD(HCD)104, 3BLD (HCD) 225, 4</p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  1908</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  CIVIL PROCEDURE</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u><br/> </u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>CODE OF CIVIL PROCEDURE, 1908</u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Order VII Rule 1(e)</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Order VII Rule 1(e) provides that the plaint should contain the particular facts constituting the cause of action and when it arose—Departure from pleading or improvement in the plaint story is fatal.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Kamar Begum Roy Vs. M. Khalilur Rahman, 11BLD (HCD) 124</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Order VII</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Material fact not incorporated in the plaint—cannot be pleaded as it does not offer opportunity to defendant to controvert it.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>The Official Liquidator, East Béngla Commercial Bank Ltd. (in Liquidation) Vs. Mrs. Jahura Khatuan and others, 1OBLD (HCD) 392.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Order VII Rule 10(1)</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Return of plaint</strong>—When one of the defendant has its Zonal Office at Comilla. the plaintiff was required to obtain leave of the Court at Comilla before filing the suit at Comilla—The cause of action for the short delivery of goods, having arisen at Chittagong the Court at Comilla has no jurisdiction to try the suit—Moreover, documents of defendant No. 2 being at Chittagong and the witness to depose being from Chittagong it is proper that the suit be tried at Chittagong Court—Code of Civil Procedure, ‘1908 (V of 1908), S. 20(b).</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Islam and co. Vs. Sarma Chemical Works Ltd; 6BLD (HCD) 23</em></strong>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 39 C.W.N. 174——Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">VII Rule 10(I)</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Suit filed in wrong forum—Because of the bar of limitation during the pendency of the present suit the petitioner will be non- suited—If the petitioner was properly ad-</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">vised, he could have taken back the plaint for presentation before the proper forum and avail of the benefit of section 14 read with section 29 of the Limitation Act—Limitation</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Act, 1908(V of l9O8) Ss. 14 and 29.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Habibur Rahman Vs. Election Commissioner and others, 8BLD (HCD) 473</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order VII Rule 10</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Return of plaint—Though Admiralty Court cannot reject the plaint, it may return the same when there is no cause of action triable by it or it lacks jurisdiction.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>M/s, Saleh Steel Industries Ltd.
