I 970(All)(FB)309—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order VII Rule 10</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Local limits of jurisdiction—When leave to sue outside a Court’s local limits of l jurisdiction is not accorded—Such leave cannot be granted on mere asking of the plaintiff and it can only be granted in the judicial exercise of Courts discretion—Considering the facts and circumstances of the case the Court finds that all the relevant evidence will be available outside the present place of suing and it will cause undue delay and harassment to defendant No. 2 who also represents defendant No. I on whom lies the main responsibility for the alleged loss or short delivery of goods—If the plaintiff can establish it claims against them then liabi3ity of other defendants will arise—So leave to sue defendant Nos. 1 and 2 in Dhaka Court (when evidence will be available in Chittagong and Chalna) cannot be granted—Code of Civil Procedure, 1908(V of 1908), S. 20.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Bangladesh Agricultural Development Corporation Vs. Moxey Seven (Chartering) Limited and others, 1OBLD (HCD) 100</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order VII Rule 10</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Return of plaint—Section 6 of Admiralty Court Act, 186 l-.E-The plaint of the admiralty suit was returned on account of:</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">(a) non-applicability of section 6 of the Admiralty Court Act 1861,</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">(b) non maintainability</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">(c)want of locus-standi of the plaintiff,</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Sadhäran Bimi Corporation Vs. Bangladesh Shipping Corporation and others, 10BLD (H CD) 347</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order VII Rule 10.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Return of plaint—Order of returning a plaint to be presented to the proper Court under Order VII Rule 10 is appealable under Order XLIII Rule 1(a) of C.P.C. subject to the provisions of sections 15 and 16 of the Code of Civil Procedure.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Md. Mansur Ali Vs. Janata Bank and others, HBLD (HCD) 23</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order VII Rule 10</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Return of plaint—Appealable order— An order passed under Order VII Rule 10 of the Code of Civil Procedure returning the plaint,, the order is, an appealable order under Order XLIII Rule 1(a) of C.P.C. and no revision lies from such an ordr under section115(l)C.P.C.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Md. Robchan Mia Vs. Mrs. Rahima Beum and others, 128LD (HCD) 257</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order VII Rule 11</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Co-operative Housing Society</span></strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">—Society allotting land to its members—Allottee transferring the land to a non-member without prior proval of the society—Transfer illegal— Society refusing to recognize the transferee .d taking possession of the land— Transferee files suit—The dispute is to be referred to the Registrar of Co-operatives— Jurisdiction of the Civil Court to adjudicate h disputes ousted—Plaint liable to be rejected—Co-operative Societies Act, 1940 (XXI of 1940), Ss. 72,86,87 and 133.</span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Baitul Aman Co-operative Housing Society Ltd. and another Vs. Mohammad Shamsur Rahman and ors., 1BLD (AD) 3O7</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order VII Rule 11</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Rejection of plaint</span></strong>—The power should be invoked at the earliest opportunity.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It is true that the Court is competent to reject the plaint at any stage of the suit, but it should be done at the earliest opportunity to save the parties from unnecessary expenses and to avoid prolongation of the dispute— Although there is no hard and fast rule as to when an application for rejection of plaint is to be filed, but having regard to the scheme of things and the order in which the law makers have placed this particular provision in the statute book, the provision should be invoked by the defendant at the earliest and not after the suit had reached the stage of peremptory hearing.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Alhaj Md. Yasuf Sardar Vs. Md. Hossam Khan and another, 1BLD (HCD) 361</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order VII Rule 11</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Rejection of plaint</span></strong>—suit for declaration that decree passed against the father of the plaintiffs is void as the father died long before institution of the suit—Defendants averred that father of the plaintiffs died during the pendency of the suit—Such question can be decided at the time of trial as an issue in the snit—Plaint having disclosed a cause of-action and accrual of interest in the suit prop-city, the plaint cannot be rejected.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Md. Hanif and others, Vs. Akhtar Rahim and others, 2BLD (HCD) 160</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order VII Rule 11</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Court-fees on memorandum of appeal— Appeal filed against an order rejecting the plaint on the ground of lack of jurisdiction of the Court—Order of rejection of the plaint amounts to a decree for J1 purposes—Value of the subject-matter of appeal is the same as the value of the subject-matter of the original suit—Ad-valorem Court-fees of the amount paid, in a original suit should be paid on memorandum of appeal—Code of. Civil Procedure, 1908 (Y of 1908), S 2 (2); Court-fees Act, 1870 (VII of 1870), Sch. I Art. I and SchilArt. 11.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Md. Basiruddin and others Vs. Saleh Steel Industries Ltd. and another Vs. TSS Pacific A,beto and others, 3BLD(HCD)104</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 34DLR (AD) 110;! 927A.C.906; 72 C.W.N.635; AIR 1973 Bombay 18—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order VII Rule 11(d)</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Rejection of plaint</span></strong>—For the rejection of the plaint it must be found on the basis of the plaint itself and not on the basis of the written statement filed or the documents produced by the defendant that the suit is barred by any law—If the plaint does not show or suggest that the suit is barred, plaint cannot be rejected.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Dulal Chandra Sarker Vs. Mst. Nurjahan, 3BLD (HCD) 225</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order-V Rule 11</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Admiralty Suit</span></strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">—<strong>Rejection of Plaint</strong>— Question of extending the period of limitation—Discretion of the Court in extending the period of limitation—If the plaintiff had failed to bring the action within two years having ample opportunity the Court will not. extend period of limitation—It is not clear why the appellant allowed the period of limitation to run out even though the period of limitation was known to it.—It appears that there was no agreement between the parties that the defendant would be bound to satisfy the claim outside the period of limitation— The appellant did not even make any application explaining the reason for its inability to bring the action within time before the Court for granting an extension of time beyond two years—Court rightly held that the plaint was barred by time in rejecting the plaint—Maritine convention Act, l9ll,S.8</span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Bangladesh Inland Water Etransport corporation Vs. MIs. Seres Shipping IncorpOrated One World Trade Centre and ors. 4BLD(AD)222</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 30 DLR 149—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Order VII Rule 11</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Rejection of plaint</em></strong>—When permissible—Unless the statements made in the plaint by itself show want of cause of action for the suit, or the suit being barred by any law there is no legal scope to reject the plaint.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Shahjadpur Central Co-operative Multipurpose Society Vs. Md. Abdul Ban, 4BLD (HCD) 236</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order VII Rule 11 read with sections 91— 93 of the Code of Civil Procedure</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Permission to file a suit for removal of trustee of a religious or charitable trust— Whether the Deputy Commissioner can grant permission for filing such suit—To exercise such powers the Deputy Commissioner must take previous sanction of the Government in each case though he was empowered to give such permission—District Judge acted illegally in not rejecting the plaint in a suit filed without such sanction.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Sunil Kumar Bhattacharjee Vs. Sree Jatindra Das and others, 5BLD (HCD) 147</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Ref A.I.R. 193 l (PC) 121; A.I.R.1932 (PC) 51</em></strong>; A.I.R.1955 (Cal) l55—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order VII Rule 11</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Maintainability of a suit</span></strong>—Question of maintainability in the face of allegation of malafide is a question of fact and the Court ordinarily decides upon it after taking evidence—But where a suit is not initially maintainable, can it be held that the bar becomes inoperative on the allegation of malafide in the plaint—If the answer is in the affirmative, provisions relating to the bar would be rendered nugatory—In view of the express legislative intention a Judge must follow the ‘hands off doctrine, otherwise chaos and anarchy would prevail—Whatever the legislature says, unless it is contrary to the Constitution, its mandate, either express or implied has to be obeyed by the Court—Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 (V of 1908), S. 9.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Nur Mohammad and others Vs. Moulvi Iainuddin Ahmed and ors., 6BLD (AD) 342</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 17 DLR (SC) 515; A.I.R. 1940 (PC) 105—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order VII Rule 11</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Rejection of plaint</span></strong>—Whether plaint can be rejected for non-service of notice required</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">to beserved before filing the suit—Primary Teachers transferred by Upazilla Education Officer—Order of transfer challenged without service of notice under section 60 of the Ordinance No. LIX of 1982—Rejection of plaint for non-service of such notice in the facts and circumstances of the case is not legal.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It appears that in order to decide whether the suit is barred under Article 60 of the Ordinance No. LIX of 1982 the Court will have to go beyond the plaint and examine some other materials. If after going into the trial of the suit the Court finds that the suit is not maintainable, the Court can dismiss the suit. But on that ground a plaint cannot be rejected—The rejection of the plaint is not identical with the dismissal of the suit—Local Government (Upazila Parishad and Upazilla Administration and Organisation) Ordinance, 1982 (LIX of 1982). S. 60.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Md. Aminur Rahman and another Vs. Maindra Nath Das and others; and Md. Asgar Ali Vs. Upazila Education Officer, Parbatipur, 6BLD (HCD) 357</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 26 D.L.R. 111—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order VII Rule 11</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Jurisdiction of civil Court</span></strong>—Ouster of jurisdiction in case of election dispute—The suit was filed challenging the acceptance of nomination and a declaration was sought that the acceptance was illegal—The statements made in the plaint clearly suggest that the suit is impliedly barred under the Ordinance and the Rules made the reunder—Local Government (Union Parishad) Ordinance, 1983 (LI of 1983), S. 26—Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 (V of 1908), S. 9.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Manir Ahmed Khan Vs. Md. Bazlu Mia and others, 8BLD (HCD) 241</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 17DLR (SC) 515; 2ODLR (SC) 335; 35 DLR, 217;—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order VII Rule 11</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Election matter</span></strong>—Question of Civil Court’s jurisdiction—The plaint in an election case pending before a civil Court has been rightly rejected in view of the Local Government (Union Parishad) Ordinance, when election petition was not filed before the Election Tribunal which was in existence a the relevant time—Election having being held earlier and the Tribunal also constituted under the Ordinance, the general jurisdiction of the civil Court is barred—Local Government (Union Parishad) Ordinance, 1983 (LI of 1983), S. 26.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Habibur Rahman Vs. Election Commissioner and others, 8BLD(HCD)473</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 8 B.C.R. (HCD) 61— Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order VII Rule 11</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Rejection of plaint</span></strong>—Rejection on the ground of non-service of the statutory notice—To file a suit against the Upazila Parishad the service of prior notice is a must—Without such notice the suit must be held to be barred by law—The plaint is liable to rejected for non-service of the notice—The Local Government (Upazila Parishad and Upazi Ia Administration Reorganisation) Ordinance, 1982 (LIX of 1982), S. 60.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Muladi (ipazila Parishad Vs. Moulana Shamsul Huque, 9BLD (HCD) 59</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 6BLD (HCD) 357; 39 DLR (AD) 1; AIR. 936 (Madras) 547; I.L.R. 35 (Bombay) 363; 22 DLR (WP) 295—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order VII Rule 11</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Rejection of plaint</span></strong>—Averments in the plaint alone will decide rejection or otherwise—The Court must apply its mind to the case of the plaintiff as set out in the plaint by assuming all the averments made therein to be true—The learned Munsif committed a serious error in taking into consideration the application filed by the defendants—In considering whether a plaint is to be rejected, the plaint alone should be considered.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Abut Hasnat and others Vs. Ershad Ali Beg, 9BLD (HCD) 250</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 35 DLR 217—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order VII Rule 11</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Election matter</span></strong>—Bar of civil suit— Rights which had no existence earlier and have been created by special laws and which are alleged to have been infringed are required to be determined in the manner prescribed by the said laws to which they owe their existence—The plea that such laws do not provide for effective and adequate remedy is untenable in view of the intention of the legislature that the Civil Courts are not to take cognizance of such disputes—Code of Civil Procedure,l908 (V of 1908), Ss. 4 and 9; Local Government (Union Parisahd) Ordinance, 1983(LT of 1983), S. 26.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Most afa Kamal Ahmed Vs. B.D. Habibullah and others, 9BLD (HCD) 326</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. I.L.R. 31 (Bombay) 604; PLD 1949(Lahore) 301; 39DLR 451; A.I.R. 1937(All)365; 27D.L.R.(AD) 138; 8 B.C.R. (HCD) 61;4ODLR 459; 28DLR (AD) 54; 44. C.W.N.709—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order VII Rule 11</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Suit of civil nature</span></strong>—When Civil Court would not have jurisdiction to entertain such suit—Special law overrides the general jurisdiction conferred on Civil Courts to entertain suits of civil nature—Where a right is created by a special law and the method of enforcing the r ight is pointed out by the law creating such right, the general remedy of suit under the Code will be impliedly barred—In such a case the method provided by the special law must be followed—Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 (V of 1908), Ss. 4 and 9.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Jalaluddin Ahmed Vs. Matiur Rahman and others, 9BLD(HCD)446</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. AIR. 1937 (All) 365; PLD 1949 (Lahore) 301; 37 L.J. 248; 15DLR (SC) 283; 39DLR 451; AIR. 1946 (Lahore) 85—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order VII Rule 11</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Maintainability of suit</span></strong>—Whether question of maintainability can be decided while disposing of an appeal relating to injunction—.In the instant case without going into any Investigation of facts simply upon a plain reading of the plaint it may be held that the Local Govt. Ordinance is a bar against the suit in a civil Court—When it was contended before the appellate Court that the suit was not at all maintainable the Judge did not commit any error of law in deciding the question in the appeal which arose out of an application for vacating temporary injunction—Local Government (Union Parishads) Ordinance, 1983 (LI of 1983), S. 26.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Md. Shamsul Haque Mollah Vs. Md. Larifur Rahrnan, 9BLD (HCD) 524</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 4ODLR 459; 26DLR 10—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Order VII Rule 11</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Rejection of plaint</em></strong>—Prayer for rejection of the plaint in a suit by alleged promoter of a Bank. whether tenable ?— Plaintiff filed the suit  on the averments that he was one of the in sponsors of the proposed Bank, his position being that of a promoter—When promoter files a suit on the averment that for great length of time it was he who had carried on the negotiation with the Bangladesh Bank for establishment of the, proposed Banks, that le was surreptitiously left Out and some new sponsors were inducted thereby injuring his potential right to be, included as a shareholder of the Bank; then the cause of action of such a suit is not dependent upon the date of incorporation of the Bank, nor. upon the fact as to whether he is an actual shareholder or Director of the Bank—His suit is on the basis of loss of a contingent interest—whether he has been able to make’ out such a case will be seen at the time of trial but he cannot be shut out before that stage on the ground that the ‘plaint discloses no cause of action—A promoter who alleges that he was left out later on in the formation of the Bank has always a cause of action—Whether he can prove it or not is a different matter.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>National Bank Ltd. Vs. Haroon Malik and others, 10BLD (HCD) 98</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order VII Rule 11</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Question of law</span></strong>—Question regarding maintainability of the appeal not raised before the lower appellate Court can be raised before High Court Division—Exercising its power the High Court Division can even suomotu interfere with an illegal order in the interest of justice—Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 (V of 1908), S. 115.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Ayezuddin Sheik and others, Vs. Md. Abdul Karim Sheikh qnd others, 1OBLD (HCD) 139</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 26 DLR(AD)l; 38; DLR(AD)33— Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order VII Rule 11</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Rejection of plaint</span></strong>—General bar to jurisdiction of Civil Courts—Parties exhausting all procedural remedies provided under the special law of Public Demands Recovery Act are precluded from invoking jurisdiction of Civil Courts—Plaint suffering from infirmities of non-disclosure of cause of action or the suits appearing from the statement made in the paint to be barred by law, consequence following is the rejection of the plaint under clauses (a) and (d) of Rule 11 of Order VII of the Code of Civil Procedure—Public Demand Recovery Act, 19 13(111 of 1913)S. 37.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Marida Begum and others Vs. Moulavi Md. Hasan and others, 10 BDL (HCD) 334</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. AIR. 1931 (Patna) 182; C.L.J. Vol. XXXV (1922) 304—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order VII Rule 11</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Rejection of plaint</span></strong>—Rejection of the plaint where it does not disclose any cause of action and where the suit appears from the statement in the plaint to be barred by any law—The plaint can be rejected only when on the averments of the plaint the plaintiff- company itself is found not to have any cause of action against the defendant.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The attorney himself has no cause of action for the suit—It is the principal who has the cause of action for the suit—In the cause title and in paragraph 1 of the plaint it has been made abundantly clear that it is the plaintiff-company which has filed the suit through its constituted attorney.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Order VII Rule 11 is not at all attracted when there are defects or irregularities in complying with the provisions of Ordçr III or Order VICP.C.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Messers Anath Bandhu Guha and sons Ltd. through its attorney’ Md. Sirajul Huq Vs. Babu Sudhangshu She khar Halder, 11 BLD (AD) 66</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. A.I.R. 1 943(Cal) 13; A.I.R. 1931 (All) 507(S.B.); A.I.R. 196l (Bom) 292; AIR. 1928 (All) 666; 7 D.L.R. (W.P.) 65;—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order VII Rule 11</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Rejection of plaint</span></strong>—It is incumbent upon a Court to reject a plaint under Order VII Rule 11 of the Code of Civil Procedure whenever it is found that the suit amongst other things is barred by law.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">An election Tribunal is quite competent to dispose of an election petition on preliminary point in exercise of power under Order VII Rule ii of the Code of Civil Procedure before hearing the election petitionon merit.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Mohammad Shah Alam Vs. Badrul Huq Chowdhury and others, 11 B.L.D. (HCD) 3 12</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. A.I.R. 1958 (S.C.) 687—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order VII Rule 11</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Rejection, of plaint</span></strong>—A plaint may be rejected under Order VII Rule,1 I of the Code of Civil Procedure if it is barred by any law or if the plaint discloses no cause of action etc; which must appear from the statements made in the plaint. A plaint, under what circumstances may be rejected—Recovery of dues, modes of— There are three modes of recovery before the District Judge by taking over management and administration of an Industry by sale, or by taking recourse to Public Demands Recovery Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Delwar Coir Foam Industries Ltd. Vs. Bangladesh Shilpa Rin Sangstha and others, 11 BLD (HCD) 315</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 38DLR 438—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order VII Rule 11</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Rejection of plaint</span></strong> — Order VII Rule 11(c) of the Code provides that where the relief claimed is properly valued but the plaint is written upon paper insufficiently stamped, and the plaintiff on being required by the Court to supply the requisite stamp paper within a time fixed by the Court fails to do so, the plaint shall be rejected — In this case it is found that the plaintiffs are required to pay advalorem Court fee, the Court below acted illegally in not allowing time to the plaintiffs to pay the requisite deficit Court fee and in rejecting the plaint for non-compliance on their part— Had the plaintiffs failed to pay the deficit advalorem Court fee within the time fixed by the Court, then the Court below would have been justified in rejecting the plaint.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Haji Md. Ishaque and others Vs. Rupali Bank, 11BLD (HCD) 489</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order VII Rule 11</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Plaint rejected for deficit Court fee without knowledge of the plaintiff — Plaintiff filed application under section 15 I C.P.C. for vacating the order and restoring the suit its file on grounds of misplacement of file in the lower Court and for his own indisposition — Trial Court vacated the order of rejection of plaint and restored the suit to its file on payment of costs to defendant — High Court Division in revision maintained the view of the trial Court— Appellate Division declined to interfere with the judgment of the High Court Division.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Shahabuddin Vs. Abu Sayed and others, 12BLD (AD) 71</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order VII Rule 11</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Rejection of plaint</span></strong> — The question of jurisdiction does not come within the purview of Order VII Rule 11 of the Code, — The question of territorial or pecuniary jurisdiction can be raised for considering whether a plaint is to be returned for presentation before an appropriate forum — When the Court rejects or refuses to reject a plaint, it does so in exercise of the jurisdiction vested in it — Even where clause (d)is invoked on the ground that the suit is barred by law, the Court is entitled to examine the question as to whether the defendant’s plea is correct. The plea of implied bar should ordinarily be decided on evidence, unless the facts disclosed in the plaint clearly prove that the suit was not maintainable — Again, in considering an application for rejection of a plaint, the specific provision under Order VII Rule I I should ordinarily be followed — A resort of section 151 of the Code may be made in the interest of justice only in an exceptional ease where the suit is foredoomed, and if it is allowed to be proceeded with, it will amount to an abuse of the process of the Court — Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 (V of 1908), S. 151.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Guiness Peat (Trading) Limited Vs. Md. Faziur Rahman, 12 BLD (A D) 247</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: PLD 1967 (Dhaka) 190; 1908(2) K.B. 161; 1955(2) Q.B.D. 327; A.I.R. 1933(Born) 179; A.I.R. 1947 (Patna) 134; 22C.W.N. 517; A.I.R. 1931 (Cal) 659; A.I.R.1931 (Cal) 659; A.I.R. 1943 (Cal) 199(202);(1891) A.C. 107. 8 C.P. 107; A.I.R. 1957(Mad) 201; 66 C.W.N.8 C.P. 107; A.I.R.1957 (Mad) 201; 66 C.W.N. 29’— Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order VII Rule 11</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Discretion of the Court under section 6 the Court Fees Act and sections 148 and 149 of the Code of Civil Procedure is of the proviso to Rule 11 of Order VII of the Code and it cannot control the provisions of the discretionary power of the Court under the aforesaid sections and as such the stringent provision of Rule II of Order VII of the Code of Civil Procedure should be reconciled and harmonized with the provision of section 6 of the Court Fees Act and sections 148 and- 149 of the Code of Civil Procedure for making a room for reasonable elasticity to facilitate justice and further its ends — The provisions of Rule II of Order VII is directory and not mandatory — Court-Fees Act, 1 870 (VII of 1870), Ss. 148 and 149.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Jesmin Ara Béjum Vs. Golain Main uddin, 12 BLD (HCD) 353</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. A.I.R. 1936 (Cal) 221; AIR. 1941 (Oudh) 30 — Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order VII Rules 14 and 18</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">If a very rigid and literal construction is given to the language of the newly added provision of Rule 18 of Order VII, then in many genuine cases, the ends of justice will be frustrated.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In an appropriate and proper case, the Court must exercise its judicial discretion in granting such leave under Rule 18 of Order VII — If a very rigid and literal interpretation is given to the -newly added words of the statute, then it will lead to manifest injustice and would be if inconsistent with the object of the legislation — In an appropriate case where the reasons for non-filing the documents at the time of filing of the plaint appears to the Court due to be bonafide and genuine mistake, then the Court in its judicial discretion, may grant leave considering the case to be one of exceptional circumstances.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Afsaruddin Ahmed Vs. Ban que Indosuez, having its Local Office at 47, Motijheel Commercial Area, Dhaka, 12 BLD (AD) 156.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 1956 Lahore 252 — Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order VII Rule 18</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Inadmissibility of document</span></strong>— Unregistered kabuliyat sought to be given in evidence to years after the plaint was presented — Since the kabuliyat was not filed along with the plaint, though it was in possession of the plaintiff, and the delay in making application for admission of that document having not been explained, the Court below exercised jurisdiction properly in rejecting the application.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Sree Birendra Nath Singh and others Vs. Md. Mokbul Shah and others, 1OBLD (HCD) 78</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 3 D.L.R. 311 —Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order VIII Rule 1</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Consequence in default of a written statement.</span></strong> Whether a Court has power to pass an exparte judgment if the defendant fails to file the written statement within the time granted by the Court — Though under the recently introduced Order Viii Rule 1(l) of the Code of Civil Procedure it is now obligatory upon the defendant to put in written statement within two months of first exparte hearing in default— The defendant still retains the right to appear on the date of hearing and participate in the trial— If on the date fixed for exparte hearing the defendant is stopped from participating, then the order of exparte hearing is illegal and without jurisdiction.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Adamjee Jute Mills Ltd. Vs. The Chairman, 3rd Labour Court, Dhaka and another, 7 BLD (HD) 67</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref; A.LR. 1938 (Bombay) 470 — Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order VIII Rules 1 and 2</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Exparte hearing—When permissible</span></strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> —Law does not contemplate an exparte hearing if the defendant fails to file a written statement—If the defendant fails to file a written statement the Court shall fix the case for hearing in default of written statement -— on the date so fixed the defendant can still appear and argue his case without the written statement — The defendant retains the right to appear on the date of hearing and participate in the trial — If the defendant is precluded from participating in the trial then the trial itself will be without jurisdiction, because law does not it contemplate an exparte hearing simply because the defendant fails to file a written statement — Late realisation of adjournment cost cannot be a ground for shutting the door of justice bn the face of the petitioner— Industrial Relations Ordinance, 1969 (XXIII of 1969), S. 36 — Code of Civil Procedure. 1908(V of 1908), Or. XVII R. 2.</span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>M/s. Adamjee Jute Mills Ltd. Vs.Chairman, 3rd Labour Court, Dhaka and another, 8 BLD (HCD) 1 and 8 BLD67</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref, 33DLR 376; I9DLR. 612; 29 DLR 148; PLD 1964 (SC) 97; A.I.R. 1938 (Born) 470—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order VII Rule I</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Written statement</span></strong>—Consequence of failure to file written statement — In the event of failure of the defendant to file written statement law does not debar the defendants to argue his case on the date fixed for hearing of the suit.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Ahmed Kabir and others Vs.
