XIV, R. I.</span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Sultan Ahmed and others Vs. Mohaminad Islam and others, 4BLD (HCD) 183</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 35 DLR 79; 1 BLD (AD) 280 — Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order Viii Rules 3 and 5</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Admission of averments in pleadings Evasive and vague denial Of averments are no denials — Pre-emptors assertion that they own 15/16 bighas of land and are competent persons to get pre-emption when not specifically denied amounts to admission — Pre-emptors need not lead any evidence in support of their averments that they are competent persons to get pre-emption under section 90 of the state Acquisition and Tenancy Act, I 950.—State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950 (XXVIII of 1951), S. 90.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Shahidur Rahman Molla and others Vs. Abdul Halim Molla and others, 3BLD (HCD) 89</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order Viii Rule 6</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Counter claim in a suit</span></strong> — Whether counter-claim made by the defendant is entertain able — The trail Court rightly exercised its discretion in allowing the counter-claim and as there is no reason for setting it aside on the ground that the amount of the counter-claim is bigger than that claimed in the plaint by the plaintiff One of the ends of justice is to avoid multiplicity of proceedings and it cannot be a good argument for pushing the defendant to filing a separate suit — There is also no prohibition, against entertaining counter-claim in the sarne suit — Code of Civil Procedure, 1908(V of 1908), Or, XX r. 19.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Messers United Shipping Corpo Evasiveration Limited Vs.W.H. Benefit and others, 4BLD (AD) 316</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 27 DLR (AD) 170; 46 C.W.N. 882(885); A.I.R. 1972 (SC) 1048; A.I.R. 1975</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">(Cal) 150; A.I.R.1964 (SC) I 1 — Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order IX Rule 5</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Dismissal for default </span></strong>—Dismissal of a case for default within 3 months from the receipt of the return showing non-service of the notice is illegal — Order IX Rule 5 of the Code of Civil Procedure applicable to proceedings under Order IX Rule 1 3 of the Code — Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 (V of l908) S. 141.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Fakhuruddin Driver Vs. Matior Rahman, 3BLD (HCD) 2</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order IX Rule 6</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Exparte disposal of suit</span></strong> — Court to observe minimum legal requirements — Judgment should show application of the Court’s judicial mind as to whether the plaintiff’s witnesses and the papers produced proved the plaintiff’s case.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Bangladesh Vs. Israil Ali and others, 1BLD (AD) 371</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 2’5DLR (AD) 90; C.A. 30 of 1978 — Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order IX Rule 6</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Ex-parte decision by a Labour Court</span></strong>— Whether a Labour Court does have power to give ex-parte decision</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Under Section 36(2) of the Industrial Relations Ordinance a Labour Court is a Civil ‘Court for the purpose of adjudicating and determining any industrial dispute — It has the same powers as are vested in the civil Court under the Code of Civil Procedure, including the power of delivering exparte decisions in the event of failure of any party’ to appear before it.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">When an exparte order can be made?</span></strong> — It can be made on the day fixed in the summons or on the day to which the hearing of the case has been adjourned if the’ defendant fails to appear in response to the summons — Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 (V of 1908), Or. XVII r. 2.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Adamjee Jute Mills Ltd. Vs. The Chairman, 3rd Labour Court, Dhaka and another, 7 BLD (HCD)67</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 33DLR 376; I9DLR 612; 29DLR 148; PLD I 964(SC) 97 — Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order IX Rules 6 and 7 read with Order XV1I Rule 2</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Acceptance of written statement after conclusion of exparte hearing — Whether the Court can accept written statement filed by the defendant when the suit was fixed for passing order after conclusion of the cxparte hearing — The suit fixed for exparte hearing for failure of the defendant to file his written statement is not an exparte proceeding</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">— An exparte proceeding against a defendant is permissible when the suit is fixed for hearing in default of appearance or the hearing of the suit is adjourned for further hearing and the defendant fails to appear when the suit is called on for hearing — Law does not contemplate an exparte hearing of the suit when the defendant fails to file a written statement — When law does not contemplate an exparte hearing for failure of the defendant tO file written statement such proceeding cannot be treated as an exparte one — Before the decree is passed in a suit fixed for hearing in default of the written statement, the defendant still may come to the Court and file a written statement. and the Court can accept it in its discretion after giving reasons — Superior Court will not interfere wth the discretion exercised by the trial Court except when it is perverse.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>K.D.II. Laboratories Ltd. Vs. Rupali Bank and ors, 8BLD (HCD)92</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: A.I.R. 1964 (SC) 993; 39 DLR II Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order IX Rule 9</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Dismissal of suit for default — Fresh suit for achieving the same result by adopting indireët method is not permissible</span></strong> — Order of dismissal for default passed by the Calcutta High Court on September I, 1949 in a suit filed by the plaintiff in I 944 has the same force as an order of the High Court at Dacca — High Courts (Bengal) Order 1947, S.13 (4).</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Kumar Begum Roy’ Vs. Rana Debi and others, 2BLD (AD) 54</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order IX Rule 9</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Whether the High Court Division in exercise of its revisional jurisdiction can interfere with the finding of fact by the trial Court — Whether inference from facts was correctly drawn is a question of fact or law Whether there was sufficient cause or not is a question pf fact and whether inference from such fact had been correctly drawn is a question of law — The learned Single Judge took the view that there is no evidence that there had been any flood — The conclusion of the learned Munsif that flood was the cause for the plaintiffs absence on the date of hearing was erroneous — Since the High Court Division rightly came to its finding it calls for interference— Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 (Vof 1908), S. 115.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Moulvi Abdus Samad Mallik Vs. Pran Gour Basak and ano; 7BLD (AD) 25</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order IX Rule 9</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Restoration of suit on setting aside dismissal </span></strong>— Courts of la leaned in favour of deciding disputes on merits — there being nothing to show that the plaintiff was negligent and harassing the defendants unnecessarily. there was no ground for interfering with the order of restoration of the suit—Code of Civil Procedure, 1908(Vol 1908),S. 115.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Md. Nurul Haque Vs. Sonali Bank and another, 8BLD (HCD) 85</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order IX Rule 9</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Dismissal of suit — Application for setting aside dismissal filed out of time</span></strong> The trial Court committed an error of law in allowing the application on the only ground of old age of the petitioner without considering the question of limitation — The impugned order is set aside and the case is seem back to trial Court for re-hearing of the miscellaneous case on its merits and for consideration of the question of limitation — Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 (V of 1908), S. 151.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Assistant Custodian, Vested Property Vs. Jugal Chandra Shaha and others, 9BLD (HCD) 63</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order IX Rule 9</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Suit dismissed for default while the plaintiff (No. 1) was alive</span></strong> — After death of the plaintiff his heirs and legal representatives were not substituted on account of want of knowledge of suit by the appellants — Subsequently appellants claiming through plaintiff (deceased) filed miscellaneous case for setting aside the order of dismissal of the suit for default under Order IX Rulel3 read with section 151 C.P.C. with a prayer for condo nation of delay — The trial Court dismissed the miscellaneous case on the ground that the appellants were not parties in the original suit</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The moot question under the circumstances is whether the application under Order IX Rule 9 of the Code of Civil Procedure is maintainable at the instance of the heirs of the plaintiff (No. 1) on his death after the order of dismissal of the suit.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The appellants claiming under plaintiff No. I after his death can apply for setting aside the order of dismissal of the suit under Order IX Rule 9 of the Code of Civil Procedure — In that view of the matter the learned Subordinate Judge was wrong in holding that the miscellaneous case was not maintainable.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Hazera Khatun and others Vs. Amulya Chandra Chakiadar and others, 11 BLD (HCD) 45</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. I.L.R. 29 Cal 33; I.L.R. 28 Mad 361; L[..R.2 I (All)274; A.I,R. I 958(SC)394; 1958 SCR 1287—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order IX Rule 13</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Labour Court — Exparte order</span></strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> — Application for setting aside an exparte order under Order IX of the C.P. Code is maintain able—Industrial Relations Ordinance, I 969 XXIII of 1969), S. 36.</span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Executive Director, Raj Textile Mills Ltd. Vs. Chairman, Labour Court, Khulna and another, 1BLD (HCD)1 75.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. I9DLR6I2; 29DLR 148 —Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order IX Rule 13</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Dismissal for default</span></strong> — Dismissal of a case for default within 3 months from the receipt of the return showing non-service of the notice is illegal — Order IX Rule 5 of the Code of the Code of Civil Procedure applicable to proceedings under Order IX Rule 13 of the Code — Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 (V of 1908), 5. 141.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Fakhruddin Driver Vs. Matior Rahman, 3BLD (HCD) 2</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order IX Rule 13</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Setting aside exparte decree</span></strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> — If summons is not duly served upon the defendant that is a good ground for setting aside an exparte decree — Due service of summons is an essential condition which must be satisfied before the Court can proceed to give a judgment — If a party satisfies a Court that summons was not duly served upon him. the Court is bound to set aside an exparte decree — In such a case the question of knowledge is not at all relevant and the exparte decree will be set aside even if the defendant had knowledge of the institution of the suit.</span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Md. Abdur Rashid and another Vs. Abdul Bank and another, 4BLD (A D)83</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. A.I.R 1916(Cal) 181 —Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order IX Rule 13</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Plaintiff claimed title by exchange from the same person against whom the defendant obtained an exparte decree for specific performance of contract — Plaintiff attempted to set aside such exparte decree in a proceeding under Order IX Rule 13 C.P.C. but failed — Plaintiffs suit for declaration of title and possession was barred by resjudicata.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 (V of 1908), S. 11</span></strong>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Alim Mohammad Vs. Tamizuddin, 4BLD (HCD) 71</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order IX Rule 13</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Proceeding not infructuous by execution of decree</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Proceeding under Order IX Rule 13 C.P.C. whether becomes infructuons by execution of the exparte decree—Execution of an exparte decree does not render the application for setting <strong><em>aside the exparte decree infructuons.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Santosh Kumar Chakraborty and others Vs. M.A. Motaleb Hossain and another, 5BLD (AD) 59.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 76C.W.N. 181 —Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order IX Rule 13</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Setting aside exparte decree—Non — service of summons </span></strong>— If summon is not duly served upon the defendant that is a good ground for setting aside the exparte decree, because service of summon is an essential condition which must be satisfied before the Court can proceed to pass an exparte decree — When a party satisfies the Court that summon was not duly served upon him the Court is bound to set aside the exparte decree</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">— In such a case, the question of knowledge is not at all relevant — The decree will be set aside even if the defendant had knowledge of the institution of the suit.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Juran Chandra Mondal Vs. Robindra Nath Mondal, 5BLD (HCD)126</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 4BLD (AD)83 — Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order IX Rule 13</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Sufficient cause for setting aside an exparte decree — Whether fault of the Advocate’s clerk is a “sufficient cause” for setting aside exparte decree</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">— Defendant could not appear on the date of hearing of the suit due to the default of Advocates clerk in noting the date in his dairy</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">— If an Advocate is engaged in a Court or if he could not appear in a suit or appeal it is the fault of the Advocate and not the fault of the party concerned — A party cannot suffer for the fault of the clerk or his Advocate.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Surjalal Roy Karmakar Vs. Imam Mi Pramanik and others, 6BLD (HCD)152</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 28 DLR(AD)158; PLD 1966 page 356; 17 DLR(SC) 487; 37 DLR7; 28 DLR (SC) 57; PLD 1964 (Dac) Page 300— Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order IX Rule 13</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Mistaken use of law—appropriate relief will not be refused for such use</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">— Mistaken use of a section of law in an application itself will not debar a Court to pass an appropriate order for the relief sought for provided that from the facts stated in the application the relief can be given under a different provision of the law—Code of Civil Procedure. 1908 (V of 1908), S. 151.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Chand Mia Vs. Serajul Hoque and others, 7BLD (HCD) 117</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 27 DLR 418; (1967) 63 I.T.R. 252—</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order IX Rule 13 read with section 151 C.P.C.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Inherent power of the Court — Whether the Miscellaneous Case under order IX Rule 13 read with section 151 of the Code of Civil Procedure for setting aside the acceptance of Advocate Commissioners report and the final decree is maintainable or not Any order passed between the preliminary and final decree is an interlocutory order although it may finally decide the rights of the parties — But when it appears to the Court that the interlocutory order has been passed through error and mistake resulting in the final decree then certainly the hand of the Court is long enough to cure the mistake — The Court in exercise of its inherent power can pass an order as may be necessary for the ends of justice or to prevent abuse of the process of the Court.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Md. Deiwar Hossain Vs. Tajul Islam and others, 7BLD (HCD) 296</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. PLD 1965 (WP) (Peshwar) 74 — Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order IX Rule 13</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Absence of a witness . can be no ground for non-appearance of a party—Setting aside exparte decree and restoration of the suit</span></strong> — Whether absence of’ a witness is sufficient cause for non-appearance of the defendant at the time of hearing of the suit — Whether clear finding by the Court regarding sufficient cause preventing the applicant from appearing in Court was necessary — Absence of a witness cannot be a. ground for non-appearance of a party Moreover, omission to record a clear finding of satisfaction of the Court has also vitiated the decision of the trial Court.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Sadha ran Bima Corporation Vs. Bangladesh inland Water Trasn port Corporation, 7BLD (HCD) 398</em></strong>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. A.LR.1943 (Mad) 38; A.I.R. 196) (All) 96 — Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order IX Rule 13</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Condonation of delay in filing a case for setting aside exparte decree — Whether delay will be deemed to have been condoned if the case is allowed on merit</span></strong> — The learned Subordinate Judge did not apply his mind to the question of limitation and there is no indication in the judgment that he was conscious about the limitation — So it cannot be said that the delay is deemed to have been condoned — Limitation Act. l908(IX of 1908), Ss. 3, 5, and Article.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>M/S. Modern Shipping Agency Vs. Central Inland Water Transport and ors, 7BLD (HCD) 420</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. PLD1952 (Lah) 456: I3DLR 225: 2 DLR (SC) 139; SCMR 1970 Page 170 — Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order IX Rule 13</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Exparte order by Labour Court— Jurisdiction to set aside such order</span></strong> — In view of conflicting decisions as to applicability of the provisions of the Code of Civil Procedure for setting aside exparte order, the ratio decidendi of the case reported in 29DLR 148 is that the Labour Court does not have the jurisdiction to set aside an ex-parte order. —Industrial Relations Ordinance, 1969 (XXIII of 1969), S. 36.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>M/s.  Adamjee Jute Mills Ltd. Vs. The Chairman, 3rd Labour Court, Dhaka amid another, 8BLLI(HCD) 236</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 33DLR 376; 19 DLR 612: 29 DLR l4 — Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order IX Rule 13</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Condonation of delay</span></strong>—Whether separate application for condonation of delay is necessary to set aside ex parte decree — Mere absence of a formal application is no bar to grant the relief sought for when in the application for restoration of the relevant suit all the facts leading to the delay are duly stated are required to be stated in an application for condonation of the delay —f- Limitation Act, 1908 (V of 1908), S. 5 — Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 (Vof 1908), S. 151.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Mozaffar Ahmed and others Vs. Woulvi Saleh Ahmed and others, 8BLD (HCD) 331</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 30DLR (SC) 221; 1968 Pat. 439; 1918 Pat. 341 —Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order IX Rule 13</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Condonation of delay</span></strong> — Condonation without separate application in a case for setting aside an ex partee decree — The Court cancondone the delay if it finds that the reasons stated in the petitioner for setting aside the decree are sufficient within the provision of law. Limitation Act, 1908 (IX of 1908). S. 5.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Ahmed Kabir and others Vs. Amnir Hamza, 9 BLD (HCD)427</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 4ODLR 239 — Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order IX Rule 13</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Service of summons — service by hanging — Such service when not ten able</span></strong> — The deposition of the PWs and the facts that DW2 could not say who were the persons present at the time of delivering the summons, who were the attesting witnesses and what was the papers he signed on, the summons appears to have been served by hanging falsely without any attempt to deliver the same to the petitioner — In such a case a duty is cast upon the Court to examine the process-server where the service return has not been verified by affidavit of the serving officer— The requirements of law as to service of summons having not been fulfilled the exparte decree is set aside — Code of Civil Procedure. 1908 (V of 1908). Or. V Rule IT and 19.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Nur Ahmed Vs. Moktar Ahmed and others, 9BLD (HCD) 465</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order IX Rule 13</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Ex-parte decree — Application for setting aside exparte final decree whether maintainable</span></strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> — The whole complaint is that the opposite parties were highly prejudiced by the final decree obtained behind their back without serving any notice by the Advocate Commissioner for effecting partition ion in the suit land in accordance with the decree passed in preliminary form — The learned Subordinate Judge has committed no error of law in holding that the application for setting aside the decree was maintainable.</span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Khalilur Rahman Bepari and others Vs. Abdur Rahman Bepari and others, 9BLD (IICD) 512</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. A.I.R. 1949 (Patna) 68; AIR. 1963 (All) 361 —Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order IX Rule 13</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order setting aside exparte decree.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">When High Court Division is justified in setting aside such a decree</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">— The Assistant Judge resorted to inherent power to set aside the exparte decree —- This he could not do, for while considering such a matter he has authority to determine whether the grounds for setting aside the exparte decree as mentioned in the Rule of the Order exists or does not exist — He cannot draw upon himself the inherent power while acting under a specific provision governing the disposal of the case.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Reazul Hoque Molla Vs. Azizullah Molla. alias Shafiuddin Motlah and others, IOBLD(AD) 44</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order IX Rule 13</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Fraudulent suppression of summons</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Setting aside an exparte decree— fraudulent suppression of service of summons is a good ground for setting aside an decree ex-parte.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Upendra Chandra Rishi and others Vs. Sufia Begum and others, 10BLD (AD) 194</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order IX Rule 13</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Setting aside ex-parte decree</span></strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> — Suit for specific performance of contract— Defendant the on date fixed for hearing of case filed an application for adjournment on grounds of illness — Adjournment not granted— Suit decreed ex-parte—Appellant started miscellaneous case under Order IX Rule 13 to set aside the ex-parte—Applications for adjournment and direction to doctor to appear before Court to prove the medical certificate rejected—Doctor not examined—Miscellaneous case dismissed.</span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Rejection of the application of the appellant for some time for examining the doctor to prove her case amounts to a denial of opportunity and as such not proper.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Khaleda Roushan Ara Vs. Md. Nurul Haq, 1OBLD(AD) 242</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order IX Rule 13</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Exparte decree — Relief against such decree</span></strong> — Apart from the remedy of getting such a decree set aside by filing an application under this rule there are other remedies open by way of appeal, review and an independent suit on grounds of fraud—</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 (V of 1908),</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Or. XL VII</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Ayezuddin Sheik and others Vs. Md.Abdul Karim Sheik and others, 10BLD (HCD) 139</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 22DLR (SC) l02; A.I.R. 1957 (Cal) 242 —Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order IX Rule 13</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Service of summons — Importance of due service — Question of setting aside an ex-parte decree for non-service of summons</span></strong> — If summons is not duly served upon the defendant this is a good ground for setting aside an exparte decree without any reference to limitation Due service of summons is an essential condition which must be satisfied before the Court proceeds to pass a judgment — In a proceeding for setting aside an exparte decree if a party satisfies the Court that summons was not duly served upon him, the Court shall be bound to set aside such a decree — In such a case question of knowledge is not at all relevant and the decree will be set aside even if the defendant had knowledge of the suit Limitation is not a material point for decision in such a case.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Moynul Hasan and others Vs. Nazmul Haq alias Nazmul Hasan and others, 10BLD (HCD) 151</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 32DLR (AD) 167; 35 DLR (AD) 163— Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order IX Rule 13 read with section 151 C.P.C</span></strong>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A miscellaneous case was filed under Order IX Rule 13 of the Code of Civil Procedure for restoration of the suit which was dismissed for default — Thereafter an application under section 151 of the Code of Civil Procedure was filed for restoration of the said miscellaneous case.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">When the Code provides for an alternative remedy to redress a grievance the inherent power of the Court is not available — The order being an appeal able order, aid of inherent power of the Court is not available.</p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Non-speaking order</span></strong> — When from the order itself it is difficult to understand what was the reason for which the application, was allowed, the impugned order is liable to be struck down on that count alone.</p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Kazi Mohammad Abdul Karim, Vs. The Government of Bangladesh, 11BLD (HCD) 365.</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order IX Rule 13 read with section 151 C.P.C</span></strong>.</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Setting aside ex-parte decree — Section 151 C.P.C. — Inherent power of the Court</span></strong> — Previous application for setting aside ex-parte decree was the rejected on the ground of laces and negligence on the part of opposite party —Whether subsequent order setting aside the ex-parte decree invoking the aid of the inherent power of the Court for the ends of justice is tenable?</p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">There is no scope for setting aside the decree passed ex-parte under Order IX Rule 13 C.P.C on invoking the inherent power of the Court under section 151 C.P.C.</p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Golam Rashid and another Vs. Mohan Bashi Nama and others, 10 BLD (HCD) 449.</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 13 DLR 542 — cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order IX Rule 13</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">An order of dismissal of the miscellaneous case for default is one of rejecting an application to set aside a decree passed ex-parte It is not an order passed on merit but exparte — Appeal lies in both cases under Order XLIII Rule 1(d).</p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Abdul Kader Chowdhury Vs. Nurul islam and others, 11 BLD (AD) 1.</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order IX Rule 13 read with section 151 C.P.C.</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Order of dismissal of miscellaneous case for under Order IX Rule 13 being an appeal able order under Order XLII Rule 1(d) of the Code of Civil Procedure, invoking aid of jurisdiction under section 151 C.P.C. is illegal Where the Code provides an alternative remedy the provision of section 151 C.P.C. is available.</p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Kazi Mohammad Abdul Karim Vs. The Government of Bangladesh 11 BLD (HCD) 110.</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order IX Rule 13</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Remedies against ex-parte decree</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A person aggrieved by an ex-parte decree— may pursue three remedies in the Court: (I) tiling an application under Order IX Rule13 for setting aside the ex-parte decree: (2) by filing an application for review under Order XLVII Rule 1, or; (3) by filing: an appeal under section 96, of C.P.C. Of these three remedies, the remedy by way of an appeal is the widest and when an appeal is dismissed he will have no other remedy available to him.</p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Md. Abdul Mannan Vs. Jobeda Khatun and ors, 12 BLD (AD) 1.</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 31 DLR (AD) 51: A.I..R 1956(SC) 367; A.I.R.1965 (Orissa) 102; A.I.R. 1978 (Cal) 392; A.I.R. 1978(H.C.) 27 — Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order IX Rule 13</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Exercise of inherent power under section 151 C.P.C</span></strong>.—under certain circumstances restoration of a suit in the exercise of the Court’s inherent power under section 151 C.P.C. is not injustified.</p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Plaint rejected for deficit Court fee without knowledge of the plaintiff — Plaintiff filed application under section 151 C.P.C. for vacating the order and restoring the suit to its file on grounds of misplacement of file in the lower Court and his own indisposition — Trial Court vacated the order of rejection of the plaint and restored the suit to its file on payment of costs to the defendant High Court Division in revision maintained the view of the trial Court— Appellate Division declined to interfere with the judgment of the High Court Division.</p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Shahabuddin Vs. Abu Sayed and others, 12 BLD (AD) 71.</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order IX Rule 13 read with section 151 C.P.C.</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The civil Court is not so powerless that in exercise of its inherent powers it cannot entertain an application for setting aside an exparte decree which is alleged to have been obtained by practicing fraud upon the Court itself. Application under section 151 C.P.C. in such circumstances is clearly maintainable in law.</p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Mrs. Shahrbanoo and another Vs. Mrs. Lailun Nahar Ershad and others, 12BLD (AD) 245.</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order IX Rule 13</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Sufficient cause for setting aside decree setting aside an ex-parte decree after transfer of the suit from the original Court to the transferee</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Court — Not informed about the proceedings—sufficient cause Defendant petitioners had no knowledge of the progress of the proceedings and Ilk’ definite order of the transferee Court to inform the parties but the order was not complied with —— Knowledge of the petitioner when the plaintiff opposite party attempted to take possession of the premises through Court on certain date - Parties to keep track of the proceedings Court’s duty — While disposing I he suit exparte the Court failed to see if its order for informing the parties about the Ii transfer of the suit was duly complied with and the defendants had knowledge about the pendency of the proceeding in that Court.</p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Order IX Rule 13 proviso -decree joint and individual, any one of the defendants can maintain the application for getting the exparte decree as a whole set aside.</p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Md. Kheraj Mia alias Abdul Hakim Vs. Ashraf Mm and others. 12 BLD (HCD) 221.</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order IX Rule 14</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Defect of party</span></strong>—----Objection as to detect of’ party when not entertained Such objection has to be taken at the earliest time After framing of issues in the ease such objection should not he entertained and it should be deemed to have been waived.</p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Mozaffar Ahrned and other Vs. Moulvi Saleh Ahmed and other B LD (HCD) 331.</span></em></strong> <span id="pastemarkerend"></span></p></div></div>
1138	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">CODE OF CIVIL PROCEDURE, 1908 [ORDER XI - XXV]</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  10 BLD (HCD) 108, 12BLD (HCD) 3, 8BLD (HCD) 330, 1BLD (AD) 456, 12 BLD (HCD) 31, 4BLD (HCD) 183, 8BLD(HCD)293, 9BLD (AD)6 7, 10 BLI)( H CD) 195, 8 BLD (HCD) 293, 11 BLD (HCD) 457, 10 BLD( HCD)195, 12 BLD (HCD) 412, 5BLD (AD) 311, 7BLD (HCD) 67, 8BLD (HCD</p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  1908</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  CIVIL PROCEDURE</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u><br/> </u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>CODE OF CIVIL PROCEDURE, 1908</u></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XI Rule I</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Time limit for Interrogatories</span></strong> Whether the limit is directory or mandatory The intention of the law—make is in making the provision that the plaintiff or the defendant by leave of the Court may deliver interrogatories in writing within 10 days from the date of’ framing of issues is to have a speedy disposal of suits --- - Where the law-makers provide a fixed period of time for doing a thing and does not make any consequential provision to follow in the event of failure to perform the act w tb in the specified period, such pro is ion of law fixing time limit is not mandatory hut directory in nature — Code of Civil Procedure (Amendment) Ordinance (XLVIII of 1 983).</p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">M/s Kohinoor Chemical company Ltd. and others Vs. 14/S. Eastern Shippers and Traders Ltd: 10 BLD (HCD) 108.</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XI Rule I</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Discovery by Interrogatories</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">SCC suit for eviction of tenant on the ground of default — Reply to interrogatories can he decided in a properly framed title suit.</p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Sree Datal Benerjee alias Muni Benerjee Vs. Sree Sarat Kamar Paul and aiiother 12BLD (HCD) 3</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XI Rule 8</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Interrogatories</span></strong> ---— Time to answer interrogatories — According to the amended provision of the Code interrogatories shall be answered within 10 day’s and in that view the Subordinate Judge acted without jurisdiction in allowing the answer in contravention of the provision of the Code — If the Court allows the  interrogatories to he accepted beyond 10 day. Then that will operate against the spirit ol law. Code of Civil Procedure, 1983 Xl VIII oh 1983).</p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Abbas Ali Vs. Sekandar Ali and others. 8BLD (HCD) 330</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order Xl Rule 21</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Striking out pleadings for not answering interrogatories —-— Pleading cannot be struck out in the absence of an application therefore. The foundation for the exercise of the power under this Rule is the fulfillment of the two requirements of Rule 2 I of Order Xl of the Code - the first is the failure of the interrogated party to comply with ny order to answer the interrogatory- and the second is the application by the interrogating party to the Court to impose the penalty.</p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Md. Yusuf Vs. Mofza1 Ahmed Sowdagar, 1BLD (AD) 456</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 26D1.R 519 A.I.R. 1968 All (Lucknow Bench) 119 ----- Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order Xli Rule 6</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The expression ‘‘or otherwise” under Rule 6 of Order XII of the Code of Civil Procedure Would empower the Court to see the admission made elsewhere iii the proceeding during the trial and it should not he confined only to written statement — It can also he in the written objection filed against the order of adinterm attachment before the judgment and also in the application made for vacating the final attachment order.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">M/s. XV: Code of Civil Procedure, 1983) (XLVIII ‘l983)Or. XXr. 5.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Sultan Miab Vs. Sree Haradlian Sh,aha and others, 8BLD(HCD)293</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 12 DLR (Dhakal 775; 3&gt;) I)LR (SC)30—- Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XIV Rule I</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Issue of fact . When it cannot he entertained</span></strong> — It was tried to he raised before the Appellate Division that the plaintiff N CS die possession covers about 3.50 acres of land whereas according to the plaint he has possession over 1argelarea the question as to the exact area under the exclusive possession of the plaintiff was raised here or the first time — It was not an issue before any of the courts held and as such it cannot he entertained at this stage</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Moharram Ali and another Vs. 4fohammad Madhu Mia and others, 9BLD (AD)6 7</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XIV Rule 2</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Issue o law — Issue touching maintainability of suit</span></strong> Whether the trial Court committed any error of law in rejecting the prayer for dismissing the suit on the question of maintainability at the stage of its peremptory hearing Whatever may be the trial Courts view on the issue of law, it is not mandatory for the Court to try and determine the issue of facts as well The trial Court may’ hear the issue of maintainability as a preliminary issue but it must postpone its judgment till the hearing of the suit on all other issues and thereafter give its findings on the issue of maintainability and on other issues as well,</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Inspector, Railway Nirapatta Bahi iii, Bangladesh Railway, Khulna and others Vs. Sohrab Ali, 10 BLI)( H CD) 195</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 30DLR (SC) 30: I9DLR65; 40 DLR26 Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XV Rule 3</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Court to give decision on all </span></strong>issues -Issues of law and tact — The trial of a suit should not ordinarily be held piecemeal —— All the issues raised should be disposed of by one ludmen1 The Court may hear the issue of maintainability as a preliminary issue but it must postpone its judgment until its findings on other issues are ‘corded as well when it pronounces its judgment—Code of Civil Procedure. 1908 (V of 1908). Or. XIV r. 2: Code of Civil Procedure, 1983 (XL VIII of 19831. or. XX r. 5.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Sultan Miahi Vs. Sree Haradhan Shaha and others, 8 BLD (HCD) 293</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 12 DLR(Dhaka)775; 30 DLR(SC)30—Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XV rule 3 read with Order XIV rule 2</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Framing of issues on law as well as on facts, whether gives the parties a chance to resolve the dispute once for all.</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Framing of issues on law as well as on facts gives the parties a fair chance to resolve the disputes in the suits once for all by adducing evidence at a minimum cost and shorter time — Sufficiency of evidence also gives the Court a better advantage in coming to a fair decision and the possibility offsetting in injustice and hardship upon any party becomes minimum.</p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Naresh La! Saha and others Vs. Bhupati Mohan Roy and others, 11 BLD (HCD) 457</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 30DLR (SC) 30— Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XV Rule 3</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Issue of law — Issue touching maintainability of suit — Whether the trial Court committed any error of law in rejecting the prayer for dismissing the suit on the question of maintainability at the stage of its peremptory hearing Whatever may be the trial Court’s view on the issue of law, it is now mandatory for the Court to try and determine the issue of facts as well — The trial Court may hear the issue of maintainability as a preliminary issue but it must postpone its judgment till the hearing of the suit on all other issues thereafter gives its findings on the issue of maintainability and on other issues as well.</p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Inspector, Railway Nirapatta Bahini, Bangladesh Railway, Khulna and others Vs. Sohrab Au, 10 BLD( HCD)195</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 3ODLR (SC)30; 19DLR65: 40 DLR 236—Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XVI Rule 10</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The Court can compel the attendance of the witnesses by issuing proclamation and, if necessary, by a warrant either with bail or. without hail, if it has reason to believe that such an evidence or production of document is material and that such person has, without lawful excuse, failed to attend the Court or to produce the document in compliance with such summons or has intentionally avoided service.</p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The Court, at any time, if it thinks necessary to examine any person, may even suo motu order summons to be served upon him to give evidence or to produce any documents in the Court.</p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">There is no bar is issuing summons upon the cited witnesses for the 2nd time if it is necessary in the interest of justice. The Court ha also inherent power to cause service of summons upon the witnesses of the parties whenever necessary — Of course, if the application for service of summons is not a bonafide one then the Court may, refuse such prayer.</p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Dildar Hossaln and another Vs. Sarat Kumar Kanangoe, 5BLD (AD) 311</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: A.1.R l943 (Born) 321; PLD1969 (SC) 270; 63C.W.N. 300; A.I.R.l941.(Bom) 83; I.L.R. (Cal) 956 - Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XVII Rule read with Order IX: Rule 6.</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">When an exparte proceeding can be ordered — It can only be ordered in respect of absence on the day fixed in the summons or on the day to which the hearing of the case has been adjourned.</p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Adamjee Jute Mills Ltd. Vs. The Chairman, 3rd Labour Court, Dhaka and another, 7BLD (HCD) 67</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. PLD1963 (SC) 97 — Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XVII Rule 2 read with Order 1X Rules 6 and 7</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">An exparte proceeding against a defendant is permissible when the suit is fixed for hearing in default of appearance or the hearing of the suit is adjourned for further hearing and the defendant fails to appear when the suit is called on for hearing — Law does not contemplate an exparte hearing’ of the suit when the defendant fails to file a written statement — When the law does not contemplate an exparte hearing for failure of the defendant to file written statement such proceeding cannot be treated as an exparte one — Before the dceree is passed in a suit fixed for hearing in default of written statement, the defendant may come to the Court and file a written statement and the Court can accept it in its discretion after giving reasons Superior Court will not interfere with the reason except when it is perverse.</p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">K.D.H. A.I.R.1964 (SC) 993; 39DLRI I — Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XVIII read with section 151C.P.C.</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Question of reopening of the plaintiff’s case by calling fresh witness — In the present case the High Court Division had fallen upon section 151 C.P.C. to meet the ends of justice — It was conscious about the special circumstances which impelled it to provide an opportunity to the plaintiff to examine witnesses after the close of defendant’s witnesses — The discretion used in allowing the examination of witnesses in the manner as provided under Order XVIII C.P.C. has been rightly exercised.</p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Md. Nurul Islam Vs. Md. Abdur Rashid and others, 3BLD (AD)310</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XVIII Rule 2</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Final hearing — Meaning of — The words ‘final hearing’, in the context of the Code of Civil Procedure embrace the entire period during which evidence is given and arguments are concluded.</p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Chowdhury Tanbir Ahined Siddiky Vs. Bangladesh and others, 8BLD (HCD) 485</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XVIII Rule 16(1)</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Order XVIII Rule 16(1) of the Code of Civil Procedure empowers a Court to take the deposition of a witness immediately when a witness is about to leave the jurisdiction of the Court or for further sufficient cause The expression “suffice cause” used in the said rule obviously covers the grounds of a witness being very old or dangerously ill.</p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Mvi.
