Sahera Khatuiz Vs. Mrs. Anwara Khat tin and others, 2BLD (HCD)60</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XX Rule 5</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Issues of law and fact — Court to give decision on all issues — The trial of a suit should not ordinarily beheld piecemeal</p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">— All the issues raised should be disposed of by one judgment — The Court may hear the issue of maintainability as a preliminary issue but it must postpone its judgment until its findings on other issues are recorded as well when it pronounces its judgment.</p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Sultan Miah Vs. Sree Haradham Shaha and others, 8 BLD (HCD) 293</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. I2DLR (Dhaka) 775: 30 DLR (SC) 30 —Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XX Rule S</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Issue of Law</span></strong> — Issue touching maintainability of suit — Whether the trial Court committed any error of law in rejecting the prayer for dismissing the suit on the question of maintainability at the stage of peremptory hearing?— whatever may be the trial Court’s view on the issue of law, it is now mandatory for the Court to try and determine the issue of facts as well — The trial Court may hear the issue of maintainability as a preliminary issue but it must postpone its judgment till the hearing of the suit on all other issues and thereafter give its findings on the issue of maintainability and on other issues as well.</p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Inspector, Railway Nirapatta Bahini, Bangladesh Railway, Khulna and others Vs. Sohrab Ali, IOBLD (HCD) 195</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 30DLR (SC) 30: 19 DLR65: 40 DLR 236 — Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XX Rule 18</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Partition of undivided family dwelling house</span></strong>—Procedure to be of followed by the Court in deciding the prayer for purchase of the share from the stranger — purchaser — Whether the High Court Division is justified in setting aside concurrent decision of the Courts below allowing the prayer for repurchase of the share of the stranger purchaser by a member of the undivided family dwelling house — The jurisdiction of the Court is limited to questions relating to the rights of the co-sharers of the original undivided family to compel the stranger transferee to sell to the former the portion of the dwelling house purchased by the latter — The purpose of section 4 of the Partition Act is to see that a transferee outsider does not force his way into a dwelling house in which other members of the transferor’s family have right to live —- Once a partition decree is made in petitioner form the rest is for the Commissioner but the Court at that stage is not concerned as to what direction should be given to the Commissioner for completing the partition — The Court can only give a limited direction as to which plot is to be partitioned — The rest will be decided at the stage when the Commissioner submits his final report and the Court proceeds to consider the same— Partition Act. 1893 (IV of 18931, S.4.</p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Sree jugal Kishori Sarker Vs. .4zizur Rabman and others, 8BLD (AD)) l1</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 60C.W.N. 829; A.I.R. 1928 Cal 539:</p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A.I.R. 1960 Cal 467: 12 Cal-U. 525; 22 C.W.N. 515; A.I.R. 1919 (Cal) 1055: A.I.R. 1928 Cal 539—Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XX Rule 19</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Counter claim in a suit</span></strong> — Whether counter claim made by the defendant is enter tamable — The trial Court has expressed its discretion in favour of allowing the counterclaim and there is no reason for setting it aside oh the ground that the amount of the counterclaim is bigger than that claimed in the plaint by the plaintiff— One of the ends of justice is to avoid multiplicity of proceedings and it cannot be a good argument for pushing the defendant to file a separate suit — There is also no prohibition against entertaining counter-claim in the same suit,</p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Messers United Shipping Corporation Limited Vs. W.H. Bennett and others, 4BLD (AD) 316</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref.I27DLR (AD) 170: 46 C.W.N. 882 (885); A.I.R.1972 (SC)l048; A,I.R.l975 (Cal) 150; A.I.R. 1964 (SC) II — Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XXI Rule 15</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Decree — Execution of</span></strong> — Question of execution in a case of joint decree holders some of whose property became vested property — Even assuming that the interest of a decree holder became vested property and the decree to the extent of his interest cannot he executed, there is no reason why the decree to the extent of the interests of other decree holders cannot be executed — Orders of the Courts below refusing execution on such grounds are set aside and the case is sent track on remand for fresh decision,</p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Tanjina Khatoon Vs. Nabaruddin and others, 1OBLD (HCD) 250</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XXI Rule 22(3)</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Execution of decree — Effect of omission to issue notice</span></strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> In view of the amended provision the observations of the High Court Division that the execution case was rightly dismissed by the first appellate Court for want of notice do not seem to be justified — Since the decree has already been put into execution and possession delivered to the decree holder the non-service of notice cannot be said to have vitiated the execution proceeding</span></p><p style="margin-right: -.1in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Nurul Alam Chowdhury and others Vs. Azimunnessa Khatun and others, 5BLD (AD) 179.</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XXI Rule 29</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Stay of execution of a decree — The power to stay is discretionary with the Court</span></strong> — But the discretion should be exercised judicially — The Courts below were not correct in holding that the executing Court was not competent to stay execution of the decree — However, the judgment debtor sought to undo the decree on the ground that it was obtained on the basis of a false claim — His plea that he was prevented by illness from contesting the suit has been negative in a civil revision case arising out of an application under Order IX Rule 13 C.P.C. His suit is bad, prima facie and has little chance of success — 1-Ic was not therefore entitled to get an order of stay of the execution.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">A.K.M. Kabiruddin Vs. Mointaz Begum and others, 4BLD (HCD) 223</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 29DLR (SC) 282 — Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XXI Rule 29</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Stay of execution of decree — Refusal of prayer for stay when interfered with</span></strong> — It is true that the facts in the present case authorize an Executing Court grant stay of execution of the decree but it does not necessarily mean that the stay cannot refused even in an appropriate case The opposition could not however be disputed that even if prayer for stay was granted it ought to have been granted for a reasonable time for the appellants suit to be disposed of -— None appeared to oppose this appeal, nor did any appear before the High Court Division on half’ of the respondents — Having considered all aspects of the case, stay already granted is allowed to continue for four months re in course of which steps are to he taken et the suit disposed of.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Soleman Miah and others Vs. Ishaque being dead his heirs Jairun 4ssa and others, 9BLD (AD) 73</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XXI Rule 29</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Money Execution case</span></strong>— W h e n execution proceedings should not he stayed — Mere filing of appeal is not sufficient to warrant slay of execution of the decree — Stay is a matter of discretion of the Court — High Court Division has given due consideration to the question as to the balance of convenience and inconvenience, nature of the decree and the submissions made on behalf of both the parties and took the view that the execution proceedings should not be stayed — The discretion has not therefore been wrongly exercised — But in view of the hardship to which the appellant might be put if the decree is executed the execution case may be stayed on payment of half of the decrial amounts.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Anwar Hossain Bhuiyan Vs. Sheikh Moslem Ali 10BLD (AD) 125 Order XXI Rule 32</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Decree of prohibitory injunction</span></strong> — Violation of the decree — Decree-holders’ remedy lies in the enforcement of the decree under Order XXI Rule 32(1) of the Code apart from any other remedy that he may have had.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The expression “willfully failed to obey” in Order XXI Rule 32(1 ) of C.P. Code denotes not only a negative act of willful failure to obey but also a positive act of disobedience.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Moyna Mia and others Vs. Haji Abdus Samad, IBLD(HCD)124</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. I6DLR6I; AIR. 1945Oudh)8l A.I.R.1961 (Mys) 268; AIR. l938(Pat) 522: A.I.R. 1950 (Mad)237 AIR. I 954(Nag) 245; A.I.R. 196 l(Pu) 547; PLD 1960 (Dac) 1022 —Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XXI Rule 32</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Decree for injunction — Question of disobeying such a decree — It was imperative to find that the defendant had willfully disobeyed the order of the Court — To haul up the defendant for disobedience of injunction something more was necessary such as evidence that he had knowledge of the High Court’s order or that he had been served with notice of such an order and he willfully disobeyed it.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Kad Banu and others Vs. Hajera Khatuii and others, 4BLD (AD) 302</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 8 Cal. 174; 21 Cal. 74; 10 C.W.N. 297 — Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XXI Rule 32</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Disobedience—remedy</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">When a decree for injunction is passed against any party and he had the opportunity of obeying the decree and he will fully failed to obey it, the decree may be enforced by detaining him in civil prison or by the attachment of his property or by both.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Sashi Mohan Sen Vs. Ain Ullah, 12BLD (AD) 8 Order XXI Rule 32</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Violation of prohibitory injunction</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">When a prohibitory injunction is violated, the remedy is not by putting the decree into execution hut by adopting other measures as provided by law — Where the prohibitory injunction has been violated, the decree is not executable and the execution case is not maintainable for any of the remedies under Rule 32 of Order XXI of the Code of Civil Procedure.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Ajiran Nessa Bewa and others Vs. Md. Abdul Mannan, 12 BLD (HCD) 323</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. IÔDLR6I; 33 DLR 207; 13 DLR</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">531; 1934 CaI.402; 1938 Pat.522 Mysore 268;</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">1961 Punjab 547; 1969(AP)92: 1969(Kerala)</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">232—Cited:</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XXI Rule 34</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Draft of document — notice upon,</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">judgment debtors</span></strong> — Whether service of copy of the draft document on the judgment debtor in a proceeding for execution of a decree for specific performance of a contract for sale is mandatory — When a draft document is placed before the Court it is the mandatory recluirement of Law that the Court shall thereupon cause the draft document to be served on the judgment-debtor together with a notice requiring his objection, if any, to be made within a specified time — Withoui giving notice to thejudgment debtors and without causing the draft to be served on the judgment debtors the Court accepted the draft copy merely on the report of the Sherestadar — This was absolutely illegal and unwarranted.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Majeda Begum and another Vs. Khoda Box Mollah and others, 7BLD (HCD) 267 Order XXI Rule 35</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The decree-holders have the right to get the actual possession of the suit property in terms of the decree, the policy of law being to avoid multiplicity of proceedings.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Ahmed Au and another Vs. If he makes such an application the same is liable to be dismissed as being not maintainable.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Where the decree-holder made no complaint under Rule 97 alleging any resistance or obstruction by the petitioners in obtaining possession in execution of the decree, it was not - open to the petitioners, who are third parties. to make any independent application under Rule 99 seeking adjudication of their alleged claim.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Regarding 151 C.P.C.— there being a remedy open to a third party by way of a separate suit—There was no room for exercise of the inherent power.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Haroon and another Vs. Ba1ui Ghani Vs. The Pioneer Bank Ltd. Cornilla (in flquidation). 1OBLD (HCD) 354</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 1964 PLD at page 741 (Dhaka) J6DLR 656 — Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XXI Rules 85 and 86</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Whether the Court can extend time for depositing balance of purchase money sold in auction beyond statutory period</span></strong>—A Court has no jurisdiction to extend period of 15 days fixed for depositing purchase money of a property sold in auction — The mandatory provision of Order XXI Rule 86 requires the Court to resell the property in case there is a failure to deposit the entire balance of the purchase money within 15 days which clearly indicates that the Court shall have no jurisdiction to extend the period — Court can extend time only when time is fixed by it for doing any act but not when time is fixed by-the statute — If the Court is allowed to have such jurisdiction to extend the time limit fixed by the statute then the statute will be defeated — An auction purchase automatically stands cancelled and the purchaser loses all his claims to auctioned property because of default in depositing the purchase money within the prescribed time.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 (V of 1908), S. 148.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Jamsheduddin Bhuiyaii Vs. Anwara Begum, 6BLD (HCD) 112</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XXI Rule 90 read with sections 38, 42, 47, 151 C.P.C.</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Property attached by the Company Judge</span></strong> — District Judge held auction on the direction of the Company Judge — District Judge is not competent to question the attachment and to set aside the auction sale.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The attachment -was made under orders of the Company Court and the sale was also held in pursuance of the direction of the Company Court — Under section 61 of the Banking - Companies Ordinance, 1961 the Company Court has exclusive jurisdiction to decide any claim by or against a Banking Company — Section 63 of the Ordinance empowers the - Court to entertain an-application even after the statutory period of limitation.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The executing Court was required to proceed taking the decree as a valid one and capable of execution — It was not open to the executing Court to decide whether the decree was a valid one or not — If there was a claim on the attachment property by any one, it is for the Court to investigate and decide the issue — The District Judge illegally questioned the attachment of the property by the High Court Division and acted beyond his jurisdiction ii setting aside the auction sale.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">In re Kuinud Ranjan Sarker and others; 1BLD(HCD)251</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; I BLD96 — Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XXI Rules 99 and 100 read with section 151</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">3rd party — any locus standi?</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Dispossession by decree</span></strong> — holder— Whether Court’s inherent power can be invoked h a 3rd Party against apprehension of such dispossession — It is the duty of the executing Court to give delivery of possession of the decreetal property to the decree-holder The Court may pass necessary orders if it finds that the ascertainment of the suit property by local investigation is necessary in order to see that the decree of the Court is correctly executed —- It cannot pass such order on an application of a 3rd party who has no locus standi in law at this stage before being-evicted.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Saleh Ahined Vs. PLD 1959 Lah 511; 25 DLR 5: 29 DLR (SC) l85 —Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XXI Rules 101 and 103</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Proceeding for rest or at ion of possession</span></strong> -— When such proceeding is incompetent and question of’ inspection relating to possession unwarranted — The result of the proceeding relating to restoration possession claimed by one dispossessed in execution of a decree is subject to the result of the suit contemplated by the rule In the instant case the judgment of the suit has already been pronounced — The petitioner ha’ ing filed a petition for local inspection as to possession of the parties which having been already decided in the regular title suit and the Court having arrived at the conclusion that the petitioners were not in possession, the inspection asked for is unwarranted.,</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Nasim Au and another Vs. Applicable to cases of the kind under consideration but Rule 10 governs such cases.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Fakram Mai Vs. A.I.R. 1962 (Orissa) 94—Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XXII Rule 9(2)(3)</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Effect of abatement</span></strong> — When an abatement of a suit takes place owing to non— substitution of heirs, the defendants acquire a vested right not to be proceeded against in the suit The effect of abatement can be overcome only by satisfying the Court as to the cause preventing the plaintiff from continuing the suit which he is under a legal obligation to do when the cause is under challenge — It is never in the discretion of the Court to allow the application for substitution either in the interest of justice or of avoiding multiplicity of proceedings — The principle relating to addition of party cannot be applied in the facts and circumstances of the present case—Code of’ Civil Procedure. 1908 (V of 1908) Or I.R. 10.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Bhupati Biswas and others Vs. Rahela Khatun and others VS. Seraj Sarkar and at, other, 4BLD (HCL) 24</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XXIII Rule 3</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Compromise to be recorded—Decree only voidable and not void.</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Compromise petition if found lawful must be recorded and the decree passed according to its terms — Compromise induced by fraudulent conduct between parties is voidable and not void --- compromise vitiated fraud can he set aside by a decree in a regular suit instituted for that purpose.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Amudi Mamud Vs. Elahi Baksha Sarker and others, 6BLD (HCD) 67</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XXIII Rule 3</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Compromise of suit — its validity</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Question of its validity — when the compromise is found lawful there would be no option left to the. Court but to pass a decree in terms of compromise.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Abdul khaleque and others Vs. Siddiqur Rahman and others, 8BLD (HCD) 9</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 1923 (Oudh) 252; 32 (Cal) 561: 1955 All l87(l).B.); 1933 Born..205—Ciied.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XXIII Rules 3</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Right of appeal</span></strong> — Aggrieved partys right to take appeal from order of compromise</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">— The aggrieved party can take an appeal from such an order and a decree drawn from the order will be no bar to his right of appeal.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Abdul khaleque and otheks Vs. Siddiqur Rahman and others, 98W (HCD) 168</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 1957 Pat..l43; 1933 Cal 94; 1936 Mad.358: l936Lah. 766; 1955 All 187: 1926 Cal. 412: 1933 Bom 205: 1929 Pat. 3l8: 1929</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Cal 689 (RB.): 1944 Bom 239 (DB)— Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XXIII Rule 3</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order of compromise</span></strong> <strong>— Question of its validit</strong>y — If a party to compromise denies having entered into the compromise the Court will have to come to a finding as to whether there had not been a compromise effected between the parties and to decide if the Compromise was lawful.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Abdul khaleque and others Vs. Siddiqur Rahman and others 9BLD (HCD) 168</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. AIR. 1923 (Oudh) 252: 32 Cal 561: 1955 All 187 (D.B.)-—Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XXIII Rule 3 Compromise</span></strong>— Under the provisions of Order XXIII Rule 3 of the Code of Civil Procedure if the defendant can satisfy th Court that the claim in the suit has been adjusted or satisfied wholly or in part by any lawful agreement or compromise then the Court shall pass a decree. in terms of such compromise.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Haji Md. Ishaqae and others Vs. Rupali Bank, 11 BLD (HCL))489</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XXV Rule I</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Security for costs from plaintiff r When can be ordered for? </span></strong>— Unless the Court arrives at findings that the plaintiff is its outside Bangladesh and, he does not pds.1ess sufficient immovable property. No order can be passed directing the plaintiff for famishing security for costs.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Ratan Kirshna Ghose and others Vs. 1139	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">CODE OF CIVIL PROCEDURE, 1908 [ORDER XLI - XLVII]</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  10 BLI) (HCD)447, 11 BLD (AD) 161, 6 8LDMD, 90, 6 BLD(HCD) 278, BLD (HCD)517, I BLD (HCD) 379, 8 BLD (HCD)3 77, 4RLD (HCD) 321, 6 BLD(IICD)102, 10 BLD (HCD) 404, 3 BLD(AI1)62, 3 BLD(AD) 277, 3 BLD (A D) 132, 6 BLD (AD) 135, 6 BLD(AD) 156, 8 BDL(A D)3, 4 </p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  1908</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  CIVIL PROCEDURE</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u><br/> </u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>CODE OF CIVIL PROCEDURE, 1908</u></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XLI Rules 4 and 33</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Abatement of appeal</span></strong> — Plaintiffs obtained decree in a suit for declaration of title and confirmation of possession in respect of the disputed land — During the pendency of the appeal the appellants failed to substitute the heirs of the deceased respondents.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It is well settled that in a case of possibility of two inconsistent decrees, the appeal as a whole abates.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Jalal Hossain Manjisee and others Vs. Jalaluddin Talukder and others, 10 BLI) (HCD)447</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 20 DLR 762 — Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XLI Rule 4</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Necessary party in appeal</span></strong> -</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">If any of the non—appealing defendants is not brought record and not be fore the appellate Court then there is a possibility of inconsistent and contradictory decrees regarding the same subject matter under litigation — An appeal can he filed by some of the defendants when it proceeds from a ground common to all the defendants tinder order XLI Rule 4 of the Code of Civil Procedure The provision of Rule 4 of Order XLI only authorises one of’ the several plaintiffs or defendants to prefer appeal —-- But the appeal which was incompetent at its inception br omission to imp lead a necessary party would remain incompetent till the end of it unless otherwise during the pendency of the appeal necessary parties are brought on record.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In order to reach the conclusion that the appeal has become no maintainable, it is necessary to find that the party’ which is left out is a necessary party or that the decree was indivisible for which the appeal could not be proceeded with over and above finding that Rule 4 does not apply when the non-appealing plaintiff or defendant is not impleaded in the appeal.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In order to hold that an appeal has become none—maintainable in the absence of a none—appealing plaintiff or defendant. as the case may be. it is necessary to give further reason than merely saying that Rule 4 does not apply.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">On the death of a non—substituted appellant the appeal against him abates and it is to be broken that he has not appealed But under 4, the other defendant-appellants are entitled to make an appeal and carry it to conclusion.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Anwara Begum and others Vs. MS.Shalsanew: and another 11 BLD (AD) 161</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 4l)LR 400: PLD 1972 (SC) 321: PLI) 1974 (SC) 322: AIR. 1946 (Lahore) 399 (F.B.): PLD 1964(SC) 559: PLD 1960 (Dhaka) 3:32 DLR(AD)96: 12 DLR 745; 16 DLR (SC 386—Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XLI Rule 5</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Stay of execution</span></strong> — Question of maintainability of a conditional stay during pendency of appeal — Deposit of the entire decretal amount as a condition for staving the execution proceeding does not appear to be proper.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">The Regional Manager, Agrani Bank, Mvinensingh and an other Vs. Nani Gopal Ghosh and another, 6 8LDMD, 90</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XLI Rule 5 (4)</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Stay of operation of judgment</span></strong> — Whether an order of stay passed without hearing the respondent is valid? — It is necessary that the Court must pass an ad interim order first and then a final order after hearing the appellant again — The Court may pass a final order after hearing the appellant only once — The Election Appellate Tribunal did not commit an illegality in passing a final order for stay of execution of the judgment and order appealed from without hearing the respondent.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">A.K.M. Shahidur Rahman Vs. Md. Maficullah Master, 6 BLD(HCD) 278</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. A.I.R. 1924 (Patna) 715 — Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XLI Rule 5(1)</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Appellate Court’s Power of stay</span></strong>— The appellate Court has got the jurisdiction to pass an order staying the operation of the ad- interim order of injunction passed by the trial Court at the time of admission of the appeal by the lower appellate Court.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Md. Abdul Latif Vs. Chairman, Sher- E-Bangla and others, 12 Governing Body, Balika Mahavidyalaya BLD (HCD)517</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 35 DLR (Al)) 42: 1977-78 BSCR (Vol. I and 2), 32: — Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XLI Rules II and 12: Appeal against ad-interim injunction</span></strong>—Appeal filed against an order of ad interim injunction— District Judge summarily dismissed the appeal and by the same order stayed the operation of the order of ad—interim injunction — Appellate Court can dismiss an appeal summarily or can pass a stay order while admitting the appeal, but cannot dispose of the appeal finally affecting the interest of respondent without serving notice upon him.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Ashrafuzzaman and others Vs. Md. Suruf Au and others, I BLD (HCD) 379</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XLI Rule 11 -</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Admission of appeal</span></strong> —- Whether without formally admitting an appeal the Court can entertain and decide an appeal on merit and whether the judgment passed in such an appeal is without jurisdiction — Where the appellate Court registers an appeal, issues notices to the respondents and calls for the record of the lower Court and fixes a date for return and order, although the appeal is not admitted formally, it shall be deemed that the appeal was admitted by the appellate Court on application of its judicial mind, because the Court will not issue any notice upon the respondents unless it admits the appeal — Though there was no formal admission of the appeal and the appeal was heard the judgment of the lower appellate Court is without jurisdiction.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Nurul Apser Vs. Mafizur Rahmau Chowdhury and others, 8 BLD (HCD)3 77</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref.5[)LR 451; 6DLR 434:9 DLR 394</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XLI Rules 17 and 19 : Readmissioin of an election appeal dismissed for default</span></strong> — Whether appeal can be dismissed on merits exparte — When the appellant or his counsel fails to appear when an appeal is called on for hearing, the appellate Court can only dismiss the appeal for default—It has no power to deliver judgment on merits -— Even if the appeal is dismissed on merits, this will be treated as a dismissal for default and the appellant’s remedy will remain open.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Manoo Meah Vs. Sultan Ahmaed Khan, 4RLD (HCD) 321</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. AIR. 1929 CAL 475: A.1.R. 1953 Assam 191: A.I.R. 1962 Punjab 82: AIR. 1963 Patmi I; A.I.R. 1973 Patna 166; — Céted.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XLI Rule 19: Re-admission of an election appeal dismissed for default</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Whether the District Judge has jurisdiction entertain application for re-admission of an citole appeal dismissed for default — The extinction between the status of an Election Antennal and the appellate forum is obvious — The Election Tribunal does not function as a part of the judicial system of the country hut District Judge does function as a part of the judicial system — Inspite of the incongruity of visional application being available to a party against the substantive decision of the District Judge and there being a provision for Appeal in the case of a reaction of an application for re—admission of appeal. the District Judge will continue to exercise all power which as an appellate Court has been  in him under the C.P.C. — Local Government Ordinance. 1984. S. 29(l); Union Parishad (Election) Rules 1983. Rule 48.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Moktad Hossain Majumder Vs. Abdul Bashar Majuinder and others, 6 BLD(IICD)102</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 30 DLR 331; 3IDLR 119: 29 DLR(SC) 295 — Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XLI Rule 19 — Family Court’s Ordinance, 1985</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Appellant filed an application under Order XLI Rule 19 read with section 151 of the Codc of Civil Procedure for readmission of the appeal dismissed for default and the learned District Judge rejected the said application as not maintainable on the ground that the Court of the District Judge being a Family Court according to the Family Court Ordinance, the provisions of the Code of Civil Procedure (except sections 10 and II of C.P.C.) including the provisions of Order XLI Rule 10 are not applicable.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The appellate Court under the said Ordinance also includes and Court of Additional District Judge — These are all civil Courts and the provisions of the Code of Civil Procedure are applicable to proceedings before these Courts — The learned District Judge was wrong in holding that the Court of the District Judge was a Family Court of which the provisions of Order XLI Rule 19 of the Code of Civil Procedure were not applicable.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Md. Mainuddin Vs. Anria khan Maflish, 10 BLD (HCD) 404</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 39 DLR (AD) 172 — Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XLI Rule 22</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Cross-objection</span></strong> — Whether appellate Court can disturb a portion of the judgment favourable to the appellant without cross-objection — The provision is wide enough to enable the respondents to support the decree not only on the points decided in their favour but also on points decided against them.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Hazrat All and others, Vs. Yakub All Khan and others, 3 BLD(AI1)62</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XLI Rule 22</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Dismissal of the suit in an appeal b the plaintiff against adverse findings</span></strong> High Court Division could either uphold or set aside such adverse findings in such an appeal —Where there has been no appeal by the defendant against the decree of the first appellate Court. nor even any cross- objection, the order of the High Court setting aside the judgment and decree of the first appellate Court and dismissing the suit while hearing the appeal is a gratuitous order not warranted by law.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Partil Rani Sen Gupta Vs. Bangladesh 3 BLD(AD) 277</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XLI Rules 23 — 25</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Remand</span></strong>—Trial Court decreed the suit and the lower appellate Court affirmed the decree although on a different ground There was no justification for the High Court Division to observe that it would have to be seen whether plaintiff was entitled to the declaration v ithout proving his legal right to the suit land There is therefore no reason to send the case back on remand to the lower appellate Court.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Abdul Halim alias Abdul Halim Mia Vs. Ahmed All and others, 3 BLD (A D) 132</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XLI Rule 23</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Remand</span></strong>—Whether remand to the trial Court b the High Court Division without remanding to the appellate Court when no further evidence was allowed to be adduced justified — Indiscriminate order of remand tantainounts to shirking the responsibility After perusal of the judgment it was held that the ends of justice would he met if the matter is emitted to the appellate Court.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Abdul Halim alias Abdul Halim Mia Vs. Abmed All and others, 3 BLD (AD) 132</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XLI Rule 23</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Remand</span></strong>—Whether remand to the trial Court h the High Court Division without remanding to the expellable Court when no further evidence was allowed to he adduced justified Indiscriminate order of remand tantarnounts to shirking the responsibility by the appellate Court — After perusal of the judgment it was held that the ends of justice would be met if the matter is remitted to the appellate Court.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Dr. Rezia Khatun Vs. Finding had been reversed on proper consideration of the evidence — when evidence on all material are there on record the provisional Court is not justified in sending the case back to the Court below br reconsidering the matter.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Abdul Awal Khan Vs. Md. Sadu Mia and others, 6 BLD(AD) 156</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XLI Rule 23</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Remand in Partition suit</span></strong>—Consideration of prayer for saham by some of the defendant% on the basis of documents admitted into evidence in the absence of oral evidence to connect the documents with the defence case— Statements made in the written statement are not evidence and in the absence of oral evidence prayer for saharn could not he considered — Whether prayer for remand ought to have been allowed to give a chance to the defendants to adduce oral evidence in support of their case — The documents having been lawfully admitted into evidence but not considered for want of oral evidence and the suit being a partition suit, the Court ought to have granted the prayer for remand</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Jobeda Khatun and others Vs. Hamed Ali being dead his heir Taherun Nessa and others, 8 BDL(A D)3</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XLI Rule 27</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Additional evidence — When it is to l)e admitted? </span></strong>— The appellate Court has discretion to allow additional evidence in order to enable in to pronounce judgment or for any other substantial cause — this discretion is not subject to any other limitation or restriction— To do justice is the special preserve or Jomain of a Court of law before judgment is pronounced there may be no harm if a vital piece of evidence is produced. though late, so that the Court may prevent an injustice being done.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Sunil Krishan Banik </span></em></strong><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">and others Vs<em> Kailash Chaizdra Saha </em>and others. 4 <em>BLD (AD)320</em></span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 58 l.A. 254: 1966 (SC)684: PLD Cited.</p><p> </p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XLI Rule 27</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Additional evidence in the appellate Court</span></strong> —- When can be allowed it — It can not allowed for filing up lacuna of any party. Additional evidence cannot be taken until the Court finds that there is some inherent defect or lacuna in the evidence for which the Court will not be able to pronounce its judgment properly — The admission of additional evidence should not be allowed to supplement the evidence of any party or to make up the cakes of his case and fill up the omission — It is purely the discretion on the part of the palate Court to grant such an application for Visional evidence — Where a party has lost his case in the trial Court, the appellate Court cannot allow him to produce additional civil defence to fill up the lacuna in that case.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Rahala Khatun and another Vs. An order of remand was necessary for allowing the additional evidence to be produced and proved in accordance with law- The appeal is allowed and the case remanded to the trial Court for rehearing upon evidence in respect of the alleged sale,</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Sona Mia Bepari and ors. Laila Begem and others, 6 BLD(HCD)141</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 28 DLR (AD) 185; — 44 M. 383 —</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XLIII Rule 1(U)</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Whether an order of remand by the Court of appeal below is appealable</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">When the trial Court disposed of the suit on preliminary point and the appellate Court finds that the decision of the trial Court is wrong and where the decree of the appellate Court is appealable then an appeal will lie against the order of remand— But after the coming into force of the Law Reforms Ordinance section. 100 of the Code of Civil Procedure providing appeal from an appellate decree has been omitted and as such no appeal shall lie from an order of remand passed under Order XLI Rule, 23 -— an order of remand passed under section 151 or Order XLI Rule 25 is not also appealable.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Mohammad Jehad Au and Vs. Bangladesl Shipping Corporation, IB I. D (H CD) 320</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XLVII Rules 1, 2 and 4</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Review of judgment — When a successor Judge can and when cannot review judgment</span></strong> — The right of review of a judgment is a substantive right and its scope. extent. manner and forum are circumscribed by the statute which confers such right— Review on the ground of discovery of new and important matter or evidence as referred to in Rule I or the existence of a clerical or arithmetical mistake or error apparent on the face of decree is entertain able and disposable by the Court which passed the decree/order as the case may be by the successor Court — But if an application for review of judgment or an order is made on any other grounds then that application shall be made only to the Judge who passed the decree or made the order in term of Rule 2 — But if a Judge who passed the decree or made the order has ordered notice to issue under Rule 4. subrule (2) provision (a), the application for review may be disposed of by his successor — ‘Record’ is a wider term than ‘decree’ — Record includes judgment, Decree, pleadings. Evidence, exhibits. hut ‘decree’ means precisely that which is defined in section 2(2) of the C.P.C. —“Error apparent on the face of the record” is much wider than the words “clerical or arithmetical mistake or error on the face of the decree” — When an application for review is made to the Judge-in- charge and who upon such application has issued notice under Order XLVII Rule 4. sub- rule 2 proviso (a) of the C.P.C. disposal of I such application by a successor Judge is without jurisdiction.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Al-haj Md. Vs. Nur Hosain. 9BLD (HCD) 453</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 1964(SC) 1372—Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XLVII</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Exparte decree</span></strong> — Relief against such decree — Apart from the remedy of getting</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">a decree set aside by filing an application under order 9 rule I 3 C.P.C. there are other remedies open by way of appeal review and also independent suit on grounds of fraud.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Ayezuddin Sheik and others Vs. text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A person aggrieved by an exparte decree zapursue three remedies in the Courts</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">(I) by filing an application under Order IX Rule 13 for setting aside the ex parte decree, (2) by filing an application for review under Order XLVII Rule I. or (3) by filing an appeal under section 96 of the C.P.C. Jobeda Khatun and others, 12BLD (AD) I</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 31 DLR (AD) 51: AIR. 1956 (SC) 367: AIR. 1965 (Orissa) 102: AIR. 1978(Calcutta) 392; AIR. 1978 (HCI)) 27 Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XLVII Rule I</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Review</span></strong>—Order XLVII Rule I covers both cases of review on the grounds of mistake or error of fact as well as law. Provided it is apparent on the face of the record— An error apparent either in the order itself or any other document which is incorporated in that order — It must be an evident error which does not require extraneous matter to its incorrectness.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Ali and other Vs. Mohainniad A/i and others, 12 BLD(HCD)387</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XLVII Rule 7(2)</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Limitation in review</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Provision for restoration of the review application is subject to Article I 60 of the Limitation Act — The alplicant is to satisfy within time that he was prevented by sufficient cause from appearing on the fixed date — The Court has got no power to extend the period prescribed for filing an application for restoration — Review is an extraordinary remedy — He who seeks review of a Court’s order must be vigilant.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">M.S. Zaman and Co. Vs. Bangladesh Sugar and Food Industries Corporation and others, 7BLD (AD) 209</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 5 BLD 337: 27 IC. 703 — Cited.</p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>

An order rejecting objections and accepting the report of an Advocate Commissioner does not mean that the Court has abdicated its functions and has decided a fact in issue solely on the port of the Commissioner — It will still be open to the Court to consider the report afresh again in the light of such fresh materials as may be legally brought on record by the parties.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Mostakim Mondal Vs. text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The Court after hearing any objection which the party may take to the report shall “confirm, vary or set aside’’ the same --—— This implies that the Parties are entitled to substantiate their objection but in such cases as rule of prudence, the Advocate Commissioner shout - be examined with reference to the objection and if it appears from the statement of the Advocate Commissioner that there is a ground for further enquiry into the matter, which is i the objection, then the parties should be al-I towed to produce evidence or the Advocate Commissioner be directed to amend his report accordingly</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The High Court Division when seized the revision proceeding as a whole is comjr-1 tent to look into the matter from start to finally because the object of scrutiny of the proceeding, as a whole by the High Court is that justice done as a whole in the proceeding.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; The People’s Republic of Bangladesh, represented by the Military Estate Officer, Dhaka Cantonment, Ministry of Defence and other, 7BLD(AD)62</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XXVII Rule 4</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Service of summons — Whether Government pleader is the agent for service of summons upon the Government</span></strong> — Government pleader is the agent for service of summons on the Government — Service of summons under Order V of CP. Code is a general provision and Order XXVII C.P.C. contains special provision in respect of suits by or against the Government and as such the special provisions of Order XXVII will override the provisions of Order V in respect of such suits — As the Government Pleader was not served with the summons there was no proper service.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Hateman Nessa and others Vs. Bangladesh, 5BLD (AD)114</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XXX Rule 1</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Partner’s authority</span></strong> — A partner may sue or be sued in the name of the firm — But such authority does not empower him to compromise or withdraw a suit or proceedings relinquish claim or admit liability against the finn — Partnership Act, 1932 (IX of 1932), S.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">19.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">M/s. Mrinal Kanti Biswas and others, 8 BLD(AD)1</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XXXII Rule 11(2)</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Retirement of Guardian</span></strong>:</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Where the Guardian for the suit retires during the pendency of the suit, the Court shall appoint a new Guardian in his place — According to Appellate Side Rules, the Deputy Registrar of the Court was to be appointed as the guardian ad Litem for minors in such a case; instead of doing so a verified application was asked for from the appellants — When there was already a Court Guardian, who could not be served with notice, the Court could straightway appoint the Deputy Registrar as the guardian without requiring the appellants to file an application — This was not done and ultimately the dismissal order was passed for non-compliance of an order which was not exactly necessary — Impugned order was not passed in exercise of a proper discretion and upon taking into consideration of all the relevant facts. Appellate Side Rules, Part 11. Ch. V, Rule 31.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Mvi. Md. Sadeque; 6BLD (HCD)72</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XXXVIII Rules 5 and 8</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Bailie’s Lien —</span></strong> Question of bailee’s right to retain goods and to have order of attachment — The plaintiff (bailee) could have exercised the right of lien under the Contract Act if he had possession over the scheduled materials — His application for attachment itself indicates that he was not in possession of the goods — Had he been in possession, he would have asked for an order of injunction and not for attachment — Contract Act, 1872 (IX of 1872), S. 170.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Mohammad Meah Vs.
