Mohammad Mia and others, 7 BLD (HCD)41</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. A.I.R. 1937 (Patna) 245 — Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XXXIX Rule 1</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Bank Guarantee</span></strong> — Bank undertaking to pay or the failure of performance of contract—There can be no temporary injunction restraining the enfor-cement of the guarantee—Contract Act, 1 872 (IX of 1 972), S. 126.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Uttara Bank Vs. Maoneill and Kilb urn Ltd. and others, 1 BLD (AD) 230</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 1975 (A.C.) 396 — Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XXXIX Rule 1</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Temporary injunction — Irreparable injury and balance of convenience</span></strong> — The object of interlocutory injunction is to protect the plaintiff against injury which cannot be adequately compensated by way of damages — The Court is to take balance of convenience and inconvenience into consideration in granting temporary injunction.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Uttara Bank Vs. Macneil! and Kilburn Ltd. and others, IBLD(AD) 230</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. (1975) A.C. 396; — Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XXXIX Rules 1, 2 and 3</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Adinterim injunction-Appealable order</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">When an ad-interim injunction is to be passed some reasoning should be given.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">No ad interim injunction is to be issued when the loss or injury is commensurable by monetary compensation.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">An order allowing ad-interim injunction is an appealable order.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Liaquat Hossain Chowdhury Vs. Mir Au Hossain and others, IBLD (HCD)93</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. PLD 1960 Dacca 153; A.I.R. 1936</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Patna 456; A.I.R. 1939 (All) 280; 29DLR(SC)82; Vol. 1 BSCR Page 32; Civil Revision No. 561 of 1978 (Unreported): — Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XXXIX Rule 1</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Status Quo</span></strong> — It amounts to an order of temporary injunction.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A suit for permanent injunction was filed with a prayer for temporary injunction restraining defendant. No. I from delivering possession of the suit land to defendant No.2</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">the trial Court directed the parties to maintain status quo — Appellate Court set a side the order on the ground that the plaintiff is a trespasser — On a revisional application the High Court Division set aside this order observing that “status quo” is different from “temporary injunction” Under Order XXXIX Rule I of the C.P.C.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The order of status quo in this case amounts to an order of temporary injunction restraining defendant No. 1 from delivering possession to defendant No. 2.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Dr. jamshed Baket Vs. Murad Ahmed and another, 2 BLD(AD) 154</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XXXIX Rule 1</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Injunction ad interim or temporary</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In the absence of prima facie and arguable title no injunction can be granted in favour of a trespasser in possession against the owners.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The plaintiffs cannot on the strength of their possession alone, in the absence of any prima facie and arguable title, claim to restrain the defendant appellants from getting possession in accordance with law — The plaintiffs do not appear to have any prima facie and arguable title in the suit land and the defendants are the prima facie owners of the suit land — The plaintiffs being trespassers cannot get any injunction ad-interim or temporary against the defendants who are the owners of the suit land.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Mahbub Alam Talukder and others Vs. Abdus Salam and others, 3 BLD (HCD)136</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XXXIX Rule 1</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Temporary injunction</span></strong> — Whether can be issued to restrain a Co-operative Society?----Whether M.L.O. 14 of 1982 applies — The expression “any corporation, body, organisation or enterprise, established, constituted managed maintained or owned by the Government or established or constituted by or under any law” explained — The whole purpose behind the order seems to be that no statutory body or organisation or enterprise should be restrained by an injunction, whether such statutory body is directly managed. maintained or owned by the Government or not, it comes within the purview of the Order — A Co-operative society formed under the Co-operative Societies Act, 1940 by private individuals does not come within the ambit of the expressions used in Martial Law Order No. 14 of 1982 — A Fishermen Co-operative Society formed under the Co-operative Societies Act by private individuals being excepted from the operation of the Martial Law Order No. 14 of 1982 can be restrained by an order of injunction. — Martial Law Order No. 14 of 1982.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Haji Nurul Islam Vs. Serajul Islam and others, 4 BLD (AD)36</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XXXIX Rule 1</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Temporary injunction</span></strong> — Grant of — Though the plaintiffs have prima facie case they are not entitled to temporary injunction as the injury likely to be sustained can be compensated in terms of money.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Jupitar Glass Industries Ltd. and others Vs. Titas Gas Transmission and Distribution Co. Ltd; 4 BLD (HCD) 36</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XXXIX Rule 1</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order of status quo</span></strong> — Whether such an order passed under M. L. 0. No. 40 of 1982 can be maintained — In the absence of any materials that the order of maintenance of status quo which has the effect of an order of injunction would not interfere with the development plans, the same cannot be maintained —M. L. 0. No. 40 of 1982.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Chunnu Miah Chowdhury Vs. Govt of the People’s Republic of Bangladesh, 4BLD(HCD) 302</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XXXIX Rule 1</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Grant of temporary injunction</span></strong> — Whether a enderer is entitled to restrain acceptance of a tender?—A tenderer has no legal right as the lowest bidder entitled to get the contract If a tender is accepted in violation of the condition emodied in the tender form then a tenderer may seek protection of his inchoate right — Where there has been no violation there is no necessity for seeking the protection of such right.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Umnie Kawsar Salsabil Vs. Shams Corporation (Pvt.) Ltd. and others, 5 BLD (AD) 263</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 32 DLR(AD) 223 — Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XXXIX Rule 1</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Temporary injunction and maintainability of the suit — So long as the suit is not thrown out as being not maintainable, an application for temporary injunction can be maintained.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Deputy Secretary, Ministry of Commerce, Vs. Nizamuddin Haider, 5 BLD (HCD)5 7</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XXXIX Rule 1</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Injunction in Trade Mark matters</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Whether temporary injunction, should be granted to restrain infringement of right of trade mark when the mark is not similar — A mark may have resemblance in some respects with another mark and have also many points of dissimilarity but the mark as a whole is to be taken into consideration to find whether two marks are similar — If one of the features of</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">the mark is similar but there are other distinguishable features and there are dissimilar points in them and the unwary purchaser is expected to keep his eyes open, injunction should not be allowed, at least before hearing of the suit.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Anath Bandhu Shaha and others Vs. MIs. Premier Soap Co. Ltd; 5 BLD (HCD) 260</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 30 DLR(HCD)244; 1970 PLD(SC) 460; 31 Reports on Patent Cases 63; 33 Reports on Patent Cases 257 and 25 Reports on Patent Cases 361 — Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XXXIX Rule 1</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Temporary injunction against proceeding with execution case</span></strong>— Temporary injunction to restrain the decree holder from proceeding with the execution case — Whether judgment debtor against whom a decree for recovery of possession was passed is entitled to restrain the decree holder— If an injunction is granted on the prayer of the judgment debtor, the object and purpose of the suit under section 9 of the Specific Relief Act will be frustrated — If the judgment debtor against whom a decree has been passed under section 9 can establish his title in a suit subsequently filed by him, he can get relief on the basis of the title so found in such suit — The defendant must first surrender possession to the decree holder in execution of a decree obtained by him in such a suit — No injunction can be granted on the plea of title to restrain the execution proceeding — Specific Relief Act, 1877 (I of 1877), S. 9.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Mosammat Mono wara Beguni Vs. Syed Asrafuddin and others, 6 BLD (AD)102</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: A.I.R. 1955 (All)64: AIR. 1972 (All) 418— Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XXXIX Rule 1</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Temporary injunction -— When to be granted</span></strong> — For grant of temporary injunction the Court need not enter into the merit of the case —The plaintiff having a prima facie and arguable case he would be entitled to an order of injunction pending the disposal of the suit so that the subject matter of the suit may not be wasted or destroyed — Appellate Court can consider facts of the case and the relevant laws violation of which is alleged in the suit for its satisfaction in order to decide as to whether the plaintiff is entitled to an order. of injunction.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Md. Nurul Hoque Khan and others Vs. Bangladesh Bank, 6 BLD(HCD)3</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 1BLD(HCD)129; PLD1964(SC) 21; IBLD(AD)103; 29DLR(SC)41 —Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XXXIX Rule 1</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Temporary injunction in a suit for partition</span></strong> — Whether injunction should be allowed pending partition of the suit properties by metes and bounds to prevent change of nature and character of the suit property — Nature and character of the suit land may be allowed to be changed pending decision in partition suit by improvements but no change in the nature and character of the suit land could be allowed if the same would diminish the value of the land or cause irreparable prejudice to the other co-shares — Co-sharers in urban areas should not be deprived of using the land in his possession by making construction at his risk — If a co-sharer chooses to make a construction at his own risk he should not be restrained from making construction</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">If any portion of such construction falls in the sof another co-sharer possession thereof shall be given to the allowed by demolition of the construction.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Ali Ahmed Vs. Rezia Begum and others, 6 BLD (HCD) 326</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XXXIX Rule 1</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Power of Labour Court to grant injunction</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">When a Labour Court is deemed to be a Civil Court and has the same powers as are vested in the Civil Court, it must have power to grant injunction or stay the operation of an impugned order to preserve the subject-matter of the dispute until it is finally decided — These powers to pass temporary or adinterim orders are designed to preserve and protect the subject matter of the dispute under Order XXXIX Rule I of the Code pending final determination of the case.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Pubali Bank Ltd. Vs. The Chairman, First Labour Court, Dhaka and another, 6 BLD (HCD)378</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 29 DLR(HCD)148; 30 DLR (HCD 141; 19 DLR (Dac) 612; 33 DLR 376; Ii DLR (SC) 140— Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XXXIX Rule I</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Temporary injunction</span></strong> — Question of such injunction in a “passing off” action and t restrain the use of a trade name — The action taken by the respondent in getting existing orders of the company for supply of goods and machines to different customers cancelled cannot be approved — There is not only the case of close similarity between the two names likely to create confusion in the minds of the customers, hut also the respondent took definite steps to entice away customers from the company to his private business — In the circumstances he should be refrained from doing</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Shafquat Haider and others Vs. M. Al-Amin and another, 7 BLD(AD) 130</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. Ch. D (17) 638; A.I.R. 1923 Born. 119; A.I.R. 1978 Guj. 216; All E.R. (1981)1 Vol. 2, Page 495; 42 Ch. D. 128; RPC Vol. 62- 63, Page-39; RPC Vol. 60-61, Page l33 A.I.R. 1942 Born 119—Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XXXIX Rule 1</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Injunction against lessee or used property</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Temporary injunction to restrain the lessee of vested property and mandatory injunction to restore possession to the plaintiff dispossessed during pendency of the suit — Admittedly the plaintiffs themselves prayed for lease of the suit property which was rejected — The property having vested in the Government it was for them to grant lease to any body they liked unless the plaintiffs could make out a case of any prior claim to lease on the basis of some authority or principle — There having been no ostensible authority of the plaintiffs to maintain possession of the suit property, the Additional District Judge was clearly not justified in granting temporary injunction merely on the basis that the plaintiffs were in possession which was found unauthorised by the trial Court — Then again defendant No. I having already been put into possession pursuant to the lease granted in his favour, the Additional District Judge was also not justified in passing an order in a mandatory form for evicting the defendant and putting the plaintiffs in possession of the suit property.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Pran Baltav Pal Vs. Santi Ranjan Salia, 7 BLD(AD) 187</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XXXIX Rule 1</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Injunction</span></strong> — Injunction to restrain Shilpa Bank from taking over or transfer of industrial concern indebted to the Bank — Whether Bank can be restrained from taking over or transferring such industrial concern — No Court shall issue, make or pass any order of adinterim or temporary injunction or any other order prohibiting or restraining the Bank any of its officers from such taking over or transfer Even when the Shilpa. Bank has not ken over the management and administration of any industrial concern the Court cannot is- we make or pass any order of ad interim or temporary injunction or any other order prohibiting or restraining the Shilpa Bank or any of its officers from such taking over or from making such transfer.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Moon Light Silk Mills Ltd. Vs. Dan gladesh Shilpa Bank, 7 BLD HCD)239</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. I 8DLR(SC) 354; Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XXXIX Rule I</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Temporary injunction on the basis of inchoate right</span></strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> — Whether temporary injunction can be granted in favour of a person claiming inchoate right in the subject matter of suit — Inchoate right means a right that has just begun but not yet developed into maturity — A tenderer by making highest offer cannot acquire any right to purchase the vessel as his was not accepted by the Corporation which reserved full power to reject the offer — Concurrent findings of Courts below upon conception cannot entitle the appellant to temporary injunction on the basis of an right.</span></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Mozaher Swodagar Vs. Mr.M.Zahirul Alam, General Manager, Bangladesh Shipping Corporation and others, 8 BLD (AD) 29</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 32 DLR (AD) 223; 5 BLD (AD)</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">1979 (SC) 1628:—Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XXXIX Rule 1</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Labour Court’s Power</span></strong>—Labour Court no power of the civil Court which empowers Labour Court, while adjudicating disputes other than industrial dispute, to grant temporary injunction — Temporary injunction can only be granted in a suit and by a civil Court by following the procedure of the Code of Civil Procedure — The power and procedure being absent with the Labour Court while adjudicating individual disputes and not industrial dispute there is no scope for a Labour Court to grant temporary injunction — Industrial Relations Ordinance, 1969 (XXIII of 1969) Ss. 34, 36 and 43; Specific Relief Act, 1877 (I of 1877) Ss. 52 and 53.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Chairman, Chittagong Port Authority Vs. Kalipada Dey and others, 8 BLD (IWD) 52</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 29 DLR l48;30 DLR l4l; 30 DLR (SC) 251; 19 DLR 612; 33 DLR 376:6 BCR 129; I BLD (AD) 21; PLD 1972 Lahore 603;— Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XXXIX Rule 1</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Status Quo — Meaning of</span></strong> — When a Court passes an order directing the parties to maintain status quo the meaning of the expression status quo has to be gathered from the plaint, petitions of parties, written objection, written statement and the petition or petitions filed by the parties praying for adinterirn order— The order directing the parties to maintain status quo till disposal of the Rule meant that if the defendants were managing and running the affairs of the school they will continue to do so.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Managing Committee, Mohammadpur Girls High School Vs. Fazjur Rahman Khan and others, 8BLD (HCD) 45</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 1968 SC MR 557; 2 BLD (AD) 154:— Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XXXIX Rule 1</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Temporary injunction — Principles to be followed in granting such injunction in election matters — Question of balance of convenience and inconvenience in election matter</span></strong> — In a contested election the voters are entitled to exercise their valuable right of francise and they will be debarred from exercising the same if one of the candidates is restrained from contesting and the other candidate steals a march over his adversary by contesting the election, then the restrained candidate will have no remedy but to challenge the election by filing an election petition giving rise to multiplicity of proceedings— But if an injunction is granted the plaintiff will be at liberty to contest the election and he will not suffer any irreparable loss and injury— Thus the balance of convenience and inconvenience is against the plaintiff.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Nurul Apser Vs. Mafizur Rahinan Chowdhury and others, 8 BLD (HCD) 377</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 5 DLR 451; 6 DLR 434; 9DLR 394;5 BLD (AD)54; 39 DLR 322; 22 DLR (SC)98; 22 DLR (SC) 41; A.I.R. 1929(PC) 95; 37 DLR 49; I.L.R (1944) Lahore 168 — Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XXXIX Rule 1</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Co-sharer’s right to injunction</span></strong> — Co-sharers in exclusive possession of their separate shares are seeking protection to maintain their exclusive possession from the onslaught of the other co-sharers who got no possession in the particular share, which is in plaintiff’s exclusive possession — Co-sharer not in possession but having the plea that he has got title to every inch of the joint property and his co-sharers are in possession of some lands in excess of their shares, his remedy lies in a suit for partition.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Moharram Au and another Vs. Mohaminad Madhu Mia and others, 9 BLD (AD)67</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 18 I.L...R Cal 10; 11 DLR4O; 5DLR39; II C.W.N. 517; A.I.R. 1924 (Cal)</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">792; A.I.R. 1943 (All) 247; 17 Indian Appeals</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">110; —Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XXXIX Rule 1</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Injunction — Maintainability of</span></strong> — The plaintiff has on his own showing made a transfer of land before his own settlement was completed — He having parted with the land under proposed settlement, he was not entitled to an order of injunction to maintain his alleged possession.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Belayet Hossain Vs. Nurul Alam Mir and others, 9 BLDAD) 167</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XXXIX Rule 1</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Election Tribunal — Extent of its jurisdiction</span></strong> — Whether it is competent to pass orders for temporary injunction — Election Tribunal would have the powers of a civil Court trying a suit under the Code of Civil Procedure only for decision of the matter before it and not beyond — It is not a Civil Court under the Civil Courts Act, 1887 and it is not a part of the judicial system of the country. The Tribunal was created for a limited purpose by a special law and it is under the superintendence of the executive authority — The power of transfer of an election petition is wit the Election Commission, not with the District Judge, the appellate authority, which indicate that the Election Tribunal is not amenable provisions of the Code of Civil Procedure — The appellate Tribunal also could not be considered a Civil Court only because the appellate authority of the Tribunal has been found to be a Civil Court — True, there is incongruity the appellate authority has one character an the Tribunal has a different character — It is for the legislature to bring about a uniformity between the superstructure and the infrastructure of an institution — Since the Election Tribunals are not civil Courts, the also are not amenable to the revision jurisdiction of the High Court Division Local Government (Union Parisahds Ordinance, 1983, S. 29. ; Union Parishad (Election) Rules, 1983, Rules. 47 and 48.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Mahmud Hussain Vs. Md. Sayed Au and others, 9 BLD (HCD) 173</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 27 DLR 388; 28 DLR 189; 29 DLIII; 38 DLR (AD)l72; 37 DLR 71; 3 DLR(HCD) 41; 38 DLR 262; 38 DLR(HC 435;31 DLRII9;38DLR198;—Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XXXIX Rules 1 and 2</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Ad-interim injunction — Refusal</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">prayer for such injunction in a suit when justified — The proceedings in such a suit known these days ‘public litigation’ do not partake of pre-deter mined private law litigation model and need for judicial intervention may not artist even in those cases where the Court’s jurisdiction is invoked, if the administration take curative measures meanwhile — In this view, the petition for special leave to appeal again refusal of interim injunction is dismissed.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Ziaul Huq and others Vs. Messers Business Resources Ltd. and others, 10BLD (AD) 17</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. AIR. 1988 (SC) 2211; AIR. 1987</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">(SC) 359; A.1.R.1988 (HP) 4(9); = Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XXXIX Rule I</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Execution proceeding—Injunction against—Question of correct exercise of discretion —</span></strong> The Bank’s suit for realisaturn of money from its debtor ended in a compromise decree When the Bank started execution case for sale of the debtor’s property under equitable mortgage, the appellant filed a suit for specific performance of his contract against both the Bank and the debtor on the basis of an agreement for sale of the property and prayed for and obtained an order after— junction h which the Bank was restrained from proceeding with the execution case till disposal of the suit — On appeal the High Court Division set aside the injunction order omitting from consideration the material point i.e: payment of money and appellant’s possession of the land — High Court Division does not therefore appear to have correctly exercised its discretion in interfering with the trial Court’s Order.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Md. Moinin Miah and another Vs. Moulvi Moinuddin Hossain and another, 10 BLD (AD) 122</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XXXIX Rule I</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Interlocutory matter</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It is well-settled that the Court will not decide a point especially in the interlocutory matter which will not advance the cause of justice — It will merely delay the process of coming top a conclusion as to claim and counter-claim which can only be thrashed out in the pending suits on taking e evidence.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">The Dhaka Dyeing and manufacturing Co. Ltd. Vs. Agrani Bank, 10 BLD (.4D) 265</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XXXIX Rules I and 2</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Temporary injunction</span></strong> —Respondents instituted a suit for permanent injunction impleading defendant appellants — plaintiffs failed to gel, an order of injunction from either of the Courts below since the institution of the suit — Further application for revision was moved 3 months after the refusal of the prayer of injunction by the Court of appeal below — In such circumstances, the granting of ad interim iflj1iflction ex-parte at the time of</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Issuing the Rule, whether can be said to he a proper exercise of discretion?</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It cannot be said to be a proper exercise of discretion — rather it should be considered to be an unusual order in the facts and circumstances of the case.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Qari Nowab Faruque and another Vs. Abdul Latif Bhuiyan and others, 10 BLD(AD)288</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XXXIX Rule I</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Injunction against holder of bill of exchange</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A holder of a bill of exchange in due course is entitled to encash the same on maturity and payment to him cannot be restrained by injunction Negotiable Instruments. Act, 1881 (XXVI of 1881). Ss. 5 and 9.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Exportos India Vs. Rupashi Garments. and others, 11BLD (HCD) 65</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XXXIX Rule 1 read with Order XLII Rule 1(r), Order XLVII and section 151 C.P.C.</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Rejection of an application of injunction</span></strong> — It is a well-settled principle of law that where a legal remedy is provided for in the Code of Civil Procedure to an aggrieved party the inherent power shall not be exercised under section 151 C.P.C.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Atash Au and others Vs. Rebati Mohan Sarker and others,11BLD(HCD)97</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 4ODLR (AD) 406: 42 DLR 19 Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XXXIX Rules 1 and 2</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Temporary injunction</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In order to get an order of injunction from any Court, the application must satisfy the Court that he has prima facie case and further that there is an obligation in his favour which the defendant owes but threatens to commit breach of such obligation and that unless he gets an order of injunction, his legal right will be frustrated and that the injury would be irreparable if no such order of injunction is granted.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Court must vindicate or protect the legal right and further keep watch so that such right is not in any way fettered —— It must not create any hindrance or impediment in the exercise of such right and no order of injunction is to be issued restraining the exercise of a legal right.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Md. Badsha Miah and others Vs. Tofael Ahined Chowdhury aizd others, 12 BLD(HCD) 78</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. XVII Indian Appeal. page 222 — Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XXXIX Rules 2</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Injunction in a simple declaratory suit</span></strong>:</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The principle that in a suit for declaration of title in the suit land simpliciter without any prayer for consequential relief the plaintiff is not entitled to ask for temporary injunction against the defendants restraining them from interfering with plaintiff’s alleged possession is generally applicable to a case where a suit for title relating to immovable property is filed and consequential prayer ought to have been made, but that having not beer done an injunction is sought for Normally this rule is to he observed, but it cannot be taken as an absolute rule, because if the suit is otherwise maintainable, and if it is found that the defendant without being in possession. wants to disturb the possession, the Court cannot be powerless to grant temporary injunction in an. appropriate case—The order granting injunction must be a speaking order. — Specific Relief Act, 1877(1 of 1877). S. 42.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Ramani Marak and another Vs. Hahihur Rahman Munshi, 7BLD (HCD) 73</span></em></strong></p><p><strong><br clear="all" style="page-break-before: always;"/> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Order XXXIX Rules 1 and 2 </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Temporary Injunction in service matter—Temporary injunction</span></strong> — In a where the order impugned appears to be without jurisdiction on the face of it or in violation of any law or rule governing the employment in service a Court can legitimately a prayer for temporary injunction — matter of service a Court has also to keep in view the difficult and problems that are likely to he created in the matter of administra1 in the particular office before allowing temporary injunction — The plaintiff was promoted on ad-hoc basis and subsequently sent hack to his original post — such are not unusual in any administration — District Judge set aside the order of opinion on the grounds of balance of convene and inconvenience and that the plaintiff at compensated by money in the event of his success in the suit — The impugned judgment of the High Court Division has not given any reason to negative his findings — The exercise of discretion by the High Court Division has been made upon correct judicial principles</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Bangladesh Sericulture Board and another Vs. Md. Faziur Rahrnan akunjee and another, 9BLD(AD)7</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order XXXIX Rules 2(3)</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In a proceeding initiated upon an application under sub-rule 3 of Rule 2 of Order XXXIX of the Code of Civil Procedure bringing allegation for violation of an injunction order passed by a Court against the offenders, the trial Court must frame issues in such a manner so that all the elements of’ a charge under criminal jurisdiction find place in the issue, so that the persons against whom the allegation of violation of Court’s order s brought is in no way misled by such issue to be prejudiced in their trial.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Abdul Matin and others Vs. text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Appointment of receiver in case of partnership</span></strong> — Where a partner misconducts or mismanages the business or misappropriate— ales funds or colludes with the debtors or partnership Lund is in danger of being lost or the whole concern is endangered then a receiver is appointed - If one partner excludes his copartner ruin his rightful interference in the management of the partnership affairs, or if he persists in acting in violation of partnership articles or he does not consult his partner on any point of importance or grossly misconducts himself the Court will interfere for the protection of the others rights —— Where the right of personal intervention has been forfeited by misconduct. or partnership funds are in danger of being lost, or a where a partner has so misconduct himself as to show that he is n. longer to he trusted, such as, he carries on private trade with the fund of the partnership firm, or he colludes with the firm’s debtors. or he has so grossly mismanaged the business to endanger the whole concern or he has made away with partnership fund, the appointment of a receiver is a must.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; 1141	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">CODE OF CIVIL PROCEDURE, 1908 [SECTION 1 - 20]</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  2 BLD (HCD) 201, 9 BLD (HCD) 512, 9 BLD (HCD) 162, 9 BLD (HCD) 326, 9 BLD (HCD) 446, 1 BLD (HCD) 25, 1 BLD (HCD) 228, 2 BLD (AD) 6, 6 BLD (AD) 342, 7 BLD (HD) 44, 8 BLD(HCD) 241, 8 BLD (HCD) 473, 9 BLD (HCD) 97, 9 BLD (HCD) 326, 11 BLD (HCD) 79, 1 BLD(HC</p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  1908</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  CIVIL PROCEDURE</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u style="text-underline: thick;">CODE OF CIVIL PROCEDURE, 1908</u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u style="text-underline: thick;">(V OF 1908)</u></strong></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span><span id="pastemarkerend"> <br/> </span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—2(2)</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Court fees on memorandum of appeal</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Appeal filed against an order rejecting a plaint on the ground of lack of jurisdiction of Court—Order of rejection of plaint amounts to a decree for all purposes—Value of the subject-matter of appeal is the same as the value of the subject-matter of original suit— Ad-valorem Court fees of the amount paid in original suit is to be paid on the memorandum of appeal—Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 (V of 1908), Or. VII R. 11; Courts Fees Act, 1870 (VII of 1870), Sch. I Art. I and Sch. II Art 11.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Md. Basiruddin and others Vs. Jamiruddin and others; 2 BLD (HCD) 201.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 13 DLR 836; 19 ‘DLR 268; 41 C.W.N. 157; AIR. 1929 Pat 615: AIR. 1935 Nag. 83.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—2(2)</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Decree</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">There is no difference between a preliminary decree and a final decree in so far as it relates to the application Order 9 Rule 13 of the Code of Civil Procedure.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Khalilur Rahman Bepari and others Vs. Abdur Rahman Bepai and others; 9 BLD (HCD) 512.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—2(11) and 50</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Legal Representative</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Whether heirs of a deceased tenant can be included as legal representatives for the purpose of executing the decree—The definition of legal representative shall be given a wide meaning to include the heirs of a deceased tenant who dies during the pendency of an execution case started in pursuance of.a decree for eviction of the tenant from the suit premises—Premises Rent Control Ordinance, 1963 (XX of 1963) S.2 (9)</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Kazal Das Sarina and others Vs. Pradip Das alias Shambu &amp; ors. 9 BLD (HCD) 162.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 1934 All 474; 32 DLR (AD) 170; 38DLR (AD) 97 2B .C.R. (AD) 428 —cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—4</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Bar of Civil Suit</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Rights which had no existence earlier and have been created by special laws and which are alleged to have been infringed are required to be determined in the manner prescribed by the laws to which they owe their existence—The plea that such laws do not provide for effective and adequate remedy is untenable in view of the intention of the legislature that the civil Courts are not to take cognizance of such disputes—-Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 (V of 1908), S. 9 and Or. 7 R. 11 —Local Government (Union Parishads) Ordinance, 1983 (LI of 1983), 5. 26.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Mostafa Karnal Ahmed Vs. B. D. Habibullah and others; 9 BLD (HCD) 326.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. I.L.R. 31 Born 604; PLD 1949 Lah 301; 39 DLR 451: A.I.R. 1937 All 365: 27 DLR(AD)138; 8BCR6I; 40DLR459: 44 C.W.N. 709—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—4</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Suit of Civil nature</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">When Civil Court would have no jurisdiction to entertain such suit—Special law overrides the general jurisdiction conferred on civil Courts to entertain suits of civil nature—Where a right is created by a special law and a method of enforcing the right is pointed out by the law creating such right, the general remedy by way of suit under the Code will be impliedly barred—In such a case the method provided by the special law must be followed—Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 (V of 1908), S. 9 and Order 7 Rule II.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Jalaluddin Ahmed Vs. Matiur Rahinan and others, 9 BLD (HCD) 446.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. AIR. 1937 All 365; PLD 1949 Lab 301; 37 L.J. 248: 15 DLR (SC) 283: 39 DLR 45 1: AIR. 1946 Lah 85—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Sections—6, 96 and 115</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">District Judge has no revisional jurisdiction in a matter over which he has no appellate jurisdiction.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">All orders are not appealable. Appeal lies only against those orders which are enumerated in Order 43 Rule I C.P.C. Section 96 C.P.C. provides for appeal against original decree. Revision lies against non-appealable orders. Previously revision against non- appealable order lay only in the High Court Division. In case of an appealable order passed by a Subordinate Judge, an appeal shall lie to the District Judge where the value of the original suit in which or in any proceeding arising out of which the order was made did not exceed Tk 20,000,00 and to the High Court in any other case. It cannot be conceived that a Court which cannot exercise jurisdiction over a matter in appeal was intended to exercise its revisional jurisdiction. It appears to be inconsistent with the scheme of the Code of Civil Procedure and Civil Courts Act to invest the District Judge with concurrent revisional jurisdiction in a matter here no appeal lies before the District Judge. Hitherto the District Judge had no revisional jurisdiction, only the High Court Division had revisional jurisdiction. Section 1 15(2) has invested the District Judge with rvisional jurisdiction. In the circumstances e contention of concurrent jurisdiction apars to be inconsistent. The District Judge’s revisional jurisdiction under section 115(2) is restricted by his appellate jurisdiction as provided under section 21(1) of the Civil Courts Act. In other words, the District Judge can exercise revisional jurisdiction under section 115(2) only in respect of those cases here the value of the subject-matter does not exceed Tk. 20,000.00. In all other cases, it is High Court Division which exercises restriction under section 115(1). Apart from section 115(3) the High Court Division, may under section 115(1) exercise its revisional jurisdiction in any case and its jurisdiction is not controlled by sub-section (2) of section 115. In the instant case the suit has been valued at Tk. 1, 00,000.00. For the reasons stated above in was held that the District Judge had no jurisdiction to entertain a revisional application under section 115(2) against the impugned order passed by the learned Subordinate Judge. The instant revisional application was found to be maintainable and competent—Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 (V of 1908), Order 43 Rule 1—Civil Courts Act, 1887 LXII of 1887) Ss. 3, 6, 7, 8, 18, 19, 20 and 21.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Nurul Islam and others Vs. Md. Abdur Rashid, 1 BLD (HCD) 25.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—9</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Jurisdiction—Ouster of</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Conviction under Martial Law Regulations and confiscation of property—Suit by a person not accused in the Martial Law case for declaration of his title to the confiscated property is not barred—Martial Law Regulations No. 1 of 1975. Reg. 4(6) (7).</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Professor Jinnatul Ferdous Vs. Government of Bangladesh and others; 1 BLD (HCD) 228.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—9</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Jurisdiction</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ouster of jurisdiction of Civil Court—An act not passed in exercise of powers granted by the Act is without jurisdiction—Provision of the Act ousting jurisdiction of Civil Court not attracted—Agricultural University Ordinance, 1961 (XXVIII of 1961), S. 33.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Bangladesh Agricultural University Vs. Md. Abdul Hye Bhuiyan, 2 BLD (AD)</em></strong><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> 6.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—9</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Maintainability of a suit</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Question of maintainability in the face of allegation of malafide is a question of fact and the Court, ordinarily, decides upon it after taking evidence—But where a suit is not initially maintainable, it cannot be held that the bar becomes inoperative on the allegation of malafide in the plaint—If the answer is in the affirmative, provisions relating to the bar would be rendered nugatory—In view of the express legislative intention a Judge must follow the “hands off doctrine”, otherwise chaos and anarchy would prevail—Whatever the legislature says, unless it is contrary to the Constitution, its mandate, either excess or implied, ha to be obeyed by Courts—Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 (V of 1908), Or. 7 R. 11.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Nur Mohammad and others Vs, Moulvi Mainuddin Ahmed &amp; ors., 6 BLD (AD) 342.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 17 DLR (SC)515; A.I.R.1940 (PC) 105 PLD 1970 (SC)180—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—9</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Civil Court’s Jurisdiction</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Whether Civil Court has jurisdiction to entertain a suit in respect of service matter which is under the exclusive jurisdiction of the Administrative Tribunal—Section 9 C.P.C. provides that Civil Courts have jurisdiction to try all suits of a civil nature excepting those trial of which is expressly or impliedly barred—Clause 2 of Article 117 of the Constitution has debarred the Court from entertaining any proceeding in respect of any matter falling within the jurisdiction of the Administrative Tribunal—Administrative Tribunal has exclusive jurisdiction in service matters—Civil Court has no jurisdiction in the matter—Constitution of the People’s Republic of Bangladesh, 1972, Article. 117(2)— The Administrative Tribunal Act, 1980 (VII of 1981). S.4.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Md. Habibur Rahman Vs. The Account- alit General of Works and WAPDA and others; 7 BLD (HD) 44.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 22 DLR(SC) 98: 17 DLR (SC) 515—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—9</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Jurisdiction of Civil Court</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Ouster of jurisdiction in case of election dispute</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The suit was filed challenging the acceptance of nomination paper and a declaration was sought for to the effect that the acceptance of the nomination paper was illegal. The suit is impliedly barred under the Ordinance and the Rules made there under—Local Government (Union Parishads) Ordinance, 1983, (LI of 1983), S. 26—Code of Civil Procedure. 1908 (V of 1908), Or.7 R. 11.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Manir Ahmed Khan Vs. Md. Bazlu Mia and others, 8 BLD(HCD,) 241</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 17 DLR(SC) 515; 20 DLR(SC) 335; 35 DLR 217—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—9</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Jurisdiction of Civil Courts</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Jurisdiction to try election dispute—On a limited compass the jurisdiction of the Civil Court always remains.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Habibur Rahman Vs. Election Commissioner &amp; others, 8 BLD (HCD) 473.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 8 B.C.R. (HCD)6l; A.I.R. 1940 (PC) 105; A.I.R.1949(Lahore)l31—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—9</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Bar of suit</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">When such a bar in a special statute does not apply—When a statutory authority acts without jurisdiction or in a manner without following a procedure provided in the statute itself, then it is not an act under the statute and in such a case the bar of suit does not apply—Emergency Requisition of Property Act, 1948 (XIII of 1948), S. 14A.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Government of Bangladesh and others Vs. Basaratullah being dead his heirs and successors Fazie Karim and others; 9 BLD (HCD) 97.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—9</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Election matter—Bar of Civil suit</span></strong>— Rights which had no existence earlier and have been created by special laws and which are alleged to have been infringed are required to be determined in the manner prescribed by the said laws to which they owe their existence.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Mostafa Kamal Ahmed Vs. B.D. Habibullah and others, 9 BLD (HCD) 326.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 1.L.R. 31 Born 604; PLD 1949 Lab 301: 39 D LR 451; AIR. 1937 (AH 365; 27 DLR (AD) 138: 8 BCR (HCD)61; 40 DLR 159; 44 C.W.N. 709—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—9</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">If a Court by error tries a suit which is cognizable by a Small Cause Courts exercising jurisdiction within the same limits, then the proceedings of the Court are not entirely without jurisdiction.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The trial of a case by a Court other than the S.C.C. Judge cannot be a case for want of jurisdiction inspire of the violation of the provisions enumerated by section 16 of the Small Cause Courts Act since the legislature intended to cure such defect by taking recourse to the provision of Order 46, Rule 7(2) of the Code of Civil Procedure.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section 23 of the Small Cause Courts Act</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Negatives the proposition that section 16 of the said Act altogether deprives the Civil Court of the jurisdiction conferred by section 9 of the Code in respect of a particular matter of the suit, namely the small causes suits. Trial of the suit is not a nullity for want of jurisdiction.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Question of Jurisdiction of Courts</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The question of jurisdiction being a mixed question of fact and law, the parties cannot be precluded from urging the point at higher stage even if it was not taken at the initial stage in the trial Court.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The preponderance of decision is that the jurisdiction cannot be attracted by consent of parties, if it is otherwise barred by law. Likewise one is not precluded from taking the point of jurisdiction at a higher stage even if it was not taken at the initial stage in the trial Court. Therefore, the learned Advocate for the petitioners cannot be estopped from rising the point of jurisdiction of the Civil Court in a revision case, though the same point was not taken in the trial Court where the trial was held and thereafter at the appellate stage.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Jurisdiction of Court cannot be attracted by consent of parties</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The jurisdiction of a Court cannot be attracted by consent of the parties if it is otherwise barred by law.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Mst. Wahida Rashid and another Vs. Miron Mohammad Zahidul Huq, 11 BLD (HCD) 79.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. (1957) 9 DLR (P.C.) 686: A.I.R. 1965 (Madras) 610—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—10</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Stay of proceedings before the Tribunal</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">An application for stay of proceedings before a Tribunal pending disposal of a suit between the same parties. over the same matter is misconceived and not maintainable— Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 (V of 1908); S. 151—Bangladesh Legal Practitioners and Bar Council Order, 1972 (P.O. 46 of 1972), Articles 34 and 35.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Fariduddin Ahmed Vs. Secretary, Bangladesh Bar Council and another, 1 BLD(HCD) 428.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—10</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Stay of further proceedings of a suit</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The Judge having rejected the respondents prayer for analoguous trial of the two suits, should not have stayed further proceedings of the suit for ejectment till disposal of the partition suit.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Kumud Behai Sarkar Vs. Jgabandhu Sarkar, 4 BLD (AD) 8.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—10</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Whether a subsequent proceeding should be stayed or it should be heard analogously with the previous one? — Analogous hearing of’ a title suit with a misc. case under a special law whether permissible? —The order for such a hearing has been made on no grounds other than mentioning ends of justice— This expression recognizes powers inherently possessed by the Court to do justice in a given case —It must not be supposed that the Court can in disregard of the established principles and norms of law make an order —The aim ol the special proceeding is speedy remedy— A grievance in such procedure cannot be tagged with any other proceeding —Title suit is pending in a separate forum and is governed by separate provisions of law—These two proceedings cannot be heard together — The title suit being a later proceeding was rightly stayed—Shilpa Bank Order. 1972 (P.O. No. 129 of 1972), Article. 33; Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 (V of) 1908), S. 151.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Bangladesh Shilpa Bank Vs. Bangladesh Hotels Limited, 6 BLD (AD) 49.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—10</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The only issue is that the House Rent Controller is required to see whether the petitioner has deposited the rent in accordance with the provision of the House Rent Control Ordinance—He is not required to decide anything with regaid to default in payment of rent—The question whether the petitioner is a defaulter or not is to be decided in the suit for ejectment and the finding of the House Rent Controller on the point of default will have no binding effect on the S.C.C. Judge while deciding the suit on merit—Petitioner is required to move first the trial Court for stay of all further proceedings—Points of issue before the House Rent Controller and the S.C.C. Judge being distinct and different no question of stay arises—Prayer for stay rejected.— Premises Rent Control Ordinance, 1986 (XXII of 1986), S. 19.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Sheikh Mohd. Salimullah Vs. Shafiqul Alam, 10 BLD (HCD) 438.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 42 DLR (HCD) 140; 4BLD (AD)8; 1 B.C.R.(HCD)450;23 DLR (HCD) 113—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—10</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">The, principle of consolidation—implication of—”shall not proceed in any suit,” —intention of the words.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The princip1 of consolidation implies that similarity or identity of the matter in issue in different suits by the same parties should be decided by the Court once for all. The object of consolidation is to avoid multiplicity of litigations between the same parties whenever the matter in issue is substantially or directly the same. The High Court Division in appropriate cases should interfere with the order of the subordinate Court refusing to consolidate suits as the principle of consolidation in no way conflicts with the purpose of section 10 of the Code of Civil Procedure.
