On the contrary, it ‘preserves and promotes it. Certain meaning of statute must not be imputed to the legislature to create situation leading to an absurd result and offending against common sense. On the contrary, it is the duty of the judiciary to give, as far as possible, an interpretation of law which inspires confidence in all responsible manners.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The words, ‘shall not proceed occurring in any suit” in section 10 C.P.C. are intended to bar separate trial -of any suit in which the matter in issue was also directly and substantially in issue in the previously instituted suit by the same parties in the same Court. But those words do not apply to simultaneous hearing of later and earlier suits after consolidation of the two suits inasmuch as the matter in issue in both the suits being directly and substantially the same.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Rezaul Karim Vs. Jahanara Begum, 11 BLD (HCD) 228.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—10</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Claim for dower and maintenance is within the exclusive jurisdiction of the Family Court—Stay of subsequent suit—Application of section 10 of the Code of Civil Procedure in a Suit in the Family Court—Pending cases relating to matters within the exclusive jurisdiction of the Family Court shall continue in that Court.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Claim for dower and maintenance was within the exclusive jurisdiction of the Family Court and the claim for recovery of value of gold ornaments and personal belongings was not within the exclusive jurisdiction of that Court. Since part of the claim was within the exclusive jurisdiction of the Family Court, the suit filed by the plaintiff-opposite party in the Family Court was maintainable as there was no bar in filing the suit in that Court.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Under section 10 of the Code of Civil Procedure, the subsequent suit can be stayed. Under the provision of section 20 of the Family Court Ordinance, section 10 and 11 of the Code shall apply in respect of a suit in the Family Court.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Pending cases in any Court other than the Family Court relating to and arising out of the matters within the exclusive jurisdiction of the Family Court shall continue in that Court and shall be heard and disposed of by that Court. There is no bar under the said provision to withdrew or discontinue a pending case from any other Court and in filing a fresh t in the Family Court for the self-same relief ct The provision is to save the pending cases in any Court other than the Family Cwt relating to matters within the exclusive jurisdiction of the Family Court and not to bar a suit or a case to be filed and entertained by Family Court for the self-same claim.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Abdur Rahman Vs. Shahanara Begum, 11 BLD (HCD) 329.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section -10</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Preceding under a special law and ordinary—Further proceedings of suit under ordinary law, whether may be stayed on the ground of self-same subject-matter and par ties in the two kinds of proceedings.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The proceedings under a special law are different in nature and are not to be tagged with proceedings under any other ordinary law. It does not matter which one was instituted first. The special proceedings under the special law (P.O. No. 129 of 1972) shall proceed independently under the provisions of that special law, no matter whether there is any other pending proceeding under any other ordinary law instituted earlier or later than the special proceeding.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">On the ground of self-same subject matter and parties in the two kinds of proceedings, further proceedings of the suit under the ordinary law may be stayed, but not vice versa. A subsequent suit filed under the ordinary law and an earlier miscellaneous case filed under a special law do not stand on the same footing. Therefore, section 10 C.P.C. cannot have any application in the case of two proceedings of different nature.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Ahmed Silk Mills Ltd. Vs. Bangladesh Shilpa Bank, 11 BLD (HCD) 398.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—11</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Res-judicata</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Two suits (title suit and partition suit) heard analogously and disposed of b’ one judgment—Appeal against the decree of partition suit only—Whether the decision in The title suit operates as res-jutdicata?</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Application of the doctrine of res-judicata to a suit or appeal preferred therefrom is dependent on the nature of the. Suits and the common issues framed in the suits. If the suits are connected and the issues framed therein are also common so as to constitute virtually a single suit on the issues, in such a case the decree not appealed from will not operate as res-judicata.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">But when the issue decided in the title suit was not directly and substantially in issue in the partition suit, the decision on the question of title in the title suit operates as a res judicata. The decision on the question of title given in the title suit could not be collaterally attacked in the appeal from the decree in partition suit.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Res judicata—Appilcation of the doctrine</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The doctrine of res judicata, so far as it relates to prohibiting retrial of an issue, refers not to the date of commencement of the suit but to the time when the Judge is called upon to decide the issue. The rule is not limited to the Court of the first instance, but it also applies to the proceedings of the first and second appellate Courts. The main object of the doctrine is to prevent multiplicity of suits and interminable disputes between litigants.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Mokarram Ali and others Vs. Abdul Sama and others; 1 BLD (AD) 221.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. A.I.R. 1927 (Lah) 289; (1951) SCR 178;37C.L.J. 184;11A11148;33A1151;29 Mad 333; 29 Mad 195; 15 Born 104; 7 PLR (Dac) 209—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—11</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Plaintiff claimed title by exchange from the same person against whom the defendant obtained an expert decree for specific performance of contract—Plaintiff attempted to set aside such ex-parte decree in a proceeding under Order 9 Rule 13 C.P.C. but failed— Plaintiffs suit for declaration of title and possession was barred by res judicata.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Aiim Mahmmad Vs. Tamizuddin, 4 BLD (HCD) 71.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—11</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Res judicata</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Whether the decision regarding possession in the suit for permanent injunction could be resjudicata in a suit for title and possession—The appellate Court was correct in decreeing the suit holding that the previous suit would not operate as resjudicata and the High Court Division in dismissing the revisional application has not committed any illegality.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Md. Danesh Vs. Md. Kala Meak and others, 5 BLD (AD) 275.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 18C.W.N.545; 7DLR6; 27DLR 541; 46C.W.N.20; 34 Allahabad 172—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—11</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Res-judicata</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The question that was decided in the present suit for title was already decided in the former redemption suits—Chandrabala wanted to be impleaded as co-plaintiff and share the fruits of redemption but her prayer was rejected—The Suits were decreed for redemption against the heirs of the mortgagee in presence of Chandrabala—The decision in those suits would not operate as res-judicata in the present suit.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Harida Ranjan Das Vs. Nihar Bala Das and others; 5 BLD (HCD) 274.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. PLD 1967(SC) 559; A.I.R. 1956 Madras 428; PLD 1967(SC) 527—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—11</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Res judicata—Whether suit for title is barred by res-judicata in view of the decree in money suit</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">After the defendants succeeded in establishing that plaintiffs were their brothers in respect of the suit land, it follows without saying that the defendants were the owners— it cannot be held that the question . to right, title and interest of the suit land was merely incidentally looked into in the money suit so that a fresh look at the same question can be given in the present suit—Different phraseology adopted by the plaintiffs cannot obliterate the effect of the decision on the point in the previous money Suit.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Abdullah Talukder, being dead his heirs: Azahar Au Tahkder and others Vs. Khaja Mahtabuddin, being dead his heirs: Mst. Sakina Bonn and others; 6 BLD (AD) 194.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—11</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Ex-parte decree and res-judicata— V hether ex-parte decision in a former suit between the parties over the same matter 14 ill operate as res-judicata.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Whether the defendants are estopped from raising the same question over again in the subsequent suit?— In the former suit the issue regarding acquisition of customary right of pasturage over the suit land by the plaintiffs was raised and finally decided though the suit was decreed expert —The decision of the former suit will operate as res judicata — The decree-even if ex-parte will operate as res-judicata —In the absence of fraud the ex-parte decree is binding.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Bangladesh Vs. Rahimuddin Mollah and others, 7 BLD (HCD) 307.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. A.I.R. 1971(SC)665; A.LR. 1969 4SC) 971; A.I.R. 1947 (Allahabad) 147; 10 DLR 523—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—11</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Res judicata</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Adverse finding against the defendant when the suit dismissed —Whether will operate as res-judicata in a subsequent suit — General principle in a subsequent suit 7 — General principle is that an adverse finding against a defendant when the suit is dismissed is not res-judicata in a subsequent suit interparties —But if the adverse finding is actually the decision in the suit and it forms a fundamental part of the decree, then it will operate as res-judicata—Adverse finding against the defendant, if made incidentally or unnecessarily while disposing a suit or made in an interlocutory order, will not operate as res-judicata.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Sachindra Lal Das and others Vs. Handay Ranjan Das being dead his heirs Bimal Kanti Das &amp; others, 8 BLD (AD) 14.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. AIR. 1959 (Ker) 56; 42 C.W.N. l; 42 C.W.N. 1065; 57 C.W.N. 707; A.I.R. 1922(PC) 241; A.I.R. 1929 (All) 910; 18 I.L.R.(Cal)647; A.I.R. 1919; 27 (PC) 252; AIR. 1967 (J &amp; K) 85; A.I.R. 1929 Cal 449; 53 I.L.R. (PC) 103; A.I.R. 1931 (PC) 231— Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—11</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Res-judicata</span></strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">—<strong>What constitutes its essential part?</strong></span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It is the subject matter in issue and not the subject-matter of the suit that forms the essential part of res-judicata—The subject matter of two suits may be different, object of the suits, the relief asked for and the cause of action may also be different but if the matter in issue in them be identical, then the principle of res-judicata will have its application.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Nasim Ali and another Vs. Safina Bibi, 8 BLD (HCD) 439.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—11</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Res judicata—When the principle comes into play?</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The contention that the earlier Suit between the parties on the same subject matter was for mete declaration of title whereas the instant suit is for declaration of title and recovery of possession and that the earlier suit was dismissed in the absence of any prayer for recovery of possession and as such the decree in that suit does not operate as resjudicata in the present suit has no substance— The view taken by the High Court Division that the plaintiff failed to prove the totality of his case, including his title and that the present suit is therefore barred by the principle of resjudicata is correct.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Hafizuddin Sarker and Lakjan Bewa beign. dead their heirs: Nur Hossain and others Vs. Bangladesh and others; 9 BLD (AD) 164</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 6 DLR Page 1—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—11</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Res-judicata</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Application of the principle with regard to interlocutory order of the same proceeding—The principle applies as between two stages of the same litigation to this extent that a Court having at an earlier stage decided a matter in one way will not allow the parties to re-agitate the matter at a subsequent stage of the proceeding.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Md. Enzdaduddin Sk. Vs. Atiqur Rahman and others, 9 BLD (HcD, 253</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref AIR 1987(Ker) 156 25DLR461 A.1.R. 1960 (SC) 941—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—11</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Bar of res-judicata and writ proceedings</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Extent of applicability of the principle in writ proceedings—The bar of res-judicata is applicable in writ proceedings on the general principle that the public interest requires that there should be an end to litigation and that a person should not b vexed twice in respect of the same subject matter—It will however depend on the facts of each case whether issues in the present proceeding were raised or could have been raised in the previous proceeding and whether the issues raised were earlier decided on merits— Constitution of Bangladesh. 1972, Art. 102; Evidence Act, 1872 (lof 1872). Ss. 13 and 43.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Dr Syed Matiur Rob being dead his heirs Shamsun Nahar and others Vs. Bangladesh and others, 1O BLD (AD) 52.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. PLDI968 (Dhaka) 367; PLD 1968 (SC) 185; PLD1967 (SC) 569; 1969 S.C. M.R. 283: A.LR. 1961 (SC) 1457; 9 BLD (AD) 135—Cited</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—11</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Res-judicata—When the principle is applicable?</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Mere showing that a matter was directly and substantially in issue in the former and subsequent suits or proceedings is not enough to attract the operation of the principle of res judicata—It has to be shown that a common issue has been heard and finally decided by the Court in earlier suit or proceeding.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Ayezuddin Sheik and others Vs. Md. Abdul Karim Sheik and others: 10 BLD (HCD) 139.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 22DLR (SC) 102; A.J.R. 1957 (Cal) 242 —Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—11</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Res-judicata</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Res-judicata cannot be pleaded in view of the decision in the case of Dwarkanath Mandal and another Vs. Sri Gobinda Chowdhury, A.I.R. 1929 (Cal) 130.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Marida Begum and others Vs. Moulvi Md. Hasan and others; 1O BLD (HCD) 334.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—11</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Res judicata</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Amendment of plaint sought to the effect that the decree made in Title Suit No. 5 of 1959 arising out of a revenue sale dated 25.9.45 was null and void—Petitioners were not impleaded in the title suit in their personal capacity but in their representative capacity as heirs of the original tenant who defaulted in payment of rent— Whether a legal representative of a previous suit in representative capacity can subsequently raise objection in individual capacity —Whether such amendment is hit by the principle of res-judicata?</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Where in a previous suit a party .of a subsequent suit was impleaded in the previous suit in his representative capacity as an heir of original tenant, it was not open to him to raise any defence in his personal capacity, he can subsequently raise objection and his hereditary nature in the former suit does not operate as res-judicata.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Kutub Uddin Bhuiyan and others Vs. Sakhina Bibi and others, 11 BLD (HCD) 33.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: A.I.R. 1947 (PC) 1; .A.1.R. 1925 (Mad) 59—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—11</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Res judicata by implication</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">To constitute res judicata, whether it is enough that the parties and the matter in issue m both the proceedings are the same — whether a final decision, even without a decree operates as res-judicata?</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In order to constitute res judicata it is not enough that the parties are the same and the same matter is directly and substantially in Issue in both the suits or proceedings, but the important condition is that the matter must have been heard and finally decided in the f4rmer suit or proceeding. There can be a bar of res judicata if there is an executable judgment. A final decision, whether right or wrong operates as res judicata even though no decree is drawn up. It is not necessary that there should be express finding on the issue in question where a question has been necessarily decided in effect though not in explicit term. When a question is decided by necessary implication, it would also operate as res judicata—But where issue is left untouched and undecided, bar of res judicata will not operate.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Refazuddin Mondal Vs. Abdul Razzaque alias Rezaul Karirn and others, 11 BLD (HCD) 256.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—11</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Res-judicata</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Claim for dower and maintenance is within the exclusive jurisdiction of the Family Court—Principle of res judicata—Application of section II of the Code of Civil Procedure in a suit in the Family Court—Pending cases relating to matters within the exclusive jurisdiction of the Family Court shall continue in that Court.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Claim for dower and maintenance was within the exclusive jurisdiction of the Family Court and the claim for recovery of value of gold ornaments and personal belongings was not-within the exclusive jurisdiction of that Court: Since part of the claim was within the exclusive jurisdiction of the Family Court, the suit filed by the plaintiff-opposite party in the Family Court was maintainable as there was no bar in filing the suit in that Court.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Under section 11 of the Code of Civil Procedure, the decision in one case will be binding in other case on the principle of res judicata. Under the provisions of the section 20 of the Ordinance, Sections 10 and II of the Code shall apply in respect of a suit in the Family Court.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Pending cases in any Court other than the Family Court relating to and arising out of the matters within the exclusive jurisdiction of the Family Court shall continue in that Court and shall be heard and disposed of by that Court. There is no bar under the said provision to withdraw or discontinue a pending case from any other Court and in filing a fresh suit in the Family Court for the self-same relief. The provision is to, save the pending cases in any Court other than the Family Court relating to matters within the exclusive jurisdiction of the Family Court and not to bar a suit or a-case to be filed and entertained by the Family Court for the self-same claim.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Abdur Rahman Vs. Shahanara Begum; 11 BLD (HCD) 329.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—11</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Res-judicata when not attracted?</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Plaintiff-petitioner a filed title suit earlier against third party for declaration of title to a portion of land covered by the deed of Hiba-bil-Ewaj and for eviction of the defendant of that suit in which his sister-defendants were impleaded as Performa defendants along with others—Suit decreed on contest against the principal defendant and expert against the rest including his sister-defendants—Whether former suit operates as resjudicata?</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The entire issue involving the Hiba-bil-Ewaj is not res-judicata between the parties</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Abdur Sattar Mir Vs. Morium Bibi, 12 BLD (AD) 296.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Sections—15 and 16</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Venue of trial</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Every suit shall be instituted in the Court of the lowest grade competent to try it. Suits to be instituted where subject- matter is situated.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Md. Mansur Ali Vs. Janata Bank and others, 11 BLD (HCD) 23.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—16</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Territorial jurisdiction of a Court— When its bar may be waived?</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The learned Munsif assumed jurisdiction bonafide out of a situation which was fraught with confusion— When a Court having the same pecuniary jurisdiction assumes jurisdiction under such circumstances the bar of territorial jurisdiction may be waived and a decree passed by the assuming Court may be left undisturbed—Such treatment shall by no means be construed as a farewell to the importance of the concept of territorial jurisdiction.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Mst. Rahela Khatun and others. Vs. Saraj Sarkar &amp; another, 4 BLD (HCD) 24.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—20</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Place of suing</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Bank Guarantee</span></strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">—Place of payment not specified—Common Law rule that debtor must seek the creditor does not apply—Suit for the enforcement of the bank guarantee lies at the place where it was executed and issued or at the place of refusal to honor it—Contract Act. 1872 (1X of 1872), S. 49.</span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Janata Bank Vs. Shyampur Sugar Mills Ltd. and others; 1 BLD (HCD) 248.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. C.A. 20 of 1978 (unreported) ; A.I.R. 1961 (Cal) 321; PLD 1956 Lah 341—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—20</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Territorial Jurisdiction—Question of</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Whether a case filed in a Court which had territorial jurisdiction at the time of filing the case could be disposed of by that Court even after the said Court subsequently was divested of such territorial jurisdiction—Transfer of the territory did not affect the vested jurisdiction in a case pending at the time of the transfer—The District Judge, Comilla did not lose his jurisdiction vested with the District Judge, Chandpur on and from 1.9.1984.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Razzaque Tapadar Vs. Taher Hossain Rusdi, 5 BLD (HD) 214.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. AJ.R. 1943(FC) 24; AIR. 1950 (Hydrabad) 71—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—20(b)</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Return of Plaint</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">When one of the defendants has its Zonal Office at Commilla the plaintiff was required to obtain leave of the Court at Comilla before filing the suit at Comilla—The cause of action for the short delivery of goods having arisen at Chittagong, the Court at Comilla has no jurisdiction to try the suit.—Moreover, documents of defendant No. 2 being at Chittagong and the witnesses to depose being from Chittagong it is proper that the suit be tried at Chittagong Court—Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 (V of 1908), Or. 7 Rule 10(i).</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Islam and Co. Vs. Sarma Chemical Works Ltd; 6 BLD (HCD) 23.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 39 C.W.N. 174—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—20</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Local limits of jurisdiction</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">When leave to sue outside a Court’s local limit units of jurisdiction is not accorded— Such leave cannot be granted on mere asking of the plaintiff and it can only be granted in the judicial exercise of Court’s discretion— Considering the facts and circumstances of the case the Court finds that all the relevant evidence will be available outside the present place of suing and it will cause undue delay and harassment to defendant No. 2 who also represents defendant No. 1 on whom lies the main responsibility for the alleged loss or short delivery of goods—If the plaintiff can establish its claim against them then liability of other defendants will arise— So leave to sue defendant Nos. 1 and 2 in Dhaka Court (when evidence will be available in Chittagong and Chalna) canot be granted. —Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 (V of 1908), Or. 7, R. 10.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Bangladesh Agricultural Development Corporation Vs. Moxey Seven (Chartering) Limited and others, 1O BLD (HCD) 100.</em></strong></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
1142	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">CODE OF CIVIL PROCEDURE, 1908 [SECTION 100 - 150]</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  4 BLD (AD) 15, 5 BLD (AD) 172, 5 BLD (AD) 333, 5 BLD (HCD) 37, 6 BLD (HCD) 63, 7 BLD (AD) 288, 8 BLD (AD) 6, 9 BLD (HCD) 351, 10 BLD (HCD) 92,  11 BLD (HD) 259, 11 BLD (HCD) 405, 12 BLD (AD) 195, 12 BLD (AD) 203, 12 BLD (AD) 271, 12 BLD (HCD) 17, 1 BLD (</p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  1908</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  CIVIL PROCEDURE</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"><br/> </span></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">CODE OF CIVIL PROCEDURE, 1908<span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></span></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"><br/> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—100</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Practice and Procedure</span></strong> —Question of reassessment of evidence—When the appellate Court reversed the findings of fact without taking notice of the documentary evidence, the second appellate Court may reassess the evidence and come to its own finding on the point— Misreading of the judgment of the Courts below has led the High Court Division to an erroneous conclusion which requires reversal.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>SK. Abdul Latif and another Vs. Abdul Malek Kazi and others, 4 BLD (AD) 15.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 19D.L.R. 912—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section— 100</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Comparison of hand-writing and signature by the Court</span></strong>—whether conclusion arrived at by comparison of handwriting or signature by the Courts below can be interfered with by the High Court Division in second appeal? —Comparison of signature with admitted signatures is a question of fact—High Court Division is not to interfere with the conclusion of the first appellate Court on such question— Comparison of signature is a perfectly legal mode of proving hand-writing and however inconclusive such proof may be it cannot be considered as an error of law to base a conclusion on such proof alone— High Court Division in second appeal is not competent to set aside a finding based on such comparison—Evidence Act, 1 872 (I of 1872), S. 73.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Abdul Matin Chowdhury Vs. Chapala Rani Sen and others, 5 BLD (AD) 172.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—100</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Jurisdiction in Second appeal</span></strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">—The learned single Judge restored the trial Court’s judgment without disturbing the lower appellate Court’s finding—Jurisdiction of the High Court Division in second appeal is limited question of law, that is to say, whether the finding arrived at by the lower appellate Count is based on consideration of evidence or ii is the product of any misapplication or misinterpretation of law —The single Judge is not clear as to the ground for reversing the decision of the lower appellate Court—In the circumstances the appeal should be reheard keeping in view the question of jurisdiction in second appeal.</span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Sayet Ullah Vs. Askar Ullah being dead his heirs Jamaluddin and others, 5 BLD (AD) 333.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—100</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Scope of Second appeal</span></strong>—Erroneous finding of fact is a different thing from an error or defect in procedure—There is no jurisdiction to entertain a second appeal on the ground of erroneous finding of fact, however gross and inexcusable the error may seem to be.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Abdul Gani Sonar Vs. Kinjor Uddin Sonar, 5 BLD (HCD) 37.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. A.I.R. 1963(SC) 902—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—100</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Finding of fact Whether can be interfered in second appeal</span></strong>—The High Courts Division in second appeal can interfere with a finding of fact only on the ground of an error of law or substantial error or defect in the procedure and as such finding of fact as to possession based on consideration of evidence on record cannot be interfered with in second appeal.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Doctor S.M. Amjad Hossain and others Vs. Ekias Au Mollah, 6 BLD (HCD) 63.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—100</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Finding of fact—power to interfere</span></strong> — High Court Division’s power to interfere with finding of fact—It should not make interference on the ground that upon the documents and evidence placed before the lower Court, the High Court Division would have come to a different conclusion.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Sudhir Chandra Sil and another Vs. Hahi Mohan Das &amp; ors., 7 BLD (AD) 288.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 3ODLR (SC)236; 35DLR(AD)2 16 = 3BLD(AD)342; 38 DLR(AD) 22; A.I.R. 191 8(PC) 92—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—100</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Finding of fact</span></strong>—High Court Division’s power in second appeal to disturb finding of fact—A finding of fact to attain immunity from attack in second appeal must be based on evidence—A finding based on inadequate of evidence on which no reasonable conclusion can be reached can be interfered with— Misreading of evidence is a ground for interference but misappreciation of evidence is not—A finding inconsistent with the evidence calls for interference—If a decision of the lower appellate Court consists of oral and documentary evidence but part of the documentary evidence is misunderstood, it will not provide a ground for interference when the document does not form the preponderance of the evidence—High Court Division’s power does not include power to review the evidence to come to a finding of its own—It can give a finding not given by the lower appellate Court on the evidence on record.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Md. Naimuddin Sarder alias Namuddin Sardar Vc. Md. Abul Kalam Biswas alias Md. Abut Kalain Basiruddin alias Abdul Kalam Azad and another, 8 BLD (AD) 6.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 3 BLD (AD) 342.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—100</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Finding of fact</span></strong>—When binding upon High Court Division? —Finding of facts arrived at by the lower appellate Court is binding upon the High Court Division if the former had before it sufficient evidence for consideration— The High Court Division in second appeal shall not set aside such findings although it may arrive at different findings of its own on assessment of evidence on record—There is no jurisdiction to entertain a second appeal on the ground of erroneous finding of fact although the error may seem to be gross or inexcusable.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Nur Mohammad and another Vs. Sultan Ahmed and another, 9 BLD (HCD) 351.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 17 DLR (SC) 47—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—100</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Finding of fact</span></strong> —When such finding cannot be interfered in second appeal— Finding of fact of the first appellate Court is final if the finding is based on proper evidence —Erroneous finding of fact is a different thing from an error or defect in the procedure—There is no jurisdiction to entertain a second appeal on the ground of erroneous finding however gross or inexcusable it may seem to be.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Nazir Ahmed and others Vs. Hazee Md. Kalu, 10 BLD (HCD) 92.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 17DLR (SC)47; 17 Indian Appeals 122—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—100</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Finding of the first appellate Court</span></strong> — In what circumstances to be rejected in second appeal? —Person in possession, whether should have actual physical contact?</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">If the finding of the first appellate Court cannot be supposed on the evidence on record, or if it has failed to take into account a material piece of evidence or if it does not reveal a logical basis for differing from the finding of the trial Court or is otherwise found to be arbitrary or capricious, it will have to be rejected in second appeal.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It is not necessary that the person possessing should have actual physical contact, it is enough if it is open and competent to him to assume such relationship with it, whenever he might chose. The physical-relation must be such as to enable him to control the use of the material object in question.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Muhammad Badsha Miáh and others Vs. Soleman Nessa Bibi and others, 11 BLD (HD) 259.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 21 DLR(SC) 448; 35DLR (AD) 216; 37DLR(AD) 205; 38DLR (AD) 201 (232); 21 DLR(SC) 450:—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—100</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Occasioning failure of Justice</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The term “occasioning failure of justice”, whether has a far reaching significance? — The plaintiff whether must not make the plaintiff whether must not make departure from pleading embodied in the plaint?</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The term ‘occasioning failure of justice” has a far reaching significance. It invests the High Court Division with wide power not only to go into the question of law but also to the question of fact, in search of fact and to make scrutiny and analyse and if necessary to assess evidence for itself for its own satisfaction, to see to what extent such failure of justice has been perpetrated.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The plaintiff must not make any departure from the earlier pleadings made in the plaint to bring into existence any new claim or raise any new ground or plea which are quite inconsistent, incongruous or a departure from the earlier stand or pleas. The Court will not allow either party from making any departure from the earlier pleadings set forth in the plaint or written statements. Plaint and written statement are the foundation of the claim of the plaintiff and the defendant; any deviation from the earlier stand would surely land the other side into serious dislocation and by Order 6 Rule 7 of the Code of Civil Procedure, the same has been prohibited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Bangladesh Vs. Md. Aslam and others, 11 BLD (HCD) 405.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref; 34 DLR278; 3ODLR(SC)4 1—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—100</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Judgment of reversal</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Lower appellate Court did not discuss evidence on record regarding possession— Whether can be interfered with?</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It is clear that the lower appellate Court did not discuss the evidence on record with regard to possession and, therefore, its abrupt finding that the plaintiff had failed to prove his possession was rightly interfered with by the High Court Division, more so when the trial Courts finding on possession was arrived on the basis of evidence on record.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Shangsharer Nessa and others Vs. Matiur Rahman &amp; others, 12 BLD (AD) 195.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—100</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Misreading and non-reading of evidence</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The High Court Division’s power to interfere with the findings of facts of the first appellate Court is limited to misreading and non-reading of material evidence and non- consideration of important documents affecting the merit of the decision. In all other cases findings of fact arrived at by the lower appellate Court, which are supported by evidence on record, are immune from attack in second appeal.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Fazlur Ali Tendal Vs. Fazal Miah and others, 12 BLD (AD) 203.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—100</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Second appeal</span></strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">—Whether the High Court Division in second appeal on proper appreciation of oral and documentary evidence on record correctly affirmed the findings .of fact of the lower appellate Court which reversed the finding of the trial Court.</span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Thus the lower appellate Court completely missed the real issue and the High Court Division too failed to locate the central locus of the plaintiff’s case. The lower appellate Court proceeded to decide the case of patta, touzi, bakizai and dakhilas. Little realising that the superstructure cannot stand without foundation.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Musa Au Vs. Nur Ahmed and’others, 12 BLD (AD) 271.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—103</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">When the lower appellate Court’s judgment is vitiated, whether the usual course for the High Court is to send back the case on remand or to make on exercise under section 103 of the Code of Civil Procedure.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">When the lower appellate Court’s judgment is vitiated by misreading or misappreciation of evidence, the usual course for the High Court Division is not to send back the case on remand to the Court below but to make an exercise under section 103 of the Code of Civil Procedure on a fresh examination by itself of the evidence on record.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Asiruddin Mondal Vs. Moeyzuddin Gachee, 12 BLD (HCD) 17.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 36 DLR (AD) 261; 28 DLR (AD) 85— Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Sections—104 and 105</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Interlocutory Order</span></strong>—Such orders can be challenged in appeal against the decree, but once appeal or revision is filed against such order and a finality reaches, such orders cannot be challenged in appeal against the decree —Position is not altered even though the appeal is dismissed as being barred by limitation.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Md. Yusuf Vs. Mofzal Ahmed Sowdagar, 1 BLD (AD) 456.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: I.L.R. 1940 Mad 901—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—104</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Probate proceeding and interlocutory orders</span></strong>—Interlocutory order passed by the District Judge is appeal able only if C.P. Code makes it an appealable order.—Succession Act, 1925 (XXXIX of 1925), S. 299.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Dhirendra Chandra Bardhan Vs. Sm. Nirod Sundari Bardhan and others, 1 BLD (HCD) 243.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 1894 I.L.R. (Cal)539; 18C.L.J. 612; I 6C.W.N. I 09; 281.C.578; A.I.R. 1920(Cal) 459;A.I.R. 1 926(Cal) 180; AIR. 1929(Cal) 733; A.I.R1932 (Cal) 734; A.I.R. 1942 Born 276; A.I.R.l963 (Ker) 188; A.I.R.1965 (All)21 1; A.I.R.1930(Oudh)424—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—104</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Attachment before judgment— Appeal</span></strong>—An order rejecting an application under Order 38 Rule 5 is not an appealable order under Order 43 Rule I (q).—Code of Civil Procedure. 1908, (V of 1908), Order 38 Rule 5. Order 43 Rule (l)q).</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Messrs R. Ahmed and sons Vs. Messrs Eastern Technique and others, 1 BLD (HCD) 67.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—107</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">When the appellate Court justified in reversing finding of fact arrived at by the trial Court ?</span></strong> When there is conflict of oral evidence and credibility of the witnesses, then unless there is some special feature about the evidence of a particular witness which has escaped the trial judge’s notice, or there is sufficient balance of improbability to displace his opinion as to where the credibility lies, the appellate Court should not interfere with the finding of the trial Judge on question of fact.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Badruddin Khan Vs. Bangladesh and another, 4 BLD (AD) 107.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. A.I.R.1960 (SC) 115; Ch.704; A.I.R. 1951 (SC) 120—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—107</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Remand</span></strong>—Plea of remand to scrutinize correctness of registration—It was argued that evidence was not scrutinized by the appellate Court below to come to the finding that the registration having been done in 1975 it will be presumed under the provision of the Registration Act that the registration was done in accordance with law and the requirement of law was fulfilled—It is a rebuttable presumption—Registration Act (XVI of 1908) S. 60.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Additional Deputy Commissioner (Revenue) and Asstt. Custodian, Vested Property, Chandpur Vs. Mosammat Tafurennessa and others, 9BLD(AD) 120</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 33 DLR(AD) 30; 29(All) 184 (P.C.); 17(All)l 12 (P.C.)—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—107</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order of remand</span></strong>—Such order when need not be passed for curing the defect of non-appointment of guardian for minors — The provision for appointment of guardian for minors is mandatory but it seems that it has been too broadly stated by the learned Judge that non-compliance with the rule will render the whole proceeding a nullity even if it is found that such non-compliance has not virtually prejudiced the defence of the minor in any way—The order of remand would serve no purpose except to allow undergoing a formal’ ritual of the observance of the Rule which will have no practical bearing on the adjudication of the matter—Code of Civil Procedure, 1908(V of 1908) Or. 32 Rule 3.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Sukumar Sen and others Vs. Guranga Bejoy Dey and others, 9 BLD (AD) 169.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—107</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Power of the appellate Court</span></strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">—Power to accord leave to .proceed with suit—The Court has the same powers as is exercisable by the Court below and can accord leave for proceeding with a suit in respect of defendants having head office outside the Cour(s jurisdiction.</span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Bangladesh Agricultural Development Corporation Vs. Moxey Seven Chartering Limited and others; 10 BLD 100</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. AIR. 1961 (Rajsthan) 187; AIR. 1969 (Bombay) 368—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—115</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">District Judge has no revisional jurisdiction over a matter over which he has no appellate jurisdiction.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A Court which cannot exercise jurisdiction over a matter in appeal is not intended to exercise its revisional jurisdiction. It is inconsistent with scheme of the Code of Civil Procedure and the Civil Courts Act to invest the District Judge with concurrent revisional jurisdiction in matters where no appeal lies before the District Judge. The District Judges national jurisdiction under section 115(2) is restricted by his appellate jurisdiction as provided under section 21(1) of the Civil Courts t —Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 (V of i9O8). Ss. 6, 96 and Order 43 Rule 1; Civil Courts Act, 1887 (XII of 1887), Ss. 3, 6, 7, 18, 19, 20 and 21.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Nurul Islam and others Vs. Md. Abdur Rashid, 1 BLD (HCD) 25.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—115</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Revisional jurisdiction</span></strong>—District Judge exercises revisional jurisdiction under section 115(2) in respect of those cases where the value of the subject—matter .does not exceed Tk. 20,000/- In all other cases it is the High Court Division which exercises the jurisdiction under section 1 15(l)—Civil Courts Act, 1887(XII of 1887), Ss. 3, 6,7, 8, 18, 19, 20 and 21.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Messrs R. Ahmed and sons. Vs. Messrs Eastern Technique and others, 1 BLD (HCD) 67.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—115</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Revision before District Judge: Court fee</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">This appears to be a new provision as contained in section 115(2) of the Code. The legislature did not make appropriate provisioi3 in the Court-Fees Act in that behalf. This indicates that it was not intended by the legislature to impose any special fee on application for revision before the District Judge under section 115(2) of the Code. The appropriate Court fee on such application is. Tk. 1/-. as prescribed by Article I of Schedule II of the Court-Fees Act—Court Fees Act, I 870( VII of 1870). Schedule I, Art, 13A and Schedule II, Art. 1.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Messrs R. Ahmed and sons Vs. Messrs .Eastern Technique and others, 1 BLD (HCD) 67.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—115</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Civil revision—Parties can affect compromise in revision?</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A revisional application is a prescribed mode of step in the Code either in prosecution or in defence of an action and as such the procedure provided for in the Code shall also apply to civil revision including the provision for compromise on the strength of section 141 of the Code of Civil Procedure provided that the revisional application arises out of a suit, appeal or original miscellaneous case or appeal there from to which the procedure provided in the Code would apply.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The Court for the ends of justice may record compromise under section 151 of the Code where the revisional application having not arisen out of ar original miscellaneous proceeding where the provision of Order 23 Rule 3 of the Code does not apply. Civil Procedure, 1908 (V of 1908), Ss 141 and 151 and Order 23 Rule 3.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Serajul Mostafa Vs. Ali Ahmed Sikder and others, 1 BLD (HCD) 80.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref AIR 1949 (Lah) 186 I8CLJ 141b A.LR.1949. (Mad) 433; A.1.R. 1953 (Raj) 189: A I R 1946 (Born) 201—Cited</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—115</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Necessary findings may be made by the Court of revision</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">If the Courts below failed to determine a material issue, the revisional Court may determine the issue and record necessary findings.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Anwara Begum Vs. Maimuna Khatun Chowdhury and others, 1 BLD (HCD) 121.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—115</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Revision—finding of fact</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In revisieia1 jurisdiction the High Court Division exercises a very limited jurisdiction on the question of finding of fact, whether concurrent or otherwise.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Bidur Chandra Majumder Vs. Oil Mia and another, 1 BLD (HCD) 328</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 28 DLR (AD) 57; 29DLR (AD)268; 31 DLR(AD) 123—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—115</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Additional issues</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Trial Court omits to incorporate them in the judgment and give necessary finding— Ael1ate Court’s failure to consider the same</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">and record findings on the issues is an error of law apparent on the face of record—Case remanded to the trial Court—Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 (V of 1908)Or. 20, R. 5.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Mst. Sahera Khatun Vs. Mrs. Anwara Khatun and others. 2 BLD (HCD) 60.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—115</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Issues of fact</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Their determination in interlocutory matters—Finding on . such issues without hearing the opposite party cannot be sustained—Summary disposal of a petition at the first he4ring admits of no scope for varying the order complained against the interest of the other party.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Faruk Ahmed Vs. Nurul Azim and others, 3 BLD (AD) 106.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—115</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Direction for disposal of suit without disposal of appeal</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Direction for dispose of the suit without disposal of the appeal is not authorized in law. The law warrants issuance of a Rule and upon hearing the parties necessary orders could be passed.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Abdur Rob Vs. Nurunnabi Bhuiyan and others, 3 BLD (AD) 108</em></strong><strong><em>.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—115 (3)</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Summary disposal of revisional application</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Upon expert ‘hearing giving relief prayed for against orders passed by the Additional District Judge is not legal.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Abu Ahmed Abdul Hafiz and others Vs. M.A. Hoque Shirajee; 3 BLD (AD) 193.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section— 115</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Revisional Court Power to make finding</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A Revisional Court is competent to make a finding on the basis of materials available in the record.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Shahidur Rahinan Molla and others Vs. Abdul Halim Molla and others, 3 BLD (HCD) 89.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. I BLD (HCD) 121</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—115</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Revisional application—Its disposal by the High Court Division</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The order does not disclose application of mind to the facts and circumstances of the case—there is no consideration of the contentions raised by the parties in the revisional application on which the Rule was issued. The impugned judgment cannot be sustained and the order is set aside and the case is remanded back to the High Court Division for disposal in accordance with law.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Taslimuddin Ahmed Vs. Abdul Jabbar, 4 BLD (AD) 220.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—115</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Revisional power of the High Court Division</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Whether High Court Division committed an error of law in rejecting the petition for rehearing of a evil revision case disposed on merits in the absence of the petitioners—The powers of the High Court under section 115 C.P.C. are very wide—Action can be taken under this section even without application by the aggrieved party—It does not preclude the High Court Division from exercising its power of revision ‘suo motu’ if the other conditions laid down in the section are satisfied.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Darasatullah and others Vs. Manik Mondal and others, 4 BLD (AD) 234.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 28DLR (AD) 159; A.I.R.1936 (Pat) 591; A.I.R.1954 (Mad) 864 (F.B.)—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—115</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">The revisional jurisdiction of the High Court Division is discretionary</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It must be exercised not only in accordance with law but also on the grounds of uity for ends of justice.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Wasef A</em></strong><strong><em>li </em></strong><strong><em>Chowdhury and others Vs. Sekandar Rahman and others, 4BLD (HCD) 104</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—115</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Whether order of the District Judge in</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Election Tribunal Appeal is revisable by the High Court Division</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Whether the District Judge is a Court or a persona designate—District Judge is a Court when hearing Election Tribunal Appeal—The District Judge under the amended provisions of the Local Government (Union Parishads) Ordinance, 1983 is a Court and thus is amenable to the jurisdiction of the High Court Division under section 115 of the C.P.C.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Razzaque Tapadar Vs. Taher Hossain Rusdi, 5 BLD(HCD)214</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—115</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Whether revision or writ petition lies against the decision of the District Judge in election appeal?</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The District Judge under the Local Government Ordinance is a District Court subordinate to the High Court Division—Revision lies against the decision of such District Judge as the petitioners could have the same relief as have been prayed for in the writ petition. Only in exceptional cases for want of jurisdiction and ex-facie illegality writ applications are maintained inspire of alternative remedy being available—The Local Government (Union Parishad) Ordinance, 1983 (LI of 1983), S. 29(4), Constitution of Bangladesh, 1972, Article 102(2).</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>A.K.M. Ruhul Amin Vs. District Judge, Bhola and others, 5 BLD (HCD) 321.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 19 DLR (SC) 516; 27 DLR 373; 22 DLR (SC) 443—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—115</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Remand</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Remand by revisional Court when not justified?—When evidence has been led by both the parties and two Courts below arrived at conflicting findings it was the revisional Court to see whether trial Courts finding had been reversed on proper consideration of the evidence—When evidence on all materialpoints are there on record, the revisional Court is not justified in sending the case back to the Court below for reconsidering the matter—Code of Civil Procedure, 1908(V of 1908), Or.41 R.23.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Abdul Awal Khan Vs. Md.
