Sadu Mia and others, 6 BLD (AD) 156.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—115</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">District Judges power in Election Appeal</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Whether revision or writ petition lies against the decision of the District Judge in an election appeal of the District Judge in an election appeal?—If the District Judge constitutes a Court he being subordinate to the High Court Division would be amenable to its jurisdiction—If he has not been intended to be a Court, Writ jurisdiction can be invoked—District Judge as used in Article 29(4) of the Local Government (Union Parishads) Ordinance, 1983 does not mean a persona designate but clearly indicates his office, that is, District Court of which he is the presiding Judge—Court of the District Judge is subject to both appellate and revisional jurisdiction of the High Court Division—High Court Division can grant any relief to which any aggrieved party is entitled to in exercise of revisional powers against the decision of the Election Appellate Tribunal.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>A.K.M. Ruhul Ainin Vs. District Judge, Bhola and others, 6 BLD (AD) 267.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—115</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Comparison of signature and hand writing</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Whether the Court should compare the disputed signature with the admitted signatures to come to a decision—Reliance by the lower appellate Court on his own comparison of the disputed signatures disregarding and in preference to the positive evidence is highly unsatisfactory, dangerous and imprudent in a judgment of reversal and such judgment is without proper reasons and results in an error in the decision on merits occasioning a failure of justice—Evidence Act, 1872(1 of 1872), S. 74.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>SK. Ansaruddin and others Vs. (Jsha Rani Ghose, 6 BLD(HCD) 26</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. AIR. 1928 (PC) 277; A.I.R.1954 (SC)3 16; A.I.R, I 979(SC)14; 5BLD(AD) 172—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—115</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Conversion of appeal into revision</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The High Court Division in an appropriate case may treat a memorandum of an appeal as an application for revision and vice versa—The present cases are fit and proper where although the appeals are not maintainable the memorandum of appeals should be treated as applications for revision—Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 (V of 1908). Or. 43 R. 1(v).</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Moharninad Jehad Au and others Vs. Khorshed Ahmed, 6 BLD (HCD) 426.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. PLD 1961 (Dhaka) 243(244); PLD 1967 (Peshwar) 262(265)—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—115</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Findings of fact and revision by High Court Division</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Whether the High Court Division in exercise of its revisional jurisdiction can interfere with the findings of fact by the trial Court?—Whether interference from facts was correctly drawn is a question of fac(or law— Whether there was sufficient cause or not is a question of fact and whether inference from such fact had been correctly drawn is a question of law—The learned single Judge took the view that there is no evidence that there had been any flood—The conclusion of the learned Musnif that flood was the cause for the plaintiffs absence on the date of hearing was erroneous—The High Court Division rightly concluded to come to this finding— Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 (V of 1908) Or. 9 R.9.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Moulavi Abdus Sarnad Mallik Vs. Pran Gour Basak and another, 7 BLD (AD) 2.</span></em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Section—115</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Limitation—Period of limitation for filing a revisional application</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Whether Article 181 of the Limitation Act will apply—Courts power to revise an order suo motu is not restricted by any time limit. But a revisional application is to be filed within the period of 90 days—The High Court Division may in its discretion entertain an application beyond that period if there is no negligence or [aches on the part of the petitioner—Limitation Act, 1908 (V of 1908). Art. 181.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Government of the People’s Republic of Bangladesh Vs.Md. Kobad Ali and others, 7 BLD (AD) 268.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. PLD 1964 (SC) 97 = 16 DLR (SC) 155—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—115</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Revisional jurisdiction of the High Court Division</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">When interference by the High Court Division is justified’?—Revisional power is discretionary—It is to be exercised only to secure the ends of justice—The High Court Division may call for the records of a case which has been decided by any Court sub ornate to it and may make any order as it thinks fit if the subordinate Court has committed an error of law resulting in an error in decision occasioning failure of justice—primary object of this jurisdiction is to hold the ends of justice—Any and every TOC of law has not been made a ground for exercise of this power—It contemplates to cover only those errors of law which result in erroneous decision occasioning failure of justice.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Mosammet Aleya Begum and others Vs. A.M.A Mohiuddin Manik and others, 7 B</em></strong><strong><em>L</em></strong><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">D (HCD) 105.</span></em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—115</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Revisional jurisdiction</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The relief one can seek under revisional jurisdiction is a discretionary relief—If a Court has committed an error of law but that has not resulted in the decision occasioning a failure of justice, then the Court may not exercise the jurisdiction—But if there is an error of law but not substantial error and no injustice has been caused this Court may not interfere in revision.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Shahida Khanam Vs. and another Ramizuddin Ahmed Bhuiyan, 7 BLD</em></strong> <strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">(HCD) 155.</span></em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—I 15</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Finding of fact by the Court of appeal be low</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Jurisdiction of the High Court Division to interfere with the same in revision when the lower appellate Court reversed the finding of fact arrived at by the trial Court after proper consideration of the evidence on record— Whether erroneous finding of fact by the Court of appeal below is binding on the High Court Division—Jurisdiction of the High Court Division under section 115 is different from the jurisdiction under section 100 C.P. Code—Power of the High Court Division under section 115 of the Code after amendment is not circumscribed by any limitation as under section 100 of the Code— The High Court Division can in a proper and fit case set aside the finding of fact arrived at by the Court of appeal below when the said finding is contrary to the finding of the trial Court and arrived at without adverting to the reasoning that weighed with the trial Court.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Monindra Mohan Kar Vs. Randhir Dutta and others, 7 BLD (HCD) 275.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 17DLR (SC) 47; 3ODLR (SC) 81;— Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—115</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Restoration of suit on setting aside dismissal</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The Courts of law lean in favour of deciding disputes on merits—There being nothing to show that the plaintiff was negligent and harassing the defendants unnecessarily, there was no ground for interfering with the order of restoration.—Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 (V of 1908) Or. 9. R.9.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Md. Nurul Hoque Vs. Sonali Bank and another, 8 BLD (HCD) 85.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 34 Cal 403 (F.B.); 9.LC. 842; 59 Cal 756; 59 Cal 906; A.I.R.1938(Cal)74; 3OMadras274; A.I.R.l951 P.291; (1878)7 Ch. D. 878—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—115</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Ex-parte order</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ex-parte final order by the High Court Division upon an application under section 115 of the Code violates the principle of natural justice—Strong disapproval recorded for disposal of revisional application in such manner.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Sukumar Sen and others Vs. Guranga Bejoy Dey and others, 9 BLD (AD) 162.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 1984 8.C.R. (AD) 532; 3 BLD (AD) I 93—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—115</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Election Tribunal-Extent of its jurisdiction</span></strong>—Whether it is competent to pass orders of temporary injunction—Election — burial would have the powers of a Civil Court trying a suit under the Code of Civil Procedure only for decision of the matter before it and not beyond—It is not a Civil Court under the Civil Courts Act, 1887 and it is not a part of the judicial system of the country—The Tribunal was created for a limited purpose by a special law and it is under the superintendence of the executive authority—The power of transfer of an election petition is with the Election Commission and not with the District Judge. The term. ‘appellate authority’, :il1djcates that the Election Tribunal is not amenable to provisions of the Code of Civil Procedure—The appellate Tribunal also could not be considered as a Civil Court only because the appellate authority of the Tribunal has been found to be a Civil Court—True, there is incongruity if the appellate authority has one character and the Tribunal has .a different character—It is for the legislature to bring about a uniformity between the superstructure and the infrastructure of an institution—Since the Election Tribunals are not Civil Courts, they also are not amenable to the revisional jurisdiction of the High Court Division—Local Government (Union Pan- shads) Ordinance, 1983 (LI of 1983), S. 29— Union Parishad (Election) Rules, 1983, Ss. 47 and 48—Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 (V of 1908), S. 94 and Or. 39 Rules 1.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Mohmud Hussain Vs. Md. Sayeb Ali and others, 9 BLD (HCD) 173.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 27 DLR 388; 28 DLR 189; 29 DLR Ill; 38 DLR (AD) 172; 37 DLR 71; 38 DLR 41; 38DLR262; 38 DLR 435; 31 DLRII9— Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—115</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Addition of party in revision</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">When prayer for addition should be refused—If the petitioner is added as a party the plaint needs to be amended introducing new facts and cause of action changing the nature and character of the suit—Such amendment at this belated stage would be unwarranted— Further, the petitioners having already filed a suit the decree that may be passed there would be binding on both the parties—In the facts of the case the Court in rejecting the prayer for addition of party had not acted illegally, arbitrarily and fancifully—The power to add a party is discretionary and unless that power was exercised arbitrarily or fancifully it cannot be interfered with—Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 (V of 1908), Or. I R. 10.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Ishaque Hossain Chowdhury Vs. Mrs. Shamsun Nahar Begum, 9 BLD (HCD) 194.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 30 DLR (SC) 244—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—i 15</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Knowledge of sale under pre-emption</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">When finding as to knowledge not liable to interference?—A finding as to knowledge of the petitioner about sale of land under preemption is a finding of fact—Unless such finding suffers from any infirmity or is perverse the Court is not to interfere with the finding of the lower appellate Court in its reisional jurisdiction.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Sree Jitendra Nath Howlader Vs. Sree Bisweswar Howlader and others, 9 BLD 11(D) 295</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref; 29 DLR I 83—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—115</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Election matter</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Petitioner getting the highest number of votes found disqualified to he elected as the Chairman of the Union Parishad—Whether candidate with the next highest number of cotes can be declared elected Chairman?— The proper order in such a case should have been to declare the election as a whole void and direct the election authorities to hold a fresh election for the Chairmanship—The Local Government (Union Parishads) Ordinance, 1983 (LI of 1983), S. 29.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Md. Lal Miah Vs. Md. Faziul Haque Bhuiyan and others, 9 BLD (HCD) 398.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: PLD l968(SC)30l; (1961)3a E.LR. 354; PLD 1966(Lah) 97—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—115</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Finding of fact</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Trial Court refused pre-emption on the pound of limitation—Appellate Court reversed the finding of the trial Court—In revision the High Court Division declined to interfere with the question of finding of fact— ppe1late Division approving the stand of the High Court Division dismissed the appeal ho1ding that this being a finding purely of  facts does not warrant interference in revision—The High Court Division rightly refused interference.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Sona Mia Vs. Abdul Khaleque, 10 BLD (AD) 209.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—115</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Question of law</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Question regarding maintainability of appeal not raised before the lower appellate Court can be raised before High Court Division—Exercising its power High Court Division can even suo-motu interfere with an illegal order in the interest of justice—Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 (V of 1908), Or. 7 Rule. 11.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Ayezuddin Sheik and others Vs. Md. Abdul Karim Sheik and others, 10 BLD (HCD) 139.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 26 DLR(AD) 1; 38 DLR (AD) 33— Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—115</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Transfer and withdrawal of case—</span></strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Whether error of law in the order of transfer and withdrawal warrants interference—For entitling the petitioner to have revision of such order he must not only prove that there was an error of law but also that the error of law resulted in an error in the decision and the same had occasioned a failure of justice—There is no cause of prejudice to the petitioner if the appeal is heard by the District Judge himself instead of by the Additional District Judge nor was there any submission on this behalf that he will have any cause of prejudice if the District Judge hears the appeal—Thus though the District Judge committed error of law in making the impugned order this error did not result in any error in the decision occasioning failure of justice and as such there is no scope for revising the order—Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 (V of 1908), S. 24.</span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Md. Haroon Malik Vs. National Bank Ltd; 10 BLD (HCD) 225.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—115</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Discretion—When High Court Division refuses to exercise it in revision</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The petitioner instead of challenging the restoration of the suit filed an application before the same Court for consideration of the order which having been rejected the present Rule was obtained under revisional jurisdiction—High Court Division refuses to exercise its discretion under revisional jurisdiction when the Subordinate Judge appears to have committed no error of law in rejecting the petition for reconsideration or when there was no failure of justice.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Syed Azizul Hoque alias Nanna Miah Vs. Sonali Bank and others, 10 BLD (AD) 247.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—115</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Disputed question of fact—Exercise of revisional jurisdiction</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It is true in revisional jurisdiction the High Court Division should not go into the disputed question of fact, but if any finding is contrary to evidence or is not based on evidence on record, the Court has jurisdiction to look into the matter and give its independent decision on it.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Md. Golam Mostafa Mridha Vs. Anjut Au Molla and others, 10 BLD(HCD)252</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—115</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The High Court Division, whether is justified as a revisional Court in sending back a suit on remand to the trial Court for fresh decision without direction to take additional evidence?</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The High Court Division is not justified as a revisional Court to send a suit back on remand to the trial Court for a fresh decision on the evidence on record and without any direction to take additional evidence. When the High Court Division cannot make up its mind on evidence already on record, it should not pass an order of remand but should make up its own mind and come to a decision of its own.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Attor Mia and another Vs. Mst. Mahmuda Khatun Chowdhury and others, 11 BLD (AD) 133.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 6 BLD(AD) 135; 6 BLD(AD)156; 1980 B.S.C.R. 457—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—115</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Principle of</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">When the Subordinate Judge and the superior Court are vested with concurrent jurisdiction the case should be instituted in the Court of the lowest jurisdiction, otherwise, in cases, the provision as to appeal etc. as provided by the Code of Civil Procedure or any other Act, would be made nugatory and the superior Court would be over crowded.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Foundation of section 115 C.P.C.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">From the construction of the section and the language used it can be said that the restriction imposed relates only to the appeals when it lies to the High Court Division and there is no such restriction in filing a revision case out of the judgment and order against which appeal lies to the District Judge’s Court.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Md. Mansur Ali Vs. Janata Bank and others, 11 BLD (HCD) 23.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 10 DLR 632—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—115</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Settlement of land and possession by Kabuliat</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Conclusion drawn by the Courts of facts based on belief or disbelief of the witnesses, evidence relates to appreciation of evidence and is not open to interference in exercise of revisional jurisdiction.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Tahan Gazi Vs. Pramila Pramanik, 11 BLD (HCD) 99.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—115</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Whether it is a function of the High Court Division to sit in appeal over the finding of the lower appellate Court in the revisional jurisdiction?</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It is no function of the High Court Division to sit in appeal over the finding of the lower appellate Court in the revisional jurisdiction. The High Court Division is only concerned with the question as to whether the lower appellate Court in giving that finding committed any error of law resulting in the error in the decision occasioning failure of justice.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Govt. of Bangladesh Vs. Chand Mia and others, 12 BLD (AD) 48.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—115</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">An order granting relief summarily on a revisional application is neither legal nor fair?</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">An order granting relief summarily on a revisoinal application without issuing any rule on the opposite party is neither legal nor fair. Such an order is against the basic norms of adjudication and principles of natural justice.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Abdul Wahab Vs. Ali Ahmed and another, 12 BLD (AD) 64.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 3BLD(AD). 193; 4 B.C.R. (AD) 532; BLD(AD) 162—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—115</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Whether the High Court Division in revision can set aside the judgment and decree passed ex-parte by the Assistant judge when the petitioner preferred another civil revision against an order of stay of further proceeding in a pending matter?</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A party who does not prefer an appeal to the District Court is under that section at liberty come for revision against a judgment and decree against which no appeal lies to the High Court Division—Ex-parte decree passed the learned Assistant Judge in view of the illegal and stay order passed by the High Court Division is without jurisdiction.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Md. Abdul Quddus Vs. Muhammad Iasrafa Hossain alias Shahid, 12 BLD (HCD) 60.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 42 DLR (HCD)22Q—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—132</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Pardanashin Lady</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">She is a lady living in seclusion—A lady oh a certain amount of education, who subscribes newspapers, manages her own affairs and even appears in Courts is not a pardanashin lady.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Musammat Firoja Begum and another Vs. Kazimuddin Bhuiyan and another, 6 BLD (HCD) 190.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. AIR. 1930 (Lahore) 985—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—141</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Civil Revision</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Parties can effect compromise in revision.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A revisional application is a prescribed mode of step in the Code either in prosecution or in defence of an action and as such the procedure provided for in the Code shall also apply to civil revision including the provision for compromise on the strength of section 141 of the Code provided that the revisional application arises out of a suit, appeal or original miscellaneous case or appeal there from in which the procedure provided in the Code would apply.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Serajul Mostafa Vs. Ali Ahmed Sikder and others, 1 BLD (HCD) 80.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—141</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Proceeding—meaning of?</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Proceeding’ is a prescribed mode of action for carrying into effect a legal right. It means and includes all the steps and measures for prosecution and defence on an action.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Serajul Mostafa Vs. A Ahmed Sikder and others, 1 BLD (HCD) 80.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—141</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Review—A substantive right</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Power of review must be conferred by law—High Court Division is not empowered under the Constitution or any law to review its judgment in writ petition.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The provisions for review made in the Code of Civil Procedure cannot be made applicable to such special proceedings under the Constitution particularly when provisions of the Code of Civil Procedure have not been made specifically applicable to any such proceeding under Article 102. An application under Article 102 might involve civil disputes, criminal allegations, constitutional issues and administrative orders emanating from different authorities of the state and the Government and local authorities. If it is assumed that the power of the Court to review its judgment under the Code of Civil Procedure would be applicable in an application under Article 102 of the Constitution only when such application involves civil disputes between the parties in question, in such circumstances, it would lead to compartmentalizing the discretionary prerogatives and extraordinary jurisdiction of this Court under one specific provision of Article 102 of the Constitution, which could not be intended by the founding framers of the Constitution. The proceeding under Article 102 must be taken as a self-explanatory, self-contained, complete single proceeding which might be civil or criminal in nature involving constitutional or administrative issues from time to time. When a proceeding under Article 102 has no permanent and over-all bearing of a civil pro- ceding, any particular case from such proceeding which involves civil disputes cannot be selected for the purpose of invoking the powers under the Code of Civil Procedure to review judgments and orders. That would lead to fragmentation of an otherwise unified exhaustive proceeding under Article 102. The High Court Division is not empowered under the Constitution or under any other law to review its judgment made in application under Article I O2.—Constitution of Bangladesh, 1972, Article 102.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>In re Mrs. Khohinoor Banu and another, 1 BLD (HCD) 155.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. PLD 1970 (SC)1; PLD 1965 (SC) 55—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section— 14 1</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Dismissal for default</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Dismissal of a case for default within 3 months from the receipt of the return showing non-service of the notice is illegal—Order 9 Rule 5 of the Code of Civil Procedure is applicable to proceedings under Order 9 Rule 13 of the Code.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Fakhruddjn Driver Vs. Matior Rahinan. 3 BLD (HCD) 2.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—141</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Reporting a case for orders of the Government</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Whether the provision for reporting is applicable for execution of Orders passed in a writ proceeding—There is no conflict of decisions regarding the fact that the execution proceeding under the C.P.C. will not apply to writ proceedings for execution of the judgment passed therein—Even if section 141 C.P.C. is applied to writ proceedings, the matters covering the execution of the decrees do not apply in such proceedings—The application for reporting the case for orders is rejected as not maintainable—Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 (V of 1908), S. 82—Constitution of Bangladesh, 1972, Article, 102.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Neerala Tea Estate Ltd. and others Vs. Govt. of Bangladesh &amp; ors. 9 BLD (HCD) 65.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 35 DLR(AD) I = 2 B.C.R. (AD) 373; A.I.R. 1957 (Cal) 702; 1959 Mad. 137; AIR. 1965 All. 517; A.I.R. 1962 Gujrat 21; A.LR. 1968 Punjab 360; AIR. 1968 Guirat 202; AIR. 1967 Cal. 275; A.I.R. 1963 Pun. jab5 I 0;P.L.D. I 963(W.P.)(Lah) 178; PLD 1965,(W.P.)(1ah)596; I.L.R. I 7A11 106(P.C.)A.1,R. I 962(SC) I 886;J L.R. I 7All I 05(P.C,);—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—141</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Determination as to whether a proceeding is a civil proceeding or not</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Civil Proceeding,—weather is a process for recovery of individual right or redress of individual wrong.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In order to determine whether a proceeding is a civil proceeding or not, it is necessary to see what the questions are raised and decided in the proceeding. If a proceeding involves the assertion or enforcement of a civil right, it is a civil proceeding. The provisions of the Code, other than the specially excepted ones, shall apply in the exercise of the High Courts jurisdiction in a civil matter, whatever may be the nature of that jurisdiction.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Civil proceeding is a process for recovery of individual right or redress of individual wrong, inclusive, in its proper legal sense, of suits by the Crown. Whether a proceeding is civil or not depends on the nature of the subject-matter of the proceeding and its object, and not on the mode adopted or the forum provided for the enforcement of the right. A proceeding which deals with a right of a civil nature does not cease to be so merely because the right is sought to be enforced by having recourse to the writ jurisdiction.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Khapaiz Bittahini Co-operative Society Ltd. Vs. Nagendra Mahisya Das and others, 12 BLD (H3) 208.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. I 97OPLD(SC) 1; A.I.R. 1921 (PC)80; I.L.R.17(All)106; 41 DLR 9O—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Sections—144 and 47</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Restitution is an independent proceeding</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">An application for restitution is independent application, no matter its object is the recovery of the fruit of a decree passed earlier but subsequently reversed. Application for restitution is an application for which no imitation has been specifically provided for in law and as such it attracts the residuary provision of Art. 181. A restitution application is not an application for execution of a decree and as such it is not governed by Article 182 but it is governed by Article 181 of the Limitation Act—Limitation Act, 1908 (IX of 1908). Arts. 181 and 182.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Shanuj Ali and others Vs. Kamalararna Bibi and others, 1 BLD (AD) 131.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Sections—144 and 151</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">If any law specifically provides for restitution such as section 144 of the Code of Civil Procedure, restitution must be granted by the Court under this section, its terms being mandatory. But this section is not exhaustive; it only defines the procedure for restitution in the case of a reversal of a decree. In the case of reversal of an order the same remedy should be given by the Court in the exercise of its inherent power under section 151 CRC.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Abdul  Hamid Vs. Abdul Jabbar, 2 BLD (AD) 172.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. A.I.R. 1952 (Nag) 190; 53C.L.J.49; 26C.W.N.408; 34C.W.N.746; 54C.W.N.896; AIR. I 922(PS)269—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—144</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Restitution</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Restitution of possession of original tenancy—Question of local investigation in order to ascertain the actual area of the original tenancy—If the tenancy ceased to exist on the tenants death all other questions including that of local investigation became irrelevant—The heirs of deceased tenant are not entitled to restitution.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Abdul Latif and another Vs. Abdul Mannaf and others, 3 BLD (AD) 37.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref.32 DLR (AD) 170—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—144</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Restitution—Restitution in respect of the decree or property covered by the decree is permissible—It does not contemplate any investigation as to the extent of the decretal land or its identity. There is no scope to adjudicate upon the question of identity of the subject matter of the suit or the decree in a proceeding for restitution.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Md. Asghar Vs. Nowab Miah and others, 3 BLD (HCD) 37. </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—145</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Execution of decree against surety</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Surety undertaking liability to pay if decretal dues cannot be realised from judgment- debtor—Execution cannot be levied against surety at the first instance.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Where the surety undertook that if the money could not be realised from the judgment—debtor then he would be liable for the amount, it was incumbent upon the decree holder to proceed in the first instance against the judgment—debtor and only when it was established that the decretal amount could not be realised from the judgment-debtor, the decree-holder could then proceed against the surety.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Yusuf Ali Mondal and others Vs. Soleman Ali Biswas, 1 BLD (HCD) 242.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—146</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Beneficial legislations</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">These were introduced for the first time in the Code of Civil Procedure of 1908 with the object of facilitation the exercise of rights by persons in whom they come to be vested by devolution or assignment, and being a beneficial provision should be construed liberally so as to advance justice not in a restricted or technical sense.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In the instant case the appellants are no other persons than the legal representatives of deceased plaintiff No. 1 who died after the dismissal of the suit. It is true that the appellants could have filed an application for substitution to be substituted in place of deceased plaintiff No. I during the pendency of the suit; but after the dismissal of the suit there is no occasion for the appellants to file any application for substitution. But they being the heirs of the deceased plaintiff can file an application for setting aside the order of dismissal of the suit for default and section 146 of the Code provides that where any proceedings be taken or application made by or against any person then the proceedings may be taken and the application may be made by or against any person claiming under him. Obviously the suit having been dismissed for default, plaintiff No. I while alive could have filed an application for setting aside the order of dismissal of the suit.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The appellants claiming under plaintiff No. I after his death, therefore, can also apply for setting aside the order of dismissal of the suit under Order 9 Rule 9 of C.P.C. In that view of the matter the learned Subordinate Judge was wrong in holding that the miscellaneous case was not maintainable.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Hazera Khatun and others Vs. Amulya Chandra Chakiadar and others, 11 BLD (HCD) 45. </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—148</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Enlargement of time to deposit money— Whether the default clause in the trial Courts order to deposit money within the specified time retained its operative force till disposal of appeal or revision against the said order?— Whether the direction to do certain act within the given time is incorporated in a decree or final order the Court cannot enlarge the time unless the decree or final order is modified in appeal or revision—Shall stand dismissed” and ‘will be dismissed—In the former, the order is final in that the order of dismissal is of automatic operation there being no scope for any further order—In the latter, the order is not final in that in case of default, the dismissal is not automatic, but further order will be required for the dismissal.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Abdul Hadi Bepari Vs. Sofaruddin Mondal and others, 6 BLD (AD) 332. </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 19 DLR(SC)143—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—148</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Extension of time for depositing auction money</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Whether the Court can extend time for depositing balance of purchase money sold in auction beyond statutory period?—A Court has no jurisdiction to extend period of 15 days fixed for depositing purchase money of a property sold in auction—The mandatory provision of Order 21 Rule 86 requires the Court to resell the property in case there is a failure to deposit the entire balance of the purchase money within 15 days, which clearly indicates that the Court shall have no jurisdiction to extend that period—Court can extend time only when time is fixed by the Court for doing of any act but not when time is fixed by the statute—If the Court is allowed to have such jurisdiction to extend the time limit fixed by the statute, then the statute will be defeated and such a position cannot be conceived—An auction purchase automatically stands cancelled and the purchaser also forfeits all his claims to auctioned property because of default in depositing purchase money within the prescribed time.—Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 (V of 1908), Order 21 Rules 85 and 86.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Jamsheduddin Bhuiyan Vs. Anwara Begum, 6 BLD (HCD) 112.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Sections—148 and 149</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Payment of deficit court fee</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Whether the Court is to pass a penal order way of notice to comply with Court’s order While passing an order to pay the deficit Court fee within a certain time the Court need not pass a continual or penal order by wav of giving notice that in the event of failure to comply with Court’s order the memorandum of appeal will be rejected.—Court Fees Act, 1870 (VII of 1870), s. 6(2).</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>District Priinaiy Education Officer, Vs.lanai Abedin and others, 9 BLD (HCD) 69</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 52 C.W.N. 684—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Sections—148 and 149</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Discretion of the Court</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Discretion of the Court under section 6 of Court Fees Act and sections 148 and 149 of the Code of Civil Procedure, whether is independent of the proviso to Rule 11 of Order 7 of the Code?</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Discretion of the Court under section 6 of The Court Fees Act and sections 148 and 149 of the Code of Civil Procedure is of the proviso to Rule II of Order 7 of the Code and it cannot control the provisions of the discre4F power of the Court under the afore said sections and as such the stringent provisions  of Rule II of Order 7 of the Code of civil Procedure should be reconciled and harmonized with the provision of section 6 of the Court Fees Act and sections 148 and 149 of the Code of Civil Procedure for making a room for reasonable elasticity to facilitate justice and further its ends. The provisions of Order 7 Rule 11 are directory and not mandatory—Court Fees Act, 1887(VII of 1870), S. 6.— Code of Civil Procedure. 1908 ), Or. 7 R. 11.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Jesmin Ara Begum Vs. Golam Mainud din, 12 BLD (HCD) 353.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. A.1.R. 1936 (Cal) 221: AIR. 1941 (Oudh)30—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—150  </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Violation of injunction—Punishment for such violation by the transferee Court</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Whether a transferee Court which did not pass the order of injunction is competent to punish for violation of injunction—Court granting an injunction—Whether the expression would mean “the Court” to which the whole case has been transferred—The transferee Court has jurisdiction to pass necessary order in case of violation of an injunction order passed by a Court other than it—Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 (V of 1908). Order 39 Rule 2(3).</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Abdul Huque Vs. Mrs. Zainab Begum and others, 4 BLD (AD) 296.</em></strong><span id="pastemarkerend"></span></p></div></div>
1143	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">CODE OF CIVIL PROCEDURE, 1908 [SECTION 151 - 153]</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  1 BLD (HCD) 46, IBLD(ffcD)80, 1 BLD (HCD) 251, 1 BLD (HCD) 428, 2 BLD (AD) 172, 2 BLD (HCD) 34, 2 BLD (HCD) 138, 3 BLD (AD) 195, 3 BLD (AD) 310, 4 BLD (HCD) 225,  5 BLD (HCD) 13, 5 BLD (HCD) 157, 5 BLD (HCD) 329, 5 BLD (HCD) 333, 6 BLD (AD) 45, 6 BLD (AD</p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  1908</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  CIVIL PROCEDURE</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u><br/> </u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>CODE OF CIVIL PROCEDURE, 1908</u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u><br/> </u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Sections—151, 152 and 153</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Partition Suit—Formal defect in preliminary decree does not nullify the work of the Pleader Commissioner</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Defect in preliminary decree can be corrected ex-debito justifies.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It will be plainly an act of injustice if for errors of the Court the entire work of the Pleader Commissioner is nullified; more so when in allocating shams he has not gone beyond the order portion of the judgment. The Pleader Commissioner’s report cannot be set aside on the ground that he lacked any jurisdictional basis. His jurisdiction under the circumstances is unaffected by the formal defects in the preliminary decree which can be corrected ex-debito justifies—Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 (V of 1908), Order 26 Rule 14.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Md. Wasiq Khan Vs. Md. Sabiq Khan and others, 1 BLD (HCD) 46.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. AIR. 1922(PC)269; L.R. 3 PC.(475); A.I.R. 1957 (M.B.) 17; 36 C.W.N. 665; 30 DLR(SC)30—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—15 1</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Compromise in revision</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Parties in a civil entitled to effect compromise.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The Court for ends of justice may also record compromise under section 15 1 of the Code where the revision application having not arises out of an original miscellaneous proceeding. The provision of Or. 23. R.3 of the Code does not apply—Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 (V of 1908), Section. 115, 141 and Or. 23 R3.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Serajul Mostafa Vs. Au Ahrned Sikder and others, IBLD(ffcD)80</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. A.IR.1949(Lah)186; 18 C.L.J. 141; A.1.R.1949 (Mad) 433: A.I.R.1953 (Raj) 189; AIR. 1946 (Born) 201—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—151</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Banking Companies Ordinance</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Property attached by the Company Judge—district Judge held auction on the direction of the Company Judge—District Judge not competent to question the attachment and to set aside the auction sale.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The attachment was made under orders of the Company Court and the sale was also held in pursuance of the direction of that Court. Under section 61 of the Banking Companies Ordinance the Company Court has exclusive jurisdiction to decide any claim by or against Banking Company. Section 63 of the Ordinance empowers the Court to entertain an application even after the statutory period of limitation.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The executing Court was required to proceed with the matter taking the decree as a valid one and capable of execution. It was not open to the executing Court to decide whether the decree was a valid one or not. If there was a claim on the attached property by any one it was for him to move the High Court Division and it is for this Court to investigate and decide the issue. The District Judge illegally questioned the attachment of the property by the High Court Division and acted beyond his jurisdiction in setting aside the auction sale.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>In re Kurnud Ranjan Sarker and others, 1 BLD (HCD) 251.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. AIR. l962(Cal)86; 20 DLR 982: 27 DLR(SC) 133; I BLD96.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—151</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Stay of proceeding before the Tribunal</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">An application for stay of proceeding before a Tribunal pending disposal of a suit between the same parties over the same matter is misconceived and not maintainable— Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 (V of: 1908), S. 10; Bangladesh Legal Practitioners and Bar Council Order. 1972, (P.O. 46 of 1972), Article 34 and 35.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Fariduddin Ahmed Vs. Secretary, Bangladesh Bar Council and another, 1 BLD (HCD) 428.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—15 1</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Restitution—Restitution in the case of an order in a pre-emption case</span></strong>—Order in such a case may have the force of a decree but it is not included in section 144 C.P.C. Restitution allowed in such a case is therefore treated as one having been passed under section 151 C.P.C.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">If any law specifically provides for restitution such as section 144 of the Code of Civil Procedure restitution must be granted by the Court under this section, its terms being mandatory. But this section is not exhaustive: it only defines the procedure for restitution in the case of a reversal of a decree. In the case of reversal of an order the same remedy should be given by the Court in the exercise of its inherent power under section 151 C.P.C.—Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 (V of 1908).</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Abdul Hamid Vs. Abdul Jabbar, 2 BLD (AD) 172.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. A.LR. 1952 (Nag) 190; 53 C.L.J. 49; 26 C.W.N. 408; 34 C.W.N. 746;. 54 C.W.N. 896; A.I.R. 1922(PS) 269—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—151</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Court’s inherent power</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Every Court has inherent power to do real and substantial justice—It is to act upon the principle that every procedure furthering the course of justice is permissible unless prohibited by law.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Alamgir and others. Vs. Joynal Abedin and others, 2 BLD (HCD) 34.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—151</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Maintainability of an application under section 151 C.P.C.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">For restoration of an application for setting aside of an ex-parte decree passed under section 1 7 of the Arbitration Act—Since no appeal lies against an order of dismissal of an application under Order 9 Rule 13 C.P.C. under the Arbitration Act itself, an application under section 151 C.P.C. is clearly maintainable.—Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 (V of 1908). Or. 43 Rule 1(d)—Arbitration Act, 1940 (X of 1940), S. 39.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Haji Karimuddin Vs. Insaf Meah and others, 2 BLD (HCD) 138.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 32 DLR(AD) 231; A.1.R. 1956 (Patna)28; A.I.R. 1950 (Madras) 295—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—151 read with Order 7 Rule 11 Rejection of plaint</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Whether Admiralty Court can reject the plaint</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Majority View—Though Admiralty Court cannot reject the plaint, it may return the same where there is no cause of action triable by it or it lacks jurisdiction.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Minority view—Rejection of plaint is not permissible—Admiralty Judge has no jurisdiction to entertain application for rejection f plaint.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">M/s Saleh Steel Industries Ltd. Vs. TSS ‘Pacific Abeto’ and others, 3 BLD (AD) 195.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. PLD l970(SC) I; AIR. 1953(Md) 897; A.I.R. 1970 All 309 (F.B)—Cited</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—151</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Question of reopening plaintiff’s case by calling fresh witness</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In the present case the High Court Division had fallen upon section 151 C.P.C. to meet the ends of justice—They were conscious about the special circumstances which impelled them to provide an opportunity to the plaintiff to examine witness after the close of the defendants witness—The discretion used in allowing the examination of witness in the manner as provided under Order 18 CPC has been rightly exercised—Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 (V of 1908), Or. 18.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Md. Nurul Islam Vs. Md. Abdur Rashid, 3 BLD (AD) 310. </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—151 read with Order 3 Rule I</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order for personal appearance of a party</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Whether the trial Court can revise such order passed earlier—A Court has always the discretion to revise such a direction and exempt a party from appearing personally and be satisfied with his appearance through attorney—It cannot be said that by the impugned order there has been a failure of justice affecting the merits of the case.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Gura Meah Shah and others Vs. Zahir Ahmed and others, 4 BLD (HCD) 225.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—151 read with Order 6 Rules 16 and 17</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Cancellation of written statement filed jointly with other defendants and acceptance of separate written statement—Pleadings may be struck out or cancelled at any stage of the proceeding—The trial Court committed illegalities in not allowing the prayer of the petitioner for cancellation of the written statement filed jointly in so far as it relates to her and acceptance of the written statement filed by her along with the petition.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Musammat Sakina Begum Vs. Moharnmad Ishaque, 5 BLD (HCD) 13.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—151 read with Order 22 Rule 3</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Whether the Court can dismiss a suit for default for non-appearance of the plaintiff after having knowledge about death of the sole plaintiff—Dismissal order is without jurisdiction—Courts duty is to rectify it upon being pointed out—Court is to record the abatement of the suit—Once the fact of the death of the sole plaintiff is brought to the notice of the Court the Court has no power and jurisdiction to fix the suit for peremptory hearing—The order of dismissal for default being wholly without jurisdiction the Court should vacate such order—The hens and successors of the deceased plaintiff had time upto 90 days from the date of plaintiffs death to substitute themselves as plaintiffs—Rules or orders of the Code dealing with the case Of noi1appearance of a suitor were inapplicable to a situation when the suitor is dead—Quite apart from section 15 1 C.P.C. the Court possesses an inherent power to rectify its mistake committed inadvertently.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Kamal Anwar and others Vs. Muhammad Kabir Khan, 5 BLD (HCD) 157.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. (1913) C.L.J. (P.C.)9.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Sections—15I and Order 21 Rules 99 and 100</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Dispossession by decree-holder— Whether Courts inherent power can be invoked by a 3rd party against apprehension of such dispossession—it is the duty of the. executing Court to give delivery of possession of the decretal property to the decree-holder—The Court may pass necessary orders it it finds that the ascertainment 01 the suit property by local investigation is necessary in order to see that the decree of the Court is correctly executed—it cannot pass such order on an application of a 3rd party who has no <em>locus standi</em> in law at this stage before being evicted.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Saleh Ahmed Vs. Md. Zakaria, 5 BLD (HCD) 329.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. PLD 1959 (Lahore) 511 25 DLR 5; 29 DLR(SC) I 85—Cited</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—151</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Court’s inherent power—Its application in case of rejection of plaint</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The order rejecting the plaint could not have taken notice of the facts as to how due to an inadvertent mistake no step could be brought to the notice of the Court appropriately and effectively except by way of an application for restoration of the plaint.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Abdur Rahnzan Vs. Mohammad Shahjahan Siddique, 5 BLD (HCD) 333.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. A.1.R. 1964 (Orissa) 134—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—151 read with Order 39 Rule 2(3) Contempt Proceeding—Whether maintainable under section 151 C.P.C.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">No Court can he supposed to have inherent power to disregard the express provisions of law, whether in the Code or any other statutes or rules—Conviction and sentence of the appellant for Contempt of Court is set aside as no appropriate proceeding for contempt was initiated.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Md. Hazrat Ali Vs. Joynal Abedin and others, 6 BLD (AD) 45.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. A.i.R. 1919 (Cal) 44—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—151</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The order of analogous hearing of the miscellaneous case and the title suit by the same judge has been made on no grounds other than mentioning “ends of justice”. This expression used in section 151 of the Code of Civil Procedure recognizes wide powers inherently possessed by the Court w do justice in a given case. From this it must not be supposed that the Court can, in disregard of the established principles and norms of law, make on order.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Bangladesh Shilpa Bank Bangladesh Hotels Limited, 6 BLD (AD) 49.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Sections—I5 1, 152 and 97</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Amendment of decree—When it can be done</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The Court can always amend the decree if there is a mistake that had crept in for bringing the decree in conformity with the judgment.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Ismail Ullah being dead his heirs Bazidullah and others Vs. Sumumar Chandra Das, 6 BLD (AD) 251.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. L.R. 1885 (CD) 239; AJ.R. 1961 (SC) 709:42 l.A. 191; A.I.R. l965(SC) 1325; 1892 L,R (A.C.)547: 48 C.WN. 435; A.I.R. 1926 (P.C.) 136; A.l.R. 1924 (Cal) 895; 36 C.W.N. 665; 59 I.L.R. (Bombay) 158;— Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—151</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Extension of time for deposit of cost when non-payment resulted in dismissal of the case—Whether time can be extended in exercise of inherent power—Misc. case stood dismissed after 15 days as the cost was not deposited and the said order’ was never challenged by filing an appeal—So the Court had no jurisdiction to extend time in exercise of its inherent power to deposit cost after the order of dismissal becomes operative.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Bangladesh Vs. Laila Begum and others, 6 BLD (HCD) 141.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section— 15 1</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Inherent jurisdiction</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Exercise of such power—Whether a case for setting aside an ex-parte decree dismissed for default on the reopening date can be restored in exercise of inherent power of the Court—The suit was decreed ex-parte— Defendant filed a Misc. case under Order 9 Rule 13 C.P.C.—In the cause list of the Court 17. 5.84 was shown as the date of hearing of the Misc. case—l7.5.84 was declared a holiday and 18.5.84 being Friday was weekly holiday—On 19.5.84 Court was re-opened, but the defendant petitioner did not appear and the misc. case was dismissed for default—Defendant filed a petition under section 151 C.P.C. for restoration of the case after setting aside order of dismissal— Whether the defendant had any obligation to appear on the re-opening date of the Court— There was no such obligation on the petitioner—Court can exercise inherent power under section 15 I C.P.C. for curing the mistake of the Court or Court’s officer even when there is an alternative remedy for such relief.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Md. Bonde Ali Khan and others Vs. The Government of Bangladesh, 6 BLD (HCD) 232.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 16 DLR (SC) 155; 28 DLR(HCD)252; 29 DLR(SC) 185—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—151 read with Order 9 Rule 13</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Mistaken use of law—appropriate relief will not be refused for such use</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Mistaken use of a section of law in an application itself will not debar a Court to lass an appropriate order for the relief sought provided ‘that from the facts stated in the application the relief can be given under a different provision of the law.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Chand Mia Vs.
