Serajul Hoque and others, 7 BLD (HCD) 117.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 27 DLR4I8: (1967)63 l.T.R. 252’:— Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—151 read with Order 43 Rule I</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Acceptance of the report of Advocate Commissioner for local investigation— Whether appeal lies against such an order</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Whether an application under section I 51 C.P. Code to set aside such order pissed ex-parte is maintainable—An order accepting an Advocate Commissioner’s report is not an appealable order—When the remedy of moving an application for revision of the order was long barred by time the aggrieved party had no other remedy except filing application under section 151 C.P. Code—Such an application is maintainable and cannot be thrown out in limine.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Rehanuddin Vs. Abdul Hakim Master, 7 BLD (HCD) 285.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—151</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Inherent power of the Court</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Any order passed between the preliminary and final decree is an interlocutory order although it may finally decide the rights of the parties—But if it appears to the Court that the interlocutory order has been passed through errors and mistake resulting in the final decree then certainly the hand of the Court is long enough to cure the mistake— The Court in exercise of its inherent power can pass an order as may be necessary for the ends of justice or to prevent an abuse of the process of the Court.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Md. Delwar Hossain Vs. Tajul Islam and others, 7 BLD (HCD) 296.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. PLD 1965(W.P.) (Peshwar) 74— Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—151 read with Order 40 Rule I </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Appointment of Receiver</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Whether appointment of receiver can be made without notice to the other side— Whether Court is to state the circumstances for appointment of receiver?—The rule does not contemplate service of notice of the application for appointment of a receiver to the other party. The learned Musnif has not stated the circumstances under which the appointment of a receiver was considered just and that it was for preserving the property. That being the position the order is arbitrary and the appellate Court has erred in law in affirming the order.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Abdul Mannan and others Vs. Govt. of Bangladesh and others, 7 BLD (HCD) 360.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 25 DLR (HCD) 252— Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Sections—151 and 47</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Inherent power of Court</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Its applicability in the case of dismissal of a petition under section 47 C.P,C. for default—An order of dismissal of an application under section 47 C.P.C. is not a decree under section 2(2) C.P.C. and as such it is not an appealable order. The petitioner has no other remedy against the order dismissing his application under section 47 of the Code for default—In the circumstances of the case, the learned Subordinate Judge should have considered his application invoking inherent power of the Court on merits and should not have thrown it out in limine.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Sonaban Bibi Vs. Abu Miah and others, 7 BLD (HCD) 364.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 28 DLR (I-IC) 3; A.I.R. 1963 p. 59—.- Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—151</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Exercise of Court’s discretion</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Discretion on question of granting and vacating order of stay—It cannot be conceived that once stay order is passed by the Court it loses its discretion to vacate the same even if it is satisfied that the same should be vacated—In view of the reasons given, there has been arbitrary exercise of the discretion.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Charandwip Bhumihin Krishi Samabaya Samity Ltd. represented by the Chairman, Md. Abdus Samand Vs. The Deputy Commissioner, Cox’s Bazar and others, 8 BLD (AD) 62.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—151</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Inherent Power of Court—When can be invoked to set at naught an exp-arte decree</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The provision of inherent power can be invoked to set at naught an order obtained from a Court by practicing fraud upon the Court by misleading it and where it passes an order or a decree upon misapprehension of the facts.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Mozaffar Ahmed and others Vs. Moulvi Saleh Ahmed and others, 8 BLD (HCD) 331.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 30 DLR (SC) 221; 1968 Pat. 439; 1918 Pat. 341—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—151 read with Order 9 Rule 13</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Condonation of delay without formal application</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Mere absence of a formal application under section 5 of the Limitation Act in the present case is no bar to grant the relief sought for by an application under Order 9 Rule 13 read with section 151 of the Code where in the said application all the facts constituting the delay are duly stated which are required to be stated in an application under section 5 of Limitation Act, on consideration of which the Court is able to condone the delay. — Limitation Act, 1908 (IX of 1908), S.5.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Mozaffar Ahmed and others Vs. Moulvi Saleh Ahnzed and others, 8 BLD (HCD) 331.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 29 DLR 376; 1959 Pun. 648; 1936 J 666: 40 DLRI0—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—151 read with Order 21 Rule 29 </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Stay or execution of decree</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Refusal of prayer for stay when interfered with—1t is true that the facts in the present ease authorise an executing Court to grant of execution of the decree but it does not ecessari1y mean that the stay cannot be refused even in an appropriate case—The proposition could not however be disputed that even if the prayer for stay was granted it ought to have been granted for a reasonable lime for the appellants suit to be disposed of—None appeared to oppose this appeal, nor did any one appear before the High Court The Division on behalf of the respondents—Having considered all aspects of the case, stay already granted should continue for four months more in course of which steps been to get the suit disposed of.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Soleman Miah and others Vs. Ishaque being dead his heirs Jairun Nessa and others 9 BLD (AD) 73.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—151</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Restoration of a case—Restoration in exercise of Court’s inherent jurisdiction</span></strong>—A Court can pass an order in exercise of its inherent power to revise its own order obtained by a party by practice of fraud upon it in order to prevent the abuse of the process of c Court—But it would be otherwise where a case of fraud between the parties and the aggrieved party has a remedy by a separate suit.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Abdur Rashid and others Vs. Din Mohammad and others, 9 BLD (HCD) 1.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—151 and Order 9 Rule 9 Dismissal of suit</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Application for setting aside dismissal of suit filed out of time—The trial Court has committed an error of law in allowing the application on the ground of old age only without considering the question of limitation—The impugned order is liable to be set aside but in the facts of the case the matter is sent back to the trial Court for re-hearing of the miscellaneous case on its merits as well as on the question of limitation.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Assistant custodian, Vested Property Vs. Jugal Chandra Shaha and others, 9 BLD (HCD) 63.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—151 read with Order VI Rule 17 </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Amendment of written statement—Principle for such amendment</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The governing consideration to amend the written statement should be how far, if at all, the proposed amendment of the defence is necessary to determine the real controversy between the parties—Amendment of written statement should not be granted if it would convert the defence into another or a different and inconsistent character.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Major (Rtd.) Mohammad Afsaruddin Vs. Kamal Rahman, 9 BLD (HCD) 380.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. (1885) 31 Ch. D. 68; 26 DLR 205; AIR. I 953(Cal) 15—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—151 read with Order VI Rule 17</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Amendment of written statement?—</span></strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> Whether it can be prayed at any stage—It can be legitimately argued by the plaintiff that the introduction of an alternative defence at a very late stage of the suit when his case is closed and the defendant has been examined in part will be highly prejudicial to him (Plaintiff).</span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Major (Rtd.) Mohammad Afsaruddin Vs. Kamal Rahman, 9 BLD (HCD) 380.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—151</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Remand of suit when non permissible— If desirable after disposal Of the suit for ejectment?</span></strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">—Such a remand would be quite unnecessary as there would be nothing more to say—A remand cannot be made for fresh evidence when there is evidence on record in a suit between the same parties over the same matter.</span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Dr. Suraiya Hossain Vs. Mrs. Taherunnessa, 9 BLD (HCD) 319. </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—151</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Court’s inherent power—Whether order of dismissal of suit for not depositing cost can be set aside in exercise of inherent power?</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Where the plaintiff’s case under Order 9 Rule 9 is allowed but subsequently dismissed for non-compliance with the Court’s order in not depositing the cost to the defendants in time and after depositing the cost he files an application invoking the inherent power of the Court for setting aside the dismissal, in such a situation the Court is competent to exercise this power in order to secure the ends of justice.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Rafiqul Islam and another Vs. Abul Kalam and others, 9 BLD (HCD) 372.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—151</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Inherent power in revision—Court is not precluded from exercising the inherent power for adding the heirs of a deceased who was made party even after her death, in a revisional application in order to secure the ends of justice.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Dr Mohaminad Golam Kibria Vs. Norman Nahar Begum and others, 9BLD (HCD) 532.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 12 DLR 745.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—151</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Restoration of a suit—Restoration in exercise of Court’s inherent power when valid</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It is now well-settled that if there is specific provision in the Code covering a particular case, or if there is a positive prohibition against an act, the Court’s inherent power cannot be invoked—But where a mistake of a Court or its officer causes some injustice to a particular party the inherent power can be exercised for the propose of giving necessary relief.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Syed Azizul Hoque alias Nanna Miah Vs. Sonali Bank &amp; ors. 10 BLD (HCD) 247.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref 4OIfA.151; 1953S.C.R.136A.I.R.1954 (SC) 23; 27 DLR 232; 7 DLR 192—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—151</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It is a settled principle that where a mistake of a Court or Court’s officer causes some injustice to a particular party, the power under section 151 of the Code can be exercised for the purpose of giving necessary relief even though there is an alternative remedy for doing the same.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Boynuddin and others Vs. Azimuddin and others, 10 BLD (HCD) 267.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Sections—151 and 24</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order for analogous trail of suits</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Identical order (of analogous trial of suit) under certain circumstances may also be passed by the District Judge and the High Court Division under section 24 of the Code of Civil Procedure in the interest of justice— In exceptional cases order for analogous trial may also be passed under section 151 of the Code of civil procedure.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Salimullah Bahar Vs. Sharifa Khatoon and others, 10 BLD (HCD) 283.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—151 read with Order 7 Rule 10</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The plaint of the Admiralty Suit was returned on account of: (a) non applicability of section 6 of the Admiralty Court Act, 1861; (b) non-maintainability and (c) want of <em>locus standi</em> of the plaintiff.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Sadharan Bima Corporation Vs. Bangladesh Shipping Corporation and others, 10 BLD (HCD) 347.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—151 read with Order 9 Rule 13 </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Inherent power: When exercisable?</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A miscellaneous case was filed under Order 9 Rule 13 of the Code of Civil Procedure for restoration of the suit which was dismissed for default—There after an application under section 151 of the Code of Civil Procedure was filed for restoration of the said miscellaneous case.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Where the Code provides for an alternative e remedy inherent power of the Court is available—The order being an appealable order, aid of inherent power of the Court is available.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Non-speaking order</span></strong>—When from the order itself it is difficult to understand the reason for which an application was allowed, it is alone sufficient to strike down that order.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Kazi Mohammad Abdul Karim Vs. The Government of Bangladesh, 10 BLD (HCD) 365.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—151 read with Order 9 Rule 13</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Previous application for setting aside an ex-parte decree rejected on the ground of laches and negligence on the part of the opposite party—Whether subsequent order setting aside the ex-parte decree invoking the aid of inherent power of the Court for the ends of Justice is tenable.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">There is no scope for setting aside the decree passed ex-parte under Order 9 Rule 13 CPC by invoking the inherent power under section 151 C.P.C.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Golam Rashid and another Vs. Mohan Bashi Nama and others, 10 BLD (HD) 449.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. I 3DLR542—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Se1ion—151 Order 9 Rule 13 read with 4dcr 43 Rule 1(d)</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The effect of an order of dismissal of the miscellaneous case for default is one of rejecting an application to set aside a decree passed ex-parte. It is not an order passed on merit, but ex-parte. Appeal lies in both cases under Order 43, Rule 1(d).</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The petitioner had a remedy by way of appeal under Order 43 Rule 1(d) C.P.C. which he did not avail of. This is not to say that the application under section 151 C.P.C. is barred under all circumstances.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Abdul Kader Chowdhury Vs. Nurul Islam and others, 11 BLD (AD) 1.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—151 and alternative remedy</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It is well settled principle of law that where a legal remedy is provided for in the C.P.C. to an aggrieved party the inherent power shall not be exercised under section 151 C.P.C.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Atash Ali and ors. Vs. Rebati Mohan Sarker and ors; 11 BLD (HCD) 97.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—151 read with Order 9 Rule 13</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Inherent power cannot be exercised when</span></strong>?</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Order of dismissal of miscellaneous case filed under Order 9 Rule 13 is an appealable order under Order 43 Rule 1(d) of the Code of Civil Procedure—Invoking aid of jurisdiction under section 151 C.P.C. is illegal— Where the Code provides an alternative remedy the provision of section 15 1 C.P.C. is not available.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Kazi Mohammad Abdul Karim Vs. The Government of Bangladesh, 11 BLD (HCD) 110.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—151</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">The Court, whether can set aside its own order, whether has power to maintain its jurisdiction</span></strong>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The Court cannot set aside its own order passed on merit unless the Court has jurisdiction to do so. The Court has inherent power to maintain its jurisdiction and render it effective on behalf of the litigants. Generally speaking the Court has the power to control its own proceedings, at least during the term of the Court, or so long as those are pending.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Buddhi Sankar Biswas Vs. Akbar Ali Sheikh, 11 BLD (HCD) 503.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref.29DLR(SC)185; 39DLR68; AIR. 1964-993: PLD 1963 (WP) Lahore, 408; PLD 196) (Lah) 579; A.I.R. 1945 (Madras) 103; PLD 1974 (Karachi) 339; AiR. 1961 (Born) 21; AIR. 1953 (Mays.)152; A.I.R.(1953) Tray-Co. 439; A.l.R. 1959 (Andh. Pra) 321;  PLD 1963 (Lah) 596: PLD 1965 (Lah) 183; 42DLR 198:—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—151</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Right of review, whether is a statutory right and a creature of law</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A right of review is a statutory right and a creature of law. No Court is empowered to review its own order unless there is an application for review of such order and the Court passing an order can review the same even without an application for review only where the order is liable to be struck down in exercise of its own power under section 151 C.P.C.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Jahura Khatun Bewa alias Jaitan Bewa Vs. Md. Monir Uddin Khan; 11 BLD (HCD) 521.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—151 read with Order 7 Rule 11(b), Order 9 Rule 13 and Order 43 Rule 1(d)</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Under certain circumstances restoration of suit in exercise of Courts inherent power under section 15) C.P.C. is not unjustified.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Plaint rejected for deficit court fee without knowledge of the plaintiff—Plaintiff filed application under section 15 1 C.P.C. for vacating the order and restoring the suit to file on grounds of misplacement of file in the lower Court and his own indisposition—Trial Court vacated the order of rejection of plaint and restored the suit to its file on payment of costs to defendant—High court Division in revision maintained the view of the trial Court—Appellate Division declined to interfere with the judgment of the High Court Division.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Shahabuddin Vs. Abu Sayed and others 12 BLD (AD) 71.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—151 read with Order 9 Rule 13</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Whether the civil Court is so powerless that in exercise of its inherent powers it can- not entertain an application for setting aside an ex-parte decree which is alleged to have been obtained an practicing fraud upon the Court itself.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Application under section 151 C.P.C. is maintainable, under such circumstances</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Mrs. Shahr Banoo and another Vs. Mrs. Lailun Nahar Ershad and others: 12 BLD (AD) 245.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Sections—152, 153 151 and Order 26 Rule14 Partition suit—Formal defect in preliminary decree does not nullify the work of Pleader Commissioner</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Defect in preliminary decree can be corrected <em>ex debito justitiae</em>. It will be plainly an act of injustice if for errors of the Court the entire work of the Pleader Commissioner is nullified, more so when in allocating sahams he has not gone beyond the order portion d the judgment—The pleader Commissioner report cannot be set aside on the ground the he lacked any jurisdictional basis—His jurisdiction under the circumstances is unaffected by the formal defects in the preliminary decree which can be corrected <em>ex debito justitiae</em>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Md. Wasiq Khan Vs. Md. Sabiq Khan and others, 1 BLD (HCD) 46.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. AIR. 1922 (PC) 269; LR. S(PC 475; AIR. 1957 (M.B.) 17; 36 CW.N. 6.5 3ODLR(SC) 3Q:—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Sections—152 and 34(2)</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Amending the decree</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Court became functus officio in respe of further amending the judgment and de cree—Grounds stated in the petition and the ground for allowing it for amending the decree are not covered by the legal provision, rather it violates the provision—Since the decree is for a definite sum of money and the judgment and decree are silent regarding the payment of further interest, the Court must be deemed to have refused it—If the petitioner was aggrieved by the judgment and decree, the remedy certainly did not lie in filing an application under section 152 C.P.C. The case reported in A.I.R. 1961 Orissa 18 is distinguishable as in that case the judgment made a provision for further interest.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Liakat Rice and Oil Mills and another Vs. Janata Bank, 4 BLD (HCD) 120</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. AIR. 1961 Orissa 18—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Sections—152, 151 and 97</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Amendment of decree—when it can be done?</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The Court can always amend the decree if there is a mistake that had crept in for bringing the decree in conformity with the judgment.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Ismãil Ullah being dead his heirs Bajdullah and others Vs. Sukumar Chandra this, 6 BLD (AD) 251</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. AIR. 1961 (SC) 790; 42 l.A. 91;AIR. 1965 (SC) 1325; L.R. 1885 (CD) 239; 1892 LR. (AC) 547; 48 C.W.N. 435; A.I.R. 1926 (P.C.) 136; A.I.R. 1924 (Cal) 895; 36 C.W.N. 665; 59 I.L.R. (Bombay)158;—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—152</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Amendment of order</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The order of sentence contains some apparent mistake—The contemner can be tenced to S.I. but. in default he cannot be asked to pay any fine—He can be fined but there must be some order of S.I. in default of payment of fine—The order of sentence gainst contemner No. 1 is therefore corrected.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>M: A. Monir Vs. The State, 8 BLD (HCD) 434</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—153 read with Order 6 Rule 17</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Amendment of the plaint</span></strong>—changing. averments do not necessarily mean changing nature and character of suit.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Whether the amendment of the plaint that a party in a suit for partition is not an heir of the original owner can be allowed?— Amendment of the plaint changing the averment regarding a party will not change the nature and character of the suit—A change in one of the links in the geneology has not the effect of changing the fundamental character of the plaint— Amendment of the plaint for getting out of the admission—Such amendment can be allowed if it is necessary for the determination of the real question of controversy between the parties.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Shahiman Bewa Vs. Shafiruddin Ahmed and others, 6 BLD (HCD)58</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 36DLR (AD) 253; A.I.R. 1992 (Cal) 307 = 35 C.L.J. 530= 68 IC. 482; 30 DLR (SC) 93—Cited.</p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
1144	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">CODE OF CIVIL PROCEDURE, 1908 [SECTION 21 - 99]</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  1 BLD (HCD) 147, 3 BLD (HCD) 49, 4 BLD(HCD) 91, 4 BLD (HCD) 306, 5 BLD (HCD) 1, 9 BLD(HCD) 304, 9 BLD (HCD) 337, 10 BLD (HCD) 94, 10 BLD (HCD) 222, 10 BLD (HCD) 225, 10 BLD (HCD) 283, 11 BLD (HCD) 325, 4 BLD (AD) 242, 4 BLD (HCD) 120, 4 BLD (AD) 74, 3 BL</p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  1908</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  CIVIL PROCEDURE</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u style="text-underline: thick;">CODE OF CIVIL PROCEDURE, 1908</u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u style="text-underline: thick;">(V OF 1908)</u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—24</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Transfer of suits or cases—Transfer of case on ground of apprehension regarding fair trial</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The apprehension must have some objectivity—It is not merely an illusion or a stage of mental attitude—When from the materials on record the apprehension entertained by the defendant are found not altogether without foundation, a case for transfer is made out.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Haji Md. Elias and another Vs. Mrs. Suraya Rahman, 1 BLD (HCD) 147.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 53 C.W.N. 770; (1973) 11 BLR61— Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Section—24</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Violation of injunction—Transferee Court competent to try</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Transferee Court competent to punish violation of injunction granted by the transferor Court—Court granting an order of injunction includes a Court before which the suit is subsequently transferred and the Court which is in seisin of the entire suit—Transferee Court to which the case is transferred under section 24 of the C.P.C. is competent to deal with the cases of breach of injunction and not to be confined with the Court granting the injunction—Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 (V of 1908); Or. 39 R. 2(3).</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Dilip Kumar Chakravorty Vs. Abdul Muyeed Chwodhury and others, 3 BLD (HCD) 49.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. A.I.R. 1914 Cal 815; 61 C.L.J. 543; A.I.R.l962Ca1519; A.I.R .1962 Pat. 443; A.I.R. 1923 Mad. 92; A.I.R. 1968 Punjab (Hariana) 374—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—24</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Power of a transferee Court</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In case of transfer of a case under section 24 C.P.C. the whole case is transferred and as such the transferee Court has seisin over the entire matter of the suit —When a case is transferred from one Court to another it means not only the transfer of the suit but the entire proceeding including the ancilliary proceeding and hence all the matters are to be disposed of by the transferee Court.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Dilip Kumar Chakravorty Vs. Abdurl Muyeed Chowdhury and others, 3 BLD (HCD) 49.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Section—24</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Transfer from one Bench to another</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Transfer of a suit from within the territorial limits of one Bench of the High Court Division by another Bench whether permissible—A Bench of the High Court Division has no jurisdiction to call for the records and withdraw a case lying in a Court beyond the territorial limits of that Bench—In view of the terriorial limits or jurisdiction transfer of such a suit is not permissible—Proclamation (Second Amendment) Order, 1982 (P.O. I of 1982), Para—44(3).</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In view of the clear limitation of territory relating to the exercise of jurisdiction by the respective Benches of the High Court Division one Bench is not vested with the power and jurisdiction to call for the records and withdraw a case lying in a Court beyond the territorial limits of another Bench. One Bench is not authorized in law to direct a Court subordiante to the High Court Division within the territorial limits of any inother Bench of the High Court Division to do or not to do certain acts or things.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Mashaid Ali Vs. Begum Shakera Banu and others; 4 BLD(HCD) 91.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 35DLR I 18A.—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—24</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Transfer of suit—When should be allowed</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ordinarily the plaintiff as the arbiter litis has the right to choose his forum and the Court should be very reluctant to disturb this right unless the defendant establishes a balance and preponderance of convenience in his favour.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Abdul Taher Vs. Abdul Kader and others; 4 BLD (HCD) 306.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. AIR. 1925 (Lah) 189; A.I.R. 1944 Lah. 400; PD 1968 (Dac) 849; A.I.R.l961 Punj. 560—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—24</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Transfer of suit by the High Court Division</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Whether after the suspension of the Constitution of Bangladesh by the Proclamation of Martial Law on 24th March, 1982, the High Court Division can exercise the power of transfer it had under the suspended Constitution? Though the Constitution was suspended by the Proclamation of Martial Law on 24th March, 1982 by the Proclamation First Amendment Order of 1982 Schedule 4 was added whereby High Court Divisions power of transferring suits under Article 110 of the suspended Constitution was revived— The High. Court Division can exercise the power in regard to transferring suits as it could exercise under Article 110 of the Constitution—Constitution of Bangladesh, 1972, Article 110; Martial Law Proclamation First Amendment Order, 1982 (Proclamation Order No. I of 1982), Schedule clause 4(3).</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Transfer of suit to the High Court Division—Public importance:</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Whether there is general public importance to warrant the transfer of the suit —The point involved in the suit only concerns the parties and not the general public— So there is no point of general public importance— The petitioner failed to make out any case for transfer of the suit to the High Court Division on the point of general public importance— Constitution of Bangladesh, 1972, Article.110.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Power of the High Court Division in matters of transfer</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Section 24 of the Code of Civil Procedure does not enjoin any condition for such transfer—Such transfer can be made by the High Court Division only upon some established principles and by exercise of proper judicial discretion—Balance of convenience and inconvenience of the parties, bias or embarrassments of the Court, intricate and complicated questions of law of general public importance and any other cogent grounds can only justify such transfer ensuring equal justice to both the parties.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Bangladesh Supreme Court Bar Association Vs. Khondker Abu Bakar and another; 5 BLD (HCD) 1.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 54 I.L.R. (Cal) 607; Ch. Div... (K.B.) Vol.1!, Page 205; D.L.C. Vol.11(1970) Page I 54;—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—24</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Pending suits</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Question of their transfer for disposal — Whether amendments raising their valuation shall affect disposal by the Courts other than where they are pending—Had the amendment been to the effect that all the pending suits of the Subordinate Judge’s Courts shall stand transferred automatically to the Courts of the Assistant Judges after promulgation of the Ordinance the position would have been different. Here, it is the discretion of the District Judge to transfer pending proceedings—It is true at the time of institution of the suits, the transferee Asstt. Judges were not competent to try them, but now by virtue of the amendment they have become competent to try them—what is needed is that the transferee Court must be competent at the time when the transfer is ordered—The amendment in question is not at al[ mandatory and in that view the impugned transfers have not occasioned any failure of justice—Civil Courts (Amendment) Ordinance, 1983 (II of 1983), S. 2 and 3.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Md. Ebadal Ali Vs. Ismail Hossain Akhand and others, 9 BLD(HCD) 304.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 6 DLR (FC)54; I IDLR(SC)200;— Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—24(1)(b)</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Power of withdrawal of appeal</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Plea of loss of right of revision—The power conferred by the Code is unfettered and the contention of loss of valuable right of revision or appeal is no bar to the exercise of such power by the High Court Division.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>M.A. Hakim Vs. Bholanath Sen and another, 9 BLD (HCD) 337.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. PLD 1962 Lah 608; 1976 Karnataka 229; A.I.R. 1961 (Raj) 186—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—24(1)</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Transfer of appeal by the District Judges</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Whether a District Judge can transfer an appeal preferred to him from a decision of the Election Tribunal—The cumulative effefct of the relevant provisions in the Code of Civil Procedure and the Civil Courts Act is that the District Judge as referred to in the Local Government Ordinance has ample authority to transfer such an appeal to any Court subordinate to him —The expression “any’ before the expression “appeal” in section. 24(1) of the Code gives the District Judge an unfettered power of transfer of such appeal to any Court subordinate to him except the Court of the Assistant Judge—Local Government (Union Parishads) Ordinance, l983 (LI of 1983), S. 29(4)—Civil Courts Act, 1897 (XII of 1897) 5.22(l).</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Muhammad Zulfikar Vs. A. Kalam Chowdhury and others, 10 BLD (HCD) 94.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref 38 D.L.R. (AD) 172; 1956(SC) 391; —Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—24</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Territorial Jurisdiction</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Whether the Court has jurisdiction to try the Suit in respect of lands of 2 schedules (out of 4) which are beyond its territorial jurisdiction—Though the schedules of the plaint included some lands which have not fallen within the territorial jurisdiction of the Court, the Court does not suffer from lack of jurisdiction in view of the fact that the suit was transferred to it by the competent Court of the District Judge.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Zahir Sheikh Vs. Md. Yakub Ali and others, 10 BLD (HCD) 222.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—24</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Petition for transfer of a suit</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Misquoting of the provision of law in the petition—By a sheer inadvertence the Advocate misquoted section 528 of the Code of Criminal Procedure in a petition seeking transfer of a civil appeal under the Code of Civil Procedure—For such misquoting it cannot be said that the petition could not be regarded as one seeking the intended transfer.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Transfer of case-Relevant provision for transfer</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The Civil Court Act provides for no provision empowering the District Judge to transfer a case from one Court to another or to withdraw a case from any other Court to the Court of District Judge—Section 24 of the C.P.C. is the sole provision of law which empowers the District Judge to do the job—Civil Courts Act, 1887 (XII of 1887), S. 8.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Suo motu transfer of suit—Absence of notice of transfer</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">When transfer is made by the Court of its own motion no notice is necessary—In this case the transfer was made not on the Courts own motion but on the application of the respondent and as such notice was required to be given—So, in making the order of transfer without serving any notice on the opposite party the District Judge committed an error of law.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Transfer and withdrawal of case</span></strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">— Whether error of law in the order of transfer and withdrawal warrants interference? —For entitling the petitioner to have a revision of such order he must not only prove that there was an error of law but also that the error of law resulted in an error in the decision and also that it occasioned failure of justice— There is no cause of prejudice to the petitioner if the appeal is heard by the District Judge himself instead of by the Additional District Judge nor was there any submission on his behalf that he will have any cause of prejudice if the District Judge hears the appeal—Thus though the District Judge committed an error of law in making the impugned order his error did not result in any error in the decision occasioning failure of justice and as such there is no scope for revising the order—Code of Civil Procedure, l9oaV f l9.O8.. S. 115.</span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Md. Malik. vs. National Bank Ltd. 10 BLD (HCD) 225.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. A, I.R. 1926 (All) 17; AIR. 1933 (All) 178: A.I.R. 1917 (Lab) 37; A.I.R. 1920 (All) 249; 20 DLR (Dhaka) 867 ;—Cited</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Sections—24 and 151</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Analoguous trial</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Identical order under certain circumstances may also be passed by the District Judge and the High Court Division under section 24 of the Code of Civil Procedure in the interest of justice. In exceptional cases order for analogous trail may also be passed under section 151 of the C.P.C.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Salimullah Bahar Vs. Sharifa Khatoon and others; 10 BLD (HCD) 283</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—24</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Power of the District Court under section 24 C.P.C.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Whether administrative in nature—Lawyers, whether must always be vigilant and careful in drafting and pressing petitions in Court.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Power of the District Judge under section 24 C.P.C. is somewhat of an administrative and discretionary in nature. In suitable cases, the District Judge can even suo motu exercise this power in the interest of justice. Lawyers must always be vigilant and careful in drafting petitions and pressing the same in Court, particularly while imputing allegations of bias against a judge in an application for transfer of a suit or case.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Sree Bijoy Kumar Basak Vs. Narendra Nath Datta and others; 11 BLD (HCD) 325.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. A.I.R. 1963 (Pat) 353; AIR. 1944 (Sind) 155; PLD 1955 (P.C.) 185—Cited:</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—34</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Power of the Court to award interest</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The Court is not bound by the stipulation in the contract itself in the matter of awarding interest it being completely within its discretion—The Court is free to award interest at such rate as it may think fit.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>M/s. M.M. Ispahani Ltd. Vs. Sonali Bank and others, 4 BLD (AD) 242.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 47 I.L.R. Born 474; A.I.R. 1922 (PC) 46; AIR. 1942 (PC) 61; A.I.R. 1933(Al1) 442(443); 1967 P.L.D. (Kar) 433; 1.L.R. 44 (Born) 474—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Sections—34(2) and 152</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Amending the decree</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Court became <em>functus officio</em> in respect of amending the judgment and decree— Grounds stated in the petition and the ground for allowing it for amending the decree are not covered by the legal provision, rather it violates the provision of law.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Liakat Rice and Oil Mills and another Vs. Janata Bank, 4 BLD (HCD) 120.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—34 read with Order XXI Rule 1(1)(a)</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Interest pendente lite</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">When objection against such interest unsustainable ?— Reading the decree in the context of what has preceded in the judgment there can be no manner of dOubt that the Court awarded interest from the date of the suit and not from the date of decree only as contended—The decree though silent as to interest from the date of the suit, the trial Court found that the plaintiff is entitled to get decree as prayed for and the prayer being the payment of interest takes effect from the date of filing of the suit.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Receipt of decretal money—no estoppel against execution</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">There is no estoppel against initiating execution case for further interest as there is nothing to show that the decree-holder withdrew the money deposited in Court as full satisfaction under the decree.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Sonali Bank Vs. Mahbubul Amin and another; 4 BLD (AD) 74.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. A.I.R. I 944(PC)46; A.I.R. 1924 Mad)l02: A.I.R.1931(Mad)650; A.I.R. 1940 I Mad) 29:—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Sections—35 and 35A</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Cost against a stranger to the proceeding</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Provision of sections 35 and 35A of the Code of Civil Procedure cannot be referred to for determining the Court’s power to award costs in writ petitions— These provisions do not authorize normally awarding of cost against a person who is not a party to the suit—In exceptional cases the Court may award costs even against a stranger provided he is given an opportunity of being heard— Such hearing must be in the suit itself and not after its disposal—Awarding of costs is no doubt a matter of discretion of the Court, but the discretion must be exercised judicially and in accordance with law or at least the practice followed by the Court—Rules 14 and 15 of Chapter A in Appendix IV to the Rules of High Court of Judicature Vol. 1.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Habibullah Khan Vs. Shah Azharuddin Ahmed and others, 3 BLD (AD) 143.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—34A</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Compensatory cost—Award of</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Whether a party setting in motion a frivolous and vexatious writ proceeding by practicing fraud and suppressing the fact of his filing a case before the Election Tribunal should be saddled with cost?</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The petitioner obtained the Rule suppressing the fact of his filing and pendency of an election petition before the Election Tribunal—Writ petition is not only frivolous but also vexatious and it was filed to harass respondent No. 5 and to cause financial loss to him for which the petitioner is liable to compensate respondent No. 5—Rule discharged with compensatory cost of Tk. 5000/- to be paid to respondent No. 5 by the petitioner.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Ziaul Hoque Vs. The Election Commissioner, Sher-E-Bangla Nagar, Dhaka and others; 10 B.L.D. (HCD) 386.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Sections—38, 42, 47 151 and Order XXI Rule 90</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Banking Companies Ordinance</span></strong>— Property attached by the Company Judge — District Judge held auction on the direction of the company Judge—District Judge is not competent to question the attachment and to set aside the auction sale—Banking Companies Ordinance, 1962 (LVII of 1962).</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The attachment was made under orders of the High Court Division and the sale was also held in pursuance of the direction of the said Court. Under section 61 of the Banking Companies Ordinance the High Court Division has exclusive jurisdiction to decide any claim by or against Banking Company. Section 63 of the Ordinance empowers the Court to entertain an application even after the statutory period of limitation.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The Executing Court was required to proceed taking the decree as a valid one and capable of execution. It was not open to the Executing Court to decide whether the decree was a valid one or not. If there was a claim on the attached property by anyone it was for him to move the High Court Division and it is for this Court to investigate and decide the issue. The District Judge illegally questioned the attachment of the property by this Court and acted beyond his jurisdiction in setting aside the auction sale.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>In re Kumud Ramjan Sarker and others, 1 BLD (HCD) 251.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. IBLD (HCD) 96; A.I.R.1962 (Cal) 86; 20 DLR982; 27 DLR (SC) 133;—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Sections—47 and 144</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Application for restitution is not an application for execution of a decree, but it is an independent application governed by Art. 181 and not Article 182 of the of the Limitation Act—Limitation Act, 1908(IX of 1908).</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">An application for restitution is an independent application, no matter its object is the recovery of the fruit of a decree passed earlier but subsequently reversed. Application for restitution is an application for which no limitation has been specifically provided for in the law and as such it attracts the residuary provision of Article 181 of the Limitation Act. A restitution application is not an application for execution of a decree and as such it is not governed by Article 182 but it is governed by Article 1 8 1 of the Limitation Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Shamuj Ali and others Vs. Kama-larma Bibi and others, 1 BLD (HCD) 131.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. A.I.R. 1934 All 626 (F.B.); A.I.R. 1932(Cal) 308; A.I.R. 1928 (Cal) 646; A.I.R. 1947(Nag) 239; AIR. 1925(Pat)l; AIR. 1917(Mad) 185; AIR. 1917 (Bom) 210; AIR. 1934 (Pat) 246; A.I.R. 1943 (Mad)248; AIR. 1921 (Born) 67; A.I.R. 1965 (SC) 1477; AIR. 1922 (PC) 269; 27 C.L.J. 45 1(1970); .I.L.R 1933 (Cal) 1—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—47</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Execution of decree passed by the Company Judge under section 63(3) of Banking Companies Ordinance</span></strong>— Subordinate Court in execution cannot question the legality of the decree— Section 63(9) empowers the Company Judge to entertain application under section 63(3) beyond the statutory period of limitation—Banking Companies Ordinance, 1962 (LVII of 1982) Sections. 61, 63(3)(9).</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Tripura Modern Bank Ltd. Vs. Shuva Karan Rajgharia, 1 BLD (HCD) 96.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—47</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Suit ending on compromise decree— Review permissible?—Decree-ho Ider taking delivery of possession by execution of the compromise decree—Decree holder taking delivery of possession of more land than entitled—Remedy of the judgment- debtor lies in filing an application under section 47 C.P.C and not in a separate suit for partition.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Abdul Mujib Chowdhury Vs. Syed Abdul Mutalib &amp; others, 1 BLD (HCD) 464.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. A.I.R. 1928 (Lah) 936; A.I.R. 1957 (Pat) 700; 26 DLR279;—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—47 &amp; Order XXII Rules 3,4 and 8 Execution of decree</span></strong>—The Executing Court becomes functus officio after execution of the decree—The question whether a decree is void abinitio may be raised in a proceeding in execution since it is a question relating to execution of the decree—But this question cannot be raised after the decree has been executed—After execution of the decree section 47 C.P.C. will not apply.—There will then be no bar to filing of a suit for declaration of nullity of the decree on the ground of its having been passed against a dead person.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Abdul Hakim Vs. Goleda Begum and another; 4 BLD (AD) 55.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 18 DLR 535; A.I.R. l924(IC) 198; A.I.R.1928 (Mad) 914; A.I.R. 1923 (Mad) 237; A.I.R. 1931 (Pat) 57; A.I.R. 1936 (Cal) 540; 1 B.C.R. 236; 20 DLR 1050; 17 I.L.R. (All) 78; 5 C.W.N. 627; A.I.R. 1935 (Cal) 645; AIR. 1929 (Lah) 121; A.I.R. 1939 Lah) 405; 12 DLR 631—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—47</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Whether an auction sale can be challenged by filing a suit by the judgment debtor —Whether such a suit is barred</span></strong>—If no question arises between the parties to the suit in which the decree was passed, such a suit by the judgment debtor against the stranger auction purchaser for recovery of possession is not barred under section 47 C.P.C. if it is brought within 12 years.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Jamsheduddin Bhuiyan Vs. Anwar Begum, 6 BLD (HCD) 112.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 5DLR 296; 5 DLR 163—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Sections—47 and 151</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Inherent power of Court</span></strong>—Its applicability in the case of dismissal of a petition under section 47 C.P.C. for default —An order of dismissal of an application under section 47 C.P.C. is not a decree under section 2(2) C.P.C. and as such it is not an appeal able order—The petitioner has no other remedy against the order dismissing his application under section 47 of the Code for default—In :he circumstances of the case, the learned Subordinate Judge should have considered :he application invoking inherent power on merits and should not have thrown it out in lmini.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Sbnaban Bibi Vs. Aba Miah and others;</span></strong> <strong>BLD (HCD) 364</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 28 DLR (HCD)3; A.I.R.1963 P.59— Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Sections—47 and 151</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Review and inherent power of the Court</span></strong> —Absence of statutory alternative remedy against dismissal of objection petition under section 47 C.P.C.— Application under section 151 C.P.C. rejected on an erroneous view of non-applicability of section 151 C.P.C. and non-maintainability of the application thereunder.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The learned Musnif acted illegally and with material irregularity in refusing to restore the objection filed under section 47 of the Code of Civil Procedure.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The submission of the learned Advocate for the opposite parties is devoid of any merit. There appears to be nothing in the Code of Civil Procedure which specifically authorizes a party to make a second application in the facts of the case. In the absence of any alternative remedy available against the order of dismissal of their objection under section 47 of the Code of Civil Procedure, the petitioners, therefore, are entitled to take resort to the inherent power of the Court under section 151 of the Code of Civil Procedure for ends of justice. It is also a settled principle that where a mistake of a Court or Courts officer causes some injuries to a particular party, the power under section 151 of the Code cans be exercised for the purpose of giving necessary relief to aggrieved party even though there is an alternative remedy for doing the same.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The learned Munsif has acted illegally and with material irregularity in refusing to restore the objection filed under section 47 of the Code of Civil Procedure.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Boynuddin and others Vs. Azimuddin and others; 10 B.L.D. (HCD) 267.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—47</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Decree—Execution of</span></strong> —Question of execution in a case of joint decree holders some of whose property became vested property—Even assuming that the interest of a decree-holder became vested property and the decree to the extent of his interest cannot be executed, there is no reason why the decree to the extent of the interest of other decree-holders cannot be executed—Orders of the Courts below refusing execution on such grounds are set aside and the case is sent back on remand for fresh decision—Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 (V of 1908), Or. 21, R.5.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Tanjina Khatoon Vs. Nubaruddin and others, 10 BLD (HCD) 250.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—47</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">After the repeal of section 47 of the Code the limited jurisdiction vested in the executing Court to decide the question of execution, discharge and satisfaction of the decree has been taken away to save the decree holder from the misery of facing unlimited number of objections against the execution of the decree and thereby delaying the execution of the decree indefinitely.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Tripura Modern Bank Ltd. Vs. Sunil Kuinary Rajgharia and others, 11 BLD (HCD) 479 (483).</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Sections—50 and 2(11)</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Legal representative</span></strong>—Whether heirs of a deceased tenant can be treated as the legal representatives for the purpose of executing the decree—The definition of legal representative shall be given a wide meaning to include the heirs of a deceased tenant who dies during the pendency of an execution case started in pursuance of a decree for eviction of the tenant from the suit premises—Premises Rent Control Ordinance, 1963 (XX of 1963), S. 2(9).</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Kazal Das Surma and others Vs. Pradip Das alias Shambhu and others, 9 BLD (HCD) 162.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 1934 (All) 474; 32DLR (AD) 170; 32 DLR (AD) 97; 2 B.C.R. (AD) 428—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—60</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Attachment before judgment</span></strong>— unless a prima facie ownership of a property is determined the same is not liable to be attached by an order of the Court—Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 (V of 1908), Order 38 Rules 5 and 6.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Messrs R. Ahmed and sons Vs. Messrs Eastern Technique &amp; ors., 1 BLD (HCD) 67.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. (1952) 2 Q.B. 84; 27DLR 256; 31 DLR(AD)1 12—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Sections—82 and 141</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Reporting of a case</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Reporting a case for orders of the Government—Whether the provision for reporting is applicable few execution of orders passed in a writ proceeding?—There is no conflict of decisions regarding the fact that the execution proceedings under the C.P.C. will not apply to writ proceedings for execution of the judgment passed therein—Even if secti&amp;i 141 C.P.C. is applied to writ proceedings, the matters covering the execution of the decrees do not apply in such proceedings—The application for reporting the case for orders is rejected as not maintainable— Constitution of Bangladesh, 1972; Article102.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Neerala Tea Estate Ltd. and others Vs.
