Government of Bangladesh and others; 9 BLD (HCD) 65.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref AIR 1957 (Cal) 702 19S9 (Mad) 137 AIR 1965 (All) 517 AIR 1962 (Guj) 202; A.I.R. 1968 (Punj) 360; AIR 1968 (Gui) 202 AIR 1967 (Cal) 275 AIR 1963 (Punj) 510 PLD 1963(W P) (Lah) 178 PLD 1965 (W P) (Lab) 596 AIR 1962 (SC) 1886 ILR 17 All106 (P.C.); 35 DLR (AD) I 2B.C.R. D) 373—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Sections—91, 93 and Order 7 Rule 11 </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Removal of a Trustee</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Permission to file a suit for removal of trustee of a Religious or Charitable Trust — Whether the Deputy Commissioner can grant permission for filing such suit ?— To exercise such powers the Deputy Commissioner must take previous sanction of the Government in each case though he was empowered to give such permission —District Judge acted illegally in not rejecting the plaint in a suit filed without such sanction.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Sunil Kumar Bhattacharjee Vs. Sree Jatindar Mohan Das and others, 5 BLD (HCD) 147.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. A.I.R. 1931 (PC) 121; A.LR. 1932 (PC) 51; A.I.R. 1955 (Cal) 155; 52 C.W.N. 83 I—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—92</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Locus standi to file suit for Public Charities</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Locus standi of a worshipper to file a suit to protect debuttar property—A suit for declaration of title and possession of such a property from a person who is in possession thereof under a void alienation being in the nature of enforcement of a private right by the idol and not being for any one of the reliefs embodied in section 92 of the C.P.C. falls outside its purview and is not barred—When such an alienation has been effected by the Shebait acting adversely to the interest of the idol, even a worshipper can file the suit.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Anil Kumar Sarkar and others Vs. Sree Kalimata Bigraha, 4 BLD (HCD) 1.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. AIR. 1967 (SC) 1044; 16 DLR (SC) 457; A.I.R. 1974 (Cal) 126; —Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—92</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Consent or sanction</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Consent or sanction communicated by the Administrator of the office of the Attorney General for filing a suit whether valid? — Since the Attorney General consented and accorded sanction for filing the suit in respect of breach of trust on perusal of the petition and copy of the plaint, the consent is proper though the Administrative Officer of the office of the Attorney General has communicated the said permission to the plaintiff.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>The Rajshahi Dharma Sava and others Vs. Sree Saktibhuti Chowdhury and others; 5 BLD (HCD) 233.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Sections—94, 115 and Order 39 Rule 1</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Election Tribunal—Extent of its jurisdiction</span></strong>—Whether it is competent to pass orders of temporary injunction— Election Tribunal would have the powers of a Civil Court trying a suit under the Code of Civil Procedure only for decision of the matter before it and not beyond —It is not a Civil Court under the civil Courts Act, 1887 and it is not a part of the judicial system of the country —The Tribunal was created for a limited purpose by a special law and it is under the superintendence of the executive authority—The power of transfer of an election petition is with the Election Commission, not with the District Judge, the appellate authority, which indicates that the Election Tribunals are not amenable to provisions of the Code of Civil Procedure—The appellate Tribunal also could not be considered as a Civil Court only because the appellate authority of the Tribuani has been found to be a Civil Court —True, there is incongruity if the appellate authority has one character and the Tribunal has a different character—It is for the legislature to bring about a uniformity between the superstructure and the infrastructure of an institution—Since the Election Tribunals are not Civil Courts, they also are not amenable to the revisiOnal jurisdiction of the High Court Division—Local Government (Union Panshads) Ordinance, 1983, S. 29—Union Panishads Ordinance, 1983, Rules 47 and 48.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Mohmd Hossain Vs. Md. Sayeb Au and others, 9 BLD (HCD) 173</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 27 DLR 388; 28 DLR189; 29 D.L.R.111; 38 DLR (AD)172; 37DLR71; 38 DLR41; 38 DLR 262; 38 DLR 435; 31 DL119—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Sections—96, 115 and Order 43 Rule 1</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">District Judge has no revisional jurisdiction over a matter in which he has no appellate jurisdiction.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A Court which cannot exercise jurisdiction over a matter in appeal is not intended to exercise its revisional jurisdiction. It is inconsistent with scheme of the Code of Civil Procedure and the Civil Courts Act to invest the District Judge with concurrent revisional juris-diction in matters where no appeal lies before the District Judge. The District Judge’s revisional jurisdiction under section 115(2) is restricted by his appellate jurisdiction as provided under section 21(1) of the Civils Court Act—Civil Courts Act, 1887 (XII of 1887), 5. 3,6,7,8, 18, 19, 20 and 21.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Nurul Islam and others Vs. Md. Abdur Rashid, 1 BLD (HCD) 25.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Section—96</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Appeal by a stranger to the suit</span></strong>— Whether a person who is not a necessary party in the suit can prefer an appeal against the decree —The application of the petitioners for being added as a party in the suit was rejected on the ground that he is a stranger to the contract sought to be specifically performed and his subsequent application to be added as a party in the proceeding for setting aside the expert decree passed in that suit was also rejected —Such finding that the petitioner is not a necessary party in the suit would be binding on him and cannot be repaginated for the second time—It could not be said that the petitioner might properly have been a party in the suit or proceeding though he was not made a party in the suit and that he is not merely a stranger and his legal interest is adversely affected by the judgment passed in his absence—The petitioner could not be said to be or ought to have been made a party in the suit or proceeding and has not been made a party and thereby even as a stranger was not competent to file the appeal.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Md. Abdul Hoque Vs. Mst. Zainab Begum, 7 BLD (HCD) 158.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 21 DLR (SC) 50; (1958) IQ.B. 12(17)—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Sections—97, 151 and 152</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Amendment of decree</span></strong>—When it can be done 7 —The Court can always amend the decree if there is a mistake that had crept in for bringing the decree in conformity with the judgment.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Ismail Ullah, being dead his heirs Bazidullah and others Vs. Sukumar Chandra Das, 6 BLD (AD) 251</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. A.I.R. 1961(S.C.) 790; 42 l.A. 91; A.I.R.1965 (SC) 1325; L.R. 1885(C.D.) 239; 1892 L.R. (AC) 547; A.I.R. 1926 (PC)136; A.I.R. 1924 (Cal) 895; 36 C.W.N.665; 591. L.R.(Bombay)158;--Cited.</p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>

1146	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">CONCILIATION COURTS ORDINANCE, 1961</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  1BLD (AD) 239</p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  1961</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  CONCILIATION COURTS</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p align="center" style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">CONCILIATION COURTS ORDINANCE, 1961 (XLIV OF 1961)</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Section—3</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Conciliation Courts Ordinance</span></strong>—The word ‘contrad’ has not been qualified in the Ordinance in any way and as such should embrace an oral contract as well as a written one.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Suchitra Kumar Das Vs. Sree Indu Bhushan Sarker; 1BLD (AD) 239</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 21 DLR (SC) 39; 17 DLR 261; 17DLR 415.</p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
1147	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">CONSTITUTION OF BANGLADESH, 1972 [ARTICLE 1 -100]</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  1989 BLD(Spl)1, 1989 BLD((Special Issue), 1BLD (AD) 107, 12BLD(AD)149, 2 BLD (AD)34, 9BLD (AD)25, 2 BLD(AD)83, 2 BLD(AD)120, 1BLD (AD)8, 1BLD(AD) 140, 1BLD (HCD) 493, 2BLD (HCD) 1, 2BLD(HCD)98, 9 BLD (AD) 25, BLD(HCD)161, 11 BLD (HCD)8, 12BLD’AD)149, 1BL</p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  1972</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  CONSTITUTION OF BANGLADESH</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p> </p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p align="center"><strong>CONSTITUTION OF BANGLADESH, 1972</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Constitution of Bangladesh — Preamble</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Interpretation — Role of the Preamble — Preamble is a part of the Constitution and it has got special importance in the interpretation of the Constitution.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The preamble can only be amended by referendum and, therefore, is a part of the Constitution. (Para-48)</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Few Constitutions have such a Preamble. Its amenability is rightly protected which can only be done by the people at a referendum. In Indian jurisdiction, the contention that Preamble should be regarded as ‘guiding star’ has been repelled (1950 S.C.R. 88(120, 198). Nor it has been regarded as a source of any substantive power (A.I.R.1960 (SC)845. [Para-501</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It is needless to pursue the point further because it has been noticed already that in our Constitution the Preamble can only be altered by the People because our Constitution has proceeded from the people and it is not a rhetorical flourish. Our Constitution is not the result of the process of the Indian Independence Act, 1947 though we have taken inspiration from the wisdom of the past. Our is an ‘autochthonous’ Constitution. [Para—5 I]</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Per S. Ahmed, J:</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">There is no dispute that the Preamble is a part of the Constitution. As to the use of the preamble of a statute, it cannot be used to modify the language of the statute if it is clear, plain and unambiguous giving one and one meaning. But if the language is not clear and the words used therein indicate or are capable of bearing more than one meaning, then the meaning which is nearest to the purpose of the statute is to be preferred. [1957 AC, 436 — ref] (Para-353)</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Anwar Hossain Chowdhury Vs. Bangladesh, 1989 BLD(Spl)1</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Articles — 1, 44 and 94 to 116</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Unitary Character of State</span></strong> — The scope of having more superior Courts are keeping in line with the unitary character of the State.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><u><span style="line-height: 115%;">Per B.H. Chowdhury, J:</span></u></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The amendment purports to create territorial units which eventually may claim the status of federating units thereby destroying the very fabric of the unitary Republic. In other words, by sowing the seeds of regionalism the next step can be dismantling the fabric of the Republic. (Para — 238).</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><u><span style="line-height: 115%;"><span style="text-decoration: none;"> </span></span></u></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><u><span style="line-height: 115%;">Per S. Ahmed, J:</span></u></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It is not permissible to create a separate High Court under the Supreme Court as it will run counter to the, unitary character of the State opening a door for its ultimate disintegration As to the unitary character of the State, it is clear that in view of the homogeneity of her people having same language, culture, tradition and way of life, within a small territory the State has been so organised as a unitary State by its founding fathers leaving no scope for devolution of executive, legislative and judicial powers on different regions to turn into Provinces ultimately. (Para —361 and 362).</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><u><span style="text-decoration: none;"> </span></u></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><u>Per M.H. Rahman, j:</u></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It has been repeatedly pointed out before us that because of the unitary character of our Republic, the Constitution makers devised only one Court for the whole of Bangladesh in the Supreme Court of Bangladesh comprising the Appellate Division and the High Court Division. In a unitary State there can be more than one Appellate Court like the High Court, but both in a unitary and in a federal State there must be one Court having full plenary power over the whole State ... Our founding fathers devised a composite Supreme court to emphasise the oneness of the country. (Para — 484)</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Anwar Hossain Chowdhury Vs. Bangladesh, 1989 BLD((Special Issue), Page 1</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Article—7</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Constitution — Its supremacy</span></strong> — With the proclamation of Martial Law the Constitution was reduced to a position subordinate to the Proclamations issued by the Chief Martial Law Administrator.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In view of the Second Proclamation there of no scope for advancing an argument that Martial Law was declared by the President nd not by the Chief Martial Law Administrator and that the Proclamation issued by the President is not above the Constitution.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It is true that Article 7(2) of tie Constitution declares the Constitution as the supreme law of the Republic and if any other law is consistent with the Constitution that other of shall, to the extent of the inconsistency, void, but the supremacy of the Constitutor cannot by any means compete with the Proclamation issued by the Chief Martial Law Administrator.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Kh. Ehteshamuddin Ahmed alias Iqbal Vs. Bangladesh and others, 1BLD (AD) 107</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 30 DLR(SC)207;32 DLR(AD) 110</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">— Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Article — 7</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">An amending law under Article 142 is not 3 law within the meaning of Article 7 of the Constitution.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><u>Per S. Ahmed, J:</u></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Article 7 provides that any law inconsistent with the Constitution is void; besides it ikclares that Constitution is the supreme law f the Republic. (Para— 340)</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">An amendment of the Constitution is not included in law within the meaning of Article 7 in the same way as it is not law in Article 26. (Para — 342)</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><u>Per M.H. Rahman, J:</u></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The validity of an amendment of the Conziwti6n cannot be examined on the touchqone of Article 7. (Para — 423)</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><u>Per A.T.M. Afzal, J(dissentin):</u></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The question, however, is whether any other law’ in sub-article (2) of Article 7 would take in a law amending the Constitution itself enacted under the constituent power, in as much the same way as an ordinary law enacted under the ordinary legislative power. Mr. Ahmed contends that whether constituent or legislative, Parliament derives the power from the Constitution and in exercise of that power enacts an Act of Parliament in both cases and by definition, ‘law’ means any Act etc (Art. 152); therefore there is no reason why a law amending the Constitution should have any higher status and be not subjected to Art. 7 for examining its legitimacy as any other law. Mr. Ahmed has not referred to any authority in support of his proposition. It becomes difficult to agree with him having regard to the views expressed by Judges and jurists as to the position and quality of a law which is enacted under the constituent power of a Parliament even though it is a derivative power and further the position of constitutional law in relation to ordinary law made under ordinary legislative process. (Para — 556)</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Anwar Hossain Chowdhury Vs. Bangladesh, 1989 BLD (Spl)1</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Articles — 7(1), 8 and 11</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A system of indirect election cannot be called undemocratic. It is provided in the</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Constitution itself. –</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Dr. Ahmed Hossain Vs. Bangladesh and others, 12BLD(AD)149</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Articles — 8 and 17</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Requisition of Property—Public Purpose</span></strong> — Requisition for accommodation of a private school is for a public purpose— Oblique hints and vague grievances cannot dislodge the purpose—Enquiry as to public purposes by reference to the Fundamental Principles of State Policy is not warranted by the Constitution. —- Emergency Requisition of Property Act, 1948 (XIII of 1948), S. 3.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Bangladesh Vs. Mrs. Winifred Rubi and others, 2 BLD (AD)34</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 14DLR486;A.I.R. 1914 (PC)21; 14 DLR 634; — Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Articles — 9, 11 and 27</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Right of Election — Protection against invasion of such right to be a candidate for election is a democratic right which must be zealously guarded and effectively protected against any invasion from any quarter — Thwarting this right by creating artificial classification among the people will cut at the root of the democratic set-up of the Republic.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Sheikh, Abdus Sabur Vs. Bangladesh I. W. T.A. Ghat Sramik Union and another, 2 BLD(AD)83</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Articles —26 and 65</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Validation of invalid Law</span></strong>—Law dedared ultra virues due to violation of fundamental right — Enactment to validate the law — Test of validity of the validating law.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The validity of a validating law is to be judged by three tests, the first is to see whether Parliament is clothed with the legislative power on the subject. The second is whether by validation, Parliament has removed the defect which the court had found in the earlier Law. And thirdly whether the validating law is consistent with the provision of the constitution. When all the three tests have been fulfilled, the validation law may operate retrospectively, if Parliament so expresses it in the validating enactment. The invalidity of a law may be owing to some</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">legislative incompetence or to us repugnancy to any of the fundamental rights and they can be cured in the manner set out above [Per K. Hossain, C.J.]</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Mofizur Rahinan Khan Vs. E.R. 694; A.I.R. 1954 (SC) 369; A.I.R. 1957 (SC) 892; A.I.R. 1965 (SC) 280; AIR. 1975 (SC) 1487; A.I.R. 1970 (All) 296; A.I.R. 1972 (Mys) 71;PLD 1967 (Lah) 227; PLD 1959 (SC) 37; PLDI97I (Kar)333; I 9DLR(SC)28 I; I 957SCA 660—Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> </span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Article — 27</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Equality before the law and equal protection of law</span></strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> — Meaning and content — Classification when permissible.</span></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The principle as stated in Article 27 of the Constitution contains the English concept of equality before law and the American concept of equal protection of the laws... These are not independent or severable concepts in their application and will often be found to Overlap each other. The principle on which i doctrine of equal protection of law is needed is that persons in similar circumstances must be governed by the same laws. The prohibition against denial of equal prohibition does not preclude the legislature from confining legislation to a class or classes, prating different acts or rules for different class. But the rule speaks the conditions classification or discrimination is not art  but reasonable and rests on a real and utensil difference or distinction which just and reasonable relation to the legion or the subject or object thereof and  the legislation operates equally, unafraid impartially on all persons or prop within the same class. The Court has to when a law is alleged to be repugnant to rule of equality is what the object of the is, what is the method provided therein tire the achievement of the object and whether there is a reasonable relation between the method adopted and the end intended to be achieved.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Dr. Nurul Islam Vs. Bangladesh, 1 BLD (AD) 14O</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Articles — 27 and 29</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Discriminatory Law</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Law conferring unfettered discretion without providing guideline is discriminatory.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A statutory provision might not in terms t a discriminatory rule of law, but if it is fraught with the inherent danger of enabling an unequal or discriminatory treatment to persons similarly placed, .offends the guarantee of equal protection.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Dr. Nurul Islam Vs. Bangladesh, 1BLD (AD)140</span></em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: AIR I 962(SC) l 602 — Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Articles — 27 and 29</span></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Service of the Republic—Ante-dated seniority—Government Servants (Seniority of</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Fighters) Rules, 1979 granting two years ante-dated seniority to freedom fighters is discriminatory and is hit by Articles 27 and 29 of the Constitution.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Zajnul Abedin and another Vs. Returning Officer, District Education Officer-in-Charge, Gopalganj and others, 9 BLD (AD) 25.</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article — 27</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Equal protection of law</strong>—The term is used to mean that all persons or things are not equal in all cases and that persons similarly situated should be treated alike — Equal protection is the guarantee that similar people will be dealt with in a similar way and that people of different circumstances will not be treated as if they were the same.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Sheikh Abdus Sabur Vs. Returning Officer, District Education Officer-in-Charge, Gopalganj and others, 9 BLD(AQ) 25</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article — 27</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>‘Permissible criteria’</strong> — What it is — A single law cannot be applied uniformly to all persons disregarding their basic differences with others — If the differences are identified, then the persons or things may be classified into different categories according to those distinctions and this is what is called the permissible criteria or intelligible differentia’.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Sheikh Abdus Sabur Vs. A reasonable classification is never ultravires of the equality thuse.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Md.
