The People’s Republic of Bangladesh, 11 BLD (HCD)8</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article — 28(4)</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Indirect Election not undemocratic</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A system of indirect election cannot be called undemocratic. It is provided in the Constitution itself. The amendment is not also violative of Article 28—Clause (4) of Article 28 of the Constitution provides that nothing in that Article shall prevent the State, which expression includes Parliament, from making special provision in favour of women.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Dr. Ahmed Hossain Vs. Bangladesh and others, 12BLD’AD)149</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article — 29</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Seniority—Promotion</strong>——Seniority is a vested right and promotion of junior without considering the cases of senior violates equality of opportunity in public employment.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Mohamniad Faizullah Vs. Govt. of Bangladesh, 1BLD(HCD)1</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article—29</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Article 29 is not confined to the initial matters prior to the act of employment but includes other matters relating to employment such as provisions about salary and periodical increments therein, terms as to leave, gratuity and pension and as to the age of superannuation. It also includes promotion to selection posts. -</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Equality of opportunity under Article 29 does not prohibit the prescription of reasonable rules.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Mohammad Faizullah Vs. Govt. of Bangladesh, 1BLD(HCD)1</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: A.I.R.1962(SC)36; A.I.R.l964 Mysore229 — Cited.</p><p> </p><p> </p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article—29</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Equality of opportunity in public employment</strong>—Classification based on reasonable and intelligible differentia bearing rational nexus with the object of classification is not discriminatory.<strong><em> Dr. Nurul Islam Vs. Bangladesh and others, 1BLD (HCD) 12</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: AIR. 1974(SC)l —Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article—31</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Constitutional law</strong>—Retrospective validation of law and actions — Article 31 of the Constitution is no bar to such retrospective validation.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Mofizur Rahman Khan Vs. Govt. of Bangladesh, 2BLD (AD)120</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article—31</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Fundamental right to protection of law</strong>—Government sold a property to the petitioner and thereafter dispossessed the petitioner from that property—To enjoy protection of law and to be treated with law is the inalienable right guaranteed to every citizen under the Constitution.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Ragib Ali Vs. Bangladesh and others, 2BLD(HCD)100</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article — 32 read with S. 3(1) of the Special Powers Act, 1974</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Constitution of Bangladesh guarantees the liberty of the citizens under Article 32— Article 32 provides that no person shall be deprived of his life or personal liberty save in accordance with law.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Upon the conflict between the constitutional mandate and the discretion of the detaining authority u/s. 3(1) of the Special Powers Act, the High Court is to exercise judicial review of the executive acts and may strike down the actions which are “malafide, colourable exercise of statutory powers or action taken upon extraneous or irrelevant consideration or action taken on no ground or without application of mind” the actions not taken with lawful authority may be branded as actions taken in an unlawful manner.”</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Nazir Ali Vs. Secretary, Ministry of Home Affairs and others, 1OBLD(HCD) 258</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 31 DLR(AD) I — Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article — 33(4) read with sections 3 and of the Special Powers Act, 1974</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Detention for over six months — Validity of such detention without approval by</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Advisory Board — It is clear from the provision of the Constitution that if the Advisory Board does not report within six months that there is sufficient cause for the detention, Government cannot detain the detenu beyond six months — The detent was never placed before the Advisory Board within six months of his detention — The order of detention therefore in contravention of the constitutional provisions.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Monowara Begum Vs. Secretary, Ministry of Home Affairs and others,  9BLD(HCD) 467</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Articles — 33(5) read with section 8(2) the Special Powers Act, 1974</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Detention — Communicating grounds detention in a leisurely manner, deprecated</strong>—The detaining authority must at ways keep in view the constitutional provisions tha the authority making the order of preventiv detention shall, as soon as possible, communicate to the detained person the grounds which the order of detention has been made The provision made in the Special Powers Act ‘but not later than 15 days from the dat of detention” does not give a general licen to the authority to cause service of grounds of detention in a leisuiely manner within 15 days in every case deliberately deprive the detenu of his valuable legal right to make effective reprsentation at the earliest possible opportunity to the appropriate authority or to move the Court at once.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Dr. Md. Habibullah, Vs. Secretary, Ministry of Home Affairs, Govt. of Bangladesh and others, 9BLD(HCD)387</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 31DLR(AD)1; 2ODLRSC)49; DLR(SC) 1; 1 9DLR(SC)403; 2ODLR(SC) 249(257); A.I.R.1975 (SC) 6231A.195ACX6— Cited.; </p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article — 38 with Preamble</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Nature of the right under Article 38</strong> — The rights under Article 38 of the Constitution to form association are fundamental for civic life so that citizens may, ‘prosper in freedom’.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Freedom of association</strong> — The right under Article 38 of the Constitution implies that several individuals having a community of interest can join together to form a voluntary association for furtherance of a common lawful object. The rights are fundamental for civic life so that citizens may ‘prosper in freedom’.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Article 38 cannot, however, be invoked for support, sustenance or fulfillment of every object of an association.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The word ‘form’ in Article 38 does not limit the exercise of the right to the formation of an association. The right to form an association must necessarily imply the right to continue and carry on the activities of the association as well.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Md. Asaduzzaman Vs. Bangladesh and others, 10 BLD(AD)267</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. A.I.R.1952(SC)l96; PLD1964 (SC) 673; A.I.Rl97l (SC)966; A.I.R.l952 (SC) 196; A.I.R.l952 (Cal) 901; A.I.R. 1970 (SC)l 29(135); A.I.R. 1981 (SC)873 (880); A.1.R.l982(SC)902 (911); 26DLR (SC) 44; 1961 AC6I 7(634);A.I.R. I 962(SC)1 71 ;—Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article — 39(2)</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Freedom of Press</strong> — When the question of restriction in the interest of or in relation to matters mentioned in Article 39(2) of the Constitution is not involved, refusal to authenticate a declaration of a newspaper on the basis of opinion of the police that the peptone’s declaration could not be authenticated in view of his political background must be held illegal and unconstitutional.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>SK. Faziul Karim Selim Vs. Bangladesh and anothei 1BLD(HCD)344</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: PLD 1969 (Dac) 463; PLD 1962 (Kar) 537 Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Articles — 45 and 102</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Writ — High Court Division has no jurisdiction to interfere with the decision and order of Court Martial except on limited grounds.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Jamil Huq Vs. Bangladesh, 1BLD (AD)488</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 44 C.W.N.709;(1969) lAll. ER. 242; (1949)lAll. E.R. 373; 259 U.S.326; 344 U.S. 137; 33 DLR(AD)143; IBLD (AD)378; IBLD(AD) 107 — Cited.</p><p> </p><p> </p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Sections — 45, 102, 134, 135 and 152(2)</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Service — Disciplined force — Members of Police Service </strong>— Writ Petition by a police officer challenging disciplinary action is maintainable. The authorities mentioned in the schedule to the Ordinance, 1976 are not “tribunals’ as contemplated in sub-article (5) of Article 102 of the constitution, so as to deny an aggrieved member of the police force the remedy under Article 102 of the constitution. In an appropriate case when has been illegally dismissed, removed discharged, compulsorily retired or reduced in Lower rank, he is entitled to invoke the writ jurisdiction under Article 102 of the constitution. <strong>[Per R. Islam, J. (B. H. Chowdhury and S. Ahmed, JJ. concurring)]</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The authority’ mentioned in the Police Officers Ordinance, 1976 is a Tribunal. Any decision of the authority of Tribunal under this ordinance is immune from challenge under article 102 of the constitution, except within the rule laid down by this Division in Khondker Ehteshamuddin Ahmed alias Iqbal Vs. The State (IBLD(AD)107). <strong>[Per K. Hossam, C.J. (F. Munim, J. concurring)]</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Bangladesh Vs. A.K.M. Zahaiigir Hossam, IBLD(AD)378</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: IBLD(AD)l07 —Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article — 47(2)</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Article 47 read with the 1st Schedule of the Constitution has protected State Acquisition and Tenancy Act-and clear indication has been given in the Constitution itself and when parent legislation is immune from attack the consequential amendments are to be viewed in that light, namely for giving effect to the parent legislation unless it could be shown that the amendment minus the protection is otherwise unconstitutional. No such case has been or could be made out and no argument was advanced on behalf of the respondents.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Bangladesh Vs. Haji Abdul Gani Biswas and others, 1BLD(AD)8</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Articles — 52 and 102</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Power of Attorney</strong> — When petition has been filed against the Government by virtue of power of attorney authorising institution of legal proceeding against the Government, the power of attorney is not invalid and does not attract the mischief of Article 52 of the Constitution merely because it authorises the done to institute legal proceeding against the President — Power of Attorney Act, 1882 (VII of 1882), S. 2.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Zamiruddin Ahmed Vs. Govt. of Bangladesh, IBLD(HCD)304</em></strong></p><p> </p><p> </p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Articles — 52 and 53</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Immunity of the President</strong> — Article 53 of the Constitution provides for impeachment of the President during the term of his office and not after he vacated the office — Article 52 of the Constitution provides for immunity of the President and the Vice-President from Court proceedings during the term of their office and not after they vacated the office — Amendment of Reg. 11 of Martial Law Regulation No. I of 1975 by Reg. 6 of Martial Law (Twenty Third Amendment) Regulations, 1 976 to bring the President within the mischief of Reg. 11 is not inalafide.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Khandker Mostaque Ahmed Vs. Govt. of Bangladesh, 1BLD(HCD)333</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 30 DLR(AD)207; 32DLR(AD) 216; 33DLR (AD)l 54 — Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article — 52(1)</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>President’s Immunity</strong>—President’s Immunity from Criminal Prosecution — The immunity is available to the President while he is in office.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Hussain Mohammad Ershad Vs. The State, 1 BLD (AD) 55.</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article — 56(3)</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Executive action of the Government</strong> — Authority to take such action — In the absence of any delegation of power the Government means the President — Unless provided for in the Rules of business, the Government order must be approved or ordered by the President — No power having been vested in the Add. Secretary to take the impugned action against the member of the Managing Committee of the Co-operative Society, the entire proceeding thereto was without jurisdiction — Co-operative Societies Ordinance, 1984 (I of 1985), S. 26.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Jn. Md. Saleh Ahmed Khan Vs. Govt. of Bangladesh and others, 9BLD(HCD) 410</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 31 DLR(AD) 152; 1 7DLR(SC)209; 34DLR 120; 40DLR353; — Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article — 56(3) read with section 3 of the Special Powers Act, 1974</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">An order of detention that is made by the District Magistrate on being satisfied about the prejudical act by any person and the cx- tension of such order by the Government under the said section 3 of the Special Power Act, there is no requirement of law to place it before the President for its approval and consequently there is no obligation nor scope to pass order by noting it as ‘By order of the President and this not being a purely executive order the provision of Article 56(3) of the Constitution is not applicable to this. case.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Md. Sekandar Ali on behalf of the detenu Abdul Majid Howlader Vs. The Govt. of Bangladesh and others, 11BLD (HCD)112</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article — 56</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Prize Court Fund— Rules of business</strong> — Matters exclusively reserved for the Ministry of Finance cannot be dealt with by any other Ministry — Ministry of Law is not competent to initiate proceeding for distribution and in- vestment of Prize Court Fund — Rules of Business, 1975, R. 10. — Prize Court Rules, 1939, Or. XXXIV.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Bangladesh Vs. Hon ‘ble Judge, Prize Court, 2 BLD’AD)147</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article — 65</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Power to validate invalid law</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Constitutional law</strong>—Legislature has power of retrospective legislation and retrospective validation of invalid law. Parliament is the supreme legislative authority subject to the constitutional limitations—One of the attributes of lcislative supremacy is its power to pass any law on any subject, not prohibited by the Constitution, both prospectively and retrospectively. It can equally validate, subject to Constitution, any earlier law found invalid either prospectively or retrospectively.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Mofizur Rahman Khan Vs. Govt. of Bangladesh, 2BLD(AD)120</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Articles — 65 and 102</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Constitutional law</strong> — Extent of legislative power — Retrospective validation of law and action taken on invalid law — Legislature cannot reverse the decision of the Court which will amount to exercise of judicial power.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Mofizur Rahman Khan Vs. The Govt. of Bangladesh, 2 BLD(AD)120</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: A.I.R.l969(SC)394; A.I.R.1970 (SC)l970 — Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p> </p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article — 83</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>‘Rate of duty’</strong> — Who can perform the function of levying duty — It is the function of the legislature to prescribe the ‘rate of duty’ in appropriate legislation — This function of levying of customs duties’ cannot be performed by or delegated to anybody or institution other than the Parliament — ft is the Parliament and Parliament alone which can levy taxes including ustoms duties — Customs Act, 1969 (IV of 1969), S. 18.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>A. Hannan Vs. The Collector of Custonzs and others, 9BLD(HCD)21</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Articles — 85 and 86</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Prize Court Fund</strong> — Prize Court Fund consists of money payable into the Public Accounts of the Republic — Under the Rules of Business only the Ministry of Finance could move an application before the Prize Court with formal proposal and a working scheme for withdrawal of money from the fund. Article 85 of the Constitution provides that all public moneys which will form part either of the Consolidated Fund or the Public Accounts of the Republic is payable into such Fund or Account or can be withdrawn from under an Act of the Parliament or Rules made by the President. There is neither an Act of Parliament nor any rules by the President which govern the mode of payment of the money constituting the Prize Court Fund into the Public Accounts of the Republic. In the absence of any enactment or rules, which the Constitution has empowered the President to make for the regulation of payment of money belonging to the Prize Court Fund into the Public Accounts of the Republic, the only alternative left to the Government is to get an Act passed by the Parliament or have Rules the framed by the President pending such enactment — Prize Court Rules, 1939, Or. XXXIV.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Bangladesh Vs. Hon‘ble Judge, Prize Court, 2 BLD (AD) 147. </em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article — 93</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Ordinance-its force</strong>—In Article 93 of our Constitution the power of the President to promulgate an Ordinance has been given for a contingency when the Parliament stands dissolved or is not in session. Under clause (4) of Article 93 such Ordinance will have the force of law as an Act of Parliament, but this does not make it an Act of Parliament. An Ordinance has got the force of an Act of Parliament as long as it is in force i.e till the expiration of thirty days after it is laid before the Parliament at its first meeting following its promulgation. If the Ordinance making power of the President is construed to give the President power to erase a statute from the statute-book permanently then it will cause violence to the Constitution itself. The President may repeal a statute by an Ordinance, but such repeal shall take permanent effect only when it is followed by an Act of Parliament.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Suranjit Sengupta Vs. Election Tribunal, Syihet and another, 1BLD (HCD) 132</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: I IDLR(SC)(1959)285; A.I.R 1958 (MP)425(429); PLD 1958 Lah 77 — Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article — 94</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Decentralisation of Judiciary</strong>—Constitution of Bangladesh — Part VI — Supreme Court — High Court Division — Decentralisation of judiciary.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Per B.H. Chowdhury, J:</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Decentralization of the judiciary is conceivable in so far as the trial Courts are concerned, but such attempt in the sphere of superior judiciary has been deprecated by the jurists far less in the case of the highest Court of the country.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Per M.H. Rahman, J:</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It is not clear how the doctrine of doorstep justice could be applied to the High Court Division, virtually the last appellate Court where, except in a few cases of original jurisdiction, most of the Court’s business is done on the basis of records, written papers and submissions of the learned Counsels, and the parties or their witnesses are not required to cross the threshold for coming to Dhaka, except for giving power and for affirming affidavits. For many it is a classic case of harassment from pillar to post, particularly for the litigants from Syihet who had to move from Dhaka to Comilla, from there to Chittagong and then, from there to Sylhet.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Per A.T.M. Afzal, J:</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Whether the decentralization of the High Court Division is justified on principle or not, whether the results shown so far are productive or not—are all matters relating to policy and consequences of the measure. The setting up of six Permanent Benches may have been</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">unwise and unproductive but whatever may have been the personal view of a Judge regarding the wisdom behind or the improving quality of an amendment, he would be ouR concerned with the legality of the amendment</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Anwar Hossain Chowdhury Vs. Bangladesh, 1989 BLD(Special)1</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Original Article — 100</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Meaning of ‘Sessions’-What it means— Constitution of Bangladesh</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Per B.H. Chowdhury, J:</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Sessions connotes temporariness. The dictionary meaning is : ‘a period of being assembled”. In the Constitution Article 100 says: as the Chief Justice may, with the approval of the President, from time to time appoint. Any other device contrary to the spirit of this Constitution will tantamount to fraud on the Constitution on the principle what cannot be done directly shall not be done indirectly.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Sessions of the High Court 1)ivision may be held at such place or places from time to time in accordance with the Rules of the Court regulating the practice and procedure and the Chief Justice may seek approval of the President whenever it becomes necessary for holding Session [para — 259].</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: A.I.R. 1979 SC 478; AIR. 1919 P.C. 145 — Cited. –</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Per S. Ahmed, J:</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">“Session is not a regular Bench of the High Court Division outside the capital but it 1 means the holding of Court in full, if feasible, or in one or two Benches — Single Bench or Division Bench in one or more places from time to time •.. Holding of a session outside the capital is a matter which lies in the discretion of the Chief Justice but the discretion is to be exercised on some principles and not arbitrarily, [Para 380].</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Per M.H. Rahman, J:</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">After revival of the old Article 100 sessions of the High Court Division may be held from time to time at the appointed places. The learned Chief Justice shall in his discretion decide, considering the convenience of the High Court Division, the Judges and the staff, what causes will be heard at which appointed place, who will constitute the Bench or Benches and what will be the duration of each sessions. The work-schedule of the seasons may not be co-extensive with that of the High Court Division sitting at Dhaka, [Para47].</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Anwar Hossain Chowdhuiy Vs. Bangladesh, 1989 BLD(Spl)1</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Original Article — 100</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Constitution of Bangladesh</strong> — for sessions outside the capital, rules have to be framed by the Supreme Court under Article</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Per B.H. Chowdhury, J:</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Rules must be framed for deciding what drass of cases will be heard and such rules mist be framed by the High Court Division itself subject to Article 107(1); the Chief Just then will initiate the proposal for the ‘approval’ of the Chief Executive namely, the President. [Para 210]</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Per B.H. Chowdhury, J:</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The Chief Justice will propose to hold sessions after framing the rules, which is done the Court itself, vide Article 107 of the constitution. The approval of the President is</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">I necessary because he is the highest executive</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">in his wisdom he can advise the Chief justice as to the viability of the proposal itself. When the holding of session is necessary, it is the Chief Justice who is to take the decision in accordance with the rules framed the Court. Because the Full Court or the Committee to be constituted by the Chief Justice will take into consideration the factors, circumstances and the necessity for hording sessions in an outlying area and the manner of nominating Judges to such Benches whereupon the Chief Justice will pass necessary orders to constitute any Bench Article 107(3). (Para 214).</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Anwar Hossain Chowdhury Vs. Bangladesh, 1989 BLD (Spl)1</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Amended Article — 100(5)</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Constitution of Bangladesh</strong> — Power given to the President to assign areas in relation to which each Permanent Bench shall exercise jurisdiction, power and functions offends the principle of separation of powers.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Per B.H. Chowdhury, J</strong>:</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">This clearly runs counter to the theory of separation of powers and cherished cannon of independence of the judiciary because it is the Chief Justice who is to initiate the proposal for holding sessions for declaring what cases or what class of cases shall be heard at the outlying areas. It is not for the Chief Executive to initiate such a proposal far less for assigning areas for Permanent Benches alternatively (as was done by the Proclamation dated l7th.June, 1986) for holding Sessions.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Amendment Article — 100(5)</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Constitution of Bangladesh</strong>— Consultation for assignment of area of jurisdiction by the President with the Chief Justice — No objection can be taken to the manner of consultation that had taken place in the instant, case.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Per M.H. Rahman, J:</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The notification issued under clause ‘(5) of Art. 100 of the Constitution has been assailed on the ground that there was no consultation between the President and the Chief Justice in the matter of assigning areas of jurisdiction for the Permanent Benches. From the consultation papers placed before the Court it appeared that the Law Secretary in a straight forward manner drew attention of the Chief Justice to the areas of six Permanent Benches that were set up during the Martial Law time. The areas mentioned in the notification under clause (5) does not call for any reflection on the ground that the whole process of consultation and the publication of the notification was completed in great expedition within a few hours. (Para 408).</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Per A.T.M. Afzal, J:</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">This extraordinary movement was apparently made to avoid dislocation in the sitting of Benches but the fact remains that the assignment of areas (already existing) was done in consultation with the Chief Justice. The objection raised, in the circumstances of the case, does not appear to be valid. (Para 624).</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Per B.H. Chowdhury, J:</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Sub-article (5) presupposes consultation of the President with the Chief Justice. The file that was produced by the Attorney General shows that there was no effective consultation concerning such a vital matter of the administration of justice. (Para 249).</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. Union of India Vs. Sankar Chand, A.I.R.1977 (SC)2328 — Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Per A.T.M. Afzal, J:</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">This extraordinary movement was apparently made to avoid dislocation in the sitting of Benches but the fact remains that the assignment of areas (already existing) was done in consultation with the Chief Justice. The objection raised, in the circumstances of the case, does not appear to be valid. (Para 624).</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Per B.H. Chowdhury, J:</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Sub-article (5) presupposes consultation of the President with the Chief Justice. The file that was produced by the Attorney General shows that there was no effective consultation concerning such a vital matter of the administration of justice. (Para 249).</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. Union of India Vs. Sankar Chand, A.I.R.1977 (SC)2328 — Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Per A.T.M. Afzal, J:</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">This extraordinary movement was apparently made to avoid dislocation in the sitting of Benches but the fact remains that the assignment of areas (already existing) was done in consultation with the Chief Justice. The objection raised, in the circumstances of the case, does not appear to be valid. (Para 624).</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Per B.H. Chowdhury, J:</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Sub-article (5) presupposes consultation of the President with the Chief Justice. The file that was produced by the Attorney General shows that there was no effective consultation concerning such a vital matter of the administration of justice. (Para 249).</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. Union of India Vs. Sankar Chand, A.I.R.1977 (SC)2328 — Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Amended Article — 100(4)</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Transfer of Judges</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Transfer of Judges to Permanent Benches violates the provision of Article 147(2) so far as the terms and conditions of service of the Judges of the Supreme Court is concerned.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Per B.H. Chowdhury, J:</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It is not necessary to pursue this point further. The question is whether such deeming provision in Sub-article (4) is violative o Article 147(2) which says the remuneration, privileges and other terms and conditions of services shall not be varied to the disadvantage of any such person during his term o office. A service condition cannot be altered1 by a deeming provision. On the face of it, this provision is ultra vires, violative of Articl 147(2).</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Anwar Hossain Chowdhury Vs. Bangla desh, 1989 BLD(Spl)1</em></strong><span id="pastemarkerend">.</span></p></div></div>
1148	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">CONSTITUTION OF BANGLADESH, 1972 [ARTICLE 101 - 110]</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  1BLD(HCD)155, 1BLD(AD)1, 1BLD (AD)61, IBLD(AD)91, 1BLD(AD)103, 1BLD(AD)1O5, 1BLD(AD)107, 1BLD(AD) 283, 1BLD(AD)296, 1BLD (AD)329, 1BLD(AD)378, IBLD(AD)450, 1BLD(AD)488, 1BLD(HCD)304, 2BLD(AQ)120, 2BLD (HCD)189, 5BLD(HD)321, 6 BLD(AD) 308, 6 BLD .HCD)323,</p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  1972</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  CONSTITUTION OF BANGLADESH</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p> </p><p align="center" style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: center;"><strong><u><br/> </u></strong></p><p align="center" style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: center;"><strong><u>CONSTITUTION OF BANGLADESH, 1972</u></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Articles — 102 and 101 </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Review of writ petition</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Review —A substantive right</strong> — Power review must be conferred by law — Hi Court Division is not empowered under Constitution or any law to review its judgment in writ petition — Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 (V of 1908) S. 141.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>In re Mrs. Kohinoor Banu and another 1BLD(HCD)155</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: PLD I 970(SC) 1; PLD 1 965(SC)55 Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Articles — 102 and 103</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Political Question</strong>—Court should refrain from answering political questions if the validity or legality of the law could otherwise decided.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>M/s. Dulichand Omraolal Vs. Bangladesh, 1BLD(AD)1</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article — 102</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Writ Jurisdiction by employees of nationalised company</strong>: The law of master and servant will not apply to the employees of a nationalised company which has lost its cor porate character. Such employees will treated as employees of the Corporation in can invoke the writ jurisdiction — Bangladesh Industrial Enterprises (Nationalisation) Order (P.O. 27 of 1972), Articles, 4, 5, 6,7, 8 and 10.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Mosharaf Hossain Chowdhury Vs. General Manager, Titas Gas Transmission and Distribution Co. Ltd and another, 1BLD </em></strong>(AD)61</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article — 102 (2)(a)(i)</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Writ of Mandamus — High Court Division’s power of giving direction</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The appellants are under ‘legal obligation’ towards the respondents ‘to carry out specific ministerial duties’ clearly imposed upon them v law, namely ‘to comp1te the formalities to transfer the mill. The High Court Division is empowered under the Constitution for giving . direction ‘to do that which is required by law to do.’</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Secretary, Ministry of Industries, Nationalised Industries Division Vs. Saleh Ahmed and another, IBLD(AD)91.</em></strong></p><p> </p><p> </p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article — 102(2)(a)(i)</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Mandamus</strong> — In order to entitle a person to ask for performance of any public duty by mandamus it is necessary to show that he has legal right for claiming such performance .part from the fact that he is interested in the performance of the duty.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Talekhal Progressive Fisherman Cooperative Society Ltd. Vs. Bangladesh and others, 1BLD(AD)103</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: (1897) 1 Q.B.498—Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article — 102</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Administrative law — Discretionary power</strong> — Authority must exercise the power ma-sonab1y — Arbitrary exercise of the power without proper application of mind cannot be sustained.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Lutful Mia Vs. Government of Bangladesh and others, 1BLD(AD)1O5</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article — 102(1) (2)(3)</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>High Court’s power to issue writ in relation to proceedings before the Martial Law Court</strong>—Restoration of original clause</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">of Article 102 of the Constitution by Proclamation (Seventh Amendment) Order, 476 made no change in High Court’s power to issue writ in relation to proceedings before the Martial Law Court —Proclamation of the 20th August, 1975, cl(g)—Second Proclamation (Seventh Amendment) Order, 1976— Martial Law Regulation No. I of 1975, Reg. 4(9)</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It is true that the High Court got back the power to give direction or order to any person or authority, including any person performing any function in connection with the affairs of the Republic, as may be appropriate for the enforcement of any of the fundamental rights conferred by Part Ill of the Constitution, but this power could be exercised in relation to only those fundamental rights which are available, for enforcement, and that too subject to ‘ouster’ of the jurisdiction of the superior Courts.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Kh. Ehteshamuddin Ahmed alias Iqbal Vs. Bangladesh and others, 1BLD(AD)107</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 3ODLR(SC)207; 32DLR(AD)1 10 — Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article — 102</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Propriety of proceedings of Martial Law Court—</strong>High Court Division is not competent to examine the propriety of the proceedings or action of the Martial Law Court or Tribunal except in case of lack of jurisdiction, coram non judice or malafide — Proclamation of the 20th August, 1975, cl.(g)</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">— Martial Law Regulations No. I of 1975, Reg.4(9).</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">As a normal practice in a Constitutional set up in exercise of the writ jurisdiction, the superior Courts are competent to examine the propriety of the proceedings or action taken by an inferior Tribunal, but the position is altogether different in the case of the Martial Law Court or Tribunal acting within the ambit of Martial Law Regulations. Of course, when a Martial Law Court or Tribunal acted without jurisdiction or such Court or Tribunal is not properly constituted, that is to say, is coamnon juice, or has acted malafide, the power of the superior Courts under Art. 102 of the Constitution in an appropriate case may be exercised.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Kh. Ehtesamuddin Ahmed alias Iqbal Vs. Bangladesh and others, 1BL.D(AD) 107</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 3ODLR(SC)207; 36DLR(AD)1 10; PLDI 973(SC)49; PLD1 974(SC) 151; (1969)1 All .E.R.208; (1 948)AC34 1: (1948) AC87; (1968)lAll.E.R.694 — Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article —102</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Service matter</strong>—High Court Division in write jurisdiction declared termination of service of an employee of Water Development Board to be without lawful authority— Consequential order that the period between termination and rejoining of the employee shall be treated as on leave without pay—High Court Division competent to pass such consequential order.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Hasan Jmam Chowdhury Vs. Government of Bangladesh and others, 1BLD(AD) 283</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article — 102</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Writ</strong>— Practice and Procedure — Limit of consequential order in writ jurisdiction</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Article 102 should not be construed so as to replace the ordinary remedies by way of suit and application available to the litigant under the general law of the land. Any declaration or direction or order to be given must be ancillary to the main relief, but in doing so. the superior Courts have always placed self-imposed limitation for not raising any new issue which requires adjudication on proper facts for which no foundation was laid by the parties in the writ proceeding.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Hasan Imam Chowdhury Vs. Government of Bangladesh and others, 1BLD</em></strong> <strong><em>(AD)283</em></strong></p><p> </p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article — 102</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Writ of Certiorari</strong> — High Court Division can declare conviction to be without lawful authority when trial is vitiated by irregularities in procedure causing prejudice to accused.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Govt. of Bangladesh Vs. Zahir and others, 1BLD(AD)296</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article — 102</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Writ— Contractual right</strong> — Government malafide cancelled lease of a plot of land a took forcible possession of the land demolishing structure without recourse to legal process — Writ Petition is maintainable even though the right of the petitioner emanates from a contract.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The Government in this particular ca did not get any power under the lease deed to enter into the premises and demolish the construction made by the lessee if the lessee does not voluntarily vacate the land. It is evident that the entry of the Government was unauthorised and it did not originatu in the lease deed or in any statute. In that view of the matter, it is to be observed that the action of the Government so far as entry into the land goes was by a public authority without any statutory sanction and so the writ was maintainable.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Mrs. Hasna Munsur and others Vs. Secretary, Ministry of Public Works and Urban Development and others, 1BLD (AD)329</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 26DLR(AD)181; A.I.R.1973(SC) 205—Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article — 102</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Writ Government not complying provision of law</strong>—Government authorised to enter into demised land upon termination or determination of lease following the procedure laid down by law — Government not complying with the provision of law — Writ petition challenging Government’s entry into demised land is maintainable — Government and Local Authority Land and Buildings (Recovery of Possession) Ordinance, 1970 (XXIV of 1970), S.3.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Mrs. Hasna Muizsur and others Vs. Secretary, Ministry of Public Works and Urban Development and others, 1BLD (AD)329</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article — 102(5)</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Tribunal, meaning of</strong> — Authorities mentioned in the schedule of the Police Officer (Special Provisions) Ordinance. 1976 and entrusted with the power of taking disciplinary action against police officers and hearing appeals against such action are not Tribunals as contemplated in Article 102(5) of the Constitution.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Bangladesh and others Vs. A.K.M. Zahangir Hossain, 1BLD(AD)378</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: A.I.R. I 950(SC) 188; (1892)1 Q.B. 431; AIR. 196 l(SC)1669; A.I.R. 1964 (SC) 1140; A.I.R.1965(SC)1595; A.I.R. 1954 (SC) 520; A.I.R.1977 (SC)2155; C.A. No. 96 of 1978; A.I.R. 1961(SC) 1969;—Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article — 102(2)</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Writ — Alternative remedy</strong> — When the impugned action is without jurisdiction, the question of availing statutory alternative remedy does not arise.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Assessing Officer, Narayanganj Range, and others Vs. Burma!, Eastern Limited, IBLD(AD)450</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article — 102(2)(b)</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Writ — Habeas Corpus — Court Martial</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">— Scope of enquiry and interference in habeas corpus — Jurisdiction to interfere with decision of Court Martial is narrow than in the case of other Court or Tribunal.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The jurisdiction of the High Court Division in an application in the nature of habeas corpus is to see if a person in custody is there in pursuance of any lawful authority and when a person is serving out an order of sentence passed by a Court or Tribunal, the jurisdictional validity of that order could be looked at. When such a question is agitated before the Court, the Court is first to see the provisions of the law as well as the provisions of the Constitution. The nature of the proceeding and the purpose of the Act are to be considered to see the jurisdictional infirmity of the order complained. When the challenge is from an order of a Court Martial set up under the Army Act to enforce the military law, the jurisdiction to interfere is narrower that in the case of other Court or Tribunal. It is consistent not only with the maintenance of strict discipline demanded from the Defence Force, but also to the constitutional protection given to the laws relating to the disciplined force, and also their action from any challenge in the Court. The first protection is given under Article 45, and the second in Article 102(5). Under the former, the law is protected, and under the latter the action under the law is protected. Keeping all these factors in view, all that can be said is the ground on which a decision of a Court Martial set up under the Army Act can be ch1- lenged by habeas corpus position will be analogous to one available under sub-article (5) of Article 102 of the Constitution.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Jamil Huq V. Bangladesh and others, 1BLD(AD)488.</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article—102</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Court Martial Scope of interference— Proceedings of such Court cannot be interfered with on the ground of procedural irregularities — Scope of interference with the proceedings of such Court in writ jurisdiction is very narrow.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The High Court Division has not been conferred with the jurisdiction under Article 102 of the Constitution to interfere with the decision given by a Court Martial convened under the Army Act, unless it can be shown that the proceeding was a coram non judice or malafide. If the Court is constituted properly and the offence is cognizable then the proceedings of such a Court cannot be interfered on the ground of procedural irregularities. But the refusal of writ in no manner suggests the approval of the findings because they are essentially questions of fact which are exclusively within the jurisdiction of the trial and appellate Court and a writ Court will not interfere with the findings unless it can be shown that the accused had been convicted without any evidence at all. The writ jurisdiction will be attracted if the proceedings are coram non judice or malafide and the writ of habeas corpus will be available for securing release of the prisoner who has been committed by a Court Martial in such circumstances—Army Act. 1952; S. 133.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Jamil Huq Vs. Bangladesh and others, 1 BLD(AD) 488.</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article — 102(2)(5)</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Malafide</strong> — In order to strike down an order passed by an excepted authority within the purview of Article 102(5) of the Constitution e.g., The Court Martial, the facts constituting malafide must have correlation with jurisdiction and be analogous to an order made coram non judice.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Jamil Huq Vs. Bangladesh and others, 1BLD(AD,)488</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article — 102</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Writ Petition — Locus standi</strong> — Petition by a person as constituted attorney of the person aggrieved is maintainable — Power of Attorney Act, 1882 (VII of 1882), s. 2.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Zamiruddin Ahmed Vs. Govt. of Bangladesh, 1BLD(HCD)304.</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: PLD 1961 (Dac) 278 — Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article — 102</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Writ Petition—Defect of party</strong>—Government of Bangladesh made respondent — Petition not bad for not impleading some of the officers of the respondent.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Zarniruddin Ahmed Vs. Govt. of Bangladesh, JBLD(HGD)304</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: PLD 1959 Dac 342, distinguished — Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article — 102</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Writ of Mandamus—Demand for justice</strong> —When there are special circumstances to indicate that demand for justice would be futile, mandamus can issue even though no demand for justice was made prior to filing of the writ petition.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article — 102</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Writ of Mandamus</strong>—Respondent having not denied the impugned action, the objection that mandamus has never been issued only for declaring that act of a person is unlawful or for declaring the little of a person to an office has been overruled.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Zamiruddin Ahmed Vs. Govt. of Bangladesh, 1BLD(HGD)304</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: PLD I 957(Dac)437, distinguished <strong>— Article — 102</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Administrative Law</strong> — Power to examine the validity of an action declared to be valid by Parliament — Effect of the validation clause on order of compulsory retirement made prior to passing of the validating law— Public Servants (Retirement) (Amendment) Ordinance, 1981 (VI of 1981), S.5.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Mofizur Rahman Khan Vs. Govt. of Bangladesh, 2BLD(AQ)120</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: PLDI97O(SC)98; PLDI958(SC) 181 — Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article — 102</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Contractual Right</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Writ Petition—Maintainability</strong>—Cotractual right, enforcement of writ petition challenging action of public authority invested with statutory power is maintainable even if the i-chef arises out of breach bf contract.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Sharping Matshjibi Samabaya Samity Ltd. Vs. Only in cx-Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Zamiruddin Ahmed Vs. Govt. of Bangladesh, 1BLD(HCD)304</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: PLD I 963(Dac)74 1(744); PLD 1961 (SC)178; AIR. 1956(Cal)456—Cited ceptional cases for want of jurisdiction and ex-facie illegality writ applications are maintained inspite of alternative remedy being available—The Local Government (Union Parishads) Ordinance, 1983, S. 29(4) — Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 (V of 1908), S. 115.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>A.KM. P.C. the Court deals only with possession and an aggrieved party can take resort to the civil Court for the redress of his grievance—Since it is a question of fact to be adjudicated on evidence, the writ jurisdiction is not appropriate for seeking the relief—Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898 (V of 1898), Ss. 145, 146, 439A(2) and 439(4).</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Haji Golam Hossain Vs. Abdur Rahmna Munshi and others, 6 BLD(AD) 308</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 35DLR(AD)127; Criminal Appeal o. 48 and 49 of 1985; 25(Bom) 337 P.C.; A.I.R.1936 (Cal) 659; A.I.R. 1923 (PC) 128— Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article — 102</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Contractual Right in Writ</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Whether writ jurisdiction can be invoked to determine the contractual right —Contractual right cannot be determined and enforced m writ jurisdiction unless the action of the authority has been taken in violation of a statutory rule or any fundamental right in force—It is also a general principle of law that hen a contract has been broken the remedy lies in an action for damages.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Majibur Rahman and others Vs. The Chairman, B.I. W. T.A. and others, 6 BLD .HCD)323</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref:A.I.R. I 975(SC) 1121(1126); AIR. 198 l(SC) 1368; A.I.R I 977(SC)2 149-Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article — 102</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Writ of Certiorari</strong> — Certiorari lies when the Deputy Commissioner of Taxes acts without jurisdiction even though alternative statutory remedies are available — But he does not act without jurisdiction when the law authorises him to do the act in question - He is completely within his jurisdiction in passing the assessment when the law authorises him to make an assessment of the income of the assesses — He is also required under section 8 of the Income Tax Ordinance, 1984 to observe and follow such order, direction or instructions as the National Board of Revenue may issue from time to time in the matter of discharging the functions under the said Ordinance — If he has obeyed the circular in question he has only complied with section 8 of the said Ordinance. He has not exceed his authority at all — If the circular is not in conformity with the Income Tax Ordinance, then the Deputy Commissioner of Taxes has merely erred in law in making the assessment— He did not act in excess of his jurisdiction — The petitioner is at liberty to challenge the order of assessment both on facts and on law before the successive appellate forums and is also at liberty to bring the matter by way of reference to the High Court Division.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Whether an appeal or writ shall lie against an order of assessment of Income Tax passed by a competent officer — When a Deputy Commissioner of Taxes passes an order of assessment without jurisdiction under section 83(2) of the Income Tax Ordinance. 1984 all questions of fact and law relating to the said assessment can only be agitated by wiy of statutory appeal and not by way of a writ petition — Income Tax Ordinance, 1984 (XXXVI of 1984), Ss. 83 and 153.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Dr. M.B. Rahman Vs. The Chairman, …. and others, 7BLD (AD)98</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article—102</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Writ Petition—Maintainability of</strong> — Whether writ petition is maintainable to challenge cancellation of lease of a fishery by the Government — Whether cancellation of a contract or lease can be challenged by writ petition for breach of condition of the same — When the Government functions in the capacity of an ordinary buyer and if there is breach of such contract, the aggrieved party can sue for damages but cannot invoke writ jurisdiction — When the Government grants lease, privilege, settlement etc. the Government, acts in these affairs in pursuance of some statutory power and if there is a breach of any statute or rule the same can be remedied by invoking writ jurisdiction — If it is a pure and simple cOntract which is entered into by the Government in its trading capacity for any breach of such contract writ will not be available but if the contract is entered into by the Government in the capacity of a sovereign, then writ can be invoked for breach of such contract — Once lease is given to a class of people in pursuance of statutory function such lease assumes the character of sovereign function and indealing with such function, any lapse by the authority is not immune from challenge before the Court by writ petition.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Per S. Ahmed, J:</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In case of breach of any obligation under a contract between the Government and a pri- I vate party, proper remedy lies in a suit and not in a writ petition but this principle will not apply When the Government violates terms of the contract with a malafide intention or acts arbitrarily or in a discriminatory manner—Cancellation of the lease without hearing is violative of the principle of natural justice — Under section 75 of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act Fishery’ is at the disposal of the Government for settlement — Government must follow certain fixed standards, principles or lines applicable to all persons seeking settlement and shall not act arbitrarily or ira any discriminatory manner — Writ will be available to a lessee to challenge arbitrary or discriminatory acts of the Government.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Sharping Matshajibi Samabaya Sanity Ltd. Vs. Bangladesh and others, 7BLD.. (‘AD)106</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: AJ.R. 1973 (SC) 205; AIR. 1979 (SC)l 628; A.I.R. I 977(SC)1 496; A.I.R. 1981 (SC) 1368; AIR. 1977 (SC) 2149; A.I.R l966(SC)334; AIR. 1983 (SC) 848; A.I.R .1 954(SC)592; A.I.R. I 975(SC) 1121; PLD I 962(Dacca) 108; 1 BLD(AD) 103 :A. 1.R. 1966 (SC)334; A.I.R.l975(SC)l121; 1990 B.S.
