Mostafa Hossaiiz Vs. Sikander Md. Faruque and another, 7BLD(AD) 315</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: Halsburys Laws of England, Third Edition, Vol. II, Page-l48; 12 CI &amp; F 537; 1KB (1916) Vol. I, Page — 95; PLD 1970 SC)98; — Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article — 102(2)(b)(ii)</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Writ of Quo Warranto — Question of maintainability </strong>— Relief by way of writ of Quo Warranto is maintainable to a person when remedy by way of, election petition is not possible or the remedy provided for else where is not appropriate one or the disqualification of the respondent is continuing one.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Sikder Mohammad Faruque Vs. Md. Hossain and another, 7 BLD(HCD)52</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: A.I.R.1957(Madhya Pradesh) 60; A.l.R.l955(Hyd.)36; 2IDLR(SC)23; PLD 1970(SC) 98; PLD1966(Kar)348; — Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Delay in filing writ of Quo-Warranto</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The delay has been satisfactorily explained and the petition for a writ of quoarranto being is bonafide the delay does not stand in the way for setting the relief sought b the petition.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Sikder Mohammad Faruque Vs. Md. Most afa Hossain and another, 7BLD (HCD,)52</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: I Q.B.39; A.I.R. 1954 All(F.B) 227; A.I.R. 196 l(Patna) 475; 21 DLR(SC)23; PLD 1970 (SC) 98; 21 DLR (SC) 23; AIR. 1954 (Bombay) 41—Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article — 102</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Writ of Certiorari</strong>—Jurisdiction of the High Court Division to interfere with the decision of the inferiors Tribunals or authority in a writ of certiorari — When the Tribunal or authority acted without jurisdiction or the order in question was malafide then the High Court Division can exercise its jurisdiction to interfere with the same—Where it is found that a person or authority is vested with a jurisdiction to do certain acts and in exercise of that jurisdiction it does the same, whether wrongly or rightly, the act done or the proceeding taken cannot be interfered with on the ground of erroneous decision of law if that authority is properly constituted and acted within its province.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Faziur Rahman Chowhdury Vs. Secretary, Ministry of Public Works and others, 7 </em>BLD(HCD)212</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 32DLR(AD)21 6; 34DLR(AD) 125— Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Articles— 102 and 117</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Administrative Tribunal and Writ Jurisdiction of the High Court Division — Ouster of such jurisdiction </strong>— Whether there is complete ouster of jurisdiction of the High Court Division to examine the decision of the Administrative Tribunal — Administrative Tribunal as referred to in substituted sub- article (5) of Article 102 of the Constitution is the Administrative Tribunal which was established under Article 117 of the Constitution and from language of sub-article (5) it is clear that the Administrative Tribunal is not a person within the meaning of Article 102(2) of the Constitution — But by such provision ipso facto it cannot be read into Article 102that there is a complete ouster of jurisdiction of the Court to examine the question — Th power of the High Court Division is not totally ousted by such constitutional provision as contained in substituted sub-article (5) of Article 102. This Court exercising jurisdiction under Article 102(2) can, of course, examine the propriety or otherwise of an act of a person or an authority when it acts malafide or the order is corarn non judice.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Faziur Rahmaiz Chowdhury Vs. Secretary, Ministry of Public Works and others, 7BLD(HCD)2 12</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 33DLR(AD)154; 34DLR(AD) 125; PLD1974(SC)l5l; —Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article — 102</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Whether a licensee of a fire arm can maintain an action under Article 102(2) of the Constitution challenging cancellation or suspension of the licence— No one has a right to possess and cary fire arms except when per- mined to do so subject to some terms and conditions—The licensee acquires a right to carry, defend and maintain his fire arms once a licence is issued to him — So long as he does not violate the terms and conditions of his licence and so long as the appropriate authority does not deem it necessary to cancel or suspend his licence for the security of the public peace. he acquires a right to defend his right and privilege to possess and carry firearms — A licensee of a firearms can challenge cancellation of his licence by filing a writ petition.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>SK. Ali Ahainmed Vs. The Secretaiy, Ministly of Home Affairs and others, 7BLD(HCD)289</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article — 102</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Alternative Remedy not always a bar to writ petition </strong>— Question of maintainability when alternative remedy by way of appeal and revision is available — When writ petition is filed raising purely a question of law or interpretation of a statute availability of an alternative remedy will not stand in the way— Such writ petition is maintainable.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>M.A. Hai, Wazed Ali Miah and Md. Moslem Vs. Trading Corporation of Bangladesh, 8 BLD(’AD)84</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article — 102(2)(b)</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Detention</strong> — Whether validity of detention or a detention order is to be decided in a writ petition challenging the detention — Whether the Rule becomes in fructuous on the revocation of the order of detention and a fresh application is to be filed to challenge the subsequent order of detention — It is not the question of order of detention. It is the detention itself of the detenu which is the subject-matter of the Rule—in a case of detention the Court is to satisfy itself that the person is not being held in custody without lawful authority or in an unlawful manner — The scope of inquiry is not in any way fettered by procedures of a writ of Habeas Corpus or the Rule laid down under the various Habeas Corpus Acts — The Court is to see that the executive authority had before it sufficient materials upon which a reasonable person could have come to the conclusion that the requirements of law were satisfied — The constitutional obligation is to see whether a person is being held without lawful authority or in an unlawful manner — Only a valid order of detention could be continued by a subsequent order of detention.— An illegal order cannot be continued by a subsequent valid order of detention — Malatde vitiates everything — The order of detention was passed for collateral purposes which had no sanction of law.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Mrs. Sajeda Parvin Banu Vs. Govt. of Bangladesh and others, 8 BLDAD)129.</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 21 DLR (SC)l; 20 DLR tSC) 249</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">(257); 3IDLR(AD)1; A.I.R.1945(FC)l 8; 46 Cr1. Li; 559; IDLR29: PLD1949 (Dhaka)1; 3 DLR 50: PLD 1959 (Dhaka) 774: 18 DLR (Dhaka) 539; 26 DLR (HCD) 201; 27 DLR (HCD)198; 27DLR (HCD)l99; AIR. 1952 (SC)l06 — Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article — 102 (2)(b)</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Detention</strong>—Applicability of Indian Judicial view—the Indian judicial view is completely different from ours—In India the approach of subjective satisfaction that is being made in preventive detention cases but our Constitutional jurisdiction is radically different — It will therefore be a dangerous slip to go into Indian decisions for persuasive argument.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Mrs. Sajeda Parvin Banu Vs. Govt. of Bangladesh and others, 8BLD’AD)129</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: A.1.R I 966(S) 1404; AIR. 1975 SC)53: A.1.R.1973( C)897 —Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>ArticIe — 102(2)(b)</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Detention</strong>—If it is found malafide—Malaride vitiates everything—The statement of the Home Minister when put in juxtaposition the grounds of detention. the conclusion becomes obvious that the order of detention was passed for collateral purposes.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Mrs. Sajeda Parvin Banu Vs. Govt. of Bangladesh and others, 8 BLD(AD)129</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 34 DLR(AD)222 — Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article—102(2)(b)(ii)</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Quowarranto proceeding—Who can take it?</strong> — The filing of a writ petition by a person other than a candidate in an election cannot be questioned in view of the clear provision of the Constitution which shows that any person. whether he is ‘aggrieved or not may seek an information as to the title of the holder of siy public office.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Quowarranto proceeding — Delay no ground for refusal—Question of dlay in taking such proceeding</strong> — Mere delay in seeking a remedy in writ jurisdiction is not a ground for denying the remedy particularly when the remedy sought for relates to the very title of a person holding any public office — The contention that the writ petition was liable to be dismissed on the ground of delay has been no substance.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Quowarranto proceeding</strong> — Whether it can he prosecuted when election petition in as alternative forum touching the same questions is pending — The argument against seeking remedy in the extraordinary jurisdiction of the High Court Division in view of the alternative forum is not convincing, for the remedy by way of quo warranto proceeding in which the title to a public office may be questioned by any person. is independent of the remedy available to a limited number of persons having personal grievance — Moreover, the election petition may be withdrawn by way of compromise on personal considerations.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Quowarranto proceeding—Addition of party in such a proceeding when unnecessary</strong>—Some members of the public filed an application to be added as parties and to contest the appeal as public interests are involved in the matter—The application was rejected as it was found to be unnecessary when the state was contesting the appeal.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Quowarranto proceeding — Whether such proceeding can be compromised</strong> — The petition for compromise was opposed on the ground of public interest and that the question raised therein cannot be left to be decided by compromise between private parties particularly when the High Court Division held that the holder of the public office got no legal authority to hold it — After hearing the parties the compromise petition was rejected and the appeal relating thereto heard on merit as a question of great public interest was involved in the matter.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Md. Most afa Hossain Vs. Sikder Md. Faruque and another, 8 BLD(AD) 170</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 2IDLR(SC)23; 12 CI. &amp; F. 537; 1KB (191 6)Vol.I.P.595; PLD I 970(SC)98; <strong>A.I.R. 1966 (SC) 580 — Cited.</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article — 102</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Writ Petition—Maintainability—Whether </strong>a writ petition challenging order of removal from service by Trading Corporation of Bangladesh is maint.ainable?—Whether writlies against an order of removal passed in pursuance of domestic enquiry—In all the charge sheets the petitioners were asked to show cause why they shall not be dismissed or removed from service of the Corporation in terms of Government Servants (Discipline and Appeal) Rules, 1976 or 1984—The Corporation was not obliged to follow the Rules Of 1976 or 1984 or any Government Rules— But once the Corporation made a conscious choice of those Rules, it holds out a promise to its officers and other employees to the effect that in respect of disciplinary proceedings it means to provide its officers and other employees with some better and higher rights and remedies—When the Corporation proceeds- against an-employee under the Rules of 1976 or 1984, it makes a promise to the employees concerned that he or she will be governed by the said Rules-If the employee acts upon the said promise and submits his or. her explanation to the charges then the employee acts in reliance of the promise and alters his or her position — The Corporation would be held bound by the promise and the promise would be entitled to enforce the promise against the Corporation—The <strong><em>writ petitions are fully maintainable.</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>M.A. Hai and others Vs. Trading Corporation of Bangladesh, 8BLD(HCD,) 228</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 32 DLR(AD)46; (1959) 359 U.S. 535; 3 L Ed 2d 1012-; A.I.R. 1979 (SC)1628; -31 DLR326;—Cited. -</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article — 102</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Election matter</strong> —Writ Court not to enter into controversy relating to such matter — In an election dispute the issue is to be raised and evidence adduced for adjudication by a competent Tribunal — This function has been given to the Election Tribunal and to none else — By taking resort to extraordinary jurisdiction for a writ in such a matter the High Court Division will be asked to enter into a territory which is beset with disputed facts., It is well settled that a writ Court will not enter into such contrc .rsy — The writ jurisdiction cannot be invoked except on the-very limited ground of total absence of jurisdiction or malice in law to challenge any step in the process of election including an order passed by the Election Commission —. The larger issue of completion of fair election with rigorous promptitude for timely emergency and functioning of eledive -bodies must take precedence over settlement of private disputes—Loc-al Government (Union Parishads) Ordinance, l983(LI of 1983), S. 29—Union Parishad (Election) Rules, 1983, Rule 70.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>A.F.M. Shah Alam Vs. Mujibul Huq and others, 9BLD (AD) 78</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">- Ref: A1R1952(SC)64; I5DLR(SC) 283; I9DLR(SC)516; 6BLD(AD)267; AIR. 1978 (SC)851; I8DLR(SC)426; A.I.R.1978 (SC) 85-1 (867); — Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article — 102</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Election dispute</strong> — -Not to be resolved by mere affidavits—Order of Election Corn-missioner accepting the election result is to be challenged before the Election Tribunal — When the High Court Division found the result controversial it should not have resolved the same on mere affidavit.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Nazir Ahmed -Vs. Bangladesh Election</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Commissioner and others, 9BLD (AD)103</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article — 102</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>- Maintainability of writ petition</strong> — Question of maintainability when alternative remedy has not been availed of—The point on which the petitioner has challenged the impugned order was certainly not a matter to be finally decided upon by any forum other than a Court of law—The interpretation and applicabilIty of the provisions of the Customs Act is a matter concerning the interplet mon of an act of the legislature — It was therefore fit and proper that the petitioner agitated the matter in the original constitutional jurisdiction rather than leave it to be decided by the executive authority— Besides, the goods being perishable, the petitioner had to obtain a quick remedy in order to release the goods —The provision for appeal was not an equally efficiacious provision for him — Customs Act, 1969 (IV of 1969), Ss. 19 and 196.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>A. Election Commission and others, 9BLD(HCD)415</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article — 102</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Abandoned Property—Forum of Release</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Building listed as abandoned property — Forum for its release — The Court of Settlement has been given the power to exclude the disputed property from the list — The petitioner has been given specific right to argue before the Court ‘1 Settlement that the building is not an abandoned property and it has not vested in the Government or that her interest therein h s not been affected — When the statute has devised an alternative forum for giving complete relief to the petitioner her present writ petition is not maintainable— Abandoned Building (Supplementary Provisions) Ordinance. 1985 (LIV of 1985), S. 5(1 )(a) and 7.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Begumn Lutfunnessa Vs. Govt. of Bangladesh and ors. 9BLD(HCD)423</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 1 963 PLD(Dhaka) 238 — Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article — 102 and 152(2)</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>‘Person’ — Meaning of the word in the context of Court’s writ jurisdiction</strong> — Person includes a juristic person — The word person’ occurring in Article 102 of the Constitution includes a Company as well — A Private Limited Company functioning under the control and supervision of and as a subordinate functionary of a statutory corporation under Article 102(5) is a ‘person’ within the meaning of Article 102 of the Constitution — The General Clauses Act, 1877 (X of 1877), S. 3(39).</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Conforce Ltd. Vs. Titas Gas Transmission and Distribution Co. Ltd. and others, 9BLD(HCD)429</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article—102</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Writ against a statutory corporation and its constituent functionary:</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The Bangladesh Oil and Gas Corpo-ration having been established by the Government under the Bangladesh Petroleum Act, 1974 is a ‘Local Authority’ and the Titas Gas Trans mission and Distribution Company Limite being a functionary under it. writ petition u der Article 102 of the Constitution is rnai tamable against it.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Conforce Limited Vs. Titas Gas Tramismission and Distribution Co. Ltd. and others, 9 BLD(HCD)429</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Articles — 102 and 143</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Writ arising out of contractual obligations</strong>—When writ petition is maintainable to enforce such obligation — The State is the owner of natural gas in its sovereign capacity by dint of a constitutional provision i.e., Article dc 143 and the Government is empowered to explore, distribute, sell etc. this wealth — Ti Titas Gas Transmission and Distribution Co Ltd. having entered into a contract with Conforce Limited for supplying of gas as a subsidiary of the Government authorised to exercise government power to deal with this wealth, the contract was not an ordinary cotract entered into acting in the trading capacity and discharging an ordinary trading function of the Government—It was a contract necessitia-ted for performing the function of the state as a sovereign power and arising out statutory rules and as such the writ petition arising out of such a contract is maintainable.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Coliforce Limited Vs. I 977(SC)l 946; AIR. 1981</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">(SC) 1368: A.t.R.l977(SC)2149: PLD 1962</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">(Dhaka) 108; A.I.R.l96lAssam 101: IBLD (AD)l03; 39DLR(AD)85; A.I.R. 1977 (SCi 1436;A.I.R.198l(SC)l638;— Cited</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article — 102</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Writ Petition—Maintaina hi lity of—</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Whether writ petition is maintainable to challenge the notice issued in compliance with the order of the Government— Government order having not been challenged and no relief having been claimed in respect of the Government order, the Court cannot decide the legality or constitutionality thereof— without deciding the constituti3LDOnality and legality of the Government order cannot be decided whether the impugned notices are illegal and without lawful authority and in that view of the matter the writ petition is not maintainable.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Conforce Limited Vs. Chief Engineer could not he implemented as in the meantime Martial Law was withdrawn and the forum for review under the MLO was abolished — As there is no forum for the disposal of the review application, the President is empowered to create a forum for the purpose of disposal of the same by exercising his powers in terms of the Proclamation for withdrawal of Martial Law — The respondent Principal Secretary be directed to place the papers in connection with the review application to the President For its disposal by creating an appropriate forum — Martial Law Order No. 9 of 1982 Paras 1 and IA; Constitution of Bangladesh (Seventh Amendment) (Act I of 1986) Para 19, 4th Schedule-General Clauses Act, I 897(X of 1897); S.6.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Mahatabuddin Ahmed Vs. I 954(Bornbay) I 16;—Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article — 102(2) (b)(ii)</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Writ of Quo Warranto</strong> — Question of its maintainability in a case where the respondent has asserted his claim to the office — The public office must be held or at least purported to be held by a person before an order can be made to show under what authority he claims to hold that office — The appellant has not yet taken oath of office and under the law he cannot enter upon the office of the Chairman before taking such oath Having regard to the plain language of our Constitution, it is only reasonable to hold that writ jurisdiction can be invoked to require a person to show under what authority he claims to hold any public office only when the said person actually assumes that office or purports to do the same.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Md. People’s Re-. public of Bangladesh ‘represented by the Secretary, Ministry of Works and others, ii BLD(AD)103</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article — 102</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Observation in the Judgment -</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It appears that the operative order relates to the respondent’s case only and the observation made in the judgment is no part of direction by the Court to dispose of any review petition that may be pending — The petitioner’s duty is to implement the direction given by the High Court Division concerning the respondents case and it is for them to take . cue, if they are so advised, from the observation referred but that is no binding part of the High Court Divisions judgment.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>The Principal Secretary, President’s Secretariat and others Vs. Mr. Mahtabuddin -Ahmed, 10 BLD(AD)137</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article — 102 (2)(b)(ii)</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Election Matter</strong> — Whether a civil suit is maintainable over an election dispute where separate forum has been created by a special law — Right to seek election to an Union Parishad is neither a common law right, for the enforcement of which a civil Court may come forward nor it is a constitutional right except on a limited ground of coram non judice or malice -- As such the right or liabilny created by the election laws can be enforced only through the Tribunal which is created there under.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Md. Mustafa Kamal and others, 10 BLD (AD) l51</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 8BLD241; 41 DLR 77; 41 DLRI97; 40 DLR 459; 40 DLR 512— Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article — 102 (2)(b)(ii)</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Valid and lawful election</strong> — Question irises as to whether on dismissal of the suit along with cancellation of respondent’s election will render appellant uncontested elected—Further question of disqualification under another provision of the Ordinance — The question is not in this appeal — uncontested election is not sustainable in law as it was declared in disregard to the Election Commission’s order — This election must go making the way clear for a fresh election giving opportunity to all parties interested in — A fresh poll is to be held — Local Government (Union Parishad) Ordinance, 1983 (LI of 1983), S. 24 and7(ii) (e).</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Md. Muctafa Kainal and others, 10BLD (AD)151</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article — 102</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Constitution</strong> — Article 102 revived by Constitution (Partial Revival) (Second) Order, 1985 (Chief Martial Law Administrator’s Order No. I of 1985) on 15th January, 1985 — Country under Martial Law at the relevant time — Constitution Revival Order made subject to certain conditions — Clause (5) of Article 102 substituted making it immune from challenge before the High Court Division any act or thing done by Government or by any person or authority at any time before the commencement of the aforesaid Order — Appellant challenged the order dated 10.11. 1984 of termination of his service, an order, that was passed before the commencement of the Constitution Revival Order before the High Court Division in its writ jurisdiction which was summarily rejected on the ground of non- maintainability. The Appellate Division held:</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">(a) The Flight Court Division in summarily rejecting the writ petition correctly propounded the legal position as it obtained on that date.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">(b) It would be an indirect way of expressing this Court’s disagreement with the view taken by the High Court Division with regard to the maintainability of the writ petition, and</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">(c) The appellant is to decide the course of action he likes.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Q.A. Zaman Vs. Bangladesh Biman Corporation and others, IOBLD(AD)206</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article — 102</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Alternative Remedy</strong> — Where the alternative remedy provided for in a statute is not equally efficacious, writ maintainable. The contention of the Government that alternative remedy was not followed is tenable because the alternative remedy given in section 194 of the Customs Act is not an equally efficacious remedy because it stipulated deposit of 50% of the amount of penaltyof the duty demanded. As such it cannot be an equally efficacious alternative remedy to bar the writ jurisdiction — Customs Act, 1969 (IV of 1969), S.l94.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>The Collector of Customs, Customs House, chittagong and others Vs. Mr. A. I 979(SC)621; A.I.R. 1983 (SC) 848; PLD l970(SC)379; PLDI96O (SC)310; PLD1987 (Karachi)63; 31 DLR 184; 8BLD (AD) 84; 22 DLR(SC)443; 19DLR592—Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article — 102</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>In absence of Provision of appeal</strong>—Absence of the provision of an appeal against a decision can never be urged to exclude the jurisdiction of the High Court Division under Article 102 of the Constitution, rather it is all the more reasonable that the petitioner in such a case (of no remedy) cannot be thrown out so easily.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Mahinudul Alain Montu Vs. Sanwar Hossain Talukder and others, 1OBLD (AD)237</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article — 102</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Writ jurisdiction—Availability of — Election — intermediary stage</strong> — No writ jurisdiction of High Court Division is available, particularly where disputed question of facts are involved, except in exceptional circumstances such as corarn non judice or malice in law.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>- Zaker Hossaiiz Vs. Abdu,:. Rahim and others, 10 BLD(AD)244</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article—102(1)</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>High Court Division is the guardian for enforcement of fundamental rights</strong>.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Under Article 102(1) of the Constitution the High Court Division has been made the guardian for enforcement of fundamental rights not only against the executive but also against the legislature.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Md. Asaduzzaman Vs. Bangladesh and others, 10 BLD(AD)267</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article — 102</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Judicial Review</strong> — Constitutional duty of the Court</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The judicial review with regard tà the vires of a law passed by the legislature flows from the Courts constitutional duty to enforce a fundamental right.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Md. Asaduzzainan Vs. Bangladesh and others, 10 BLD (AD) 267</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article — 102</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Martial Law Offence</strong> — Whether conviction for such offence brings one under disqualification for election — Martial Law is no a part of the Constituting scheme of this1 country — It is extra-constitutional and temporary measure meeting an interim need — It is good as long as it lasts, but with its departure it no longer casts a shadow upon the ordinary laws of the land — In that view of the matter, the Local Government Ordinance does not refer to a conviction of a Military Court or to an offence under Martial Law Regulations and accordingly the respondent did not incur1 any disqualification for election — The Local Government (Union Parishads) Ordinance,1983 (LI of 1983), s. 7(2)(d).</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Monoranjan Mukherjee Vs. Election Commissioner and others, 10 BLD (HCD)17</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Articles — 102(5) and 152</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Disciplined force</strong> — Question of bar of writ jurisdiction for such force — The bar comes into play only when a personnel belonging to any disciplined force is dealt with by a Court or Tribunal established under a law relating to such force — The petitioners were nçt dealt with by any Court or Tribunal under any law relating to them — They were discharged from service by orders of an individual officer — They can therefore very well maintain the applications invoking writ jurisdiction.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Md. Faziur Rahman and others Vs.</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Govt. of Bangladesh and others, 1OBLD (HCD) 65Article — 102, 117 and 152(1)</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Administrative Tribunal</strong> — Extent of its authority and ouster of jurisdiction of other Courts — The Constitution uses the words Court to mean any Court of law including the Supreme Court — Not to speak of any other Court even the Supreme Court is constitutionally debarred from exercising any jurisdiction over any matter covered by the jurisdiction of the Administrative Tribunal — The Constitution has designed the Administrative Tribunal as an exclusive forum — The Tribunal does not need the umbrella of the High Court Division’s writ jurisdiction for implementation of its decision—The Administrative Tribunals Act ought to be interpreted in such manner as is consistent with the constitutional provision and legislative intent so that ii may provide a complete and self-<strong>sufficient remedy to the affected parties.</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Md. Shaifur Rahman Vs. Bangladesh and others, 10BLD (HC’D)2O5</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article — 102</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>The expression in an ‘unlawful manner’</strong> — referable to conflict between constitutional mandate and exercise of discretion by he executive authority — judicial review — In ease of conflict between the constitutional mandate and the exercise of discretion of the detaining authority under section 3(1) of the Special Powers Act, the High Court Division is to exercise judicial review of the executive to and it may strike down the actions which are malafide, colorable exercise of statutory powers or action taken upon extraneous or. irrelavent consideration or action taken on no around or without application of mind — these 3ctions not taken with lawful authority may be branded as actions taken in an unlawful manner — Special Powers Act, 1974 (XIV of</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">:974),s.3( I).</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Nazir Ali Vs. Secretary, Ministry of Home Affairs and others, 1OBLD(HCD) 258</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article — 102</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Alternative remedy</strong>: <strong>vires of the statute—</strong>Where an alternative statutory remedy is available, an application under Article 102 of the Constitution may not be entertained to circumvent a statutory procedure. There are, however, exceptions to the rule. Inspite of an alternative statutory remedy, an aggrieved person may take recourse to Article 102 of the Constitution where the vires of a statute or a statutory provision is challenged; where the alternative remedy is not efficacious or adequate; and where the wrong complained of is inextricably mixed up.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Dhaka Warehouse Ltd. and another Vs. Assistant Collector of Customs and others, IIBLD(AD) 227</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 42DLR (AD) 167; A.I.R. l968(SC) 13; A.I.R.1966 (SC) 142; 29 DLR (SC) 232;</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">-Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Articles — 102(2)(b)(i) and 102(2)(a)(ii)</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Distinction — Scope and Purpose </strong>— Article 102(2)(b)(ii) of the Constitution is for directing a person in custody to be brought before the Court so that it may satisfy itself that he is not being detained without lawful authority on the application of any person when the detenu is in custody. But under Article 102(2)(a)(ii) the High Court Division may declare any act done or proceeding taken by a person performing functions in connection with the affairs of the Republic or of a local authority to have been done or taken without lawful authority and is of no legal effect. It can only be done on the application of a person aggrieved. The scope and purpose of those two articles are quite different. There is no reason to hold that Article l02(2)(b)(i) stands as a bar in exercising jurisdiction under Article l02(2)(a)(ii) of the Constitution. Moreover, the former was not invoked by the petitioner nor any body questioning his detention but he was released by the Government without intervention of the Court beforeexpiry of the period of detention extended by the <strong><em>Gvernrnent.</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Mirza Ali Asharf Vs. The State and others, 11BLD(HCD)88</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article — 102(2)</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Association not a person</strong>—Under Article 102(2) of the Constitution, the High Court Division can, on the application of any aggrieved person, make an order directing a person, performing any functions in connection with the affairs of the Republic or of a local authority to refrain from doing that which is not permitted by law to do or to do that which he is required by law to do or declaring that any act done or proceeding taken by a person performing functions in connection with the affairs of the Republic or of a local authority has been done or taken without lawful authority and is of no legal effect.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The Bangladesh Diabetic Association is not a person performing any functions in connection with the affairs of the Republic or of a local authority within the meaning of section 3(28) of the General Clauses Act, 1897 — General Clauses Act, 1897 (X of 1897), S. 3(28).</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Manjurul Huq Vs. Bangladesh and others, 11 BLD(HCD)462</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article—102(1) read with Article 44 and 117</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Service matter</strong>—Without exhausting all available remedies before the administrative authorities including administrative appellate authority, the Administrative Tribunal and the Administrative Appellate Tribunal, generally speaking, the petitioner is not entitled to any relief before the High Court Division for enforcement of any fundamental right under Article 44 read with Article 102(I) of the Constitution.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Md. Abdul Hainzaiz Khan Vs. Secretary, Ministry of Home Affairs, Govt. of Bangladesh and others, 11BLD(HD,) 540</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: A.I.R.1953 (SC)86; A.1.R.l96l (SC)609 — Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article — 102</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Locus standi</strong>—It is quite clear that the petitioner may represent the employers in the Wage Board and may even have capacity to act as the employer’s representative in various other forums, but its locus standi to act on behalf of its members in an application under Article 102 of the Constitution is just not there.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">When it has no locus standi to challenge the Wage Board award, it cannot have the locus standi to cha1lnge the parent Act itself.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Bangladesh Sangbadpatra Parishad (BSP) Vs. The Government of Bangladesh and others, 12 BLD(AD)153</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: AIR. 1975(SC)2092; AIR. 1976</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">(SC)242; A.LR. 1981 (SC)344; A.1.R. 1982 (SC)149; A.I.R. 1983 (SC) 130; A.LR, 1984 (SC) 802; A.I.R. l987(SC)579; 29 DLRI88 — Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article 102</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Locus Standi </strong>— Petitioner, Principal of Rajbari Homeopathic Medical College and convener of proposed Homeopathic Medical College Recognition Implementation Committee — Such status of the petitioner neither denied nor objected before hand — But the question of locus standi of the petitioner belatedly introduced and faintly argued at the end of the petition — Whether locus standi of the petitioner is questionable?—His locus standi is unquestionable.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Dr. A.B.M. Quabil Ahmed Vs. The Secretary, Ministry of Health and another, I2BLD(HCD)340</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article — 102</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Breach of agreement for sale</strong>—Under Article 102 of the Constitution, the High Court Division can only declare that an act done by a person in connection with the affai s of the Republic has been done without jurisdiction or malafide or refrain from doing the act which he is required to do so under a law, the High Court can declare either the act done without jurisdiction or can issue writ of mandamus upon that person to do the actwhich he refrained from doing, but the High Court Division under Article 102 cannot give order for enforcement of a right by an authority to be declared without jurisdiction. If there is a breach of any terms of the agreement for sale, the remedy lies in a properly constituted suit for damage against the party to such contract for the breach of any term of the contract.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>The National Engineers Ltd. Vs. Director, Military Lands and Cantonment Directorate and others, l2BLD(HCD)563</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: (1910)A.C.381; 1985(Mad)104; 42 DLR(AD) 167; 1 BLD(AD)9 I ;7BLD(AD) 106; A.I.R. I 979(SC)62 I; (1948)2 A1l.E.R. 767; AIR. I 973(SC)2520: A.1.R. 1980 (SC) 1285; 332U.S.379 (1951)A.C. 837; (1976) (supp) S.C.R.532; (l956)IAII. E.R. 256; 332 U.S. 380—388; IBLD(AD) 103; A.I.R. 1977 (SC) 1496;l966(SC)334; (1972) (SC)843; —Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article — 103</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Political Question</strong> — Court should refrain trorn answering political questions if the validity or legality of the law could otherwise be decided.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>M/s. Dulichand Omraolal Vs. Bangladesh. IBLD(AD)1</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article— 103</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Power and jurisdiction of the Appellate Division</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Article 103 of the Constitution provides the jurisdiction of the Appellate Division and further it could exercise jurisdiction under such other cases as may be provided for by Act of Parliament. An appeal is a creature of the statute and no amount of consent can confer a jurisdiction which is not otherwise vested in it. The observation of the learned Company Judge is therefore bereft of any legal foundation.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Ellal Textile Mills Ltd. and others Vs. Md. Abdul Awal and others, SBLD(’AD) 230</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 14 l.A. 160—Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article — 103(2)(a)</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Substantial question of law</strong>—The High Court Division gave certificate under Article I 03(2)(a) of the Constitution that the matter involved a substantial question of law as to the interpretation of the Constitution, particularly Article 38 thereof.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Md. Asaduzzainan Vs. Bangladesh and others, 10 BLD(AD)267</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article — 103(2)</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Leave to appeal</strong>—The High Court Di vision is normally the Court of appeal, excepting the cases covered by clause (2) of Article 103 of the Constitution. In other matters appeal will lie to the Appellate Division only when it grants leave to appeal. By practice this does not interfere with a finding of fact, more so with a concurrent finding of the High Court Division and the trial Court. It would not normally reappraise or review evidence or enter into the credibility of the evidence with a view to substitute its own opinion for that of the High Court Division or even when it strongly feels that a different view is possible. Interference by the Appellate Division is exceptional and that is why the provision for special leave. For promoting the cause of justice, for doing complete justice and for prevention of miscarriage of justice, the power of the Appellate Division is very wide, overriding, and exceptional and is not encumbered by any technicality. It, however, exercises this power sparingly and only in furtherance of the cause of justice, and in this regard, it is guided by its own practice and precedents, [Per M.H. Rahman, J.J</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Abu Taher Chowdhury and others Vs. The State 11 BLD’AD,2</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Articles — 104 and 105</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Power of the Appellate Division to suo motu review its own judgment</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">There is no controversy regarding the power of the Appellate Division to review its judgment. The power has been conferred by the Constitution which also provides how the exercise of this power will be regulated. Article 105 provides that the Parliament may enact law as to how the power will be exercised or this Court may make rule for its exercise.So far, no Act of Parliament has been passed as mentioned in the Article, the Court has not framed any rule, but has adopted the rules which were made under similar provisions for review in the Constitution of Pakistan, 1962. In practice the Court also regards the provisions of Order 47 Rule I C.P.C. for the purpose of reviewing its judgment, though these provisions are not binding upon it. As a matter of practice and rule the Appellate Division proceeds to review a judgment pronounced earlier by it upon an application for review by an aggrieved party. Prior to hearing a review petition the Court has to be satisfied that grounds for review as mentioned in Order XXVIof the Rules of the Supreme Court exist. The power to review is derived from the Constitution and as such this power cannot be restricted in any manner whatsoever excepting by what has been provided in the Constitution itself. There is mention of an Act of Parliament and rules of the Court itself. Neither the Parliament nor the Court has up till now made any provision against exercising the power suo motu. Since the power to review has been conferred by the Constitution, nothing can, negative this power if the Court wants to exercise it of its own. The expression “doing complete justice” as occurs in Article 104 of the Constitution are of great significance. Their importance cannot be whittled down nor can the Court give up a fraction of this power. It is a great power with which the Court has been armed. For the reasons set forth above, it must be held that the Appellate Division has the power to review its judgment acting suo motu.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Mahbubur Rahman Sikder and others Vs. Mujibur Rahman Sikder and others, 4 BLD(AD)175</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: PLD 1 959(SC)423; (1962)PLD(SC) 335; PLD 1949 (PC)1; (1966)3 All. E.R. 77; (1979)2 AII.E.R 1146(1155);</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article —104</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Complete of Justice</strong>—Complete justice</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">may not be perfect justice, and any endeavour to attain the latter will be an act of vanity. In the name of complete justice if a frequent recourse is made to Article 104, then this Court will be exposed to the opprobrium of purveyor of “palm-tree justice”</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>A.F.M. Naziruddin Vs. Mrs. Hamee-da Barn 12BLD(AD)261</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article — 107(3)</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Power of the Chief Justice to Constitute Benches</strong>—Chief Justice alone has power of constitution of Benches and distribution of business amongst the Judges.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Moazzem Hossain, DAG Vs. The State, 3BLD(AD)251</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Articles — 109 and 114</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Supervisory Jurisdiction under Article 109</strong>—Court Martial not a Court subordinate to the High Court Division.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Per K. Hossain, C.J:</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The Court’s mentioned in Article 109 is to be looked at in the context in which it has been used. The Court Martial set up under the Army Act is at best a military Tribunal and not a Court as contemplated under Article 109 of the Constitution. Article 114 only enables the Parliament to set up Courts with jurisdiction not equal or superior to the Supreme Court, and the word ‘subordinate’ has been used in this sense in this Article, neither in the Constitution, nor in any other law, this is any provisions to make a Court Martial set up under the Army Act subordinate to the High Court Division under Article 109.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Per B.H. Chowdhury, J:</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It is not correct to suggest that the Court Martial is a Court which is amenable to the supervisory or superintending jurisdiction of the High Court Division under Article 109 of the Constitution. These Courts, namely, the Courts Martial are creation of the Army Act and these are all ad-hoc Courts unlike the Courts as understood in the common parlance. These are ad-hoc Courts and they are convened as and when necessity arises. Thenecessary supervisory hierarchy has been created by the Army Act itself and both the Constitution and the law have cautiously kept those Courts out of the ambit of the civil Courts.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Jamil Huq Vs. Bangladesh and others, IBLD(AD)488</em></strong> Ref: (1949)All.E.R., 242 and 373 —Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article — 109</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Jurisdiction of High Court Division</strong> — Whether it can quash the proceeding before the Special Tribunal after proclamation of Martial Law suspending the Constitution — High Court Division has the same powers as it had before the Proclamation.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The jurisdiction of the High Court Division in so far as the exercise of powers under section 56lA Cr.P.C. over the proceedings of the Special Tribunal are concerned, remains unchanged and unaffected by the Proclamation of Martial Law on 243l982 — Proclamation Order No. I of 1982, Clause 4(3); Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898(V of 1898), S. 561A.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Baidynath Kar and others Vs. The State, 4BLD(BcD)2 75</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article — 110</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Transfer of suit by the High Court Division —</strong> Whether after the suspension of the Constitution of Bangladesh by the Proclamation of Martial Law on 24th of March, 1982 the High Court Division can exercise the power of transfer it had under the suspended Constitution — Though the Constitution was suspended by the Proclamation of Martial Law on 24th March 1982 by the Proclamation First Amendment Order of 1982, schedule 4 was added whereby High Court Division’s power of transferring Suits under Article 110 of the suspended Constitution was revived — The High Court Division can exercise the power in regard to transferring suits it could ercise under Article 110 of the Constitution — Martial Law Proclamation First Amendment Order, 1982 (Proclamation Order No. I of 1982), Schedule Clause 4(3).</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Bangladesh Supreme Court Bar Association Vs. Khondker Abu Bakar and another, 5BLD(HCD)l</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 54 I.L.R.(Cal)607; Chancery Division, Kings Bench Vol. II page 205; D.L.C. Vol. II, 1970 at page 154; Unreported decision of Justice Nurul Islam in Transferred Suit No 4 of 1979 between the Chairman DIT and an advocate of this Court who was a legal Advisor of DIT — Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article —110</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Transfer of suit to the High Court Division</strong> — Whether there is general public importance to warrant the transfer of the suit</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The point involved in the suit only concerns the parties and not the general public — So there is no point of general public importance— The petitioner failed to make out any case for transfer of the suit to the High Court Division on the point of general public importance.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Bangladesh Supreme Court Bar Association Vs. Vol. II, 1970 at page 154; Unreported decision of Justice Nurul Islam in Transferred Suit No. 4 of 1979 between the Chairman DIT and an Advocate of this Court who was a legal Advisor of D.I.T. — Cited.<span id="pastemarkerend"></span></p></div></div>
1149	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">CONSTITUTION OF BANGLADESH, 1972 [ARTICLE 111 - 152]</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  10BLD (HCD)5, 1IBLD(HCD)533, 10BLD(AD)71, 11BLl3HcD,23, 10 BLD(AD)151, JBLD (AD)140, 1BLD (HCD) 493,  1BLD (AD)140, 1BLD (AD) 378, 1BLD (AD)3 78, 1BLD (HD) 12, 6BLD(AD)118, 11BLD (HCD)528, J2BLD (AD)140, 2BLD(AD)178, 1BLD(HCD)381, 1989 BLD(Spl)1, 10BLD (</p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  1972</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  CONSTITUTION OF BANGLADESH</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p align="center" style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: center;"><strong><u><br/> </u></strong></p><p align="center" style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: center;"><strong><u>CONSTITUTION OF BANGLADESH, 1972</u></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article — 112</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Contempt of Court</strong> — Failure to act in aid of the Supreme Court may lead to contempt — Since the delay in implementing the Court’s advance order of release of the detenu cannot be explained in terms of any provision in the Jail Code or in terms of the Government’s instruction, the contemners have acted not in aid of the Supreme Court in releasing the detenu but in aid of the Home Ministry in facilitating the making and serving of a fresh order of detention — The contemners have thus disobeyed the order of the Court and are thus guilty of the contempt of Court — Contempt of Court Act, 1926 (XII 1926), Sections — 2 and 3.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Amit Kumar Banik and another Vs. Manjurul Karim, Jailor, Dhaka Central Jail, Dhaka and another, 10BLD (HCD)5</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Articles — 112 and 135</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Liberty of citizens</strong>—The authority is obligated to act in aid of the Supreme Court and to protect liberty of citizens.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Farzana Huq Vs. Bangladesh and others, 1IBLD(HCD)533</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article — 117(2)</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Transfer of a Trade Union Leader</strong> — Plea of protection to a person in the service of a statutory public authority — Provisions of I.R.O empowering Labour Court to give protection to a trade union leader against his harassment by transfer are not applicable to those leaders who are working in statutory public authorities like the H.B.F.C. — The basic status of the appellant (trade union leader) is that he is a worker of the Corporation and transferability or non-transferability of his service is a condition of his employment and the matter clearly comes within the purview of the Administrative Tribunal which has the full power to give complete relief to an applicant, and then the right of a trade union leader in such a case must yield to the supervening provision of the Constitution—Industrial Relations Ordinance, 1969 (XXIII of 1969), S. 47B — Administrative Tribunal Act, 1980(VII of 1981), S. 4</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Abdul Mannan Talukder Vs Bangladesh House Building Finance Corporation and another, 10BLD(AD)71</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: I 968( l)Al1.E.R.433 (439 — 490); (1948) 1 K.B.72l (724); 33 DLR (AD) 305; — Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article — 117(2)</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Administrative Tribunal</strong>—Where any Administrative Tribunal is set up no Court shall entertain any proceeding or make any order in respect of ahy matter falling within the jurisdiction of such tribunal.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">When by a statute an authority is vested in another tribunal with exclusive power over any subject matter, a Court ceases to have any jurisdiction to try such suit having jurisdiction.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Md. Mansur All Vs. Janata Bank and others, 11BLl3HcD,23</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 33 DLR(AD)143; 33 DLR(AD) 150; — Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article —119</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Election</strong> — The Election Commission got power both under the Constitution in Article 119, and under section 24 of the Union Parishad Ordinance, to organize, conduct, supervise and hold an election and that the Election Commission, by necessary implication, got power to intervene at any stage of the election process before the notification in the Gazette is published — Local Government (Union Parishad) Ordinance, 1983 (LI of 1983), S. 24. -</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Md. Rafiqul A lain Vs.Mustafa Kamal and others, 10 BLD(AD)151</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 41 DLR(AD)68 — Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Articles — 133 and 134</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Enactment</strong> :-Conflict with constitution—Provision of Articles 133 and 134 of the Constitution cannot save an enactment of the kind under consideration if it is in conflict with other constitutional provisions.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Dr. Nurul Islam Vs. Bangladesh, JBLD (AD)140Articles — 133 and 136 read with para 10(2) (b) of Fourth Schedule</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Service of the Republic—Ante—dated seniority</strong>—A law under paragraph lO(2)(b) of the Fourth Schedule or under Article 136 of the Constitution can have both retrospective and prospective effect, but a law made under Article 133 of the Constitution can have only prospective effect — Government Servants Seniority of Freedom Fighters) Rules, 1979 at-c ultra vires rules making power under Article 133 of the Constitution.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Zainal Abedin and another Vs. Govt. of Bangladesh and others, 1BLD (HCD) 493</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Articles — 134 and 135</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Pleasure of the President</strong>—The doctrine of holding office during the pleasure of the President embodied in Article 134 is limited by the guarantee provided under Article 135 of the Constitution.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Dr. Nurul Islam Vs. Bangladesh, 1BLD (AD)140</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Articles — 134, 135 and 152(1)</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Constitution — Service of the Republic </strong>— Disciplined Force — Constitution has divided persons in the service of the Republic into two broad categories: one holding a post in civil capacity and the other in military capacity — A person who is not in any one of the defence forces, i.e., army, navy or air force, cannot be said to be holding a post in military capacity — A police officer holds civil post in the service of the Republic.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Bangladesh and others Vs. A.K.M.
