Zahaiigir Hossain, 1BLD (AD) 378</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Articles — 134 and 135</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Constitution</strong> — Service of the Republic</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">— Extent of the doctrine of pleasure of the President — The doctrine is subject to the limitations prescribed by Article 135 in respect of persons holding civil post in the service of the Republic.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Bangladesh and others Vs. A.K.M. Zahangir, 1BLD (AD)3 78</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article — 135</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Opportunity to show cause</strong>—Notification retiring petitioner of his duties and designation of Professor of Medicine without giving him opportunity of showing cause violates Article 135 of the Constitution — Financial sanction or payment of remuneration not essential pre-condition for creating a civil post.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It has been contended that by the impugned notification relieving the petitioner of his duties and designation of Professor of amounts to his removal from the said post. Admittedly the petitioner was not given any opportunity to show cause as required under Article 135(2) of the Constitution before taking the impugned action. Thus apparently the impugned notification appears to have been made in violation of the aforesaid Article. It has been argued by the learned Attorney General that since there was neither any post nor appointment as Professor of Medicine, the question of the petitioner’s removal does not arise. Although there was no sanctioned post of Professor of Medicine of IPGMR, by appointing the petitioner as Professor of Medicine in 1967 was the post was created and consequently the relationship of master and servant between the Government and the petitioner was established by such appointment and the petitioner continues to hold that post. Since admittedly, the petitioner never received any extra remuneration for the post. there does not appear any necessity of financial sanction; besides for creating a civil post, payment of remuneration is not an essential precondition.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Dr. Nurul Islam Vs. Bangladesh and others, 1BLD (HD) 12</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: AIR. I C) 67(SC) 884 — Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article — 135</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Employee of Co-operative Land Mortgage Bank—Whether—Government servant </strong>— Whether such an employee is entitled to protection of Article 135 of the suspended Constitution?—Registrar of Co-operative So- cieties has been given wide powers of supervision and control as well as guidance of Land Mortgage Banks — In line with such policy the Registrar exercises power of appointment of employees of the Bank who are employees of the Bank and not of the Government — Managing Committee of the Bank has power to appoint and dismiss employees— Managing Committee may make its own rules, regulations and bye-laws to deal with disciplinary matters and can also adopt Government Service Rules for regulating service of its employees — But these rules have no statutory force — Though the employee was appointed by the Registrar and he was given certain service benefits of Government servants, he is not a Government servant and the Managing Committee has got absolute power of appointing and dismissing its employees — Such an employee is not entitled to protection of Article 1 35 of the Constitution, yet he was given opportunity to explain his position in response to the allegations brought against him and as such the principles of natural justice were duly complied with — Co-operative Societies Rules, 1942, Rule 37.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>The People Republic of Bangladesh and another Vs. Md. Aladdin alias Alauddin Sarker and another, 6BLD(AD)118</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 1966PLD(SC)445; PLDI96I(SC)</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">445; PLDI 958(SC)533; PLD 1962(SC) 315:PLD I 958(SC)l 47; PLDI 959(SC) 210; A.I.R .l970(SC)1150;AJ.R.1969 (Cal) 95; 33 DLR(AD)37l; 29 DLR(AD) 41; All. E.R. 1950</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Vol.(1) P. 38 — Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article — 135</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Second show cause notice</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The principle of second show cause notice as provided in Article 135 of the Constitution is for protection of any person holding a civil post under the Republic.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Fazlul Karim Vs. Agrani Bank, 11BLD (HCD)528</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article—135</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Second show cause</strong>—In Article 135 of the Constitution, a person holding any civil post in the service of the Republic is entitled to a second show cause notice in the event of dismissal, removal or reduction in rank, but that is a constitutional protectioli given to them. But this protection cannot be extended to the employees of a statutory corporation on the ground of natural justice. This protection can only be extended by statutory rules.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Jamuna Oil Company Ltd. and another Vs. S.K. Dey and another, J2BLD (AD)140</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article—136</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Constitutional Law</strong> — Constitution empowers the Government to recognize ‘service of the Republic’— the notification by which placements of the respondent and others was made got effect notwithstanding any other law in force — Notification cannot be questioned on the ground that it has varied or revoked the condition of service of a Government Servant — Services (Reorganisation and Condition) Act, 1975 (XXXII of 1975), S.4.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Bangladesh, through the Secretary, Ministry of Finance (Implementation Division) and others, Vs. Md. Azizur Rahman, 2BLD(AD)178</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article — 142</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Limitation on the power Qf the Parliament</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Constitutional Law — Amendment of Constitution </strong>— The Parliament cannot alter the essential featuresand basic structures of the Constitution— Incorporation of emergency provisions and introduction of Fourth Amendment altered the basic and essential features of the Constitution. But Government owned Newspapers (Management) Act, 1975 cannot be declared constitutional on the ground of loss of competence of the Parliament on account of Fourth Amendment and creation of immunity of laws during Proclamation of Emergency as the constitutionalprocess in the country has followed a different course.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Hamidul Huq Chowdhury and others Vs. Bangladesh, 1BLD(HCD)381</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Rei: A.LR. I 967(SC) 1643; A.I.R. 1980 (SC)l 89—Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article—142</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Constitution of Bangladesh</strong> — Amending power of Parliament — Scope and extent of the power — Whether any basic structure or essential feature of the Constitution can be altered or damaged by the Parliament under Article 142 of the Constitution.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Per B.H. Chowdhury, J:</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It does not need citation of any authority that the power to frame a Constitution is a primary power whereas a power to amend a rigid Constitution is a derivative power derived from the Constitution and subject at least to the limitation imposed by prescribed procedure. Secondly, laws made under a rigid Constitution, as also the amendment of such a Constitution can be ultra vires if they contravene the limitations put on the law making or amending power by the Constitution, for the Constitution is the touch stone of validity of the exercise of the powers conferred by it. But no provision of the Constitution can be ultra vires because there is no touch stone outside the Constitution by which the validity of a provision of the Constitution can be judged. [Para 145]</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The term amendment implies such an addition or change within the lines of the original instrument as will effect an improvement or better carry out the purpose for which it was formed. [Para 192]</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The people accepted the Constitution which is baptised by the blood of the martyrs. That Constitution promises ‘economic and social justice in a society in which ‘the rule of law, fundamental human right and freedom, equality and justice’ are assured and declared. Call it by any a name — basic feature or whatever but that is the fabric of the Constitution which cannot be dismantled by an authority created by the Constitution itself, namely, the Parliament. Necessarily, the amendment passed by the Parliament is to be tested as against Article 7. Because the amending power is but a power given by the Constitution to Parliament, it is a higher power than any other given by the Constitution to Parliament, but nevertheless it is a power within and not outside the Constitution. [Para 1951</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Now, some of the features are basic features of the Constitution and they are not amenable by the amending power of the Parliament. In the scheme of Article 7 and therefore of the Constitution the structural pillars of the Parliament and the Judiciary are basic and fundamental. It is inconceivable that by its amending power the Parliarment can deprive itself wholly or partly of the plenary legislative power over the entire Republic the Constitutional scheme if follow carefully reveals that these basic features are unamendable and unalterable [Para 255, 256].</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Per S. Ahmed, J:</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">‘Amendment’ of a statute may have various meanings depending upon its context. Dictionary meaning of the word ‘amendment is change for the purpose of effecting improvement or removing any defect ... the word ‘amendment’ or ‘amend’ has been used in different places to mean different things; so it is the context by referring to which the actual meaning of the word ‘amendment’ can be ascertained. My conclusion is that the word ‘amendment’ is a change or alteration, for the purpose of bringing in improvement in the statute to make it more effective and meaningful, but it does not mean its abrogation or destruction or a change resulting in the loss of its original identity and character. In the case of amendment of a constitutional provision “amendment” should be that which accords with the intention of the makers of the Constitution. [Para 334, 336]</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Article 142, before it was amended by the First Amendment Act, 1973 provided that any provision of the Constitution ‘may be amended or repealed by an Act of Parliament’...It appears that by this amendment of Article 142 only the words ‘by way of addition, alteration, substitution or repeal’ have been brought in for the words ‘amended or repealed. There does not appear to be any substantial change and by this substitution only different kinds of amendments have been indicated. (Para 338)</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">There is no dispute that the Constitution stands on certain fundamental principles which are its structural pillars and if those pillars are demolished or damaged the whole Constitutional edifice will fall down. It is by construing the Constitutional provisions that these pillars are to be identified. Implied limitation on the amending power is also to be gathered from the Constitution itself including its preamble ... Main objection to the doctrine of basic structure is that it is uncertain in nature and is based on unfounded fear. But in reality basic structures of the Constitution are clearly identifiable. ‘Sovereignty’ belongs to the people and it is a basic structure of the Constitution Supremacy of the Constitution, is the solemn expression of the people.. Democracy, Republican Government, ‘Unitary State, Separation of Powers, Independence of the Judiciary, Fundamental Rights are basic structures of the Constitution. There is no dispute about their identity. By amending the Constitution the Republic cannot be replaced by monarchy, democracy by oligarchy or the judiciary cannot be abolished, although there is no express bar to the amending power given in the Constitution. Principle of separation of powers means that the sovereign authority is equally distributed among the three organs and as such one organ can not destroy the others. These are the structural pillars of the Constitution and they stand beyond any change by amendatory process. (Para 376, 377).</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">..As to implied limitation on the amending power it is inherent in the word ‘amendment’ in Art. 142 and is also deducible from the entire scheme of the Constitution. Amendment of the Constitution means change or alteration for improvement or make it effective or meaningful and not - elimination or abrogation. Amendment is subject to the retention of the basic structures The Court therefore has power to undo amendment if it transgresses its limit and alters a basic structure of the Constitution. [Para 378]</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Per M.H. Rahman, J:</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The people of Bangladesh adopted, en— acted and gave to themselves the Constitution pledging in clear terms in the preamble “that it shall be a fundamental aim of the State release through the democratic process a se cialist society, free from exploitation—a ciety in which the rule of law, fundament4 human rights and freedom, equality and justice, political, economic and social, will secured for all citizens” ... the Proclamation Order No. IV of 1978 made the Prea along with Articles 8, 48, 56, 5, 80, 92A entrenched provision in the Constitution The Preamble has become the touchstone I’ assaying the worth or the validity of amendment that may be passed in accord with clause (I) of Art. 142. When the Parliament cannot by itself amend the Preamble cannot indirectly by amending a provision the Constitution impair or destroy the fu mental aim of our society.(Para 388)</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The provisions contained in Part VI the Supreme Court are not entrenched provisions and they can be amended by the leg lecture under Art. 142. But if any amendment causes any serious impairment of the of and the functions of the Supreme Court in makers of the Constitution devised as t kingpin for securing the rule of law to all ‘zens, then the validity of such an amendment will be examined on the touchstone of t Preamble. (Para 391)</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The doctrine of basic structure is o growing point in the constitutional jurisprudence. It has developed in a climate w1 the executive, commanding an over majority in the legislature; pets snap amendment of the Constitution passed with any public opinion, without sending the Bill to any select committee and without giving sufficient time to the members of the Parliament for deliberation on the Bill for amendment. . .The doctrine of basic structure is a new one and appears to be an extension of the principle of judicial review... It may take some time before the doctrine of basic structure gets acceptance from the superior Courts of the countries where constitutionalism is prevailing. (Para 435, 438, 439)</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Per A.T.M. Afzal, J:</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">According to dictionary meaning, to “amend”, inter alia, means, to “free from faults”, correct, rectify. reform, make alteration, to repair. to better and surpass, For the purpose of this issue the word “amendment” will be understood in the sense of “alteration” as was understood by the majority judgment in Kessavananda’s case in regard to Parliament’s power to amend the basic structure and framework of the Constitution.(Para 529)</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It will be seen, in the first place, that there is no substantive limitation on the power of the Parliament to amend any provision of the Constitution as may be found under Art. V of the Constitution of the USA... The limitation which is provided in Art. 142 relates only to procedure for amendment and not substantive in the sense that no article is beyond the purview of amendment. (Para 530)</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Sub-art. (I) shows that any provision of the Constitution may be amended by way of addition, alteration, substitution or repeal by Act of Parliament. Any provision evidently includes all provisions. The language is clear and suffers from no ambiguity. Any provision could not mean some provision. This clear language amply indicates the wide sweep and plenitude of power of the Parliament to amend any provision of the Constitution. It is difficult, therefore, to conceive, as contended by the appellants, that there are some provisions called “basic” which are not amenable to the amendatory process... It is significant that the article opens with a Non-obstante</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">used in a provision to indicate that, that provision should prevail despite any-thing to the contrary in the provision mentioned in such Non-obstante Clause... in the presence of such a clause in Art. 142, it is difficult to sustain the contention of the appellants that some provisions containing basic features are unamendable or that the amendment of any provision has to stand the test of validity under Art.7(Para 534,535)</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The “basic feature” theory does not appeal to reason on two fundamental grounds. The first is that it is inconceivable that the makers of theConstitution had decided on all matters for all people of all ages without leaving any option to the future generation. Secondly, if it is right that they wanted the so- called “basic features” to be permanent features of the Constitution there was nothing to prevent them from making such a provision in the Constitution itself. On the other hand, it has been noticed that the makers placed no limitation whatsoever in the matter of amendment of the Constitution except providing for some special procedure in Art. 142. Further after the incorporation of sub-art. (IA) providing for a more difficult procedure of referendum in case of amendment of the provisions mentioned therein, the contention as to further essential features, becomes all the more difficult to accept. (Para 536)</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">All the provisions of the Constitution are essential and no distinction can be made between essential and non-essential feature from the point of view of amendment unless the makers of the Constitution make it expressly clear in the Constitution itself. If the positive power of amendment of the Constitution in Art. 142 is restricted by raising the wall of essential feature, the clear intention of the Constitution-makers will be nullified and that would lead to destruction of the Constitution by paving the way for extra constitutional or revolutionary changes. (Para537)</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The power to amend any provision of the Constitution by way of addition, alteration,</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Green Paper or White Paper, without eliciting Clause. A Non-obstante Clause is usuallysubstitution or repeal is found to be unlimited except as provided in Art. 142 itself. But there is a limitation inherent in the word “amend” or “amendment” which may be said to be a built-in limitation... Whatever meaning those words may bear, this, in my, opinion, cannot be disputed that they can never mean, to ‘destroy’ or ‘abrogate’,. It is significant that under Art.l42 any provision of the Constitution may be repealed but there is no conferment of power to repeal the Constitution itself as are to be found in the then Constitution of Pakistan of 1956 and the Constitution of Ceylon... Therefore in exercise of the power under Art. 142 the Constitution cannot be destroyed or abrogated. The destruction of the Constitution will be the result if any of its “structural pillars”, that is, the three organs of the Government. Executive, Legislature and Judiciary are destroyed. The result will also be the same if any of these organs is emasculated and castrated in such a manner as would make the Constitution unworkable.(Para 562)</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Anwar Hossain Chowdhury Vs. Bangaldesh, 1989 BLD(Spl)l</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article — 142</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>(b) Constitution of Bangladesh—Doctrine of basic structure—Because the doctrine was not invoked in our country in the past, the Court cannot be precluded now from considering and applying it.</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Per S. Ahmed,J:</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The fact that basic structures of the Constitution were changed in the past, cannot be, and is not, accepted as a valid ground to answer the challenge to future amendments of this nature, that is, the impugned amendment may be challenged on the ground that it has altered the basic structure of the Constitution. (Para 332)</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Per A.T.M.Afzal,J(disagreeing):</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In our context the doctrine of basic features has indigenous and special difficulties for acceptance... The “basic features” have been varied in such abandon and with such quick succession that the credibility in the viability of the theory of fundamentally is bound to erode. (Para 551)</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>(c) Constitution of Bangladesh—Amend. ment of Article 100 damaged the High Court Division of the Supreme Court with plenary judicial power of the Republic and as such amendment of Article 100 of the Constitution (Eighth Amendment) Act, 1988 is void.</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Per B.H. Chowdhury,J:</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In our Constitution no territorial conception has been injected. The High Court Division exercised plenary power for giving directions and orders to any person or authority including any person performing any function in connection with the affairs of the Republic irrespective of consideration of residence location. It exercises plenary power because I is the integral part of the Supreme Court Bangladesh.(Para 138)</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The amended sub-article(5) has disri - structural balance that was carefully erec in Part VI of the Constitution:.. If sub-article (5) attempted to create two new sets of Courts by a device terming them as “permane Benches” and the “Bench at the permanei seat” then... the least that can be said is that is hit by Article 114 which enables the legislature for setting up subordinate Courts of law but such must not be of co-ordil3ate jurisdiction or compete with Article 44 Sub-article (5) has clearly destroyed the structural pill of the Constitution as given in Article 94 and thus has violated the mandate of the Constitution and further brought itself within the mischief of the provision in Article 7(2). (Para 139,140, 141)</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Now this impugned amendment Act has violated directly two Articles, namely, Articles 102 and 44 and without amending expressly the other Articles of Chapter I and II of Part VI(Articles 94 to 116). it has disrupted the provisions in relation to the judiciary given in Article 94 because it has added some alien concept by way of introducing Permanent Benches” conferring specifically Jurisdiction, power and functions” of the High Court Division, thereby creating seven Courts in the name of permanent Benches. This has been done indirectly because it could not be done directly... It has disrupted the constitutional fabric of Article 102 by introducing territorial concept thereby creating innumerable difficulties and incongruities. Para 151, 152)</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The impugned amendment in a subtle manner in the name of creating “permanent Benches”, has indeed created new Courts parallel to the High Court Division as contemplated in Article 94,101,102. Thus the basic structural pillar, that is judiciary, has been destroyed and plenary judicial power of the Republic vested in the High Court Division has been taken away. (para 257)</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The amended Article 100 is ultra vires because it has destroyed the essential limb of the judiciary, namely, of the Supreme Court of Bangladesh by setting up rival Courts to the High Court Division in the name of permanent Benches conferring full jurisdictions, powers and functions of the High Court Division.(Para 259)</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Per S. Ahmed,J:</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The concept of the Supreme Court of Bangladesh consisting of both the Appellate Division and’ the High Court Division is a unique one and it has been so devised as to keep the Supreme Court, the highest judicial organ of the State, in line with Article I which provides that “Bangladesh is a unitary, independent, sovereign Republic”. ..This integrated Supreme Court is a part of the basic structure of the Constitution, it cannot be damaged directly or indirectly.., the High Court Division as an integral part of the Supreme Court is headed by the Chief Justice of the country and its territorial jurisdiction is all over the Republic...The unitary character of the State has been reflected in the field of judiciary, one of the three State organs, by creating an integrated Supreme Court. Once this integrity is damaged, affected or broken, more High Courts than one are likely to be created either directly or indirectly under the garb of permanent Benches making them independent of each other. Creation of more permanent seats than one is not permissible if the Supreme Court is to continue as an integrated judicial organ of the State at the apex. (Para 361, 362)</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Looking at the impugned Article and other relevant Articles, it is found that by the impugned Article the High Court Division has been denuded of its power and jurisdiction under Article 102 of the Constitution over a large part of the country... Because of the territorial divisions for the jurisdiction of the Benches and the High Court Division in the permanent seat, which have no common authority over them all, writs issued by them will be limited in operation in their respective areas only. As to Admiralty jurisdiction of the High Court Division, it cannot be assigned to any of the areas for the territorial waters do not belong to any district but belong to the Republic and in case the cause of action of a case under Admiralty jurisdiction arises in the territorial waters, none of the Benches and the High Court Division in the permanent seat shall have jurisdiction thereon. High Court Division’s power to transfer any case from one subordinate Court to another or to withdraw it to itself under Article 110 has been negative; at best this power now may be exercised by the six Benches and the High Court Division sitting in the permanent seat over their respective subordinate Courts. Similar is the case with superintendence and control over subordinate Courts under Article 109. As to the binding effect of judgment under Article 111, the judgment of one Bench or Court is not binding upon another Bench /Court and the Courts subordinate to it; as such conflicting decisions are quite likely. As to the Supreme Court as the only Court of record under Article 108, it is not clear how many such Courts of Records have now resulted from the amendment (f-. 27c)The High Court Division as an integral part of the Supreme Court has lost its original character as well as most of its territorial jurisdiction. Seven judicial bodies, by whatever name they are called, Benches or Courts, are, to all intents and purposes, independent Courts having no relation with each other except a thin link through the Chief Justice... The “High Court Division” sitting in the permanent seat is not the original High Court Division with jurisdiction over the whole of the Republic, it is a Court with limited territorial jurisdiction—that is, the jurisdiction over what is called the “residuary area” in clause(5) of the impugned Article…High Court Division as contemplated in the unlamented Article is no longer in existence and as such the Supreme Court, one of the basic structures of the Constitution, ha been badly damaged, if not destroyed altogether. (Para 378)</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Per M. H. Rahman, J:</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In part VI of the Constitution the scheme of the judiciary has been delineated. Art. 94 provides for the establishment of a Supreme Court comprising the Appellate Division and the High Court Division. The functions of the two Divisions are different, but the two together form the Supreme Court, a single Court, having plenary power over the whole Country. (Para 390)</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">From the content and circumstances in which the amendment was made one may assume that its object was merely to provide a basis for setting up some permanent Benches</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It is not clear why second half of clause (5) was not included in the Bill... The private member’s contribution was the last straw on the camel’s back. The High Court Division lost its resonance and its plenary jurisdiction was totally undermined. (Para 405)</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In this case we are concerned with only one basic feature, the rule of law, marked out as one of the fundamental aims of our society in the Preamble. The validity of the impugned amendment may be examined, with or without resorting to the doctrine of basic feature, on the touchstone of the Preamble itself. (Para443) One of the fundamental aims of our society is to secure the rule of law for all citizens -l and in furtherance of that aim Part VI and other provisions were incorporated in the Constitution. Now by the impugned amendment that structure of rule of law has been badly impaired, and as a result the High Court Division has fallen into sixes and sevens—six at the seats of the permanent Benches and seven at the permanent seat of the Supreme Court. (Para 456)</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The reasoning’s of the decisions reported in 17 DLR(SC) 384 and the two Allahabad cases, AIR 1972 All 200(F.B) and AIR 1977 488(F.B.) might have been a complete answer to the appellants’ contentions as to mutilations of the High Court Division’s power ‘ jurisdiction had there been no concept of con fining the High Court Division within the residual area as in Art. 100(5). Because of the last part of Clause (5), the High Court Division has been left high and dry. It has lost ñ valency as an integral limb of the Supreme Court... It has been faint-heartedly argued t1c the High Court Division sitting in the permanent seat shall have all kinds of areas of juris-4 diction that are not assigned to the permanent, Benches. This submission has got no force the term “area” has been mentioned in Article 100 three times always meaning a territorial area and the six notifications-shows that to areas are zilla areas. The term “area” cannot be extended to mean jurisdiction. (Para 474)</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It appears that uncertainties loomed large even in the minds of the Judges not to speak of the minds of the lay public. The learned Attorney General’s remark that no difficulty will arise for any litigant if he gets prop legal advice is rather far fetching. I am, however, striking down the amendment not ground of uncertainties or irreconcilability of the existing provisions with the amended provisions as such but on the ground of the amendment’s irreconcilability with the rule of law, as envisaged in the Preamble, and in furtherance of which Arts 27, 31, 32, 44, 94 to I IA were particularly incorporated in the Constitution. (Para 483)</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Per A.T.M. Afzal, J (dissenting):</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The entire argument on behalf of the appellants rests on an assumption... that by assigning the areas to the permanent Benches and leaving the residue to the High Court Division sitting at the permanent seat, the jurisdiction of the Judges sitting on those benches has been limited to the areas thus assigned (territorially limited) and as such they have ceased to be Judges of the High Court Division exercising plenary power through out the Republic as envisaged under the Constitution. If this assumption or interpretation is correct, I shall have no hesitation to accept the argument... that the High Court Division, a structural pillar of the Constitution, has ceased to exist and the impugned amendment has passed a sentence of death upon the Supreme Court... I have given full consideration to all the learned arguments. but I remain convinced that the assumption or interpretation made by them is wrong and not tenable in law. (Para572)</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The plenary jurisdiction which is vested in the Judges of the High, Court Division under Arts. 101 and 102 has remained unaffected and the provisions of amended Art. 100, particularly that of sub-art. (5) read with Rule (4) of the impugned Rules merely provide for the places from where and the manner in which such jurisdiction is to be exercised. The limitation of territory under sub art. (5) is meant to operate not on the jurisdiction of the Court or of its Judges, but on the manner of its exercise. (Para 573)</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">According to the appellants.. .Bangladesh has been parcelled out into seven mutually exclusive divisions by such assignment and the Judges sitting in these divisions are Judges of regional Courts with territorially limited jurisdiction. ..This view wills inevitably he in conflict with all the relevant articles of chapter 1 Part VI... It will be seen that sub-art. (5) read with Rule (4) amounts to no more than a statutory allocation of the category of cases arising from the respective areas to each of the permanent Benches and it does not in any manner limit or affect the plenary power of the Judges of these Benches as are vested in them as Judges of the High Court Division under the Constitution. (Para 577)</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It is clear that in matters of exercise of judicial power, the High Court Divisions has been treated separately in the Constitution and the impugned amendment is but only an extension of such treatment. What is important to remember is that no article of Chapter I has been amended (except 107(3) which is consequential) and is must be presumed that the integrity of the Supreme Court/High Court Division with its unlimited territorial jurisdiction has not been impaired the High Court Division has remained one as before and therefore the impugned amendment has to be construed in harmony with all other provisions of Chapter I. (Para 580).</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Anwar Hossain Chowdhuiy Vs. Bangla- r desh, 1989 BLD(Spl)1</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article — 142</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Clause (5) of the impugned Art. 100 has</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">been challenged on a number of grounds. One is that an essential legislative power, in this</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">case, the power of amendment of a constitutional provision, was delegatcd by the Parliament to the President to assign the area in relation to which each permanent Bench shall have jurisdiction. This power, it is contended, shall be exercised by the amending body, namely, the Parliament by following a special procedure and that clause (5) under which Parliament relinquished its power to the President is void. Learned Counsels for the appellants have cited a number of decisions in support of this contention. Of them decisions of the Privy Council in the two Canadian cases, “Attorney General of Nova Scotia (1951) SCR Canada 31, and the Initiative &amp; Referendum case, AIR 1919 PC 145:1919 AC 935—have been discussed in connection with the question as to implied limitation. In the former, the Canadian Legislature and the Nova Scotia (Provincial) Legislature proceeded to transfer their legislative powers to each other but the Privy Council ruled that such delegation of legislative powers was not permissible under the B.N.A. Act 1867. In the latter, a proposed Bill of the Legislature of Manitoba by which its legislative power was sought to be vested in a separate body was held invalid on the same ground. In Pakistan, the first case of such a nature is Sobho Gyan Chandani V. Crown PLD 1952 FC 29. In that case the Federal Legislature after promulgating the Public Safety Ordinance. 1949, delegated to the Government the power of extending its life year by year. This delegation of legislative power was held to be ultra vires and it was held that after the expiry of one year the Ordinance died its natural death. Similar views were taken by the Supreme Court in the case of F.Q. Chowdhury v. Abdul Huq, 18 DLR(SC)69 which has been discussed by me in an earlier paragraph. It appears that the essential legislative work under clause (5) is not the assignment of areas of jurisdiction for the Benches but what jurisdiction would he transfer to the Benches. This has been done by this clause and it has been provided that whatever jurisdiction, power and function the High Court Division got would be the power, function and jurisdiction of the Benches. This jurisdiction, power and function were given by the amending body itself and, the President was given authority to assign the area for each Bench the seat of which was also fixed by this body. Assignment of the area does not fall within the essential legislative power of the amending body. (Para-366) It is difficult to see how the principles enunciated in the aforesaid cases are applicable to the facts of the present case. It is well- settled that a legislature cannot part with its essential legislative function and invest another agency with the same but within the framework of the legislation it can entrust subordinate functions to other agencies. This will be clear from the quotation reproduced above from the judgment in the Initiative Referendum case. I have already found in connection with issue no III that sub-art. (5) neither limits the plenary jurisdiction of the High Court Division nor puts territorial limitation to the jurisdiction of the Judges sitting in the permanent Benches. I have also found that the assigning of area by the President read with Rule (4) of the Rules is meant only for regulating the manner of exercise of jurisdiction by the permanent Benches by allocation of cases arising from the respective assigned areas to the concerned Benches. The assigning of areas left to the Chief Executive is no part of the legislative function and it is only a ministerial act. It will be seen that similar power has been given to the Governor under Art. 198 of the 1973 Constitution of Pakistan for assigning the area in .relation to which each Benches shall exercise jurisdiction vested in the High Court. Sub-art. (5), therefore, cannot be said to be ultra vires. (Para 620)</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>An war Flossain Chowdhurv Vs. Banglade h, 1989 BLD(Spl)1</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article —142</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Learned Att. Gen. has referred to the “Limited Government and Judicial Review by Barua order to press his view that omission of details in the ‘long title’ of the impugned Bill did not create any confusion in the minds of the legislators, particularly when the subject was not a new one and that they got sufficient notice about the matter. He has refuted the argument that inclusion of other subjects in the Bill had misled the legislators. It appears that the long title of the Bill was closely followed by a detailed statement as to the subject-matter of the Bill specifically naming the Articles of the Constitution which were proposed to be amended and in which manner. There is hardly anything to indicate that members of the Parliament were in confusion or misled as to the nature and scope of the Bill. In the circumstances I am of theopinion that the mandatory requirement as to procedure was substantially fulfilled. (Para</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">359)</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Mr. Khandakar Mahbubuddin has contended that the Bangla word in the second line is to be read was ct for giving a correct meaning to the provision. The term tT has been used seven times in art. 142 meaning either ‘a’ or ‘any’. We cannot as-. cribe the meaning of ‘which’ to that word by adding a hasanta to its last letter without violating elementary principles of construction. (Para 411)</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The learned Attorney General without seriously disputing the procedural requirement for an amendment has submitted that the long title of the Bill contained clear indication as to the amendment of some provisions of the Constitution, and the omission of details in the long title of the Bill did not create any confusion in the minds of the legislature because the long title was immediately followed by clear statements as to the subject matters of the Bill and as to the articles of the Constitution that were proposed to be amended. Before us there is no affirmed statement, giving sufficient particulars, as to whether any member of the Parliament made any objection on the ground that he was confused because of the lack of details in the long title. Had the aggrieved person been a member of the Parliament then the matter would have al led for closer scrutiny. The purpose for the long title is to give a notice to the members of the Parliament and there is nothing on record m show that any member of the Parliament felt aggrieved or misled for the long title not being really a long one. Therefore, I reject the appellants’ objection as to the non compliance of procedural requirement in passing the impugned amendment.(Para 415)</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Since the provisions of art. 142 provide for a special procedure for amendment of the Constitution itself there can be no doubt that the conditions of law-making” as described</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">by the Privy Council in the Bribery Commissioners case must be strictly complied with. The provision as to the long title of the bill shows that it has to be expressly stated that it ‘ill amend a provision of the Constitution. Under art. 152(2) the General Clauses Act 1897 has been made applicable to the Constitution. (Para 608)</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It is, therefore, clear that words in the singular shall include the plural and vice- versa (s. 13 (2)). ‘A provision’ will mean provisions’ and the long title will not be bad if it provides for amendment of more than one provision. The argument that •the bill for amendment should be ‘a mono-provision’ bill has, therefore, no basis in the language of he relevant clause. Nor there is any basis fr the submission that the long title must mention expressly the articles sought to be amended. Neither the Bengali version nor the English version of clause (1) tothe proviso can be construed to mean that specific articles, are required to be mentioned in the long title. The learned Attorney-General has pointed out rightly that unlike the provision under art. 82(1) of the Ceylonese Constitution which requires the specific mention of the ‘provision’ to be amended in the long title of the bill, there is no such requirement in our provision. The requirement in our case only is that it must be mentioned in the long title that a provisions of the Constitution will be amended. In my opinion it will be sufficient compliance with law if it is expressly mentioned in the long title that a provision or certain provision of the Constitution will be amended. This reference to the Constitution in the long title of the bill will put the legislators on guard and they are expected to go through the bill to find out what are the provisions that are going to be amended under the bill. There can thus be no question of stealth or concealment in passing the amending Act. (Para 608)</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">On a reference to the bill, however, it is found that the purposes for the fulfillment of which the bill ‘vas brought have been stated at the bottom of the bill and reference has been made at the bottom of the bill and reference has been made in the long title itself to the said purposes. This has been done apparently in accordance with the ordinary practice and procedure of law-making, but clause (i) to the proviso in article 142 does not mandatory require that the subject or object of the law is to be expressed in the long title of the bill. (Para 612)</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It is no use multiplying such instances. It is clear that the draftsmen knew the purpose and distinction between the long title and short title. When the Constitution by prohibitive language issued a mandate it is not understood as to why such mandate was disobeyed. (Para 172)</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Anwar Hossain Chowdhury Vs. Bangladesh, 1989 BLD (Spl) 1</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article — 142</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In art. 142 there is no embargo as to inclusion of more than one object in a Bill for amendment. The private member’s amendment was clearly within the scope of the Bill, and it complied with rule 84(1) of the Rules of procedure of the Parliament. (Para 414)</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Since the provisions of art. 142 provide for a special procedure for amendment of the Constitution itself there can be no doubt that “the conditions of law-making” as described by the Privy Council in the Bribery Commissioners case must be strictly complied with. The provision as to the long title of the bill shows that it has to be expressly stated that it will amend a provision of the Constitution. Under art. 152(2) the General Clauses Act 1897 has been made applicable to the Constitution.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It is, therefore, clear that words in the singular shall include the plural and vice-versa (s. 13 (2)). ‘A provision’ will mean ‘provisions’ and the long title will not be bad if it provides for amendment of more than one provision. The argument that the bill for amendment should be ‘a mono-provision’ bill has, therefore, no basis in the language of the relevant clause. Nor there is any basis for the submission that the long title must mention expressly the articles sought to be amended. Neither the Bengali version nor the English version of clause (1) to the proviso can be construed to mean that specific articles are required to be mentioned in the long title. The learned Attorney-General has pointed our rightly that unlike the provision under alt 82(1) of the Ceylonese Constitution which requires the specific mention of the ‘provision’ to be amended in the long title of the bill, there is no such requirement in our provision. The requirement in our case only is that it must be mentioned in the long title that a provisions of the Constitution will be amended. In my opinion, it will be sufficient compliance with law if it is expressly mentioned in the long title that a provision certain provision of the Constitution will be amended. This reference to the Constitution in the long title of the bill will put the legislators on guard and they are expected to go through the bill to find out what are the provisions that are going to be amended under the bill. There can thus be no question of stealth or concealment in passing the amending Act.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Anwar Hossain Chowdhury Vs. Bangladesh, 1989 BLD (SpL)1</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article—147(2)</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Article is not necessary to pursue this poi further. The question is whether such deeming provision in sub-article (4) is violative Article 147(2) which says the remunerator. privileges and other terms and conditions services shall not be varied to the disadvantage of any such person during his term ofoffice. A service condition cannot be altered by a deeming provision. On the face of it, his provision is ultra vires, violative of Article 147(2). (Para 219)</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Anwar Hossain chowdhury Vs. Bangladesh, 1989 BLD (Spl.) 1</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article — 147</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The assessee is a Judge of the Supreme Court of Bangladesh. The salary income of the Judges of the Supreme Court is exempted from taxation by Presidents Order No. 21 of 1973 and it cannot be included for the purpose of taxation while computing total income. But the Deputy Commissioner of Taxes while asessing the income of the assessee by the misapplication of a notification (No. S.R.O.440/ L/76 dated 18.12.76 vide item No. iii) issued under section 60 of the Income Tax Act, 1922, erroneously included the salary income of the Judge while computing the total income. Such notification is included for other class of persons and can have no manner of application when it involves the question of assessment of the assessee who is a Judge of the Supreme Court of Bangladesh. For, the reason is that the Constitution came into force on the 16th December, 1972 and the President’s Order No.21 of 1973 was promulgated in pursuance of paragraph 3 of the Fourth Schedule to the Constitution read with Article 147 which settled the terms and conditions of service of the Judge’s of the Supreme Court. Accordingly, the terms and conditions of service of a Supreme Court Judge are sanctioned by constitutional provision and the P.O. 21 of 1973 having the backing of constitutional provision achieved the status of sub-constitutional legislation and such sub-constitutional legislation cannot be displaced by notification in exercise of the powers conferred by sub-section( I) of section 60 of the Income Tax Act (XI of 1922), which is a statutory law and no notification under such law controls the sub-constitutional legislation — Income Tax Act, 1922 (XI of 1922) S. 60.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>The Commissioner of Taxes Vs. Mr. Justice Shahabuddin Ahmed, 10BLD (AD) 245</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 171.T.R.1949(Bombay) 180; IR.C. Vs. Wolfson (1949)1 All. E.R. 865 (868) — Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article — 149 and Paragraph 10 of Fourth Schedule</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Former Central and Provincial service rules and the terms and conditions of service of the employees of former Central and Principal services continued in Bangladesh to the extent these have not been repealed, modified or altered after independence — Laws Continuance Enforcement Order, 1971.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">On perusal of Laws Continuance Enforcement Order, it would appear that former Central and Provincial rules relating to services and terms and conditions thereof continue to be applicable in the cases of concerned officers, to the extent that these have not been repealed, modified or altered after independence.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The terms and conditions of the petitioner’s service have been recognised, continued and protected by the Laws Continuance Enforcement Order as well as by Paragraph 10 of Fourth Schedule to the Constitution of Bangladesh subject to the condition that the said terms and conditions may be varied by law.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Until new rules are made by law the seniority of the officers of erstwhile services to be determined by the relevant Rules that were in force in Bangladesh on 25th March, 1971 and to the extent that these have not been replaced, modified or altered after independence.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Mohammad Faizullah Vs. Govt. of Bangladesh, 1BLD (HCD)l</em>Article — 149 and• Paragraph 10 of the Fourth Schedule</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Terms and conditions of service available to a Government servant before the commencement of the Constitution can be varied or revoked only by law.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The petitioner was not willing to accept non-practising post of Director and laid down two conditions for accepting the post, namely Professorship and the right of private practice. The Government ultimately appointed the petitioner as Director of the Institute on his terms. The terms of the petitioner’s service as were available to him before the amendment of the Constitution have been guaranteed under the First part of Paragraph 10 of the Constitution. Sub-para 2 provides that notwithstanding the guarantee laws can be passed varying or revoking the terms and conditions of service of a person. In the instant case the Government sought to vary the terms and conditions of service of the petitioner in a manner which is clearly not envisaged in the Constitution.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Dr. Nurul Islam Vs. Bangladesh and others, IBLD(HCD)12</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article — 149</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Privileges of Members of Parliament</strong> — Members of the National Assembly (Exemption from preventive detention and personal appearance) Ordinance (IX of 1963) was continued in Bangladesh and is at present an existing law. — Law Continuance Enforcement Order, 1971.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Suranjit Sengupata Vs. Election Tribunal, Syihet and another, 1BLD (HCD) 132</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article—150</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Article 150 of the Constitution does not protect any piece of legislation under paragraph 10(2)(b) from challenge regarding its constitutionality. What Article 150 protects are the provisions contained in the Fourth Schedule of the Constitution.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Dr. Nurul Islam Vs. Bangladesh and others, 1BLD(AD)140</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article — 152(1)</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">An employee of a Corporation set up by a Presidential order having the force of law is an employee under the State, particularly when the definitions of state and statutoty public authority given in Article 152(1) of the Constitution are read and considered together. The petitioner being an employee of a Corporation set up under the authority of P.O. No. 27 of 1972 is an employee under the State to be called a State employee as such.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Md. Hazrat Ali Vs. Chairman, Bangladesh Chemical Industries Corporation and another, I BLD(HCD)86</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article — 152(1)</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Statutory Public Authority</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Bangladesh Shilpa Bank—Its legal status — In our Constitution the expression ‘statutory public authority has been given a wide connotation defining it to mean any authority, corporation or body, the activities or principal activities of which are authority by an Act, Ordinance, Order or Instrument having the force of law in Bangladesh — Bangladesh Shilpa Bank is a ‘statutory public authority’ and by legal fiction it has been brought within the ambit of the expression ‘the state’.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Md. Anwar Ali Vs. The State, 9BLD(HCD)88</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Fourth Schedule, Paragraphs 3A and 18 — Proclamation of April 6, 1979 cI. (h)</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ouster of jurisdiction of Courts to examine proceedings and actions.of Martial Law Courts and Tribunals has not ceased to be operative upon lifting of Martial Law and revocation of Proclamations and Martial Law Regulations and Orders.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Kh. Ehteshamuddin Ahmed alias Iqbal Vs. Bangladesh and others, 1BLD (AD)107.</em></strong></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
1150	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">CONSTITUTION OF PAKISTAN, 1962</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  17 DLR 451, 3BLD (AD) 68, 4 BLD (AD) 113</p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  1962</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  CONSTITUTION </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p align="center" style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: center;"><strong><u>CONSTITUTION OF PAKISTAN, 1962</u></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Articles—6, 58 and 93</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Prior permission of the specified authority for registration of deed of transfer of immovable property by a member of minority community</strong>—Section 4 of the Disturbed Persons Rehabilitation Ordinance declared violative of Fundamental Right by the High Court—Supreme Court pending hearing of appeal stayed operation of the judgment of High Court—Deed of transfer registered without requisite permission during the period operation of the judgment of the High Court remained stayed—Whether the transfer in the absence of permission valid?—Disturbed Persons Rehabilitation Ordinance (1 of 1964)S.4.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">High Court Division held the transfer to be valid on the ground that sec. 4 &amp; 6 of Ordinance I of 1964 having been declared void in Chittaranjan Sutar’s case, the said provision not being in existence in the eye of law, the transfer in question never lost its legal validity on account of non-compliance of the requirement of sec. 4. The High Court Division further concurred with the finding of the trial Court that the plaintiffs failed to prove that defendants collusively created the impugned kabala. S. Ahmed, J upheld the decision of the High Court Division and F. Munim, J concurred with S. Ahmed, J. R. Islam, J held that the kabala was invalid for noncompliance of the requirement of section 4 and also held that the kabala was a product of conspiracy and fraud. B.H. Chowdhury, J did not render any opinion as to the necessity of complying with the provision of section 4, but held that the kabala was spurious.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Per R. Islam, J</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In view of the certificate granted by the Special Bench under Article 58 of the Constitution and the order of the Supreme Court staying operation of the judgment and order of the Special Bench, I find it difficult to appreciate the view taken by the learned Judges of the High Court Division that section 4 having been declared ultra vires of the Con- situation, the requirement of production of prior permission from the competent authority was no longer required, and in the absence of such requirement of law validity of the impugned kabala was not lost.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The finality of the judgment of the Special Bench in Chittaranjan Sutar’s case was subject to the decision in the appeal preferred by the Government of East Pakistan on the basis of the certificate granted by the Special Bench under Art. 58 of the Constitution. Beside that the operation of the judgment and order of the Special Bench having been stayed by the Supreme Court on July 3, 1965, the declaration made in the judgment became ineffective. Consequently sections 4 and 6 of the Ordinance continued to be operative.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Since section 4 as substituted by Ordinance X of 1964 was declared ultra vires of the Constitution it means that section 4 (new) never came into existence This state in the statute brings in another consequence, that is the provision of law which was repealed or substituted by the statutory provision declared ultra vires, automatically became revived.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">When an amendatory provision proves unconstitutional, the amended provision stands wholly unaffected. That being the position section 4 as obtaining in Ordinance I of 1964 before its substitution by Ordinance X of’ 1964 remained unaffected, as if section 4 (old) continued to he operative.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Whatever restrictions the section (sec. 4 old) imposed on the registration of transfer deeds by the members of the minority .community could not be termed unreasonable as contemplated in the Thirteenth Fundamental Right. Section 4 (original) is harmless, and there is nothing in the section to be in conflict with the Fundamental Rights. Section 4 (new) has been rightly found by the Special Bench to have no relation to the object of the legislation, that Ordinance I of 1964 as promulgated on 12.2.1964, and it was in excess of the object and the prevailing circumstances did not warrant the restriction.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Chittaranjan Sutar V. Secretary, Judicial Department, Government of East Pakistan, 17 DLR 451; Frost V. State Corporation commission, (1929) 278 Us 515, ref</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Per S. Ahmed, J</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The Ordinance was intended to provide speedy rehabilitation of persons affected by communal disturbance in January, 1964 and for the protection of their property during the disturbed period. But to impose a legal restriction on transfer of their property for an indefinite period extending over years cannot be said to be the object of the Ordinance. Since sections 2 and 5 of the Ordinance could provide adequate remedy to the members of the minority community affected by the civil disturbance of January, 1964 legal restrictions on transfer of their property as contemplated in sections 4 and 6 of the Ordinance are found to be inconsistent with Fundamental Rights 13 and 15 are void abinitio and as such these sections did not revive when the Fundamental Rights were suspended. Nor were these sections re-enacted during the period when the Emergency continued. The doctrine of eclipse is not applicable to Ordinance I of 1964.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Ful Chand Das and others Vs. Mohammad Hammad and others; 3BLD (AD) 68</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 17 DLR 451; (1929)278 U.S. 515; A.I.R. l963(SC)lOl9.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article—177</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Service matter—Meaning of the expression ‘Temporarily’—When an officer is elected from one service to another service by such expression as ‘appointed temporarily’ the idea of temporariness attaches to the appointment may be whittled down by any subsequent event or development—The temporariness or permanence of an appointment would not depend so much upon whether the appointment is intended to be permanent, though apparently made temporarily—If the cadre is temporary, the appointment would also be temporary but not so if the cadre continues to exist—The abolition of the cadre itself renders the decision in the case of Bangladesh Vs. Md. Ismail Hossain, reported in 31 DLR(AD) 127 in applicable to this case.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Saleh Ahmed Zoarder Vs. People’s Re public of Bangladesh; 4BLD (AD) 113</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 31 DLR(AD)127.</p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
1151	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">CONTEMPT OF COURT ACT, 1926</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  7BLD (HD) 315, 8 BLD (AD) 62, 1 BLD (HCD) 487, 3BLD (AD) 317, 3 BLD (HD) 298, 8 BLD (AD) 62, 8 BLD(HcD) 357, 8 BLD (HCD) 434, 9 BLD(HC’D) 298, 9BLD(HD)5, 10 BLD (HCD) 73, 12 BLD(AD) 150, I2BLD(AD)227, 12 BLD (HD) 54, 4BLD (AD) 237.      </p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  1926</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  CONTEMPT OF COURT</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p align="center" style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: center;"><strong> </strong></p><p align="center" style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: center;"><strong>CONTEMPT OF COURT ACT, 1926</strong></p><p align="center" style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: center;">(XII OF 1926)</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Sections—2 and 3</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Contempt of Court</strong>—Whether the respondents did commit any contempt of Court by not allowing the petitioner to resume his duties after the order of staS’—The petitioner was not functioning as the University Engineer when he obtained the order of stay was passed—He was out of office when he obtained the order of stay and therefore there was nothing to stay—In that view of the matter the respondents did not commit any contempt of Court by not allowing the petitioner to resume his duties.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Md. Mahtab Hossain Vs. Bangladesh University of Engineering and Technology, Dhaka and others, 7BLD (HD) 315</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—2</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Violation of stay order</strong>-Contempt when lies—Since the appeal from which the contempt petition has arisen has been dismissed, the petition has no legs to stand upon—As to the merit of the petition, at the time of admission of the appeal the appellant was satisfied by obtaining a short order of stay with respect to the High Court’s order—The effect of Court’s order on the orders passed by the High Court Division or on the respondents does not appear to be clear and leaves scope for wrong understanding—Having regard to the circum-stances, it would not be reasonable to entertain the application.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Charandwip Bhumihin Krishi Sainàbaya Samity Ltd., represented by the Chairman, Md. Abdus Sainad Vs.
