<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  7BLD (HCD) 315</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  ENGINEERING AND TECHNOLOGICAL UNIVERSITY EMPLOYEES</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p align="center" style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: center;"><strong><u>ENGINEERING AND TECHNOLOGICAL UNIVERSITY EMPLOYEES ORDINANCE</u></strong></p><p align="center" style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: center;"><strong>(XXX VI OF 1.61) SECOND STATUTES (EFFICIENCY AND DISCIPLINE)</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong><strong>Statutes — 6, 7 and 15</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Suspension</strong> — Whether an order of suspension can be passed against an employee of Bangladesh University of Engineering and Technology until and unless a formal charge- sheet under statute 7 is served upon the delinquent employee — From the language of clause (2) of statute 15 it cannot be said that the authority is precluded from passing an order of suspension unless and until a formal charge sheet under statute 7 is served upon a delinquent employee — Clause(2) of statute 15 applies when the “conduct of a delinquent employee is under investigation of a charge’ — — In the statutes care has been taken to describe a formal charge as a “charge sheet” — The stage to suspend a delinquent employee arises when the authority has taken a decision that the allegations, if established, would entail a penalty of dismissal or removal from service — The authority may arrive at that decision with or without making a preliminary investigation under clause(2) of statute (6) — But once the authority takes this decision, its power to suspend is attracted under clause(2) of statute 15 — This power is not dependent upon the framing and service of charge-sheet under statute 7.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Md. Mahtab Hossain Vs. Bangladesh University of Engineering and Technology, Dhaka and others; 7BLD (HCD) 315.</strong></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
1166	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">EVIDENCE ACT, 1872</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  5BLD (HCD) 303, 4BLD (HCD) 291, 9BLD (AD)135, 8BLD(AD)22, 6BLD (AD) 224, 4BLD (HCD) 183, 5BLD (AD) 102, 6BLD (HD) 25O, 3BLD (AD)334, 9BLD(AD)135, 4BLD (HCD)150, 7BLD(HCD,)235, 12BLD (HCD) 90, 7BLD (AD) 142, 11BLD (HCD)386, 12BLD (HCD) 277, 1BLD (AD) 86, </p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  1872</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  EVIDENCE</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p align="center" style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: center;"><strong><u>EVIDENCE ACT, 1872 (I OF 1872)</u></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—3</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Video Cassette</strong>—Video cassette whether is a document and whether the same is admissible in evidence — Video Cassette is a document within the meaning of the Evidence Act and is accordingly admissible in evidence if otherwise relevant in course of a trial or proceeding — when sound recorded on a tape is admissible in evidence, the record of sound and picture should equally be admissible in evidence.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Mrs. Khaleda Akhtar Vs. The State; 5BLD (HCD) 303</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. AIR. 1964 (SC) 72; AIR. 1968 (SC) 147; PLD l976 (SC) 57 (69) Cited,<strong>Section—8</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Non-payment of rent whether relevant</strong> —Non-payment of rent alone will not extinguish or disprove a tenancy but when it is a question of the very existence of the status of a tenant, payment of rent would be relevant as the subsequent of the parties concerned.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Sahabuddin Vs. Saluddin Talukder and others; 4BLD (HCD) 291</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—13</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Relevance of previous judgment</strong> — When a judgment, though not inter parties, may be admissible — Ordinarily a judgment cannot be used as evidence against a person who is a stranger thereto — But the judgment in a prior suit together with the plaint and other steps taken in connection therewith is evidence of an assertion by the holder of the judgment of the right which he claims to acquire and is then admissible in evidence of his right.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Hazi Waziullah alias Waziullah Miah and others Vs. The Additional Deputy Commissioner (Revenue), Noakhali and Assistant Custodian, Vested and Non-Resident Property and others; 9BLD (AD)135</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 21 DLR(SC)94; 2 C.W.N. 501; 58 Indian Appeals 125; A.I.R.1937(PC)69— Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—7</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Admission</strong>— Value of admission made in the plaint of a previous suit which was withdrawn — In our law of evidence an admission made by a party in a plaint is admissible as evidence against him in other actions as well but such admission cannot be regarded as conclusive proof and it is open to the party to show that it is untrue.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Abdul Kader Khan being dead his heirs All Akbar Khan and others Vs. Basek Khan being dead his heirs Shaju Bia and others; 8BLD(AD)22</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. A.I.R. 1967 (SC) 341; AiR. 1968 (Cal)550; (1952) 1 Macq 212: 8DLR3I I Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—20 </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Admission between the parties made in another proceeding</strong> — Such admission whether binds a party in a subsequent proceeding - Respondent’s admission that he was a tenant under the appellant estops him from denying appellant’s title in the suit premises — Admission by way of statements made in documents certified to be true copies by an authorised officer of the Government are admissible in evidence.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Hajee Abdus Sattar Vs. Mahiuddin and others; 6BLD (AD) 224</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—21</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Admissibility of previous statement</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A party’s previous statement regarding a fact in issue is relevant and can be used against him if he has not appeared in the witness box at all — Even if the party appearing in the witness box is not confronted with his contrary previous admission, his such previous admission, if duly proved is admissible.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Sultan Ahmed and others Vs. Mohammad Islam and others; 4BLD (HCD) 183</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: A.I.R. 1946 (Lah) 65 (PB); AIR. l957(AIl) 1(FB); AIR. 1966(SC)402 — Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—23 </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Admission made by a party in a letter written “without prejudice” — Admissibility of</strong> — The letter written by the appellant cannot be used to determine the extent of its liability, but in so far as it shows the relationship between the appellant and the respondent No. I as debtor and creditor and that they tried to settle the account, the letter can be taken into consideration.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>M/s. Haque Brothers (Carbide) Ltd. Vs. Bangladesh Shilpa Rin Sangstha and others; 5BLD (AD) 102</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. (1967) 72 C.W.N. 1 — Cited.<strong>Section—35</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Entry in School Register</strong> — Its admissibility in evidence — Entry in School Register, Admit Cards and Board’s Certificate is that such Registers, Cards and Certificates are public documents, and are admissible in evidence, but the evidentiary value to be attached to the entries will vary from case to case.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Abul Hashem (Bulbul) Vs. Mobarakuddin Mahmud; 6BLD (HD) 25O</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. I.L.R. 14 (Lahore) 473; A.I.R. 1965 (SC)282 — Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—43</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Findings of the Criminal Court are not binding on the Civil Courts</strong> — An order under section 145 Cr. P.C. cannot be treated as substantive evidence of possession — A judgment of acquittal in a criminal case only decides that the accused has not been found guilty of the offence with which he had been charged but the opinion and the conclusion expressed in the judgment are not admissible in evidence in civil Courts.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Akhtar Hossain Sharif and others Vs. Munshi Akkas Flossain and others; 3BLD (AD)334</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—43</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Relevance of previous judgment</strong> — When a judgment, though not inter parties, may be admissible — Ordinarily a judgment cannot be used as evidence against a person who is a stranger thereto — But the judgment in a prior suit together with the plaint-and other steps taken in connection there with is evidence of an assertion by the holder of the judgment of the right which he claims to acquire and is then admissible in evidence of his right.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Hazi Waziullah alias Waziullah Miah and others Vs. The Additional Deputy Commissioner (Revenue), Noakhali and Assistant Custodian, Vested and Non-Resident Property and others; 9BLD(AD)135</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref.2IDLR (SC) 94; 2 C.W.N 501; 58 Indian Appeals 125: A.I.R. 1937(PC)69 — Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—43</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Findings in the judgment of a criminal case</strong> — Whether can be relied upon in a subsequent civil suit between the parties — The findings and decision in a criminal case relating to the subject matter of the suit Scan n be relied upon — the fact that the accused was acquitted in a criminal case can be relied but not the opinion or conclusion expressed in such judgment.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Md. Arshad Ali Vs. Abed Ali and other, 4BLD (HCD)150</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—44</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Benamdar</strong> — Whether a decree against a benamdar is binding on the real owner — Whether real owner can agitate in another suit that the decree obtained against his benamdar was fraudulent and not binding on him — It is now a settled principle of law that a decree on the ostensible owner is binding on the real owner — The plaintiff obtained the decree against the benandar fraudulently knowing full well that the real owner defendant was in possession — When a decree is obtained by the plaintiff practicing fraud it is not necessary to file a separate suit for avoiding such decree but the said decree can be impugned in another suit by such person aggrieved by such fraudulent decree — The real owner can avoid the transfer by his benamdar provided that no reasonable care was taken by the transferee in getting the transfer from the Benamdar — Transfer of property Act (IV of 1882) S.41. -</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Sultan Ahmed Vs. Md. Waziullah and others; 7BLD(HCD,)235</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 24 DLR 63 — Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—44</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Plea of Fraud</strong>—Under section 44 of the Evidence Act, whether it is competent for a party to a suit or proceeding to show that a docunient or a decree proved against him was obtained by fraud without having it set aside.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Under section 44 of the Evidence Act it is competent for a party to a suit or other pro-ceeding to show in it that a document or a decree which has been proved against him by his adversary in that suit was obtained by fraud without having it set aside — When subsisting judgment, order or decree is set up by one party as a bar to the claim of the other, the latter can show that the judgment, order or decree was delivered by a Court without jurisdiction or was obtained by fraud, collusion and it is not necessary for him to have it previously set aside by a separate suit — A party to a proceeding is never disabled from showing that a document has been obtained by the adverse party by resorting to fraud.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Abdul Gani Khan Vs. Shamser Ali and others; 12BLD (HCD) 90</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—45</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Expert’s opinion — Value of</strong> — Opinion of an expert, such as a hand-writing expert, is only a relevant fact — The Court will certainly consider the expert’s opinion but it is the Court which alone will come to its own conclusion regarding the matter — An expert’s opinion, particularly that of a handwriting expert, is always received with great caution.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Ekias Khan and others Vs. Prajesh Chandra Das and others, 7BLD (AD) 142</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—45</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Assessment or evaluation of the evidence of hand writing expert</strong> — Requirements of law as to plaintiff’s obligation to prove his own case — Court to come to findings on assessment of the materials on record.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Evidence of an expert witness is of very weak nature</strong> — The evidence and the opinion of the expert deserves consideration like any other evidence but such evidence has to be received with great caution — In assessing or evaluating the evidence of a handwriting expert on the question of genuineness of a signature, the following facts must be kept in view : (1) very few people sign in the same manner on all occasions. (2) expert opinion of the genuineness of the signature should be received with great caution, especially in a case when there is positive evidence of persons who saw a person sign. (3) all the test evidence by the expert in the matter of comparison of hand writing and signature is merely tentative in character. (4) Opinion is weak evidence.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">(ii) Law requires that the plaintiff must prove his own case to the hilt by cogent and sufficient evidence—He cannot succeed merely on the weakness of the defence — Disbelief of the defence case ipso facto does not make the plaintiff’s case believable.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">(iii) The Court is required to come to a finding on assessment of the evidence on record that the plaintiff has been able to prove his case — The plaintiff must prove his case with sufficient evidence to obtain even an expaite decree in his favour.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Sheikh Salimuddin Vs. Ataur Raharnn and others; 11BLD (HCD)386</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 7 BLD (AD)142; IODLR(PC)l; 25 DLR(SC)90; 3 BLD(AD)225 — Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Sections—45, 47, 67 and 73</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Mode of proof of hand-writing or signature</strong>—It is well-known that the Evidence Act has provided for the following 4 modes for proving hand-writing or signature of a person in any document namely:</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">(1.) By proof of the signature or handwriting of the person alleged to have signed or written the document by evidence vide section 67 of the Evidence Act.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">(2.) By the opinion of an expert who can examine and compare the handwriting or signature in a scientific process vide section 45 as the Evidence Act.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">(3.) By a witness who is acquainted with the handwriting or signature of the person by whom the same is supposed to be written and signed, vide section 47 of the Evidence Act.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">(4.) Also by comparison of the signature or handwriting of the person with his other admitted and proved handwriting on signature by the Court it self vide section 73 of the Act.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In the instant case when it is the duty of the plaintiffs to prove the identity and genuineness of the signature of the petitioner in thealleged document, the plaintiffs may avail of any of the methods as enumerated above — He or they cannot be forced by the defendants to resort to any particular method of proving the alleged signature.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Shree Dulal Benerfee alias Moni Vs. Shree Sharat Chandra Pal and another; 12BLD (HCD) 277</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Sections—56, 78(6) and 85</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Power of attorney authentic in foreign city</strong>—Power of attorney executed and authenticated by a Magistrate or Notary Public in a foreign country—Whether could be acted upon as a valid document in Bangladesh.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">If a notarial act is done in a foreign country by a foreign notary and there is reciprocal arrangement between Bangladesh and that foreign country, then by reference to section 14 of Notaries Ordinance and section 33of the Registration Act, those Notarial acts will be valid and the power of attorney admissible in Bangladesh.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Nurunizessa and others Vs. Babar Ali Bepari and others; 1BLD (AD) 86</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—64</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Admissibility of newspaper report — Probative nature of such report</strong> — Although a newspaper is admissible in evidence without formal proof, yet the paper ipso facto is no proof of its contents — The newspaper cannot be treated as proof of the facts.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Nurul Islam and others Vs. The State, 7BLD (HCD) 193</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. A.I.R. 1925 (Lahore) 299: A.I.R. 1961 (Pun) 215; AIR. 1951(SC)1376 — Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—57</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Judicial Notice of a period of general dislocation</strong> — Momentous changes took place when Benches of the High Court Division were established outside the capital — the cases arising from Barisal were initially sent to the Jessore Bench and then after the establishment of the Barisal Bench, to Barisal — It was a period of general dislocation of which judicial notice should be taken.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Mvi. Md. Keramat Ali and another Vs. Syed Munsur Ali and others; 11BLDAD97</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Sections—64 and 65</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Best evidence</strong> — The rule of evidence is that the best evidence which the case in its nature is susceptible should always be given — Primary evidence is the best evidence as it is that kind of proof which in the eye of law affords the greatest certainty of facts in question — Unless it is shown that the production of this evidence is out of the party’s power, no other proof of fact is generally admitted — Overall testimony to prove shortage of stay and stationery is inadmissible in evidence when documentary evidence to prove the same was available and purposely withheld.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>S.K. Abdul Majid Vs. The State; 7BLD (HCD) 413</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Sections—65 and 66</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Admissibility of certified copy of an application —</strong> Original called for from the custody of the person granting the copy bi the original not produced — In view of clauses (a) (c) of sections 65 and 66 of the Evidence Act the certified copy of the application is admissible in evidence.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Indus Ali and others Vs. Abdul Jabbar Mia, 3BLD (HCD) 258</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—65</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Secondary evidence</strong> — Question of admissibility without formal proof — Though no objection was raised when the secondary evidence in the Photostat copy was produced, the party producing it was not exempt from explaining why its original was not produced</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">— If the original is not available, the reason for non-availability must be given.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Hazi Waziullah and others Vs. Additionial Deputy Commissionier, Noakhali and others; 9BLD (AD)135</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 20 DLR (SC)205; — Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—65</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Award in respect of a property — When cannot be considered</strong> — The original of the alleged award having not been filed in the Court the true copy of the alleged award cannot be considered.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Chan Jun Talukder and another Vs. Ching Neshazy Magni and others, 9BLD (HCD)10</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Sections—67 and 68</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Presumption of genuineness of a registered kabala</strong> — In the absence of proof of its due execution a registered kabala by itself does not raise any presumption of its genuineness.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Abdul Malek Sarkar Vs. Govt. of Bangladesh; 3BLD(HCD)1 70</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Sections—67 and 68</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Execution and attestation of a will</strong> — I-low is to be proved — Due execution of a will means not only that the testator executed it by putting his signature or affixing his mark but also it requires that the testator executed it in sound mind, fully knowing the nature and effect of his action — It must be proved that the testator had the testamentary capacity’ at the time he put his signature or thumb impression on the Will — The requirements of sections 67 and 68 of the Evidence Act must be fulfilled.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Paresh Chandra Bhowmik Vs. Hiralal Nath and another, 4BLD (AD) 199</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Sections—67 and 68</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Proof of execution of a document</strong> — Whether Registrar’s endorsement is conclusive proof of execution — The certificate of a Registrar although raises a presumption as to the admission of execution by the executant yet such admission cannot be the evidence of due execution against third persons — The execution of a document is required to be proved in the manner provided by sections 67 and 68 of the Evidence Act.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Abani Mohan Saha Vs. Assistant Custodian Vested Property and others; 7BLD (AD) 306</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—73</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Comparison of handwriting and signature by the Court</strong> — Court’s power to examine disputed signature is not restricted but the power should be exercised with great caution as an arbitrary exercise of the power may lead to miscarriage of justice Only in appropriate cases the Court may exercise its enabling power where the Court finds that the exercise of this power is necessary in the interest of justice.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Syed Nurul Flossain and another Vs. Salema Khatun &amp; another; 1BLD(HCD)474</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 10 DLR 129; 49 C.W.N. 481; 26 C.W.N. 113; 64 C.W.N. 1067—Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—73</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Comparison of handwriting by Court</strong>—Whether conclusion arrived at by comparison of hand writing or signature by the Courts below can be interfered with by the High Court Division in Second Appeal — Comparison of signature with admitted signature is a question of fact — High Court Division is not to interfere with the conclusion of the First Appellate Court on such question — Comparison of signature is a perfectly legal mode of proving hand-writing and, however inconclusive such proof may be, it cannot be considered as an error of law to base a conclusion on such proof alone — High Court in second appeal is not competent to set aside a finding based on such method — Code of Civil Procedure, l908(V of 1908) S. 100 (repealed).</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Abdul Matin Chowdhary Vs. Chapala Rani Sen and others; 5BLD (AD) 172</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—73</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Expert’s opinion</strong>—Whether it is better to have and come to a decision, particularly in case of L.T.L</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It is true that the Court itself can compare any signature or L.T.1. of any concerned person himself under section 73 of the Evidence Act and come to a decision, but it is better to have an expert’s opinion also, particularly in case of L.T.1.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Sk. Abul Qasem and others Vs. Mayez liddin Mondal and others; 12BLD (HD) 161</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 28 D.L.R. 123; A.I.R. 1928(P.C.)277 —Cited<strong>Section—74</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Comparison of signature or hand writing</strong> — Whether- Court should compare the disputed signature with the admitted signature to come to a decision — reliance by the lower appellate Court on his own comparison of the disputed signatures disregarding and in preference to the positive evidence by an expert is highly unsatisfactory, dangerous and imprudent in a judgment of reversal and such judgment without proper reasons results in an error in the decision on merits occasioning a failure of justice — Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 (V of 1908), S. 115.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>SK. Anseruddin and others Vs. Usha Raid Ghose; 6BLD (HCD) 26</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. A.I.R. I 928(PC)277; A.I.R. I 954(SC) 320; A.I.R. 1979 (SC) 14; 5BLD (AD) 172 —Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—74</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Whether plaint of a suit is a public document —</strong> Whether certified copy of the plaint is admissible in evidence — The plaint of a suit as soon as it is registered by a judicial officer within the meaning of clause (iii) of sub-section (1) of section 74 of the Evidence Act and as soon as it forms part of the record of the judicial officer it is a public document. Certified copy of such document is therefore admissible in evidence.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Reazuddin and another Vs. Azimuddin and others; 7BLD (HCD)16</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 19 DLR349; PLD I 967(Lahore) 1051; A.I.R. 1940 (Mad)768; 36 DLR(AD)248; 27 DLR 398: 29 DLR(SC)268; 92 IC. 184 — Cited. V</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—85</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Authentication of power of attorney</strong> — A power of attorney duly authenticated raises the presumption that it was duly executed by the donor who has signed the instrument — The presumption unless rebutted, stands and the document can be admitted in evidence as a document executed by the persons alleged to have executed it, without any further proof — The defendant having failed to rebut the presumption plaintiff’s case stands.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Md. Arshad Ali Vs. Abed Ali and others 4BLD(HCD)150</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 30 DLR(SC)99; A.I.R. 1930 (Afl 524: A.I.R. 1971 (SC) 76; 1971(I) S.C. A. 136 —Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—85</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Power of Attorney</strong> — Authentication of —Whether a power attorney, is to be authenticated for authorizing the attorney by a No-tary Public —- Whether a power of attorney duly executed and registered by the Si* Registrar can be used as a valid document Whether written statement filed by the attorney of the defendant on the strength of power of attorney duly executed by the defendant and registered by the Sub-Regisia can be accepted or the same is liable to b expunged — Section 85 of the Evidence raises a presumption as to the execution authentication of a power of attorney exec and authenticated by the executant and authority described in the section itself Although the power of attorney was authenticated by the Notary Public as request under section 85 of the Evidence Act the being duly executed and registered under provisions of the Registration Act is a document — Section 85 does not say the duly executed and a registered power of in Bangladesh is unacceptable and in document for reason of non-authentication Written statement filed by the attorney of defendant on the strength of such a attorney duly presented cannot be expunged</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Monindra Mohan Kar Vs. Ran Dutta and others. 7BLD (HCD) 275</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 33 DLR(AD) 124— Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Sections—91 and 92</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Evidence</strong> —Its admissibility in a preemption case — No evidence is admissible to vary the contents of the documents by any oral evidence — In a pre-emption case it is the transfer which is sought to be pre-empted.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Jaynal Abedin Molla Vs. Aliar Rahmax and others; 3BLD (AD) 105Sections—91 and 92</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Admissibility of oral evidence?</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>In a pre-emption case sale or exchange can be decided</strong> — Whether evidence can be adduced to prove that the document is not what it purports to be When the disputed Kabala is between stranger to the document in question and a party thereto, there is no bar in leading oral evidence to prove that the document in question is not what it purports to be but when it is between the parties to the document such evidence is not admissible — There is no error of law in holding that the transaction is an exchange and not a sale and as such exempted from preemption — State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950 (XXVIII of 1951), S. 96</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Brindaban Das and another Vs. Ershad A</em></strong><strong><em>li Mondal, 6BLD (HCD)85</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 17 DLR 15; 26 DLR(SC) 59; 35 DLR(AD)230; A.I.R. 1958 (SC)448 — Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Sections—91 and 92</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Admissibility of oral evidence</strong> — Whether a sale deed can be declared a mortgage deed solely on oral evidence — Oral or extraneous evidence to contradict the terms of the contents of a document is inadmissible — It is an established rule of evidence that oral evidence is inadmissible for the purpose either of construing the terms of a document or of ascertaining the intention of the parties thereto — Evidence of the witnesses that the document is not a sale deed but is a mortgage deed is clearly inadmissible.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Mrs. Feroza Majid and another Vs. Jiban Biina Corporation, represented by its Managing Director, 7BLD(AD)124</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 27 l.A. 58 — Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Sections—91 and 92</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Exclusion of oral evidence</strong>—Admission of oral evidence of the acts and conducts of the parties in determining the true nature of the transaction does not infringe upon the provision of section 92 of the Evidence Act — it can be shown by oral evidence that though a document in a particular form was executed, in fact it is different from what it appears to be — When a docuriient is meant merely as an informal memorandum of transaction and not as a document embodying disposition of a property, oral evidence is not excluded.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>A.M. Abul Kashim Vs. Nasiruddin Ahmed and others; 8BLD (HCD) 33</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 37 DLR 87 — Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—91</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Kabalas under pre-emption under section 96 of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act — recitals in documents are of out and out sale — no mention about any exchange or compromise.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Section 91 of the Evidence Act will not bar any challenge as to the character of the disputed documents — But for that reason, the kabalas in question cannot be construed as instruments of exchange, simply because the ownership of the case land was not transferred for the ownership of any other land — State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1951 (XX VIII of 1951), S. 96.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Abu Hassan (Minor) and others Vs. Basiruddin Ahmed and others; 11BLD (AD) 231, 12 BLD(AD)191</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—92</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Evidence</strong> — whether it is admissible to vary the terms of a written and registered document — Oral evidence though not admissible to vary, modify or alter the terms of a written registered document, will however be admissible to prove that the nature and character of the instrument is different from what it is alleged to be or that the instrument was a mere paper transaction that it was never intended to be given effect to or acted upon.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Mozem Par and others Vs. Fazie Karim Biswas and others; 4BLD (HCD) 173</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 19 DLRI7; 38 l.A. Page-85; (1924) 51 l.A. Page-305; 38 C.W.N. Page — 883; 20 C.W.N. Page-347; 16 DLR(SC)629; PLl968(Karachi) 307; A.LR. 1936 (PC) 61 — Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—101</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Onus of Proof — in a case of disputed parentage</strong> — The onus is not on the defendant to prove the factum of marriage — The onus was clearly upon the plaintiff to establish that there was no marriage when the defendant proved acknowledgement in his favour — All the Courts below in the facts of the case misplaced the onus on the defendant for proving the marriage of Monwar Begum with Amir Ali Mia whereas the settled principle of law is that the person who denies it will have to establish it — it was for the plaintiff to prove that there was no marriage with Manwara as alleged — As such the concurrent findings of fact is no finding in the eye of law.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Khorshed A lain alias Shah Alam Vs. Amir Sultan All Hyder and another 5BLD (AD) 121</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 3 M.I.A. 295; 8 M.I.A. 836 and 11 M.1.A, 94; 561.A. 201; 51 C,W.N. 98—Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Sections—101 and 102</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Onus</strong> — Onus on whom lies in a suit for specific performance of a contract for sale of property where the signatures in the documents regarding the contract are admitted by the defendants pleading that the same were obtained from them by threat, intimidation and coercion — Law does not require that all facts alleged by the plaintiff shall be strictly proved, for burden of proof is often lightened by presumptions, admissions and estoppels — Primarily onus, of course lies in a civil proceeding, upon the plaintiff — In this case primary onus has been discharged satisfactorily by the plaintiff — Then onus has shifted upon the defendants to prove their particular fact that their signatures were extorted — This onus they failed to prove — Consequently, the evidence adduced by the plaintiffs as to execution of the documents stands.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Jabed Ali Mondal and others Vs. Jamini Kanta Dey and others, 7BLD (AD) 156</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—101</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Onus to prove parentage</strong> — When oral evidence was inconclusive to decide the question of parentage whether the Court can decide the same on the basis of the documents showing dealings with the property — The onus was on the plaintiff to prove that his father Nagar was the son of Gour Majhi — In view of the inconclusive testimony of the witnesses as to parentage of the plaintiff, the appellate Court rightly dismissed the suit when the documentary evidence as to the ownership, use and mode of transfer of the impartibly property clearly indicated that the plaintiff had at no point of time raised any claim or had any possession in the suit property.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Sree Gopal Chandra Mondal and another Vs. Lasman Dasi and others; 7BLD (AD) 107</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—101</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Finding of fact</strong>—Finding of fact is ordinarily binding in a second appeal — Section 101 distinctly prohibits second appeal on a finding of fact based on legal evidence unless in the process of arriving at a finding of fact the Court has committed an error of law or a substantial error of procedure.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Abdul Gaizi Khan Vs. Shainser Ali and others; 12BLD (HCD)90</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Sections---101 and 102</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Burden of proof</strong> — The onus of proving the genuineness of the signature and the questioned document is on the plaintiff.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Shree Dulal Benergee alias Moni Vs. Shree Sha rat Chandra Pal and another. I2BLD (HCD) 277</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—102</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Onus of proof</strong> — Onus in a suit for his on whom declaring a heba-bil-ewaz deed in favour of the defendant was forged and without consideration.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Initial onus was upon the plaintiff — Plaintiff having discharged that onus it shifted on to the defendant to prove that there was the intention for making the heba-bil-ewaz and that the consideration was paid — the onus of proving the formalities in connection with thedeed is upon the person who upholds the transaction.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Montajur Rahman Vs. A.K.M. Mokbul Hossain and others; 5BLD (HCD) 18</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 9 DLR (1957) Page 422 — Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—102</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Burden of proof when special knowledge is involved</strong> — when the petitioner gives a list of dead persons and the opposite party does not controvert the same, the contents of the list are not proved — It is not the opposite party who maintains officially a list of dead voters — He does not have a special knowledge as to who are dead voters.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Abul Hashern (Bulbul,) Vs.Mobarak Uddin Mahmud, 6BLD(HCD)250</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Sections—102 and 103</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Burden of proof — When both parties adduced evidence in order to set up their respective cases, the question of onus loses significance.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Chinibash Pramanik Vs. Md. Nurul Hossain Mollah, 7BLD (AD) 103</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—102</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Onus Probandi</strong> — When onus is arbitrarily shifted and found not discharged — The plaintiff did not examine any independent witness in support of its case that the food supplied by the defendant’s canteen was not good — Trial Court arbitrarily shifted the onus on the defendant for proving its defence plea — The plaintiff therefore failed to bring its case home that he needed the tenanted premises for efficient management of the canteen — Premises Rent Control Ordinance, 1963 (XX of 1963), S. l8(l)(E).</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>M/s. Channel Cinema Ltd. Vs. Chowdhury Golain Malek; 10BLD (AD,)82</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—103</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Burden of proof</strong> — Onus of proof that the left-out co-sharer has no subsisting right of pre-emption is upon the pre-emptor — State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950(XXVIII of 1951), S. 96(2).</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Md. Abdul Jalil Vs. Durjan Ali alias Siddique Hossain and others, IBLD(’AD,) 241</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—111</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Burden of proof </strong>— Pardanashin Lady — Burden lies on the person who claims benefit under a deed executed by a pardanashin lady to establish that the deed was executed by the pardanashin lady after clearly understanding the nature of the transaction — The burden lies not only on the receipient of the deed, but also upon the transferee from the beneficiary.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Mst. Rokeya KhatunVs. Aljan alias Aljan Bepari and others; 2BLD(4D)139</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 52 l.A. 342; A.I.R. 1928 (PC) 303; A.I.R. 1940 (PC) 1,34 — Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—111</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Burden of proof</strong> — Pardanashin lady — Protection given to pardanashin lady by the special rule of onus will extend to her legal heir — If the person upon whom the property of the pardanashin woman devolves by operation of law, and who, in the facts of the case, represents her can challenge the legality of disposition.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Mst. Rokeya Khatun Vs. Aljan alias Alijan Bepari and others; 2BLD (AD) 139</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 33 DLR (AD) 1 — Cited. -</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—111</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Hiba-bil-Ewaj</strong>—Question of absurdity of the reason for Hiba-bil-Ewaj — Special rule on onus of proof devised to protect a pardanashin lady need not be understood to create disability in her right to deal with her property — When the final Court of fact is satisfied that the questioned document is beyond suspicion, no further examination of the document is called for.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Jahura Khatun and another Vs. Md. Nurul Momen and others; 2BLD (HCD) 165</em></strong>Ref. 70 C.L.J. 402: A.LR. 1940 (PC) 134: 45 C.W.N. 259; 82 C.L.J. 26; 59 C.W.N. 147; 6 DLR 202; 33 DLR (AD) 1; A.I.R. 1919 (PC) 24; — Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—111</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Pardanashin Lady</strong> — Discharge of special onus by the recipient of the document from a pardanashin lady — Without making any pleading that the executant was a pardanashin lady and she could not comprehend and understand the transaction there was no special onus upon the recipient of the kabala to prove that the document was a bonafide one and the executant understood and comprehended the transaction and that she had independent advice before she executed the kabala,</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Noad Chand Vs. Mst. Hjssain Banu and others; 6BLD (HCD) 173</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. A.I.R. 1956 (SC)593; A.LR. 1966</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">(SC) 635; 34 LA. 27: A.I.R. 1930(Sind) 25; 33DLR (AD) 1; 34 DLR(AD)266; A.I.R. 1930 (PC) 57; 28DLR(AD)57; A.I.R. 1920 (PC) 65 — Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—111</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Pardanashin and illeterate lady</strong> — Execution of deed by her — Onus on whom that she had independent and disinterested advice at the time of execution and registration of the sale deed — Mere reading over and explaining of the contents of the deed will not meet the requirement of law — Onus is on the vendee to prove that independent and disinterested advice in the matter was received by her — The party relying on a document executed by an illeterate pardanashin village woman must satisfy the Court that not only the deed was read over and explained to her but also to prove that she understood the contents and that she got independent and disinterested advice in the matter.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Rangbi Bewa Vs. Md. Abed Ali and others; 7BLD(HD)319</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 26 C.W.N. 517(DB).</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—1 14(e)</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Public Notice</strong> — Presumption of service of such notice — Public notice for acquisition of property being an official act a presumption is available under the Evidence Act that it has been regularly performed unless the contrary is proved — Emergency Requisition of Property Act (XIII of 1948), S. 5(1).</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Government of Bangladesh, represented</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>by the Deputy Commissioizer, Dhaka and others Vs. Basharatultah being dead his heirs and successors: Fade Karim and others; 1OBLD (AD)11O</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—114</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Presumption of Judicial or official</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Acts—</strong>Whether illustration (C) of the section provides that all acts are presumed to have been rightly and regularly done.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Illustration (C) of section 114 of the Evidence Act provides that all acts are presumed to have been rightly and regularly done — This presumption applies to judicial as well as to official acts — Where judicial or official act is shown to have been done, it is presumed to have been done rightly and regularly complying with the necessary requirements.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Md. Akhtar Hossain Vs. The Governinent of the People’s Republic of Bangladesh and others; I2BLD (HCD,) 541</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—114(e) (f)</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Service of notice u/s. 106 T.P. Act</strong> — Notice sent by registered post and returned with endorsement “refused” — Notice presumed to be served — Examination of peon to prove the endorsement is not necessary — Mere denial of the tenant that he did not receive the notice or that the notice was not tendered to him is not sufficient to rebut the presumption — General Clauses Act, 1 897 (X of 1897)</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Dr. Jainshed Bakht Vs. Md. Kainaluddin, 1BLD (HCD) 97</strong>Ref. A.I,R. 191 5(Cal)3 13; 39C.W.N. 934; 51C.W.N. 650; 52 C.W.N. 659; 6 DLR267; A.I.R. 1918 (PC) 102; A.I.R. 1958 (Cal) 251; 22 DLR 664; 17 DLR(WP)26—Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—114</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Reserved Forest</strong> — Whether in the absence of notification under the Assam Forest Regulation or Forest Act nature of the forest land under the Forest Department as ‘reserved forest’ is affected — Even assuming that the defendant Forest Department did not acquire any title in the suit land of the forest as no subsequent notification required under section 17 of the Assam Forest Regulation VII of</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">1 891 or under section 20 of the Forest Act, 1927 was issued, even in that case, the possession of the Forest Department in the lands of the notification Ext. A is not denied or disputed and the long possession of the Forest Department is a fact — So under section 114(e) and (f) of the Evidence Act there is presumption that notification under section 17 of the Assam Forest Regulation was duly made -— Forest Department has got title and possession in the suit land or at least a better title and prior possession than thoe of the plaintiff—Assam Forest Regulation (VII of 1891). S. 17.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Kanglu Khasia Vs. Divisional Forest Officer and others; 7BLD(HCD)96</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—1 15</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Estoppel</strong> — Plaintiff’s karsha right sold in auction — Defendants claiming kol-karsha right setting aside the auction sale under section 174(3) of B.T. Act impleading the plaintiff in the proceeding — Plaintiff is estopped from denying defendant’s kol-karsha.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Sunil Kumar Biswas Vs. Mohammad Idris and others, 1BLD (AD)367</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—115</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Estoppel</strong> — Series of litigation’s between the parties ultimately concluded by a compromise decree — Defendant gave up his claim of Tk, 1000/- as a consideration of compromise — Subsequent suit which in effect is directed against the compromise is hit by the principle of estoppel.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Abdul Mujib Chowdhury Vs. Syed Abdul Mutalib and others; 1BLD (HCD)467</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>No estoppel against Statute</strong> — Whether this rule of law can be invoked by one to takes advantage of his own fraud — The rule is attracted only when its invocation will defeat the public policy behind a Statute — If, in disregard of the obligation imposed by section 75A upon the landlord he has alienated his land he cannot subsequently raise an objection to nullify his own action — The plaintiff- appellant has filed the suit certaintly not for the benefit of the Government, nor is there any reason to suppose that the statutory provisions would be nullified if the declaration sought for is not granted — If he is allowed to succeed he would be enabled to take advantage of his own fraud.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Sree Sudhir Chandra Saha and another Vs. Matiran Bewa, being dead her heirs Nazmul Rahrnan Sarker and others; 6BLD (AD) 182</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. A.I.R. l937 (PC)1 14; (1903)30 l.A. 114; (l964)I6DLR(SC)685 —Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—115</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Right of Pre-emption</strong> — Whether barred by acquiescence and estoppel — When the pre-emptor negotiates the sale under pre-emption or the facts are such that his acquiescence can be safely concluded, the doctrine of estoppel comes into full play — His conduct will be a bar even though he files his application for pre-emption in a statutory right — State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950(XXVIII of 195 1),S.96.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Moulana Abdul Karim Vs. Nurfahan Begum and others; 6BLD (HCD) 125</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. A.I.R. 1968(SC) 933; PLD 196 l(SC)436(444); 22 DLR 449; A.I.R. 1947 (Oudh)81; A.I.R. 1951 (Nagpur) 451; AIR. 1950(Madhya Bharat)85; A.I.R. I 925( Lahore)57; A.I.R. 1928(P.C.)190— Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—115</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Resignation from service</strong> — Employee of Biman Bangladesh Air Lines resigning with immediate effect allowed to resume his duties — Whether the employer in such a position waived its right to continue the services of the employee — When a permanent employee, as in the present case resigns with immediate effect the employer is required neither to accept nor to reject the resignation — The question of acceptance or refusal of resignation arises only when the employee gives a notice of resignation — Since the petitioner resigned with immediate effect, he has only to surrender his pay in lieu of notice period — But by allowing the employee to resume his duties from 4.8.87 the employer literally waived its right to discontinue his service — It is as if the employee has not taken any notice of the letter of resignation and thus caused the employee to believe that he was still in service — the employer was therefore estopped by its conduct from saying that the employee was no longer in service — Bangladesh Biman Corporation Employees (Service) Regulations, 1979, Peg. 53.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>M.A. Mannan Vs. Biman Bangladesh Air Lines, 9BLD(HCD)516</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—115</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Promissory Estoppel — Principle of</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">When a party acts upon Government assurance, the latter is estopped from denying such position particularly when there is no formal contract executed between the parties and a right vests in him.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">There was acute shortage of sugar in the country and the government encouraged the importation of sugar under Wage Earner’s Scheme exempting so much of customs duty and sales tax leviable thereon as in excess of 50% and 10% respectively — The importer respondent imported sugar acting upon assurance of the Government — the subsequent notification dated 6. 11 .84 withdrawing confessional rate with retrospective effect can have no operation when a right has vested in the importer inasmuch as the respondent had acted upon assurance that the favourable terms mentioned in the notification dated 16.10.1984 will be applicable to him — He acted upon his assurance and now the Government cannot fall back upon it and say LriZ he will have to pay customs duty at the rate that prevailed on 16.11.1988, which reduced the exemption —- This is clearly a case of as the respondent had acted on the assurance given by the Government and a right vested in him could not be taken away.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>The Collector of Customs, Customs House, Chittagong and others Vs. Mr. A. .Hannan, 1OBLD(AD)216</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—115</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Estoppel — Bar of estoppel when not applicable — Once a candidate is declared Chairman by notification in the official Gazette he acquires a legal status and by his subsequent conduct, it cannot be said, he created an estoppel against statute itself.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Hazrat Ali Vs. Election Commission and others; 10BLD (HCD)157</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—115</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Estoppel-Under the Retirement Rules, 1968, the word ‘competent authority’ has been defined as the authority competent to make appointment of such service — From the definition, it is clear that the competent authority to make appointments in Barisal Pourashava is the executive head, namely the Chairman.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Since the appointment of the petitioners was made by the then Chairman of the Pourashava and since the petitioner joined their services on the basis of those appointment letters and rendered 12 years uninterrupted service their appointment cannot now be said to be made irregularly and, if any irregularity was there initially, it has been cured by lapse of time.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Kanaklata Halder and others Vs. Barisal Pourashava and another 10BLD (HCD) 381 Section—116</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Tenant’s estoppel</strong> — It is founded upon a contract — when a person enters into possession of immovable property as a tenant of another person then neither he nor any body claiming though him shall be permitted during continuance of the tenancy to deny the land-lord’s title however defective that title might be.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Hajee Abdus Sattar Vs. Mahiuddin and other. 6BLD (AD) 224</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 49 l.A. 299; A.LR. 1933 (PC)29 — Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—116</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Estoppel — Estoppel against a tenant</strong> — A tenant during his possession is estopped from denying that the landlord who let him into possession had no title at the time entry — The estoppel is however restricted to denial of the title at the commencement of the tenancy — It is open to the tenant even without surrendering possession to show that since the date of commencement of tenancy, the title of the landlord came to an end or that he has been evicted by the paramount title holder — The defendant is estopped from questioning or denying the exclusive title of the plaintiff landlord who let him into the possession of the suit property at the beginning Of the tenancy.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Fazal Kariin Vs.
