Mallick Brothers, 1BLD(AD)286</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 13 I.T.R. 285 — Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section — 34A</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Assessment of tax</strong> — Jurisdiction of reporting — Application of section 34A of Income Tax Act to assume jurisdiction and power under this section can be exercised only when assessment was erroneous and pre judical to the interest of revenue — There must be some materials for finding that the order of the Income Tax Officer was such — was mere observation to that effect is not sufficient to assume his jurisdiction.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Zebunnessa Vs. The Commissioner of Income Tax, Dhaka (North Zone), Dhaka, 3BLD (AD) 113</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 9 ITR 695 — 696(PC); 14 ITR (Born) 298; 20 ITR (1951)162; 831TR700—discussed.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section — 34(2A)</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Reopening of assessment</strong> — Notice of reopening assessment if can be issued after 8 years of assessment—Whether it is barred by limitation—Notice for reopening of an assesment can be issued at any time notwithstanding that at the time of issuance of such notice We period of 8 years had expired—Reassessment of tax upon such notice cannot be called in question on the ground of limitation.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>The Commissioner of Taxes Vs. M/s. M. Ismail and sons, 3BLD (AD) 273</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Section-41 and 66B</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Income Tax</strong> — Assessment of — Question of violability The assessee company exactly knew what was all about — Mistake, defect want of form shall not make the assessm void unless the assessee is prejudiced — The assessee could not make out a case of prejudice and therefore no objection could be taken to the assessment order.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Commissioner of Taxes, Chittagong Zone, Chittagong Vs. M/s. Metropolitan Tanneries Ltd; 4BLD (AD)310</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—6O</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Sa1ary of the Judges of Supreme Court</strong>—Salary income of the Judges of the Supreme Court is exempted from taxation by President’s Order 21 of 1973 and it cannot be included for the purpose of taxation while computing total income.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The assessee is a Judge of the Supreme Court of Bangladesh. The salary income of the Judges of Supreme Court is exempted from taxation by President’s Order No. 21 of 1973 and it cannot be included for the purpose of taxation while computing total income. But the Deputy Commissioner of Taxes while assessing the income of the assessee by the misapplication of a notification (SRO. Nq. 440/ L/176 dated 18.12.76 vide item No. iii) issued under section 60 of the Income Tax Act, 1922 erroneously included the salary income of the Judge while computing the total income. Such notification is included for other class of persons and can have no manner of application when it involves the question of assessment of the assessee who is a Judge of the Supreme Court of Bangladesh. The reason is that the Constitution came into force on the 16th December, 1972 and the President’s Order No.21 of 1973 was promulgated in pursuance of paragraph 3 of the Fourth Schedule of the Constitution read with Article 147 which settled the terms and conditions of ser ice t the Judges of the Supreme Court. Accordingly, the terms and conditions of service of a Supreme Court Judge were sanctioned by constitutional provision and the P.O. 21 of 1973b having the backing of constitutional provision achieved the status of sub—constitutional legislation and such constitutional legislation cannot he displaced by notification in exercise of the powers confirmed by sub-section (1) of Section 60 of the Income Tax Act which is a statutory law but no notification under such law controls the sub-constitutional legislation.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>The Commissioner of Taxes Vs. Mr. Justice Shahabuddin Ahmed, 10 BLD (AD) 145</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section — 66</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Income tax matter: Tribunals Jurisdiction</strong> .—In Income Tax matters it is for the Tribunal to decide questions of fact, and in a reference -under section 66 of the Act, the High (‘ourt Division, not constituted as a Court of appeal. exercises an advisory jurisdiction only and lays down the law in the facts found by the Tribunal. Where the High Court finds that there is no evidence to support the finding of fact of the Tribunal, or finding of the Tribunal is so unreasonable or perverse that no person acting judicially and properly instructed as to the relevant law could have arrived at it, then in such circumstances, there would arise a question of law which can be agitated before the High Court Division. The question of the applicability of a section of the Act to a particular set of facts or its construction is always a question of law.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Mackinon Mackenzie and Company (Pakistan) Ltd. Vs. Commissioner of Taxes, Chittagong (South) Zone, Chittagong, 12 BLD(AD)51</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section — 66(1)</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Absence of Party in reference-its effect</strong>—If the party at whose instance the reference is made fails to appear at the hearing, it is no duty of the Court suo motu to decide the questions and delkver the judgment. Since the preliminary condition of the sub-section is not satisfied in such a case, the consequent obliratIon of deciding the questions of law dcliv- of criig a judgment does not also arise.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>M/s. Dhaka Steel Works Ltd. Vs. The Commissioner of Taxes, Dhaka (North Zone), Dhaka, 12BLD(HCD)334</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section — 66(7)</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Stay realisation of tax</strong>—Where there is no specific conferment of power to stay realisation of tax till decision of the questions of law referred to the High Court Division, it, in its advisory jurisdiction, in a proper case, can order stay of realisation of tax in order to prevent injustice. In a proper case, it can order stay of realistion of tax in order to prevent the reference from being rendered nugatory’ in the event of its final success.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Meghna Petroleum Ltd. Vs. The commissioner of Taxes, (East Zone), Presently Taxes Zone —3, Dhaka, 12BLD (HCD)634</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 98 I.T.R. 39; 29 I.T.R. 222; 71 I.T.R. (SC) 815—Cited.</p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
1177	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">INCOME TAX ORDINANCE, 1984</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  6 BLD (HCD) 385, 12BLD (HCD)581</p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  1984</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  INCOME TAX</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>INCOME TAX ORDINANCE, 1984 (XXX VI of 1984)</u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Sections—83 and 153</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Whether writ lies against the order of assessment of income tax</strong>—Whether an appeal or writ shall lie against an order of assessment of income tax passed by a competent officer?—When a Deputy Commissioner of Taxes passes an order of assessment with jurisdiction under section 83(2) of the Income Tax Ordinance, 1984 all questions of fact and law relating to the said assessment call only be agitated by way of an statutory appeal and not by way of a writ petition under Article 102 of the Constitution.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Dr. M.B. Rahman Vs. Deputy Commissioner of Taxes, Taxes Circle—IV, Dhaka (South), Dhaka, 6 BLD (HCD) 385</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 28 DLR 381: Writ Petition No. 262 1978 (Unreported); -- Cited.<strong>INCOME TAX ORDINANCE, 1989</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section — 158(3)(5)</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Deputy Commissioner of Taxes is not entitled to prefer file appeal</strong>—Deputy Commissioner of Taxes is not entitled to prefer an appeal against the order of the Appellate Joint Commissioner unless he is directed to file the appeal by the Commissioner of Taxes to whom the Appellate Joint Commissioner is bound to communicate its order on appeal.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Time runs for filing appeal before the Taxes Appellate Tribunal not from the date of communication of the order of A.J.C.J. to the D.CT. but from the date of communication of the order of AZCT to the Commissioner.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>The Commissioner of Taxes, Dhaka (North) Vs. M/S. M.A. Hossain and ço, Dhaka, 12BLD (HCD)581.</em></strong></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
1178	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS ORDINANCE, 1969</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  1BLD (AD) 21, 11BLD (HCD)367, 12BLD(HCD)71, 11BLD (AD) 326, 1BLD (AD)59, 8BLD (HCD) 52, 8BLD(HCD)125, 10BLD (HCD) 61, 1IBLD(HCD)141, 12BLD (AD) 72, 2BLD(AD) 1, 1BLD (HD)175, 5BLD (AD)193, 6BLD (HCD)378, 8 BLD(HD)1, 8BLD(HD)236, 10 BLD (HCD) 440, 12BLD(AD</p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  1969</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS ORDINANCE, 1969 (XXII of 1969)</u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Sections —2 (XXVIII), 34 and 43</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Worker dismissal not in connection with industrial dispute</strong>—A dismissed worker, whose dismissal is not in connection with or in consequence of, or has not led to, an industrial dispute, cannot come within the purview of section 34 of the Industrial Relations Ordinance (I.R.O.).</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>James Finlay and Co. Ltd. Vs. Chairman, Second Labour Court, Dacca and another, 1BLD (AD) 21</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 28 DLRI6O; 30 DLR (SC) 252; 28 DLR 178; 13 DLR (SC)280—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section — 3(c)</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Freedom of Trade Unions</strong>—.--Under section 3(c) of the Ordinance trade unions and employees’ associations shall have the right to draw up their constitutions and rules to, elect their representatives in full freedom to organise their administration and activities and to formulate their programmers.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Karnaphuli Paper Mills Sramik Karmachan Union Vs. Registrars of Trade Unions and others, 11BLD (HCD)367</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section-.7—A(1)(b)</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Group of establishments</strong>—the expression ‘group of establishments in clause (1) of sub-section (1) of section 7 — A if the Ordinance refers to the group o establishments owned by different, separate and independent owners and not by the same owner in which case the workers of such group of establishments will be disqualified for being members of one registered union but the three halls in the present case being owned by the different, separate and independent owners, namely the petitioners the workers thereof cannot be considered to be workers of one group of establishments and they cannot, therefore, form one registered union.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Naogaon Chitrabani Ltd. and others Vs. Naogaon Cinema Hall Sramajibi Union and another, 12BLD(HCD)71</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section — 10(1)(e)(i)</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Power of Registrar of Trade Union to cancel registration</strong>-—-Under section 10(1)(e)(i) of the Ordinance, the Registrar of a Trade Union may cancel the registration of a trade union if the trade union has made in its constitution any provision which is inconsistent with the Ordinance or the Rules and if the trade union has contravened any provision of the Ordinance or the Rules.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Naogaon Chitrabani Ltd. and ors. Vs. Naogaon Cinema Hall Sramajibi Union and another, 12BLD (HCD) 71</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section — 10(3)</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Matter pending before Registrar of Trade Union</strong>—Since the Registrar of Trade Unions has to apply to the Labour Court under section 10(3) of the Ordinance and the employers have furnished some materials to that effect the matter is at least pending with the Registrar of Trade Unions.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>United Commercial Bank Karmachari Union Vs. S.M. Shafiul Azam and others, 11BLD (AD) 326</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section —34</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Enforcement of right</strong>—Section 34 of the Ordinance is not meant for establishment of any right but it provides for enforcement of any existing right guaranteed or secured by law, award or settlement.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Chairman, Power Development Board and others Vs. Chairman, Labour Court, Khulna Division and another, 1BLD (AD)59</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Sections — 34, 36 and 43</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Labour Court’s Power</strong>—Whether it can grant temporary injunction—Labour Court has no power of the civil Court which empowers the Labour Court, while adjudicating dispute, to grant temporary injunction—Temporary injunction can only be granted in a suit and by a civil Court by following the procedure of the Code of Civil Procedure—The power and procedure being absent with the Labour Court while adjudicating individual disputes, and not industrial disputes there is no scope for a Labour Court to grant temporary injunction.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Chairman, Chittagong Port Authority Vs. Kalipada Dey and others, 8BLD (HCD) 52</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section — 34</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Jurisdiction of Labour Court</strong>—Jurisdiction with regard to an employee of the Railway Board — The respondent’s petition before the Labour Court relates to terms and conditions of his service — In view of the falt that Administrative Tribunal had exclusive jurisdiction in the matter, the Labour Court had no jurisdiction to entertain the application.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>The General Manager (West), Bangladesh Railway and another Vs. The Chairman, Labour Court, Rajshahi and another, 8BLD(HCD)125</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section — 34</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Enforcement of service benefits</strong> — Question of applicability of memorandums giving benefits to freedom fighter Govt. servants to The case of the employees of a Limited Company — The memorandums were mere executive orders giving excreta benefits — They were passed in exercise of inherent discretionary powers and they have no force of law — The petitioner company being a Public Limited Company cannot be said to be bound by the memorandums as they cannot be enforced as instructions issued under any statutory law or rules framed there under.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>M/s. Bangladesh Can Company Ld. is. Chairman, Labour Court, Chittagong and others, 10BLD (HCD) 61</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 31 DLR 58; 40 DLR 520 — relied upon.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section —34</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Labour Courts Power</strong>—In the absence any cogent evidence to establish that the aforesaid posts are of different and separate scales and the Labour Court having found that it was not proved, instead of rejecting the prayer and leaving the matter undecided and still allowing the application without any direction on that point, acted illegally and without jurisdiction in giving the benefit allowing all the applications.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Kohinoor Battery Manufacturers Ltd. and others Vs. The Chairman, Second Labour Court and another 1IBLD(HCD)141</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Sections — 34, 36(2)</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Labour Court: Civil Court for Limited purpose</strong>—An adjudication on an industrial dispute under section 36(2) or a proceeding on an application under section 34 of the Ordinance for enforcement of any guaranteed or secured right, though a matter of civil nature, is not a suit and does not attract all the panoply of powers of the Code of Civil Procedure. In adjudicating or determining an industrial dispute, the Labour Court acts as a civil Court for limited purpose and it will not exercise the powers like those given in Order IX or Order XXXIX, rule I of the Code of Civil Procedure, which the civil Court may exercise in a suit, but are in no sense necessary for deciding an industrial dispute.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Pubali Bank Vs. The Chairman, First Labour Court, Dhaka and another, 12BLD (AD) 72</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 19 DLR(HCD)612; 29 DLR (HCD) 148; 33 DLR (HCD) 376; 29 DLR(HCD)ll; 27 DLR(HCD)367; 28 DLR(HCD) 369; 39 DLR(HCD)39; PLD 1973 Karachi 383; PLD 1973 Karachil89; PLD1975(SC)32: 105 A.C. 369: PLD 1971 (SC) 243; 30 DLR (SC) 251; AJ.R. I 973(SC) 1016: 39DLR(AD)59— Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section — 35(2)(7)</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Labour Court</strong> — Failure of the Chairman to consult one member. who did not attend the sitting of the Court, does not render the decision of the Court invalid.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>General Manager, Jamuna Oil Company Ltd. Vs. Golap Rahinan and another, 2BLD(AD) 1</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 27 DLR 158; 26 DLR(SC) 33; 31 DLR 124-Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section —36</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Labour Court</strong> — Exparte order — Application for setting aside an exparte order under Order IX of the Code of Civil Procedure is maintainable.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Executive Director, Raj Textile Mills Ltd. Vs. Chairman, Labour Court, Khulna and another, 1BLD (HD)175</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section — 36</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Whether appeal lies against an order of conviction and sentence passed by the Labour Court under section 56 of the I.R.O</strong>. — Whether jurisdiction of the High Court Division to entertain an appeal under section 36 of the Ordinance has been ousted by Martial Law Order No. 19 of 1982 — An appeal lies to the High Court Division against conviction and sentence passed by the Labour Court as it deemed to be a Court of Sessions. for the purpose of appeal from all sentences — When offences are tried the Labour Court acts as a Magistrate 1st Class but when punishment is given and sentence is recorded by it then for the purpose of appeal it shall be deemed to be a Court of Sessions—All appeals from a Court of Sessions lie to the High Court Division— MLO 19 of 1982 dealt with the decision not with award or sentence—So jurisdiction of the High Court Division to entertain an appeal against sentence passed by the Labout Court is not ousted—Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898 (V of l898),S. 410—Martial Law Order No. 19 of 1982 (MLO 19 of 1982).</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Maqbul Hossain and others Vs. Bangladesh Milk Producers Co-operative Union Ltd. 5BLD (AD)193</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: A.I.R. 1949 (FC)I —Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section — 36(1)</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Labour Court</strong>—Whether the Labour Court constituted under Industrial Relations Ordinance.l969 as amended, has power to grant interim or temporary orders of stay or injunction to keep the status quo of the subject matter of the dispute till its final disposal — The industrial dispute referred to in section 36(I) must be referable to the definition ofthe word as given in section 2(XIII) of the I.R.O. which includes all disputes as have been contemplated in the LR.O.—It would therefore be reasonable to hold that the Labour Court constituted under the I.R.O. shall be deemed to be a civil Court and shall take the same power as are vested in such Court under the Code of Civil Procedure — When a Labour Court ,is deemed to be a civil Court and has the same powers as are vested in the civil Court it must have power to grant injunction or stay to preserve the subject-matter of the dispute untjl it is fiiially decided—These powers to pass ternporary or ad-interim order are designed to preserve and protect the subject matter of the dispute under Order 39 Rule I of C.P.C. pending final determination of the case.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Pubali Bank Ltd. Vs. The Chairman, First Labour Court, Dhaka and another, 6BLD (HCD)378 -</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 29 DLR (HCD)148; 30 DLR(HCD) 141; 19 DLR(Dhaka) 612; 33 DLR 376; II DLR(SC) 140— Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section —36</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Exparte hearing</strong>—When permissible—The law does hot contemplate an exparte hearing because the defendant fails to file a written statement—If the defendant fails to file a written statement the Court shall fix the case for hearing in default of written statement — On the date so fixed the defendantcan still appear and argue his case without the written statement — The defendant retains the right to appear on the date of hearing and participate in the trial — If the defendant is precluded from participating at the .trial then the trial itself is without ‘jurisdiction’ because Law does not contemplate an exparte hearing when the defendant fails to file a written statement — Late realisation of adjournment cost cannot be a ground for shutting the door of justice on the face of the petitioner.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>M/s. Adamjee Jute Mills Ltd. Vs. Chairman, 3rd Labour Court, Dhaka and another, 8 BLD(HD)1: 8BLD(HD)236</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 33 DLR 376; 19 DLR 12; PLD 1964 (SC) 97: A.I.R. 1938(Bom) 470; 29 DLR 148: —Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section — 36</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Labour Court: procedure</strong>—Procedure to be followed by the Labour Court while deciding individual dispute — In the absence of any procedure being provided the Labour Court is left with its discretion to follow the procedure which it finds expedient for maintaining and securing rules of natural justice. A Labour Court is to decide an application submitted by an individual worker judicially and not arbitrarily and may follow its own procedure on the principle of natural justice.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Chairman, chittagong Port Authority Vs. Kalipada Dey and ors, 8BLD(HCD) 52</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Rf: PLD l972(Lahore) 603 —Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section — 36</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Ex-parte order by Labour Court</strong> — Jurisdiction to set aside such order — In view of the conflicting decisions as to applicability of the provisions under the Code of Civil Procedure for setting aside exparte order, the ratio decided of the case reported in 29 DLR 148 is followed and it is decided that the Labour Court does not have jurisdiction to set aside exparte order under the Code.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>M/s. Adainjee Jute Mills Ltd. Vs. The Chairman 3rd Labour court, Dhaka and another, 8BLD (HCD)236: 8BLD(HCD) I</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 33 DLR 376; 19 DLR 612: 29 DLR148:--Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Sections — 36(3) and 64</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Labour Court: Jurisdiction to by offence</strong>—Under the provision of section 363k I of the Ordinance the Labour Court has be vested with the power of the Magistrate Ig Class for the purpose of trying an offence under the Ordinance.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Under the provision of section 64 of the Ordinance the Labour Court and the Magistrate 1st class having jurisdiction in the matte shall have concurrent jurisdiction to try m offence punishable under the said Ordinance.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Kamaluddin chowdhury Vs. Masiuddawllah and another, 10 BLD (HCD) 440</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 5 BLD (AD) 278: -- Not applicable.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section — 36(2)</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Labour Court-Power of Injunction</strong>— An order of stay in the nature of an in junction under Order XXX1X Rule I of the Code of Civil Procedure or under sections 52 and 53 of the Specific Relief Act, as available in a suit, is not so available in any proceeding before the Labour Court, despite the provisior of sub-section (2) of section 36 of the I.R.ft under which it is deemed as a civil Court.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Pubali Bank Vs. The chairman, Fire Labour Court, Dhaka and another, 12BLD(AD)72</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 19 DLR (HCD) 612: 29 1)LR(HCD</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">148: 33 DLR (HCI))376: 29 DLR(HCL))II; 27 DLR (HCD) 367; 28 DLR (HCD) 369: 39 DLR (HCD) 39; PLD 1973 (Karachi) 3 - PLD 1973 (Karachi) 189; PLD 1975 (SC) 3_; 105A.C.369; PLD 197 1(SC)243; 30 DLR(SC) 251; AIR. 1973 (SC) 1016; 39 DLR (AD) 59—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section — 47B</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Transfer of a trade union leader</strong> — Plea of protection by a person in the service of a statutory public authority — Provisions of I.R.O. empowering Labour Court to give protection to a trade union leader against his harassment by transfer are not applicable to those leaders who are working in statutory public authorities like the H.B.F.C. — The basic status of the appellant (trade union leader) is that he is a worker of the Corporation and transferability or non-transferability of his service is a condition of his employment and the matter clearly comes within the purview f the Administrative Tribunal which has the lull power to give complete relief to an applicant and then the right of a trade union leader in such a case must yield to the supervening provision of the Constitution — Administrative Tribunal Act, 1980 (VII of 1981), S. 4 — Constitution of Bangladesh, 1972, Article — 117(2).</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Abdul Mannan Talukder Vs. Bangladesh House Building Finance Corporation and another, 10BLD (AD)71</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 1968(1) All.E.R. 433 (439 — 440); (1948) 1 K.B. 721; 33 DLR (AD)305 — Cited.</p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
1179	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">INSURANCE CORPORATION ACT, 1973</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  1 BLD (AD) 191</p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  1973</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  INSURANCE CORPORATION</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>INSURANCE CORPORATION ACT, 1973 (VI of 1973)</u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Sections—14 and 15</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Service matter—Insurance Company nationalized</strong>—Contracts of the Company kept alive—Employees of the Company absorbed in the service of the Corporation—Corporation not exercising option given by law—Employees of the Company continue to be employees of the Corporation.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The service of the appellant continued in Surma Jiban Bima Corporation and the fact of continuity of service gets further confirmation from payment of his salary by the said Corporation. V</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">As with the transfer of the entire undertakings of the Eastern Federal Insurance Company, all the contracts and agreements entered by the said company subsisted which include the contract of service that the appel-. taut had with the company, similarly, with the transfer of the entire undertaking of the same Corporation and absorption of the services of its officers and employees in the respondent— Corporation, the appellant’s service must also be held to have been similarly absorbed in it. There is no indication in any of the provisions contained in the Act that the contract of service was put an end to.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>M.A. Qasem Vs. Jiban Bima Corporation and another, 1 BLD (AD) 191</em></strong></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
1180	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">INTERMEDIATE AND SECONDARY EDUCATION ORDINANCE, 1961</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  4 BL D(HCD)309, 12BLD (HCD)79</p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  1961</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  INTERMEDIATE AND SECONDARY EDUCATION</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>INTERMEDIATE AND SECONDARY EDUCATION ORDINANCE, 1961 (XXXIII of 1961)</u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—30</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Removal from Service of a teacher of a secondary school</strong>—Whether can be removed without drawing up a proceeding against him?— The law contemplates a proceeding for removal of a teacher and if there is a proceeding, it needs be initiated and conducted in accordance with the provisions of law, namely that in the proceeding drawn against him, he must be given a reasonable opportunity of controvert the allegations made against him and be allowed to lead evidence in support of his case and if that is not done, the proceeding would be coram non jaundice.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Sardar Ahmed Ali Vs. G.M. All Baksha and others, 4 BL D(HCD)309</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—39(2)</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Boards power</strong>—The Board has power to make any regulation for the purpose of carrying into effect the provisions of the Ordinance generally though some particular subjects are enumerated in section 39(2), which are not exhaustive. Moreover section 39(2)(ii) empowers the Board to frame regulations for granting and withholding of certificates.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Although no regulations for withdrawing certificate, in particular, has been framed, the Board is not powerless if unfair means is found to have been adopted and it is detected after the result is published and the certificate is granted as the law has given it the power to do so.The Board is the sole authority to maintain and preserve discipline to hold examination properly and to take action in accordance with the relevant Ordinance and the concurred Regulations after holding enquiry where necessary. Such proceeding is domestic and administrative one and is not judicial or quasi-judicial proceeding and as such the Code of Civil Procedure or the Evidence Act has no application thereto and the Enquiry Committee is under no obligation to allow the student concerned to cross-examine any witness.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It is sufficient if the student is given opportunity of being heard and to explain his case against the allegation on which the proposed punishment is based.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Kazi Nafiul Majid Vs. The Secretary and Higher Secondary Education Board, Jessore and others, 12BLD (HCD)79</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: A.I.R. 1961 (All) 301; A.I.R. 1948 (Jammu and Kashmir) 40—Cited.</p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
