1192	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">MULLA’S MAHOMEDAN LAW</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  5 BLD (AD) 121</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  MULLA’S MAHOMEDAN LAW</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><em> </em><u><span style="text-decoration: none;"> <br/> </span></u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>MULLA’S MAHOMEDAN LAW</u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Sections—342 to 344</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Legitimacy of a child</strong>—Whether acknowledgement by father without proof of any valid marriage between the father and mother of such child is sufficient to establish legitimacy?— Where paternity of a child is unknown, the law presumes him to be the child of the acknowledger—But acknowledgment will not establish legitimacy if it is found that the child is an offspring of Zina or of another person—If the defendant failed to prove the marriage of his mother that will not create an impediment to the acknowledgment itself—Since the’ plaintiff did not take up the plea that the marriage could not have been possible, it being within the prohibitory degree or offspring of Zina—The force of logic therefore upholds the contention of the defendant for the doctrine of acknowledgement to dome into play—Defendant proved acknowledgment by the father—The plaintiff failed to establish that there was no marriage between the father and mother of the defendant—Therefore acknowledgement is sufficient to establish paternity of the defendant. [Majority per B.H. Chowdhury, J (Munim, CJ and Masud, J, concurring]</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Valid marriage between the parents is the essential precondition of legitimacy—If such a marriage is disproved, no amount of acknowledgement shall make the child legitimate it must be borne in mind that acknowledgement’ in Mohammadan Law is no substitute for adoption in Hindu Law or Roman Law—under the Mohammadan Law relationship by consanguinity is prerequisite for legitimacy and the latter is dependent upon’ a valid marriage of the parents—If Amir Au had acknowledged the defendant as his son, then he knew better who was defendant’s mother but that woman not being any of his three wives, the defendant is not his legitimate son——The learned Single Judge is found to have rightly refused interference with the findings of the Court below which stand on a solid basis..</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Khorshed Alam alias Shah Alam Vs. Amir Sultan Ali Hyder and another, 5 BLD (AD) 121</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 10 I, L.R Allahabad 289; 48 l.A. 114: 43 I.A.212; 56 l.A. 201; 1IM.I.A. 94 8 l.A.; 136— Cited.</p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
1193	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">MUNICIPAL ADMINISTRATION OR DINANCE, 1960</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  1BLD (AD) 470, </p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  1960</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  MUNICIPAL ADMINISTRATION OR DINANCE</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u><br/> </u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>MUNICIPAL ADMINISTRATION OR DINANCE, 1960</u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>(IX OF 1960)</u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Definition of Tax</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Definition of Tax as given in Municipal Administration Ordinance, 1960—The definition may he taken into consideration to interprete the statute when its language is ambiguous to find out the legislative intent. In this statute the language is clear enough to show what is tax and what is rate.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Dacca Municipal Corporation Vs. Sonali Bank and others, 1BLD (AD) 470</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—3(1 )(42)</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Power of Municipality to levy taxes and rates</strong>—Municipal Committee may levy all or any taxes or rates—If tax included rate separate methods of levying taxes and rates would not have been prescribed.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Dacca Municipal Corporation Vs. Sonali Batik and others, 1BLD (AD) 470</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section-3(1)(42)</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Building Tax</strong>—Building Tax does not in- elude lighting rate, conservancy rate or any other rate.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Dacca Municipal Corporation Vs. Sonali Bank and others, 1 BLD (AD) 47O</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—36</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Writ Petition</strong>—Writ Petition at the instance of a Municipal Committee against the decision of its Controlling Authority is not maintainable4Vhen the Municipal Administration Ordinance says that the Municipal Committee must obey the direction of the Government and that direction is given by the Controlling Authority, which has not been given by law, tantamount to disregarding the very provisions of law and it would amount to usurpation of power by way of writ petition.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Dacca Municipal Corporation Vs. Sonali Bank and others, 1 BLD (AD) 47O</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>MUNICIPAL COMMITTEE (APPEAL) RULES, 1960</u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Rule—8(4)</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Writ Petition</strong>—Writ Petition at the instance of the Municipal Committee against the decision of its Controlling Authority is not maintainable—When the Municipal Administration Ordinance says that the Municipal Committee must obey the direction of the Government and that direction is given by the Controlling Authority, any attempt for nullifying the decision of the Controlling Authority tantamount to disregarding the very provisions of law and it would amount to usurpation on power by way of writ petition.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Dacca Municipal Corporation Vs. Sonali Bank and others, 1 BLD (AD) 47O</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>MUNICIPAL COMMITTEE (TAXATION) RULES, 1960</u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Rules—22 and 42</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Power of the Municipality to levy taxes and rates</strong>—Municipal Committee may levy all or any taxes or rates—If tax included rate, separate methods of levying taxes and rates would not have been prescribed.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Dacca Municipal Corporation Vs. 1195	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">MUSSALMAN WAKF VALIDATING ACT, 1913</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  4 BLD (HCD) 240, 2BLD (AD)164</p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  1913</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  MUSSALMAN WAKF VALIDATING</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>MUSSALMAN WAKF VALIDATING ACT, 1913 (VI of 1913)</u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section-2</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Public Waqf—Creation of</strong>—Whether mention of the word cheragi for mosque in the deed of gift and khatian means creating of a valid wakf—The recitals in the deed of heba created absolute transfers to the donees with an obligation to maintain the mosque—it did not create any dedication of the properties in rahelillah—The recitals however indicate that out of the income of the tank, maintenance of the mosque was to be made by the donees— There has been no dedication of the properties creating any wafk—Although there is no dedication of the tank in Rahelillah’ since a portion of the income of the tank is to be applied for maintenance of the mosque, an obligation has been created upon the donees to maintain the mosque—In view of the evidence that the musallis had been using the tank for ablution for a long time, they have acquired a right of easement to use the water of the tank for ablution.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Jangli Bibi Mosque Wakf Estate, represented by Mutwally Zakir Hossain Vs. Abdur Rashid and others, 2BLD (AD)164</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 14 DLR 745 and 14 DLR 163 distinguished.</p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>

Rupashi Garments and others; 11BLD (HCD) 65</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—118</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Claim for recovery of money by Bank</strong>—Claim for recovery of money by a Banking Company whether can be decreed in the absence of any evidence as to actual payment of the amount—In view of the fact that title deeds were deposited with the bank along with all other usual documents, executed by the predecessor of the defendant Company .ind regular entries in the ledger and clean :ash book of the Bank in respect of the loan, the claim is established—There is also admission of the Managing Director of the defendant Company as to the liability to the Bank—Moreover there is presumption under he Negotiable instruments Act, Bankers Books of Evidence Act and Banking Companies Ordinance.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Planters (Bangladesh) Ltd. Vs. Mahaluxmi Bank Limited and others 5BLD(AD)150.</p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
1198	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">NON-AGRICULTURAL TENANCY ACT, 1949</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  6BLD(AD)330, 4BLD (AD) 162, 1BLD (HCD) 34, 3BLD(AD)45, 1BLD (HCD) 423, 3 BLD (AD) 303, 4 BLD (AD) 320, 5BLD (HCD) 277, 6 BLD(HCD)46, 6BLD (AD) 297 </p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  1949</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  NON-AGRICULTURAL TENANCY</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>NON-AGRICULTURAL TENANCY ACT, 1949 (XXIII OF 1949)</u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section — 2(4)</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Whether “Tilla Ban” or elevated homestead Is non-agricultural land</strong>— Whether a holder of a contiguous land can preempt the same—Whether a particular land is non-agricultural land is to be determined with reference to the user thereof and if it is held on lease with reference to the purpose of the said lease—it is to be determined upon evidence and there is no material on record to hold the same a non-agricultural land— There seems to be no reason at all for holding that the case land is non-agricultural land— The wide definition of land is capable of taking in even a Tilla Ban (elevated homestead land) unless it can be shown that it is non-agricultural land—State Acquisition and Tenancy Act (xxxviii of 1951) Ss.2( 16) &amp;96.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Sayeda Khatun and another Versus Abdur Rahman and others. 6BLD(AD)330</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Sections — 2(5) and 7</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>‘Non-agricultural Tenant’</strong>‘—Meaning of such a tenant—Non-agricultural tenant does not include any person who holds any land on which any premises occupied by such person are situated, if such premises have been erected or are owned by the person to whom such occupier is liable to pay rent for such occupation—Mere using of his own materials’ does not make the tenant owner of the land as well as of the structures—The landlords gave permission for using these materials on condition that the tenant would remove his materials whenever the landlords require the land—When land was not leased out but premises thereupon was leased out— Continuous occupation of the premises for over 12 years by the tenant did not bring him within the category of ‘Non-agricultural tenant’ and as such protection under section 7 was not available to him.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Md. Tabibur Rahman Mollah Vs. Md. Sayidur Rahman Being Dead his heirs and legal representatives. 4BLD (AD) 162</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section — 23(1)</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Oral gift of non-agricultural land by a Muslim is valid not with sanding subsequent execution and registration of a deed of gift. The provision of 23 of the Nonagricultural Tenancy Act prohibiting transfer of nonagricultural tenancy without a registered document shall not apply to gifts of immovable property by a Muslim. A valid gift of immovable property with building and structures inter vivos can be made under the Muslim Law by oral gift. According to Muslim Law an oral gift is complete as soon as the declaration of gift and the delivery of possession is given by the donor to the donee. When these essential conditions are complied with, the gift becomes perfectly valid and if a written deed is executed afterwards and registered, the oral gift would be valid notwithstanding the latter instrument of gift.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Alhaj Aklima Khatun and another Vs. Shah Alam and another. 1BLD (HCD) 34</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 1968 SCMR34I: 2IDLR (SC)l34, AIR 1949 Mad 307; 49 IA 195; referred.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section —23</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Oral gift</strong>— Whether it attracts the provisions of Section 23 of the Non-Agricultural Tenancy Act—If the property was nonagricultural tenancy it would be hit by section 23 of the Non-Agricultural Tenancy Act— The provisions of Non-Agricultural Tenancy Act do not apply as the suit properly was not non-agricultural land held by a nonagricultural tenant—Section 23 of the Non Agricultural Tenancy Act (XXIII of 1949) is not attracted to oral gift of non-agricultural land held by a tenant directly under the Government long before the coming into force of the said Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Shah Alam and another Vs. Alhaj Ak- jima Khatun and another. 3BLD(AD)45</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">[The judgment reported in 1BLD (HCD) 34 has been affirmed by the above judgment i.e 3BLD (AD) 45]</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section —24</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Pre-emption</strong>-Right of pre-emption accrues as soon as transfer is made—Subsequent transfer is subject to that right—Original transfer without an agreement for recon -veyance—The fact that the subsequent transferee is the original transferor, who continued to be a co-sharer after the original transfer of no consequence.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Shafi Khan Vs. Mannujan Hossain aa others. 1BLD (HCD) 423</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 5OCWN 806, 50 CWN 841 <strong>29DLRI 64 29DLR 229—Cited.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—24</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Pre-emption</strong>-Whether the right of emption is available when the land sought 1 be pre-empted has already been recovery a the vendor—The main question for exemption will be whether he actually got back land—If the answer is the affirmative. The position will be as if no transfer was at made by him—If it is found that the resale mere paper transaction then the resale may ignored and preemption may be allowed.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Shafi Khan Vs. Mannujan Hussain others, 3 BLD (AD) 303</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref 12 DLR 849; 53 CWN 678; 57 253; 13 DLR 287; 58 CWN 1000; 50 C 806; 50 CWN 807; 19 DLR 677; 29 D9 164; 29 DLR 229; 18 DLR 317—-Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">[The judgment reported in 1 BLD (HC 423 has been reversed by. the above judge i.e., 3BLD (AD) 303]</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section —24</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Pre-emption</strong>—Co-Sharer’s right when ceases—A co-sharer seeking preempting must have a subsisting interest in the holding at the time when he files an application f pre-emption.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Sunil Krishna Banik and others Kailash Chandra Saha and others. 4 BLD (AD) 320</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 33 DLR (AD) 505—-Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section —24</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Pre-emption</strong>—-Whether a person in pos-session of land in part performance of a contract is a co-sharer entitling him to pre-empt the sale-— The pre-emptor having been in possession as part performance of contract for sale can be deemed to be a co-sharer for the purpose of pre-emption.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Abid Ali Vs. Maleka Khatun and others. 5BLD (HCD) 277</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 35 DLR (AD) 230; PLD 1971 (Bagdul Jadid ) 42 ; BLD 1967 (SC) 411—- Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section —24</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Separation of jama</strong>—Question of right pre-emption-—-The separation of jama in favour of opposite party No.1 having been .reated subsequent to the impugned transfer, the separation in favour of the opposite party No.1 cannot Affect the petitioners right to re-emption.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Abid Ali Vs. Maleka Khatun and others. 5BLD (HCD) 277</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section —24</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Pre-emption</strong>—-question of pre-emption after reconveyance—-The case land has been retransferred to the vendor in pursuance of civil Court’s decree and the vendor is in possessions of the case land—-This being the position there is nothing left with the transferee which can be pre-empted—-The Court can look into the question of re-sale of the property if it is found that the re-sale of the property is a colorable show up or a mere paper transaction and the right, title and possession of the property have not gone back to the vendor—It can then ignore the re-sale and allow the pre-emption case.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Satindra Nath Mistry and others Vs. Baziur Rahman Sarker and others, 6 BLD(HCD)46</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 29 DLR164; 35 DLR(AD)225— Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—85</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Tenancy right under Government</strong>— Whether after the acquisition of rent receiving interest a leasee under the Municipality has become a tenant under the. Government— Whether he can be evicted from the land by the Municipality—Whether Municipality is a local authority—Whether the land belonging to the Municipality is exempt from acquisition—Local authority is understood to mean an authority entrusted with the administration of a local fund— The Municipality is a local authority—The property had vested in the Municipality which is not a rent receiver and therefore exempt from acquisition of the property—The defendant did not acquire tenancy right under the Government—Defendant also did not acquire tenancy right under the Non-Agricultural Tenancy Act since land belonging to the Municipality is exempt from its provisions.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Narendra Basu Roy and another Vs. Municipal Committee, Mymensingh. 6BLD (AD) 297</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: I 7DLR (SC)74—Cited.</p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
1199	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">PAKISTAN (CONTROL OF ENTRY) ACT, 1952</h2>

1201	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">PARTITION ACT, 1898</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  2BLL (HCD) 203</p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  1898</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  PARTITION</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong> </strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>PARTITION ACT, 1898</u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong>(IV OF 1898)</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—4(1)</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Partition</strong>—Partition of dwelling house an undivided family—A member of such L. divided family has right to purchase share of stranger—A previous alienation will not ( entitle a co-sharer from purchasing the est of the stranger—There is no waiver of right to file an application.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Prassana Kumar Shil and others Vs. jo gendra handra Shil and others. 2BLL (HCD) 203</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: Civil Appeal No.24 of 1980 (unrI ported)—Cited.</p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
1202	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">  PARTNERSHIP ACT, 1932 </h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  9BLD (AD) 118, 2BLD (HCD) 181, 12 BLD (AD) 186, 8 BLD (HCD) 509, SBLD (AD)24, 10BLD (AD) 132, 10 BLD (AD) 231, 3BLD (AD) 164, 5BLD (AD) 85   </p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  1932</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  PARTNERSHIP  </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>PARTNERSHIP ACT, 1932 </u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>(IX OF 1932)</u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—6</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Criminal breach of trust</strong>—Defence p of partnership against the offence—In determining whether a person is or is not a partner regard shall be had to the real relation between the parties as shown by all receive facts taken together—With regard to transaction that gave rise to the case the complainant used the terms howlas’ in his cot plaint and the word jimma in his depositia which clearly connote entrustment—It is not the case of the prosecution or of the defenc ethat the profits of the sale in question would be distributed between them—The -prosecution case of entrustment was fully proved</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Mohammad Musa Vs. Kabir Ahmed and another, 9BLD (AD) 118</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 36DLR (AD) 14—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—14</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Retention of excess lands</strong>—Applicative for such retention can be made by rent—r-1 cleavers, cultivating raiyats or under—raiyats—Subsequent partners though may claim interest in the property of the firm are not entitled to claim retention of excess lands— They cannot continue with any suit challenging the refusal to grant permission to ret1 excess land held by original partners who were rent—receivers.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>M/s. Farmers and co. Vs. Sree Monotosh Bera and another, 2BLD (HCD) 181</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Sections—14, 46 and 69(2) read with section 4s of the Transfer of Property Act, 1882—</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Property of the firm</strong>—Section 14 is in the nature of an inclusive definition. It does not properly define the expression ‘the property of the firm’.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In paragraph 2 section 14 a legal fiction has been created. Though property acquired with money belonging to the firm may not have been acquired for the firm, yet, by a legal fiction, the said property is “deemed to have been acquired for the firm, unless the contrary intention appears.”</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The legal fiction creates only a rebuttable presumption. Even when the purchase money is money belonging to the firm, that fact itself is not decisive.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Whether the disputed property is or is not a partnership property. Would depend upon the intention of the partners as the second paragraph of section 14 specifically lays down,. Evidence is admissible to show that a contrary intention governed the transaction.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The contrary intention may justifiably be gathered from (a) the purpose for which the property was acquired; and (b) the mode in which it has been dealt with. These two considerations, it appears, are germane to the determination of contrary intention.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">When the suit properties are net partnership properties, the bar of section 69(2) of the Partnership Act is not attracted.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Where properties were acquired by them jointly for their own benefit and not for the benefit of the partnership and therefore, under section 14 of the Partnership Act read with Section 45 of the Transfer of Property Act, the properties in suit were not partnership properties.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Mahbubul Alam chowdhury and others Vs. Chaman Ara Begum and others, 12 BLD (AD) 186</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Sections—16(b), 22 and 23</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Election dispute</strong>—Nature of the proceeding —Whether right title and interest of other persons, unconnected with the election dispute, can be settled by an Election Tribunal—It cannot be decided in an election petition whether a partner obtained some work for his personal benefit or as a partner representing his partnership firm—It is very much a matter between the Partners themselves and the Upazila Parishad concerned that issued the work order—There are matters between Partners and certainly the Election Tribunal or the appellate Court is not the forum for determination of such question in the absence of the partners—Local Government (Upazila Pan- shad and Upazila Administration Reorganisation) Ordinance (Ordinance LIX of 1982) S.6(2)(f).</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Mafizur Rahman Manju Vs. Md. Mahmudun Nabi and others, 8 BLD (HCD) 509.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: PLD 1967 Dhaka 35; PLD 1957(SC) (Pak) 301— Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—19</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Partner’s authority</strong>—-A partner may sue or be sued in the name of the firm—But such authority does not empower him to compromise or withdraw a suit or proceedings or relinqhish claim or admit liability against the firm.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>M/S. Farmers and co. Vs. Sree Monotosh Bera and another, 2BLD (HCD) 181</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Sections—31 to 55</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Retirement of a partner</strong>—It is a different concept from dissolution of the firm—The consequences flowing from each are entirely different—In the case of retirement of a partner, it is only the partner who goes out of the firm and the remaining partners continue to carry on the business—In the latter case the firm as such no more exists and the dissolution is between all the partners of the firm.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Liu Ying Ping Vs. Leon Fang Al, SBLD (AD)24</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Sections—32(3) and 72</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Retiring partner</strong>—Continuation of his liability—A retiring partner continues to be liable for any subsequent act of any other partners as his retirement is not effective unless and until other partners agree to discharge him of possible liability and a public notice is given under provisions of the law.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Md. Mahmudun Nabi Vs. Mafizur Rahman Manju and others, 10BLD (AD) 132</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: PLD 1983(Kar.)431; AIR 1963(AP) 154—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">[The judgment reported in 8BLD (HCD) 509 has been reversed by this judgment i.e.]10 BLD(AD)132j</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Sections—32(3) and 72</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Liability of a retiring partner</strong>—Under Section 32(3) read with section72 of the partnership Act, retiring partner continues to be liable for any subsequent act of any other partners which would bind the firm until the public notice as prescribed by section 72 is given.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Thus assuring that it was a partnership firm and the respondent No.1 had severed his connection still his liability to the Upazila Parishad continues. This point is now well- settled that the retirement of the partner is not effective unless and until other partners agree to discharge him of possible liability and a public notice is given under section 72.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Liability of a partner—Where the creditors are not notified of dissolution any ackriowledgement made and by ex-partner shall be binding on the Firm and its partners.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Md. Mahinudun Nabi Vs. Mafizur Rahman Manju and others, 10 BLD (AD) 231.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—43</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Dissolution of Partnership</strong>—In case of partnership-at-will it is dissolved by notice— Filing of a plaint by a partner is enough to put a and to the partnership.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Mujibur Rahman Sikder Vs. Mahbubur Rahman Sikder and others. 3BLD (AD) 164</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—69</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Amendment of the plaint by substituting original prayer</strong>—Amendment of the plaint by substituting the original prayer for declaration of share and accounts of an unregistered firm, by dissolution and accounts, whether maintainable—Whether such amendment will change the nature and character of the suit—The proposed amendment was necessary for avoiding multiplicity of proceedings and complete adjudication of the disputes between the parties on determination of the real question in controversy—The suit was originally for declaration of shares and accounts — By amending the prayer the plaintiff now also seeks dissolution of the firm—It is difficult to understand why the prayer for dissolution cannot proceed in combination with the original prayer in the plaint—If a partner of an unregistered firm can maintain a suit for dissolution and accounts, his prayer for declaration of his share may as well be tried prior to dissolving the firm—Whatever bar was imposed by the provisions of sub-section (1) and (2) of section 69 of the Partnership Act cannot stand in the way of combining the prayers—The prayer for amendment is allowed.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Radha Krishna Jogani (Agarwalla) Vs. Dwarka Das Agarwalla and others, 5BLD (AD) 85</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 63 CWN 766; (1833) ILR 20 Cal. 805; AIR 1922 PC 249: ILR 48 Cal. 832: AIR 1933 Rangoon 247; (1977) 29DLR SC 311; I5DLR (SC)l20; I979BSCR 135; 11 MIA 468—Cited.</p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>

<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  6BLD (AD) 66, 4BLD (HCD) 179 </p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  1911</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  PATENTS AND DESIGNS </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p style="margin-left: -.25in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p align="center" style="margin-top: 0in; margin-right: -.2in; margin-left: -.25in; text-align: center;"><strong><u>PATENTS AND DESIGNS ACT, 1911 (II OF 1911)</u></strong></p><p style="margin-left: -.25in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-left: -.25in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Sections — 43, 47, 51A and 53</strong></p><p style="margin-left: -.25in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-left: -.25in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Copy right</strong> — Piracy of designs and their protection — A copy right in a design registered under the Act can be protected by an order of injunction against any other person who is found to infringe upon such copy right</p><p style="margin-left: -.25in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">— As long as the register of designs is not rectified or registration is not cancelled by following the procedure in the Act an ordinary Court has no other alternative than enforcing. the copy right.</p><p style="margin-left: -.25in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Md. Abdul Latif Vs. Md. Harunur Rashid, 6BLD (AD) 66</strong></p><p style="margin-left: -.25in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">[The decision reported in 4BLD (HCD) 179 is affirmed by the Appellate Division by this judgment.]</p><p style="margin-left: -.25in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-left: -.25in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Sections — 47 and 53</strong></p><p style="margin-left: -.25in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-left: -.25in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Copy right in design</strong> — Right of such registered proprietor of a design — A registered proprietor of a design shall have the right in the design during five years from the date of registration and it is unlawful for any person during the existence of copy right in any design to make any obvious imitation thereof — As long as registration is not cancelled he is entitled to safeguard his copy right by injunction against one who initiates his registered design.</p><p style="margin-left: -.25in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Md. Abdul Latif Vs. Md. Harunur Rashid, 4BLD (HCD) 179.</strong></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
1204	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">PORT RULES, 1966</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  2BLD (AD) 83</p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  1966</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  PORT </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>PORT RULES, 1966</u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Rule—80</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Appointment of stevedores and handling contractors of inland ports</strong>—B IWTA as conservator of such ports can appoint stevedores and handling contractors and grant licence to them—Holding of public auction for such appointment is not prohibited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The whole object of Rule 80 is to enable the Conservator of Ports to appoint stevedores and handling contractors and to regulate their activity within the port area by appropriate terms and conditions. The method of appointment by advertisement in the daily newspapers to hold public auction for selecting the highest bidder at such auction for appointment has been laid down in circulars and these are provided in the circulars in detail. Reading the provisions Of Rule 80 as a whole, we nowhere find the prohibition to hold public auction for the purpose of selecting stevedores and handling contractors.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Bangladesh Inland Water Transport Authority Vs. Bangladesh 1. W. T.A. Ghat Sramik Union and another, 2BLD (AD) 83.</em></strong></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>

IV</u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article—31 1</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Termination of Employee</strong>—If the Government has by contract, express or implied, or under the rules, the right to terminate the employment at any time, then such termination in the manner provided by the contract or the rules is prima facie and per se, not a punishment and as such it does not attract the provisions of Article 311 of the Post and Telegraphs Manual, Volume IV.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Bangladesh Vs. <div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  10BLD (AD) 21</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  POURASHAVA ELECTION</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>POURASHAVA ELECTION RULES</u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Rule—73</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Pourashava election</strong>—Election Commissions power to direct re-poll in Pourashava election—Election Commission has power to direct re-poll in appropriate circumstances and such power has been conferred by law for a free and fair election —Paurashava Election Rule is in identical term of the Union Parishad Election Rule—Controversial points which were disputed questions of fact involving Union Parishad Election Rule could be decided. It had been held in earlier judgments, on evidence by the Election Tribunal—The High Court Division has therefore erred in setting aside the order of re-poll by the Election Commission.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Golam Murshed Vs. Mostafizur Rahman and others, 10BLD (AD) 21</em></strong></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
1207	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">POURASHAVA ORDINANCE, 1977</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  10BLD (HCD) 145, 1BLD (HCD) 407, 10BLD (HCD)22.</p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  1977</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  POURASHAVA </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>POURASHAVA ORDINANCE</u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;">(XXVI OF 1977)</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—4</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Urban area—Declaration of</strong>—Legal effect that follows from mere declaration of some area as urgban area—Mere declaration of a rural area to be an urban area by notification in the gazette under the Pourashava Ordinance does not ipso facto make it a Municipality or make it included in the limits of an existing Municipality by way of extension— The rural area of Union Parisad so declared as urban area must be taken over by the authority concerned as municipal area—The old Union Parisad will exercise its function over the area declared as urban area, until the said urban areas are included in Paurashava, after corn plying with the relevant provisions of Paurasava Ordinance and the Rules made there under—-The residents of the rural area, declared as urban area, will not be franchiseless by mere declaration of rural area as urban area—They will exercise their franchise and enjoy other facilities as per provision of Union Parisad Ordinance 1983—The alleged existing precarious condition of people of the area concerned due to the declaration are not to he considered in writ jurisdiction.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Md. Jalaluddin Vs. Bangladesh Repre sented by the Secretary Ministry of LGRD and others. 10BLD (HCD) 145</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—15(2)</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Interpretation of statute</strong>—Mandatory and directory provision—Whether the provision for holding by-election for electing Chairman of the Pourasava within one month -of the vacancy is mandatory or directory in nature—No consequence has been provided in the law for breach of this requirement of holding by election within one month—In normal course where a public officer is directed by a statute to perform a duty within a specified time the provision as to time limit is regarded as directory—Had the provision of clause 15(2) been intended by the legistature to be mandatory then the consequences in the matter of default would have been provided but this having not been done the normal meaning would be that it was a directory provision.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Abdul Hamid Miah Vs. Bangladesh Election Commission and others</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Sections—95 and 96</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Jurisdiction</strong>—No exclusive jurisdiction of Dacca Imptovement Trust or Dacca Municipal Corporation for land reclamation, land development and housing etc.—These powers are permissible in nature subject to approval of the Government.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Md. Ismail and others Vs. Bangladesh and others. 1BLD (HCD) 407</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—143</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Encroachment</strong>—Plea of encroachment when sustainable—Question of encroachment arises only in circumstances when someone is in lawful possession of a particular premises but makes an unlawful extension thereof.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Al-Haj Mirza Shamsuddin Beg Vs. Bangladesh and another; 10BLD (HCD)22.</em></strong></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
1208	None
