1209	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">PREMISES RENT CONTROL ORBINANCE, 1963</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  9BLD (HCD) 162, 6BLD (AD) 279, 5BLD (AD) 77,  6BLD (AD) 91, 1BLD (AD) 19, 1BLD (AD) 207, 1 BLD (HCD) 273, 3BLD (HCD) 116, 4BLD (AD) 74, 4BLD (AD) 298, 5 BLD (HCD) 337, 6 BLD (AD) 354, 6BLD (HCD) 93, 6BLD (HCD) 317, 10BLD (HCD) 192, 10BLD (AD) 82, 11 BLD </p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  1963</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  PREMISES RENT CONTROL</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>PREMISES RENT CONTROL ORBINANCE, 1963 (XX OF 1963</u></strong><u>)</u></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—2(9)</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Legal representative</strong> — Whether heirs of a deceased tenant can be included as legal representatives for the purpose of executing the decree — The definition of legal representative shall be given t wide meaning to include the heirs of a deceased tenant who dies during the pendency of an execution case started in pursuance of a decree for eviction of the tenant from the suit premises — Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 (V of 1908), Ss. 2(11) and 50.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Kazal Das Surma and others Vs. Prodip Das alias Shambhu aftd others, 9BLD (HCD) 162</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref; 32 DLR (AD) 170; 2 B.C.R.(AD)428; 1934 A11474; 38DLR(AD)97; — Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Sections —9 and 10</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Payment of municipal tax</strong> — Whether the agreement that such tax for the premises would be payable by the tenant is void? — By mutual agreement payment of municipal tax is payable either by the tenant or the landlord — Whatsoever is agreed to between the parties can be a term of the tenancy as no prohibition exists in the matter of payment of such tax — Contract Act, 1872 (IX of 1872), S. 23.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Meherunnessa Khatun Vs. Abdul Latif an4 another, 6BLD (AD) 279</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 31DLR (AD) 155—Distinguished; 38 DLR(AD) 1; — Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section— 14</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Adjustment of rent against security deposit</strong> — Whether can be allowed in a suit for selectmen?—On the tenant’s application within six months from the date of payment of security deposit the House Rent Controller can order adjustment against rents if the tenant so desires — Such application does not appear to have been made — No order exists adjusting the rents against the security deposit — This cannot be made now after the landlord instituted the suit for eviction of the tenants.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Mosammat Rahima Khatun Vs. Abdur Rashid Bhuiyan and another, 5BLD (AD) 77.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 31 DLR (AD)I 55 — Not applicable.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Sections — 14(b) and 18(2)</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Default in payment of rent</strong> — When the tenant paid tax to the Municipality in compliance of a distress warrant, non-payment of rent to the extent of the amount of tax so paid whether will make the tenant defaulter? — Whether payment of taxes is adjustable against rent ? — Payment of arrear tax which. was paid to the credit of the previous owner is adjustable, if the application is made before the Controller at the option of the tenant when the Controller will be obliged to order the adjustment of any sum so paid or deposited in any other manner.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Mst. Esarunnessa Bibi being dead her heirs Amjad Hossain and others Vs. Md. Amir Hossain, 6BLD (AD) 91</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Sections — 18(1) (5) and 19</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Payment of rent in lump—A tenant paying rent of several months in a lump shall ordinarily be treated as defaulter unless there is contract to the contrary or such payment is covered by waiver or acquiescence on the part of the landlord.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>P.K Chakraborty Vs. A.P. Chowdhuiy and others, 1BLD (AD) 19</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 31 DLR (AD) 183 — Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Sections — 18(1)(5)</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Landlord and tenant</strong> — Tenant failing to pay rent due to supervening circumstances, war of liberation compelling him to leave the premises for fear of life — Tenant is not deprived of the protection under section 18(1).</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Kalu Mondal Vs. Begum Frilatunnessa, 1BLD (AD) 207</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 31 DLR (AD) 183.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Sections — 18 and 19</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Abandoned property</strong> — Building in urban areas — abandoned premises let out by Government to private person on monthly rent General Law of landlord and tenant will apply in respect of termination of such tenancy.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">There is no provision either in P.O. 16 of 1972 or in the Rules framed there under laying down any provision for selectmen of any private allotted from the premises in case the Government requires the premises bonafid in public interest or on account of any default in paying monthly rents as such — In such circumstances, there is no other option left with the Government as the substituted landlord of an abandoned building but to take recourse to the normal law of termination of a monthly lease and tenancy under action 106 of the Transfer of Property Act read with the relevant provisions of sections 18 and 19 of the Premises Rent Control Ordinance — In the absence of any specific statutory provision providing for any special right of the Government to summarily evict and eject a private allottee of a government building, the normal rule of landlord and tenant will apply.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Bank of Credit and Commerce international (Overseas) Ltd. Vs. Bangladesh, 1 BLD (HCD) 273</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section — 18(5)</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Default</strong>—Default in payment of rent is waived if the landlord accepts rent after such default made by the tenant — The landlord cannot sue the tenant for ejectrnent on the ground of default after such acceptance of rent.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Benoy Bhusan Chakraborty Vs. Dr. Shaukat Au Bhuiyan, 3BLD (HCD) 116</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 28 DLR443; 19 DLR (Dhaka) 775; 26 DLR342; — Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Sections — 18(5) and 19</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Ejectment of tenant on the ground of default in payment of rent</strong> — Protection against selectmen — To avail the protection against ejectment, the tenant was required to deposit rents of every month within. 15th of the following month, even after termination of the tenancy.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Nowab Mean . Vs. Nur Nahar. Begum, 4BLD (AD) 74 </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 31 DLR (AD) 183—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section —18(5)</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Time limit for payment of rent — Whether can be varied except by a written contract</strong> — No implied contract can be said to have been created simply by payment and acceptance of rents for several months at a time — Such irregular payment also did not constitute an waiver of the right to receive payment as laid down in the statute — In the absence of a written contract non-payment of rent within the 15th day of the month next following that for which rent is payable shall make the tenant a defaulter.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>M/s. A. Hoque and Co. and another Vs. Al-haj Zakir Hossàin, 4BLD (AD) 298</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 31 DLR (AD) 1 83; 33DLR (AD)55; — Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section — 18(5)</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Maintainability of rent deposit case</strong> — Whether deposit of rent without cost of transmission by money order is a valid deposit — Simple deposit of the amount of rent without depositing the cost of transmission by postal money orders cannot be considered to be a valid deposit — Such case is not maintainable.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Mir M.A. Razzaque and others Vs. Md. Abdul Hai Patwari, 5 BLD(AD)97</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section — 18</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Bonafide requirement — Elements to determine it</strong> — Merely because a person has got a house other then the house in suit it cannot be held that the plaintiff does not require the house bonafide for his personal use and occupation, particularly when the other house is tenanted — Plaintiff is not entitled to lead evidence to prove that he required the premises for building and re-building in the absence of any case made out in the plaint for the bonafide requirement for the purpose of building and rebuilding.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Md. Chand Miah Sowdagar Vs. S.M.A. Rahman, 5 BLD (HCD) 337</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 56 C.W.N. 480; 27 DLR643 — Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section — 18</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Waiver of default</strong> — Default in payment of rent whether is waiver by subsequent acceptance of the rent for the period of default at a time — Mere acceptance of rent is not sufficient to constitute waiver — Whether there has been any waiver by the landlord must be gathered from the facts of each case — Evidence must be given to establish plea of waiver after raising the plea in the pleading — Once a default occurs subsequent acceptance of the rent in lump by the landlord, does not in the absence of any positive proof of his intention to waiver such default, amounts to waiver so as to entitle him to the protection against the consequence of default, that is, eviction.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>M/s. Binning and Co. (Bangladesh) Ltd. Vs. M/s. Naziabad Properties Ltd; 6 BLD (AD) 354</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 31 DLR (AD) 183; 33DLR (AD) 55; (1904) 28 IL.R. Born 440; A.I.R. 1939 (PC) 159; 29DLR (SC) 13; 4BLD (AD) 298;— Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section — 18(c)</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Bonafide requirement — Meaning of</strong>— Plaintiff has a two storied residential building and a business office adjacent to the suit premises — The plaintiff requires the suit premises for expanding his office — Whether requirement is bonafide — Bonafide requirement means an honest and genuine requirement and does not mean an absolute requirement — So the plaintiffs requirements of the suit premises is bonafide.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Md. Ayub Au Vs. Mst. Jahanara Shirin, 6BLD (HCD) 93</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section — 18(3)</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Ejectment of a monthly tenant on the ground of subletting</strong> - Whether a tenant becomes liable to be evicted from the premises used by him for commercial or industrial purposes on the ground of sub-letting without the consent of the landlord — In the instant case the premises in question was mainly used for commercial purposes — The defendant Nos. 3 and 4 were inducted in the premises for the purpose of the said business — So there is no illegality in such subletting by the tenant defendant Nos. 1 and 2 — In the instant case consent of the landlord for subletting does not arise but as the premises was used for commercial purpose on the subletting of the premises with the transfer of the business therein the sub lessee is to be treated as tenant on the determination of the tenancy — The agreement of monthly tenancy being illegal and inadmissible in evidence the plaintiff cannot take advantage of the agreement.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Shawkat Ara Vs. Begum Motia Akter Khan, 6BLD (HCD) 317</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref .20DLR429;3 1 DLR(AD) 155 ;—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Sections — 18(5) and 19(1)</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Depositing rents.</strong>—Lump deposit and computation of the period of limitation — Provision of the Presidents Order No. 12 of 1972 that excludes certain period for instituting any legal proceeding on grounds of atrocities by Pakistan occupation army has no manner of application in a case where the tenants deposited arrear rents at a time in lump of several months — President Order No. 12 of 1972, Article 4.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Md. Osman Vs. Fatema Khatun, 10BLD (HCD) 192</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref; 8DLR 272 — Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—18</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Proceedings before the Rent Controller</strong> — Nature of — The deposit of rent in the office of the Controller is no institution of a case as the Controller upon the deposit does not decide the disput between the tenant and the landlord. He is merely a ‘conduit pipe’ — President’s Order No. 12 of 1972; Articles — 2 and 4.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Md. Osinan Vs.Fatema Khatun, IOBLD (HCD)192</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 8DLR 272 — Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section — 18(1)(e)</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Onus probandi —When onus is arbitrarily shifted and found not discharged </strong>— The plaintiff did not examine any independent witness in support of its case that the food supplied by the defendant’s canteen was not good — Trial Court arbitrarily shifted the</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">onus on the defendant for proving its defence plea — The plaintiff therefore failed to bring its case home that he needed the tenanted premises for efficient management of the canteen — Evidence Act, 1872 (I of 1872), S. 102.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>M/s. Channel Cinema Ltd. Vs. Chowdhury Golam Malek, 10BLD (AD) 82</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Sections — 18 and 19</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Remittance of rent</strong>—Remittance of rent after becoming defaulter and deposit of rent beyond the prescribed period are not in compliance of sections 18 and 19 and come within the rule of default.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Mst. Wahida Rashid and another Vz. Miron Mohammad Zahidul Huq, 11 BLD (HCD) 79: 43 DLR (HCD) 115</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 31 DLR (AD) 155 — Not applicable and 33 DLR(AD)55 — Relied.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—19</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Deposit of rent</strong> — Whether deposit aft transfer by the landlord may continue by impleading the transferee landlord — Such deposit cannot be taken as a ground to resin ejectment by the transferee landlords — ho- pleading the transferee landlords in the Reni deposit case filed against the previous landlord is a clear device to avoid payment of t to the plaintiffs — They may not be entitled to rents prior to the transfer but they are entitled to it since the transfer and this having n been paid’ the tenants were defaulters.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Basiruddin Ahmed and another Vs. Dhirendra Mohan Das and another.  4BLD (AD) 180</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section — 19(2)</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Payment of rent</strong>—Question of deposit in case of doubt or dispute as to the person who is entitled to the rent—The tenant went into possession under an agreement of tenancy and he is guided by the Premises Rent Control Ordinance and if there is a bonafide doubt l is to deposit the rent before the House Reni Controller.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Md. Shafiuddin Vs. Mahboob Hasan, BLD (HCD)108</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: A.I.R. 1928 (Bombay) 265; A.I.R. 1956 (CaI)148; 33 DLR(AD)37; 24 DLR 202; —Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—19</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Bonafide requirement</strong> —- Owning of houses more than one is no ground to hold that the premises of the suit is not required for bonafide use by the landlord.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Md. Osman Vs. Fatema Khatun and others, 10BLD (HCD) 192</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section — 19</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The only issue the House Rent Controller is required to see whether the petitioner has deposited the rent in accordance with the provision of the House Rent Control Ordinance— He is not required to decide anything with regard to default in payment of rent — The question whether the petitioner is a defaulter or not is to decided in the suit for ejectment and the finding of the House Rent Controller on the point of default will have no binding effect on the S.C.C. Judge while deciding the suit on merit — Petitioner is required to move first the trial Court for stay of all further proceedings — Point of issue before the House Rent Controller and the S.C.C Judge being distinct and different no question of stay arises — prayer for stay rejected.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Sheikh Mohd. Salimullah Vs. Shaftqul Alam, 10BLD(HCD)438</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 42DLR(HCD) 140; 4BLD(AD) 8; IBCR(HCD)450; 23DLR(HCD)l 13; Revision No. 1397 of 1978 (Unreported) — Cited.</p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
1210	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">PRESIDENT ORDERS</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  1BLD (AD) 348, 8BLD (HCD) 485, 4BLD (AD) 80, 12BLD (AD) 199, 11BLD (HCD) 398, 9BLD (AD) 116.</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  PRESIDENT ORDERS</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u><br/> </u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>PRESIDENT ORDER NO. 8 OF 1972 and PRESIDENT ORDER NO.67 OF 1972</u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Interpretation of</strong>—Precisely President’s Order No.8 of 1972 was drafted in such language so as to cover the acts already committed and by express words it was given retrospective effect. Whereas President’s Order No.67 of 1972 does not contain any such express words. Rather the statute has been drafted in clear language to cover those persons who are still ‘exhibiting” faith in Pakistan ideology or “manifesting” ardour, or zeal “amounting” to collaboration etc.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It is only a mental makeup of certain persons whose conduct “exhibiting”, “manifesting”, “amounting to collaboration’ etc. which have been the subject matter of the enactment that they are liable to be thrown out. It is not the activity which was performed in the past or immediate past which had been made offence under another special statute, e.g., President’s Order No.8 of 1972. On the other hand by making President’s Order No.8 of 1972 retrospective a person who has aided, abetted, participated, issued statement were brought within its ambit but not the persons whose conduct or activity in the discharge of their duties “manifesting” exhibiting” etc. are within it. Later class of people does come within President’s Order No.67 of 1972 if such mental make up is still continuing.”</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Per B.H. Chowdhury, J (R. Islam, J concurring)</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Registrar, University of Dacca Vs. Dr. Sajjad Hossain, 1BLD (AD) 348</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>PRESIDENT’S ORDER NO. 90 of 1972</u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article —2</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Non-obstante clause —</strong> Import of such clause appearing in a statute — It is well — established that when a non-obstante clause is used it has first to be ascertained what the enacting part of the section provides — Nonobstante clause is to be understood as operating to set aside as no longer valid anything contained in the relevant existing law which is inconsistent with the new enactment.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Chowdhury Tanbir Ahmed Siddiky Vs. Bangladesh and others, 8BLD (HCD) 485</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 33 DLR(AD)13.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">[The above judgment has been reversed by the Appellate Division, reported in 17 BLD(AD) 13 1.]</p><p> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>PRESIDENT ORDER NO.12 OF 1972 (P.0.12 OF 1972)</u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article—3</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Arbitrator—</strong>Whether he is excluded from the definition of “Court”—An arbitrator does not adjudicate and he does not sit as a Tribunal—He is not bound by the technicalities of the Evidence Act—His function is like that of conciliator—He is neither a Court nor a Tribunal and his award is not a judgment, decree or order of any Court or Tribunal within the mischief of Article 3 of President’s Order No. 12 of 1972.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Begum Khadija Akhtar Banu and Another Vs. A.K.M. Amanullah and another 4BLD (AD) 80.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>PRESIDENT’S ORDER NO.64 OF 1972</u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article — 4(1)</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Right to fresh hearing</strong> — Whether Government of Bangladesh being added as a party in a suit pending prior to promulgation of P.0. 69/72 has such a right — Whatever hearing took place before the liberation of Bangladesh was between the petitioner and the Province of East Pakistan — The Government of Bangladesh substituted itself as a party to the suit by a fiction of law — That does not mean that the Government of Bangladesh became a successor of the province of East Pakistan — The Government of Bangladesh acquired the right to have the suit heard de novo.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Chowdhury Tanbir Ahmed Siddiky Vs. Bangladesh and others, 8BLD (HCD)485</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 33 DLR(AD)13.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">[The above judgment has been reversed by the Appellante Division, reported in I7BLD (AD)131]</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>PRESIDENTS ORDER NO.94 OF 1972</u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article —11A</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Delegation of authority</strong>—When an express provision for delegation of power is not exercised in accordance with law, then it cannot be said that it was deemed to have been. done impliedly, because, the delegating authority did not object to it. The Board’s ratification of the order after it was struck down by the High Court Division will have no effect. -</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Bangladesh Freedom Fighters Welfare Trust and another Vs. Md. Momtazul Hossam, 12BLD (AD) 199</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>PRESIDENT’S ORDER NO. 129 OF 1972</u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Proceedings under ordinary law and special law</strong>—The proceedings under a special law are different in nature and are not to be tagged with proceedings under any other ordinary law. It does not matter which one was instituted first. The special proceedings under the special law (P.O. 1.29 of 1972) shall proceed independently under the provisions of that special law, no matter whether there is any other pending proceeding under any other ordinary law instituted earlier or later than the special proceeding.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Ahmed Silk Mills Ltd. Vs. Bangladesh Shilpa Bank, 11BLD (HCD) 398</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>PRESIDENT ORDER NO. 135 OF 1972</u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article — 2</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Diluvion and extinguishment of right</strong> — When diluvion had taken place before commencement of P.O... 135 of 1972 and the lands reappeared before the commencement of the Order, the right, title and interest of the tenant got extinguished with the. diluvion — The lands having re-appeared before the commencement of the Order it vested absolutely in the Government free from all encumbrances to be at its disposal until the tenant’s right to re-possession was finally recognised by a competent authority — State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950 (XXVIII. of 1951), S.86.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Syed Nizamuddin Mohsin being dead his heirs Vs. People’s Republic of Bangladesh and others, 9BLD (AD) 116</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 31 DLR (AD) 195.</p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span> <span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
1211	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">PRINTING PRESS AND PUBLICATION (DECLARATION) AND REGISTRATION ACT, 1973</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  1BLD (HCD) 344</p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  1973</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  PRINTING PRESS AND PUBLICATION (DECLARATION) AND REGISTRATION </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>  <br/> </em></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>PRINTING PRESS AND PUBLICATION (DECLARATION) AND REGISTRATION ACT (XXIII OF 1973)</u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—12</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Printing Press and Publication</strong>—Audialteram, Partem—District Magistrate acting under Act XXIII of 1973 is a quasi judicial authority and is required to decide giving personal hearing to the person making the declaration—Appeal is provided against his refusal to authenticate a declaration and he cannot act on the instruction of the appellate authority.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Sk. Faziul Karim Selim Vs. Bangladesh and another. 1BLD (HCD) 344</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—12(2)</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Printing Press and Publication</strong>— Authentication of declaration—Once the District Magistrate is satisfied that the person making the declaration fulfilled all the requirements of s.12(2) of Act XXIII of 1973, the District Magistrate has no option but to authenticate the declaration and he cannot refer the matter to the Government which is the appellate authority.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Sk. Faziul Karim Selim Vs. Bangladesh and another. 1BLD (HCD) 344.</em></strong></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
1212	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">PRIZE COURT RULES, 1939</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  2BLD (AD)147</p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  1939</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  PRIZE COURT</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>PRIZE COURT RULES, 1939</u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Order XXXIV</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Prize Court Fund</strong>—Rules of business— Matters exclusively reserved for the Ministry of Finance cannot be dealt with by any other Ministry—Ministry of Law not competent to initiate proceeding for distribution and investment of Prize Court Fund—Constitution of Bangladesh.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Bangladesh Vs. Hon’ble Judge, Prize Court, High Court Division. 2BLD (AD)147.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Order—34</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Prize Court Fund—</strong>Prize Court Fund consists of money payable into the Public Account of the Republic—Under the Rules of Business only the Ministry of Fin1nce could move an application before the Prize Court with formal proposal and a working scheme for withdrawal of money from the fun&amp; Art.85 of the Constitution provides that all public moneys which will form part either of the Consolidated Fund or the Public Account of the Republic is payable into such Fund or Account or can be withdrawn from under an Act of Parliament or Rules made by the President. There is neither an Act of Parliament nor any rules by the President which govern the mode of payment of the money cotistitution the Prize Court Fund into the public Account of the Republic. In the absence of any enactment or rules which the Constitution has empowered the President to make for the regulation of payment of money belonging to the Prize Court Fund into the Public Accounts of the Republic, the only alternative left to the Government is to get an Act passed by Parliament or have Rules framed by the President pending such enactment—Constitution of Bangladesh.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Bangladesh Vs. Hon‘ble Judge, Prize Court, High Jourt Divison, 2 BLD (AD) 147.</em></strong></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
