1214	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">PUBLIC SERVANT’S (RETIREMENT) ACT, 1974</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  1BLD (AD) 140, 1BLD (HCD) 420, 1BLD (HCD)399, 2BLD (HCD) 98, 3 BLD(AD)143</p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  1974</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  PUBLIC SERVANT’S (RETIREMENT)</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>PUBLIC SERVANT’S (RETIREMENT) ACT, 1974 (XII OF 1974)</u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Government power to retire a Government servant</strong>—The power of the Government to retire a Government servant before the age of superannuating is only on the ground of ‘public interest’—That is to say there must be a case that the Government servant concerned suffers from inefficiency or incompetence.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Government servant substantively appointed has the right to hold the post till the age of superannuation—This right is subject to law conforming to constitutional provisions.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Section 9(2) of Act XII of 1974 permitting an impugned notification prematurely retiring appellant without affording opportunity of showing cause is violative of Article 135 of the Constitution.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A Government servant is retired with full pension after 25years service not as a measure of punishment—It does not bear any stigma, nor any imputation is made or allegation is brought against the Government servant when thus retired with pension—The Indian Supreme Court has consistently held that premature retirement is not a punishment and it does not amount to removal—This is no reason to take a different view in this case.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Dr. Narul islam Vs. Bangladesh and others, 1BLD (AD) 140</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. A.I.R. 1958 (SC)36; A.I.R. 1964 (SC) 600; A.I.R. 1954(SC)369; A.I.R. 1975 (SC) 1487; A.I.R. l965(SC)280; A.I.R. 1965 (SC)l 967.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Violation of equality clause of the Constitution</strong>—Section 9(2) of Act XII of 1974 conferring unfettered discretion on the Government in the matter of compulsory retirement without any guideline either in the Act or in the Rules framed there under is violative of equality clause of the Constitution—Constitution of Bangladesh, 1972, Articles 27 and 29.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Dr. Nurul Islam vs. Bangladesh and others; 1BLD (AD) 140</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: A.IR. l958 (SC)538; A.LR. 1955 4SC)191;PLD1957(SC)159;PLD1957 (SC) 9; A.I.R. 1961 (SC)552; PLDI 958(SC)4 1; A.I.R. 1956(SC)44; (1968) 1 All. E.R. 694; A.I.R. 1954 (SC) 369; A.I.R. 1957 (SC) 892; A.I.R. 1965 (SC) 280; A.I.R. 1975 (SC) 1487; A.I.R. 1970 (All) 269; A.I.R. 1972 (Mys) 71; PLD 1967(Lah) 227; PLD1959 (SC) 37; PLD 1971 (Kar) 333; 19DLR(SC)281; 1957 SCA. 660.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section — 2(d)</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Public Servant</strong>—Public servant includes any person who is in the service of the Republic, corporation, nationalised enterprise or local authority as defined in clause (d) of section 2 of the Public Servants (Retirement) Act, 1974.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Golam Morshed Vs. Bangladesh Textile Mills Corporation &amp; ors., 1BLD (HCD) 420</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Sections — 3 and 4</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Service—Termination of service</strong>— Simple termination of service of any employee of any statutory corporation even invoking any provision of any contract or terms of service is grossly violative of the provision of section 4 read with section 3 of the Public Servants (Retirement) Act, 1974.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Golam Morshed Vs. Bangladesh Textile Mills Corporation and others, 1 BLD (HCD)420</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section —4</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Termination of service</strong> In the absence of any publication of Rules and Regulations relating to terms and conditions of service in terms of Articles 24 and 25 of P.O. No. 27 of 1972 and without holding a proceeding there under upon giving a cause, no employee of a statutory corporation can be dismissed, removed or even terminated from service prior to attainment of the age of retirement as specified in Public Servants (Retirement) Act, 1974 — Bangladesh, Industrial Enterprises (Nationalisation) Order,1972 (P.O. 27 of 1972), Articles, 24 and 25. -</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Golam Morshed Vs. Bangladesh Textile Mills Corporation &amp; ors., 1 BLD (HCD) 420.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: IBLD 86—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section — 9(2)</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Compulsory retirement</strong>—Section 9(2) of Act XII of 1974 conferring unfettered discretion on the Government in the matter of compulsory retirement without any guideline either in the Act or in the rules framed there under is violative of equality clause of the Constitution. — Constitution of Bangladesh, 1972, Articles 27 and 29.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Per F. Munim, J:</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Since neither the impugned provisions nor the Act nor the rules containing them provide any principle or guideline for the exercise of discretion by the Government when it proposes to retire a Government servant from amongst a group of government servants similarly situated and holding similar jobs, there invariably exists scope far arbitrary exercise of such discretion. What is of importance and consequence to the Government servant concerned, who is proposed to be retired, is that the discretion of the relevant authority must be seen to have been exercised on some such principles as are discernible in Fundamental Rule 56, Note 2, East Bengal .Service Rule and Rule 3 of the Bangladesh Public Servants Retirement Rules, 1973. Where such basis has been provided by the enunciation of such principles, whether under the Act or rules made under an Act or even in the note to such rules regarding the retirement of government servants, the concerned authority before exercising its discretion, has to conform to the principles so provided therein ... The omission of such basis in the Public Servants (Retirement) Rules, 1975 leaves scope to the concerned authority to arbitrarily retire a Government servant who has completed 25 years of service. The existence of such principles as are found in the Rules of 1973 would have provided a complete answer to any challenge to their constitutionality, inspite of the expression “without assigning any reason’ used in section 9(2) of the Act. In such a case the authority concerned would have remained free, so as not to disclose any reason in the retirement order, but if its action in retiring a Government servant was challenged as arbitrary, as has been done by the appellant in the present case, them authority could have disclosed before the Court the basis of its action.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Per F. Munim, J:</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The minimum principle or guideline as has been provided in service rules as appear from the cases cited in the judgment is that of public interest or the interest of public service. If either the impugned Act or the rules made there under provided such principle, the minimum requirement of law as showing the existence of some guideline for the exercise of discretion in retiring a Government servant, who has completed 25 years of service, would, be satisfied, thus making it immune from any challenge on the ground of d crimination violative of Arts. 27 and 29 of Constitution. In the absence of such a guide line either in the Act or the rules from there under, section 9(2) of Act XII of 19 suffers from unconstitutionality and the I pugned action based on it is open to the chalenge as being discriminatory and in violatof the equality provisions of the Constitution</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: A.I.R. I 958(SC)538; A.I.R. I 955(</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">191; PLD 1957 (SC)l59; PLD1959(SCk A.I.R. 196 l(SC)552; PLD I 958(SC)4 1; A.I.R.. 1956 (SC) 44; (1968) lAll. E.R.694; A.IR.. 1954 (SC) 369; A.I.R.l957 (SC) 892; A.L 1965 (SC) 280; A.I.R.l975(SC)1487; AJL 1970 (AlI)296; A.I.R.1972(Mys)7l; PLDI96 (Lah) 227; PLD1959(SC) 37; PLDI97I (K 333; I9DLR(SC) 281; 1957SCA 660—CiteL</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Per Ruhul Islam, J:</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In the absence of any principle or guide line for the exercise of uncontrolled and unqualified discretion, S. 9(2) of the Act vided the scope to the authority to pick choose and to discriminate between Government servants similarly placed on complete of 25 years of service in the matter of premature retirement and as such discrimination - inherent in the Act itself and S. 9(2) is violative of Articles 27 and 29.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Per B.H. Chowdhury, J:</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Neither the Act nor the rules provide a principle or guideline for the exercise of discretion by the Government when it proposed to retire a Government servant under S. 9(2. In such case the scope for arbitrary exercise i discretion cannot be ruled out as happened this case.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Dr. Nurul islam Vs. Bangladesh aad others, 1BLD (AD) 140</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section — 9(2)</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Section 9(2) of Act XII of 1974 permitting an impugned notification prematurely retiring appellant without affording him opportunity of showing cause is violative of Artclee 135 of the Constitution.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Per Ruhul Islam, J:</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Premature retirement is per se a punishment, because the Government servant is –prived of his right to continue in service until he attains the age of superannuation and he loses the benefit of service accrued to him. Termination of service before his superannuation is undoubtedly removal if not termed as ‘dismissal’.. It is true that the (impugned) order does not contain any stigma, but the very fact that the appellant was selected out of a number of persons similarly placed, and consequently he has been deprived not only from continuing in the employment for the remaining period of his term of service but also from some of the service benefits accrued to him, makes out a case of punishment. In effect, whatever may be the phraseology used in terminating the service, it is punishment imposed on him, for it not only destroys his right to the post held by him, but also inevitably carries with it a stigma. Such a termination is ‘removal’ within the meaning of Article 135 of the Constitution. Therefore the statute or rule providing a mode of terminating service at the discretion of the authority without complying with impugned action having been taken against the appellant without issuing any notice upon him or giving him an opportunity of being heard before taking the impugned action, the impugned notification is violative of Article 1 35 of the Constitution.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: A.I.R.1958 (SC) 36; A.I.R. 1954 (SC) 369; A.I.R.1964 (SC) 600; A.I.R.1975 (SC) l487 —Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Per S. Ahmed, J:</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A Government servant is retired with full pension after 25 years service not as a measure of punishment. It does not bear any stigma, nor any imputation is made or allegation is brought against the Government servant when thus retired with pension ... The Indian Supreme Court has consistently held that premature retirement is not a punishment and it does not amount to removal.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: A.I.R1954SC369; A.I.R1965SC280; A.1.R.1965 SC1967; A.I.R.1975SC487 — Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Dr. Nurul Islam Vs. Bangladesh and others, 1BLD (AD) 140</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—9(2)</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Government Servant — Compulsory retirement</strong> For validity of an order of compulsory retirement, Government must form an opinion as to the necessity of retiring an employee in public interest — There1must be materials to support that the employees retirement is necessary in public interest —. Public Servants (Retirement) (Amendment) Ordinance, 1981 (VI of 1981), S—4.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>A.K.M. Arshad Ali Vs. Government of Bangladesh, 1BLD (HCD)399</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: I BLD (AD)140 — Relied.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section — 9(2)</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Government Servant—Compulsory retirement</strong>—Fundamental right to equality— Government record must show that the Government has considered the necessity of such retirement and the retirement is in public interest—Government did not apply its mind as to why amongst 34 doctors who completed 25 years of service the petitioner should be signed out for compulsory retirement— Such retirement must be held to be discriminatory and ordered with ulterior motive—Constitution of Bangladesh, 1972, Articles 27 and 29.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Dr. Abu Ahmed chowdhury Vs Bangladesh, 2BLD (HCD) 98</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: I BLD (AD) 140; 1BLD 399 — relied.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section — 9(2)</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Service matter — Order of retirement— It’s validity</strong> — There is no instance of misconduct on the part of the respondent prior to passing of the impugned order of retirement — According to the Government the action was taken with a view to enforcing strict discipline in the office — Such justification for taking exemplary punishment only on finding the respondent absent for a short period is undoubtedly arbitrary — Law does not empower the Government to päs such arbitrary order of retirement. [Per Ruhul Islam, J.]</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Habibullah Khan Vs. Shah Azharuddin Ahmed and others, 3 BLD(AD)143</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—9(2)</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Retirement order</strong> - In what case retirement should be resorted to is a matter within the absolute discretion of the authorities — Retirement with full pensionary benefits after completion of 25 years service is not a punishment nor does it contain any stigma — Even if respondent’s punishment has been referred to as an exemplary punishment in the office file, still then when the action of the Government is found to have been taken in accordance with law and there is no malafide therein, it cannot be assailed as arbitrary. [Per Shahabuddin Ahmed, J. (dissenting)]</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Public interest</strong> — A person aggrieved by retirement order may contend that the order was not in the public interest — Government is the better judge to decide what is public interest.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">There may be various reasons for which the Government may retire a Government servant after he completed the requisite period of service qualifying for pension; the Government is in a better position to decide whom to retire. It is not possible for a Court to sit on judgment over Government’s action if from the facts disclosed it does not appear that Government’s action was malafide or courable exercise of power. Subject to these limitations, the discretion of the Government in such a matter is absolute. The Court may call for record only to see that the Government had some materials for deciding that retirement of a Government servant was considered necessary in the public interest and that order of retirement was not malafide — In this case the order of retirement is found to be perfectly lawful. [Per Shahabuddin Ahmed J. (dissenting).]</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Public interest</strong>—Whether order of retirement is in public interest can be examined by the Court — The Court may declare it not in public interest after examining materials produced. [Per Fazie Munim, J.]</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Habibullah Khan Vs. Shah Azharuddin Ahmed and others, 3 BLD (AD) 143</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 33DLR (AD)20 1; PLD1958SC 181; I 97OPLDSC98; PLD1 969(SC)14—discussed.</p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
1215	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">PUBLIC SERVANTS (RETIREMENT) (AMENDMENT) ORDINANCE, 1981</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  1BLD (HCD) 399, 2BLD(AD)120</p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  1981</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  PUBLIC SERVANTS (RETIREMENT) (AMENDMENT)</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>PUBLIC SERVANTS (RETIREMENT) (AMENDMENT) ORDINANCE, 1981 <br/> </u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>(VI OF 1981)</u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section —4</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Government Servant—Compulsory retirement —</strong> For validity of an order of compulsory retirement, Government must form an opinion as to the necessity of retiring an employee in public interest — There must be materials to support that the employee’s retirement is necessary in public interest — Public Servants (Retirement) Act, 1974 (XII of 1974), S. 9(2).</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>A.K.M. Arshad Ali Vs. Government of Bangladesh, 1BLD (HCD) 399</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 1BLD (AD) 140 — relied.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section — 5</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Government Servant</strong>—Compulsory retirement—Effect of validation clause on orders of compulsory retirement made prior to the passing of the Ordinance.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">There must be objective satisfaction behind the order on the part of the Government before the order of retirement may be considered as valid even under the ‘Amending Ordinance and by this validation only those orders are contemplated which have been passed in the public interest after consideration of materials upon which the Government. wants to retire the person concerned.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Arshad Ali Vs. Govt. of Bangladesh, 1BLD (HCD) 399 -</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—5</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Administrative law</strong> — Power to examine the validit. of action declared to be valid by Parliament -- Effect of the validation clause on orders of compulsory retirement made prior to passing of the validating law — Constitution of Bangladesh, 1972, Article — 102.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Mofizur Ruhmna I(han Vs. Govt. of Bangladesh, 2BLD(AD)120</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref PLD I 970(SC)98; PLD 195 8(SC) 181—Cited.</p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
1216	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">RAILWAYS ACT, 1890</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  3 BLD (HCD) 143</p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  1890</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  RAILWAYS </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>RAILWAYS ACT, 1890 (IX OF 1908)</u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—77</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Limitation</strong>—Limitation in a suit for compensation against Railway for loss of goods—Notice must be given within the period of limitation.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Since there is no distinction of any loss caused by non-delivery and loss caused by negligence of the Railway as a carrier, a notice under section 77 of the Act must be given in all cases of claim against Railway for compensation within the period of limitation.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Chairman, Bangladesh Railway Board vs. Maintaz Hossain and others, 3 BLD (HCD) 143</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 31 DLR 146—Cited.</p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
1217	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">REGISTRATION ACT, 1908</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  4BLD (HCD)157, 5 BLD (AD) 24, SBLD(AD)260, 8BLD (HCD) 6, 9BLD (HCD) 10, 5BLD (AD) 289, 1BLD (AD) 85, 1BLD (AD) 86, 4BLD (HCD) 150, 8BLD (AD) 73 and 149, 10BLD (AD) 160, 42DLRC4D) 123,  l2BLD (AD) 77, 4BLD (HCD) 215, 3BLD (AD)58, 6BLD (AD) 178.   </p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  1908</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  REGISTRATION </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>REGISTRATION ACT, 1908 (XVI OF 1908)</u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—17</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Relinquishment</strong>—Whether oral agreement to relinquish right in immovable property valid—Relinquishment of interest amounting to transfer of absolute interest in immovable property cannot be effected without a registered instrument if the value of the property exceeds Tk. 100/00.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Md. Golam Au Molla Vs.Khondakar Abdul Mazid and others, 4BLD (HCD)157</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—17(i)(b)</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Transfer of partners interest</strong>—Whether registered document necessary to transfer the interest of a partner in immovable property of a partnership—The interest of a partner in partnership assets in movable property though the assets includes immovable property?— The transfer of interest of a partner in partnership firm can be effected by registered document under the provisions of the Registration Act when the firm is possessed of immovable property as the transfer operates to create an interest in immovable property does not appear to be a sound law—Registration of such document for conveying share in partnership in immovable property is not required.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Lin Ying Ping Vs. Leon Fang Ai, 5 BLD (AD) 24</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: A.I.R. 1966(SC)1300; 20 DLR 1056; I.L.R. 17 Bombay 235; A.I.R. 1947 Lahore I 3;—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Sections—17(2)(VI) and 50</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Registration of compromise decree</strong>— Compromise decree when exempt from registration—If the compromise deals with suit properties then the decree on such compromise is exempt from registration but if the compromise relates to properties which are not subject-matter of the suit, in such case the decree is not exempt from registration— If the compromise has been acted upon or is covered by the decree then it is a settled law that compromise is exempt from registration.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Jonab All Sardar and others Vs. Taser All Fakir and another, SBLD(AD)260</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: A.I.R. 1919 (PC)79—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—17(2)(VI)</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Compromise decree</strong>—Such decree creating interest in immovable property, which is subject matter of the suit, whether requires to be registered ‘?—Compromise decree in respect of immovable property which is subject matter of the suit creating or transferring interest therein does not require registration— The respondents have no locus standi to challenge the compromise decree when they had no interest in the subject matter of the suit.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Sreemati Parul Kusum Roy Vs. Bangladesh and others, 8BLD (HCD) 6.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Sections—17(1)(b) and 49</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Award in respect of property</strong>—Question of registration—The alleged award is a non-testamentary instrument which operates to create right, title or interest valued above Tk. 100/- in immovable property—The award relating to such property having not been registered it is not enforceable in law.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Chan Jun Talukder and another Vs. Ching Neshay Magni and others, 9BLD (HCD) 10</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 17 DLR (Dhaka) 649—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—28 -</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Validity of registration</strong>—Question of protection of third party’s title—The vendor and vendee of Ext. A are precluded from questioning the validity of registration on the ground that the property did not exist or was fictitious or insignificant or was not intended to be conveyed and the registration was invalid.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Syed Kawsar Au Vs. Gahar Kazi and others, 5BLD (AD) 289</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 41 l.A. 110; 41 All 22; 16 l.A. 12; 39 C.W.N. 120; 55 Mad. 507; A.I.R. 1954 Bombay 54; PLD 1957 Dhaka 165; 61 l.A. 286; 16l.A. 112; A.LR. 1925 Mad. 430; I.L.R. 1914 (Cal)972; 48 l.A. 127;—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Sections—32 and 33</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Power of attorney</strong>—its registration— Contention that a power of attorney empowering a person to execute a deed of transfer of immovable property requires registration is not tenable as a power of attorney executed in terms of Registration Act or under other provisions of law which confers a valid power on the attorney to act as an agent for the principal does not require registration except that its authentication under the law is necessary.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Nurunnessa and others Vs. Babar Au Bepari and others, 1BLD (AD) 85</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Sections—32 and 33</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Power of Attorney</strong>—Power of attorney executed and authenticated by a Magistrate or Notary Public in a foreign country—Whether could be acted upon as a valid document in Bangladesh?</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">If a notarial act is done in a foreign country by a foreign notary and there is reciprocal arrangement between Bangladesh and that foreign country, then by reference to S. 14 of Notaries Ordinance and S. 33 of the Registration Act, those notarial acts will be valid and the power of attorney admissible in Bangladesh.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">If there is no reciprocal arrangement the question is whether by reference to S. 14 of the Notaries Ordinance, 1961 it could be said that foreign notarial act will not be recognised as a valid act or document. A reading of S. 14 does not indicate any such prohibition or exclusion. Notarial act in a foreign country having no reciprocal arrangement can be accepted into evidence if there is evidence to show that the person before whom the notarial act was done was a Notary Public and that the state in which the notarial act was done authorised him by law to do the notarial acts. If a notarial act takes place in a foreign country, the person asking the Court to accept the notarial acts done in a foreign country can do so by showing that the law of that country authorised notarial acts to be done by Notaries as they are so done in Bangladesh and by proving the authentication made by the Notary Public.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A power of attorney authenticated by a Magistrate in India will be admissible if it is proved that the Magistrate by law and practice having the force of law in India is authorised to authenticate power of attorney and that it was duly authenticated by the Magistrate.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Nurunnessa and others Vs. Babar Au Bepari and others, 1BLD (AD) 86</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref; 16 Cal 776; 25 Ch. D. 769; PLD 1969 (SC) 477; A.I.R. 1958(Andra Pradesh) 107 ;—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Sections—32 to 35</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Registration of document on the basis of power of attorney</strong>—If the Sub-Registrar is satisfied and presentation is accepted by him and he registers the document it is prima facie evidence that the conditions have been satisfied—There is presumption in law that official acts are regularly performed—There is an initial presumption that the document was duly presented and the person presenting was duly authorised—Once the plaintiff admits the endorsement in the document the burden shifts on the defendant to prove that the power of attorney was forged.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Md. Arshad Ali Vs. Abed Au and others, 4BLD (HCD) 150</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: A.LR. l922 (P.C.)279; AIR. 1934 (Lah) 452—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Sections— 47 and 60</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Documents of successive transfers— Dispute as to precedence of one document over the other—</strong>Whether the document registered earlier in point of time will prevail over the other ?—A document that has been registered relates back to the date of its execution and the question of title as between the two contestants claiming on the basis of successive documents executed by the selfsame vendor must be determined with reference to the title to the latter on the date of execution and not of registration.<strong><em>Mir Abdul Ali Vs. Md. Rafiqul Islam, 8BLD (AD) 73 and 149</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 9 DLR 258; 15 DLR 77: A.I.R. 1941 Pat 247—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Sections—47 and 60</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Accrual of right of Pre-emption</strong>—Long line of decisions of the erstwhile Dhaka High Court has followed the principle that the date of accrual of the right of pre-emption is not the date of execution of the sale deed but the date of registration under section 60 of the Registration Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Abdul Motalib Vs. Imam Ali Mollah and others. 10BLD (AD) 160: 42DLRC4D) 123</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 13 DLR889: 17 DLR 365; 17 DLR 231; 20 DLR 355; 21 DLR599; 31 I)LR(AD)1 18; 34 DLR (AD) 220: 2 BCR (AD)87:—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—47</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Fraudulent operations of vendor</strong>—Section 47 of the Registration Act is designed to protect a vendee from the fraudulent operations of a vendor—This section applies when the same vendor successively transfers the same property to different purchasers at different times,</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Abdul Motalib Vs. Imam Ali Mollah, 10BLD (AD) 160: 42DLR (AD) 123</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 9 DLR 258: 21 DLR 599: 40 DLR(AD)75. —Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—47</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Which document prevails</strong>—When the same vendor executes and registers two sale deeds in respect of the same land in favour of two different purchasers on two different dates section 47 of the Act settles which one will prevail over the other. The sale-deed which was executed earlier but registered later in point of time will prevail over the other. The sale deed which was executed earlier but registered later in point of time and the criterion in such cases for the purpose of determining when the sale takes effect is not the date of registration hut the date of execution of the sale deed itself.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Md. Raiqu1 Islam Vs. Mir Abdul All, l2BLD (AD) 77</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 9 DLR258: 15 DLR77 (F.B.t— Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—49</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Unregistered deed of sale</strong>—Its evidentiary value in a suit for specific performance of contract—The unregistered deed of sale Ext. I has been admitted into evidence not as an evidence of title to the suit land but for a collateral purpose namely to prove the existence of an agreement for sale for the purpose of specific performance of contract—As such it cannot be treated as a substantive piece of document. It is only admissible to prove the existence of an agreement and not beyond that.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Shahadat Hossain and others Vs. Md. Jabed Ali, 4BLD (HCD) 215.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—60</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Right of pre-emption accrues on the date of registration—Stare decisis—An established precedent handed by past Judges.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Abdul Motalib Vs. Imam Ali Mollah and others, 10BLD (AD) 160: 42 DLR (AD) 123</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—77</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Registration of deed</strong>—Arbitrary and illegal refusal to register the deed presented with in the time—Registration authority wrongly refusing to register the deed the appellant should not be penalised for delay caused when there was no default on the art of the appellant.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A deed executed on 20.12.1971 was presented for registration on 27.3.1972. District Registrar refused registration without assignh’ g any reason. Appellant filed O.C. Suit No. 101 of 1972 under section 77 of the Registration Act and got decree on 31.12. 1973. The deed with copy of decree was presented for registration on 29.1.1974. Deed reciuired with endorsement that an affidavit was required. Appellant submitted application for permission but the prayer for registration was refused.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Court directed presentation of the deed for registration within 30 days from the order.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Md. Sajjad Au Vs. inspector General, Registration and others. 3BLD (AD)58</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—77</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Suit for registration of document</strong>— Scope of the suit against refusal of registration by the Registrar—It is well settled that in such a suit the Court is only concerned whether the document is executed by the person by whom it is alleged to have been executed and not its validity—The question of its validity must be determined in a suit properly framed for that purpose—The Court will not go to deal with the question that the deed is void for want of consideration or that it was obtained by fraud.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Md. Moshahaq Au and others Vs. Rabeya Khatuii and another, 6BLD (AD) 178</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 8DLR 648: A.I.R. 1932 Cal 588; AIR. 1921 Lahore 136; 14 C.W.N. 12; 17 DLR 476—Cited.</p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>

1220	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">SERVICES (RE- ORGANISATION AND CONDITIONS) ACT, 1975</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  9BLD (HCD)136</p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  1975</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  SERVICES (RE- ORGANISATION AND CONDITIONS) </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong> </strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>SERVICES (RE- ORGANISATION AND CONDITIONS) ACT, 1975</u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong>(XXXII of 1975)</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section —2 (b)</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>‘Pay’ — Definition of</strong> — Whether the self-same definition can be made applicable to office memorandums introducing Annual Festival Bonus, Dearness Allowance and Festival Allowance — Such Bonus and Allowances were no examples of statutory exercise of power — The memorandums were not published in the Bangladesh Gazette and not passed in exercise of powers under any provision of Act XXXII of 1975 wherein pay’ has been defined — These are executive orders for ex-gratia payments not in exercise of statutory power but in exercise of inherent discretionary power to grant financial relief — The definition of the word pay’ in the said Act cannot be imported in the office memorandums.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Md. Israil and others Vs. Secretary, Ministry of Industries and others, 9BLD (HCD)136.</em></strong></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
1221	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">SMALL CAUSES COURTS ACT, 1887</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  I BLD(AD)128, 11BLD (HCD) 79, 43DLR115, 1BLD (AD)95, 3 BLD(AD) 107, 3BLD(HCD)274, 4 BLD(AD)3, 8 BLD (AD) 210, 12 BLD (AD) 133   </p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  1887</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  SMALL CAUSES COURTS </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>SMALL CAUSES COURTS ACT, 1887</u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong>(IX OF 1887)</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section — 15</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S.C.C.Suit</strong> — Court has no jurisdiction to go into the question of title except incidentally or to set aside the decree of a civil Court</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Respondent filed S.C.C. suit ft)r eviction of the appellants from the suit premises claiming title to the premises on the basis of a decree for specific performance passed against the landlords of the appellants. Appellants challenged the title of the respondents contending that the decree was fraudulently obtained. The finding of the S.C. Court in substance has established that respondents succeeded in proving the relationship of landlord and tenant. But the S.C. Court proceeded to examine the paramount title of the respondents and held that the decree for specific performance was fraudulently obtainedand therefore the respondents did not acquire title to the suit premises and dismissed the suit.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The S.C.C. Judge had no jurisdiction to go into the question of paramount title and in doing so to set aside the decree of a Civil Court obtained by the predecessor of the plaintiff in a suit for specific performance of contract. The Small Causes Court has no jurisdiction to go into the question of title, except incidentally.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Sudhangshu Kuinar Chowdhury and another Vs. Md. Au Hossain and others, I BLD(AD)128</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 11 DLR 427 — Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Sections — 15. 16 and 23</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S.C.C. suit</strong>—The suit falling within the exclusive jurisdiction of the Small Causes Court Judge but erroneously tried by a Court other than the SCC Judge suffers from no legal infirmity and the trial cannot be vitiated. Section 23 of the Small Cause Courts Act negatives the proposition that section 16 of the Act altogether deprives the civil Court of the jurisdiction conferred by section 9 of the Code in respect of the Small Causes Suit.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Mst. Wahida Rashid and another Vs. Miron Mohammad Zahidul Huq, 11BLD (HCD) 79: 43DLR115.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: A.1.R.l956 (Mad) 610; 9 DLR (PC) o86; A.I.R.1956 (Mad) 611: 6DLR 588; 25 DLR 142: A,I.R.1938 (Rangoon) 35; 22 DLR 444— Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section — 17(1) Proviso</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S.C.C decree passed exparte</strong> — Application to set aside the decree — Deposit of decretal amount or furnishing of security with the application, not mandatory — Application to set aside the decree along with another application seeking Courts direction may be filed within the period of limitation—Court may pass order beyond the period of limitation giving direction — Compliance with the Courts direction within the time fixed by the</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Court — Application to set aside the decree is maintainable.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Benode Behari Saha Vs.Nitya Gopal Saha, 1BLD (AD)95</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: AIR. 1931 (Lah) 332; l.L.R. 43 (Mad) 597; (1894)108 P.R. 1894: (1910)54 P.R. 1910: 6 IC. 945; (1919) 50 IC. 917;</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">(189l)j8 Cal. 83; (1907) 9 Born. L.R. 883; (1905) 32 Cal. 339: 1 C.L.J.l43: I.L.R.43 (Mad)579: 55 IC. 977 (F.B); AIR. 1928 (All) 111: 53 All. 254: A.I.R. l93l(Lah)332; 54 C.W.N.(2DR)67; 24C.W.N. 380— Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section — 17(1)</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Application for setting aside an exparte deeree passed in a S.C.C. Suit</strong> — Conditions laid down in the proviso of section 17(1) of S.C.C. Act must be fulfilled normally —. But non-compliance with such conditions will not affect the order setting aside the exparte decree restoring the S.C.C. suit when it escaped notice of either of the Court or of the plaintiff- respondent leading to granting relief to the defendant — appellant — Plaintiff-respondent cannot be said to be prejudicially affected if the case is determined on merits in the presence of both parties — One cannot take advantage of his own wrong when, as in the pie- sent case, by taking no objection at the right moment before the right Court, one allows its machinery to function and takes objection at the conclusion of the case when it goes against him and this also not by an appropriate proceeding.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>A.K. Marshed Ahmed Vs. Md. Meher Ali and others, 3 BLD(AD) 107</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 33 DLR (AD)130—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section — 23</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S.C.C. Suit</strong> — <strong>Whether question of title can be decided in such a suit</strong> — S.C.C. Act gives discretion to the Court to return a plaint involving question of title — This power is discretionary and it is indicated that a Court of Small Cause has the power to decide incidentally question of title in a suit which is essentially a S.C.C. matter — In the instant case for eviction of a tenant the plaintiff wasnot required to prove his title to the suit premises — If he could prove that he had inducted the deceased defendant, any other person in his place would be estopped from denying the title of the plaintiff — Evidence Act. 1872(1 of 1872). S. 116.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Banu Gopal Lala Vs. Hajee Abdul Hainid Khan and others, 3BLD(HCD)274</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Sections —25 and 28A</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Revision</strong>—Whether revision lies against an order of transfer of a S.C.C. suit by the District Judge — Reivisional jurisdiction when attracted — It is attracted only in a case decided by a Small Causes Court to satisfy whether the decree or order made by such Court was according to law — Revisional jurisdiction under section 25 S.C.C. Act does not confer power of revision of an order of transfer of a S.C.C. suit under section 28A.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Abdul Khalek Mia Vs. Maya Debi and others, 4 BLD(AD)3</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. AiR. 1938 Lahore 95; (1887)18 Q.B.D.704 — Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section — 25</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Revision</strong>—Whether appeal or revision lies against a decision in a suit of the nature of small causes — No appeal lies against a decision in a suit of the nature of small causes if the Court trying had S.C.C. jurisdiction but a revision will lie before the High Court.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Mosammat Khorshed Akhtar Khanam Vs. Haji Mohammad Ayub Hossain, 4BLD (HCD) 62</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 25DLR 142: 1 2DLR380; 29DLR3 14; 29DLR380 — Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section — 25</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Attornment — Tenant’s plea against attornment when cannot be considered</strong> — Defendant contends hat mere deposit of rent did not ipso facto prove attornrnent by him to the palintilis predecessor — The contention cannot be considered because it is found that the question of attornment was not raised either in the pleading or in the proceeding at any time — There is no substance in the question raised that there existed no relationship of landlord and tenant between the parties.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Shambhu Nath Saha Vs. Alfazuddin Ahniçd and others, 8 BLD (AD) 210</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 33DLR(AD)37 — Cited</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section — 25</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Revision</strong>—Scope, reversal of finding of S,C.C. Court by the High Court Division. whether justified — Trial Courts finding based on elaborate and detailed consideration of both the documentary evidence (Ext.A) and the attendant circumstances, the High Court Division exceeded its revisional jurisdiction under se n 25 of the Small Cause Courts Act in reversing the finding of fact arrived at by the trial Court which decreed the suit for eviction of the tenant. The reversal of the finding of fact on the grounds stated by the High Court Division is totally unwarranted. The High Court Division itself has failed to read the judgment of the learned S.C.C. Judge properly.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Md. Abdur Razzaq alias Md. Raja Miah Vs. Md. Ansar Au and another, 12 BLD (AD) 133</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 32 DLR (AD) 170—Cited.</p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>

<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  8BLD HCD)403</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  SONALI BANK STAFF SERVICE</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>SONALI BANK STAFF SERVICE RULES</u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Rules — 40, 42(ii)</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Departmental proceedings</strong>—Whether enquiry done by an officer not appointed by the authority having the power to dismiss the employee vitiates proceeding — The report of the, Enquiry Officer was forwarded to the Managing Directors and the Central Board of Director of the Bank after examining the report dismissed the plaintiff — Findings of the District Judge that the departmental proceeding and appointment of Enquiry Officer were not made by the Central Board of directors and his judgment and decree based thereon cannot be maintained—Bangladesh Bank (Na-aonalisation) Order. 1972 (P.O. 26 of 1972), Art. 10.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>General Manager, Sonali Bank and ors.
