MIS. Zennath Textile Mills Limited and others, 8BLD(AD)189</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Sections—19, 144 and 1444</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Presumption of correctness in respect of S.A. Khatian and R.S. Khatian</strong>—Every entry in a record of right prepared or revised under section 144 shall be evidence of the matter referred to in such entry and shall be presumed to be correct until it is proved by evidence to be incorrect—But such presumption is not attached to an entry in a record of right prepared or revised under Chapter IV of the SAT. Act. — To say that the entry in a record of right has a presumption of co1Tect- ness is to read something into the statute which is not there in it.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Ahmed Meah Mistty Vs. Abdul Majid, SBLD(HCD)47</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. I9DLR 9—Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—20( 4)</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Retention of excess lands</strong>—Application for such retention can be made by rent-receivers, cultivating raiyats or under-raiyats— Subsequent partners though may claim interest in the property of the firm are not entitled to claim retention of excess lands — They cannot continue with any suit challenging the refusal to grant permission to retain excess land held by the original partners who were rent-receivers — Partnership Act, 1932 (IX of 1932),S. l4—P.O. 98 of 1972, Articles 3 and 4.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>M/s. Farmers and Co. Vs. Sree Monotosh Bera and another, 2BLD(HCD)181</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—20(2a)</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Hat and Bazar—</strong>If a hat sits once a week regularly, then whether it will come under the mischief of the Act? If we read the “expression” particular days” in the definition of ‘hat or bazar together and give the necessary emphasis the word particular’ deserves, then it will be clear that ‘days’ will also include a day as well in view of sub-section (2) of section 13 of the General Clauses Act and in view of the history of the legislation of the acquisition of inte’est in hats and bazars by the Government.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Government of Bangladesh Vs. Shakhipur Islamia High School, 12BLD(AD)170</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 15 DLR 37; 11 DLR (SC)3l6; 15 DLR(SC)l39: 27DLR98; 9DLR674; 16 DLR (SC)28 I; 2ODLR 18(1 968) ;25DLR476— Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—20</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Fishery non</strong>—retainable—Fishery’ is a non-retainable khas land under section 20 of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act and it vested absolutely in the Government.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Sharping Matsh&amp;ibi Samabaya Samity Ltd. Vs. Bangladesh and others, 7BLD’AD) 106</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—44( 3)</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Vesting of Hats and Bazar</strong>—Hats and Bazars belonging to the rent receivers vested in the Government with effect from the date of notification in 1956 and the Hats and Bazars belonging to the raiyats vested in the Government after the final publication of the compensation assessment roll.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Shamsur Rahnzan Khan and others Vs. Government of Bangladesh, 3BLD(HCD) 284</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 25DLR 248 and 476; I6DLR(SC) 281; 25DLR284 — Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—75A</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>No estoppel against Statute</strong>—Whether this rule of law can be invoked by one to take advantage of his own fraud?—The rule is attracted only when its invocation will defeat the public policy behind statute—If, in disregard of the obligation imposed by section 75A upon the landlord he has alienated his land he cannot subsequently raise an objection to nullify his own auction—The plaintiff—appellant has filed the suit certainly not for the benefit of the Government. nor can there be any reason to suppose that the statutory provisions would be nullified if the declaration sought for is not granted—If he is allowed to succeed it will allow him to take advantage of his own fraud—Evidence Act, 1 872 (I of 1872), S. 115.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Sree Sudir Chandra Saha and another Vs Matuan Bewa, being dead her heirs Nazmul Rahman Sarker and others, 6BLD (AD)182</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. AIR. 1937 (PC) 114; (1903) 30 l.A. 114; (1964) I6DLR(SC)685; —Cited</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—75A</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Sub-letting prohibited</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">No person shall sub-let any land in his khas possession in the area to which a notification under section 17(3) or 3 1(1) relates Section 75A inserted by the East Bengal Act XII of 1954 and amendment by East Pakistan Act IV of 1956 on 13.4.1956—Notification referred to section 75A(l) stated to be one under section 17(3) and section 31(3) and both the sections come under Chapter IV and not under Chapter V of the Act—Kabuliat settlement of land on 12.4.56 (in the District of Faridpur ) is within the mischief of section 75A of the Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Taham Gazi Vs. Promila Promanik, 11BLD (HCD) 99</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—76</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Family— What it means</strong>— The expression ‘family’ is to be understood in the height of the given enactment—In so far as settlement of khas land is concerned the expression ‘family’ has not been used in definite sense—The emphasis is only that the land should be cultivable by himself or by members of the family— Evidence was led by the plaintiff to prove that his nephew ploughed the land who resided with him—This evidence was not rebutted—So it cannot be said that the plaintiff did not answer the description of the persons to whom settlement could be made.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Province of East Pakistan (Now Bangladesh) Vs. Syeduddin Ahmed, 4 BLD (AD) 61.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Sections—76 and 148</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Settlement of Government khas land</strong>— Whether can be made to Government servants. their children of female members of the family of a Government servant—Whether such settlement is valid by lapse of time—No settlement of Government khas land can be made in favoui of Government servants, their children or female members of their family— the plaintiff respondents being sons of a Government servant were not entitled to take settlement of Government khas land—Any settlement granted in violation of express provisions of law and Government Circular cannot become valid by any lapse of time—There is no provision of law to cure such illegality—In view of the fraud subsequently revealed vitiating the transaction, delay is no bar to the cancellation.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>The People’s Republic of Bangladesh, represented by the Deputy Commissioner, Maymensingh and others Vs. Satyendra Kishore Roy; 6BLD(AD)169</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—76</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Government’s right to deal with its properties by granting lease or license</strong>--- Lease or license granted by the Government— Whether Government is entitled to deal with its property in any manner it likes or award a contract to any person it chooses without any constitutional limit upon it—Lease or licence to use Government property is regulated by the state for the welfare of its people—Lease of fishery exclusively owned by the Government is a new kind of wealth which the Government distributes by way of settlement amongst the class of people who deserves it— In doing so Government was to enter into agreement but such lease agreement can by no stretch of imagination be termed as ordinary contract entered into by two individuals as trading ventures—On the other hand, when the Government deals with this new kind of wealth for the welfare of the citizens and regulates distribution of such wealth by way of settlement or lease, the Government acts in its sovereign capacity—When authority over- steps or commits breach of rule or even commits breach of principle of natural justice the same can be challenged by filing writ petition—Government Estate Manual, 1958, Rules 205 and 206.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Fishery is non-retainable khas land under section 20 of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act and it vested absolutely in the Government. Under section 76 of this Act it lies at the disposal of the Government who may either manage it as khas or make settlement thereof in accordance with rules to be made by them.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Sharping Matshajibi Shamabaya Sainity Ltd. Vs. Bangladesh and others, 7BLD(AD, 106</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. A.I.R. I 979(SC) 1628; 1 BLD(AD) 105 —Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Sections—51 and 81A</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Pre-emption—Non-agricultural land</strong>— Omission of sub-section (2) and (3) in section 81 and insertion of section 81A in State Acquisition and Tenancy Act have not rendered section 24 of Non-Agricultural Tenancy Act ineffective or impliedly repealed—Section 24 of Non-Agricultural Tenancy Act and not section 96 of State Acquisition and Tenancy Act is applicable for pre-emption of land falling within Municipal area.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Md. Abdur Rouf and others Vs. Ahmuda Khatun and others, 1BLD(AD)269</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—86</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Diluvion and extinguishment of tenant’s right—</strong>When diluvion had taken place before commencement of P.O. No. 135 of 1972 and the lands reappeared before the commencement of the Order, the right, title and interest of the tenant got extinguished with the diluvion—The lands having reappeared before the commencement of the Order, it vested absolutely in the Government free from all encumbrances to be at its disposal until the tenant’s right to re-possession was finally recognised by a competent authority—Presidents Order No. 135 of 1972, Article. 2.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Syed Nizamuddin Mohsin being dead his heirs Vs. People’s Republic of Bangladesh and others, 9BLD(AD)116</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 31 DLR(AD) 195 — Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Sections — 86(5) and 87(3)</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Sections—86(5) and 87 (3) as amended by P.O. Nos. 72 of 1972, 135 of 1972 and 137 of 1972</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Abatement of all suits, application, appeals or other proceedings. The present suit comes within the mischief of subsection (5) of section 86 as well as sub-section (3) of Section 87 of the Act which provides for abatement of all such appeals and suits. In that view of the matter the appeal is clearly liable to abate there under.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The expression used in sub-section (5) of section 86 and sub-section(3) of section 87 of the Act gave rise to a great deal of controversy as to the extent of their retrospectively at one time but the point is no longer res integra. The suits, applications, appeals and other legal proceedings referred to in sub-section(S) must necessarily involve claims which come within the mischief of sub-sections (2) and (3) of section 86 and relate to lands which are lost by diluvion after the commencement of the Order as well as lands which are lost by diluvion before the commencement of the Order but have re-appeared after coming into force of Part V of the Act. It is further laid down in that decision that sub-section (3) should be read -harmoniously with sub-section (1) and (2) and the land gained or alleged to have. been gained from the recess of a river or the sea as have been contemplated in sub-section (3) must be such lands as are within the purview of sub-sections (1) and (2) of sections 87 “and” it will necessarily be those accreted lands which have appeared as hard soil only after the coming into force of Part V of the Act and the provision as to the bar and abatement of suits etc. as made in sub-section (3) are attracted in case of those suits where a claim of the right IS asserted in respect of such lands.”</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Government of Bangladesh Vs. A. Wahed Sikder and others, 10BLD (HCD)270</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 5 BCR(AD)29; 4BCR(AD)60: 4BLD (AD)209; 35DLR(AD) 1; 3BLD(AD)10: 2 BCR(AD)373; 31 DLR(AD) 195; — Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Sections—86(3) and 146</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Settlement of land vested in the Government by Revenue Authorities</strong>—The Government was not empowered under any provision of law to pass the impugned order of cancellation and revise the order passed by the Revenue Officer granting settlement to the petitioner and his co-tenants.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Section 146(1), therefore, shows that the general power of superintendence and control over all Revenue Officers is vested in the Board of Land Administration and not in the Government. Moreover, section 146(1) vests the Board of Land Administration with administrative control over the revenue Officers and by no means empowers it to revise the orders passed by the Revenue Officers under the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 195(1. The powers of appeal, revision and review are in sections 147 to 151 Of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950. The power of section 146 does not, therefore, include the power to revise the orders of a Revenue officer and this aspect of the legal provision was candidly accepted by Mr. Ahmed while arguing for respondent No &amp; Nothing has been placed before us to show that the Government is empowered under any provision of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, the cancel or rescind any order passed by the revenue authorities.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Saifur Rahman Vs. Government of Bangladesh and others, 10BLD (HCD) 286</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—87</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Accretion of land to the holding of a tenant</strong>—If such accretion is by artificial or mechanical process due to development work—Whether such increment will form part of the holding of the tenant—As the suit was filed in 1963 and Ordinance No. VIII of 1967 was not retrospective in nature the accretion of the land to the holding due to development work would not deprive the plaintiff from the same—Plaintiffs suit is not also hit by abatement clause nor his right is disturbed by the operation of sub-section (2) because the provision is also not retrospective but prospective.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Makku Mian and others Vs. Act restricting its application to any particular class of land—After the enactment of S.A.T. Act or section 26C of the B.T..Act as to exclude the operation of section 129 of the Transfer of Property Act in case of transfer of agricultural land. If lands as provided in section 129 of T.P. Act has exempted the owner of urban property, which are generally more valuable than agricultural lands from transferring the same by a registered instrument, why should greater hardship be imposed on the holder of agricultural lands by the requirement of a registered instrument for transferring his interest therein by way of gift judged from different view points. The effectiveness of an oral gift of immoveable, property when properly made has not been curtailed by the language of section 26C of the Bengal Tenancy Act or section 89 of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act in so far as it has been preserved by section 129 of the Transfer of Property Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Jobed Ali Vs. Nazir Ahmed, 2 BLD (AD) 151.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—95A</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Section 95A of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act as amended by P.O. 88 of 1972, P.O. 136 of 1972 and P.0.24 of 1973 is not discriminatory and does not violate fundamental right relating to property.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">By P.ONo. 88 of 1972, P.O. No. 136 of 1972 and P.0.No. 24 of 197 the provisions of section 95 of State Acquisition and Tenancy Act have been amended and section 95A has been inserted and amended whereby them period of complete usufructuary mortgage has been reduced to 7 years, a summary procedure for redemption and restoration of possession by and to mortgagor has been provided and it has been provided that an out and out sale with agreement for reconveyance shall be deemed to be a complete usufructuary mortgage for a period not exceeding 7 years. It was contended that S.95A as amended is violative of Articles 27 and 42 of the Constitution.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">S. 95A is not a discriminatory legislation inasmuch as indebted agricultural tenants who constitute poorer section of the people may be regarded as a class apart for which there appears to be a rational basis having a just and reasonable relation to the object of the legislation. The removal of factual, social and economic discrimination by legislation is not only sanctioned by the Constitution, it is supported by well established canon of interpretation, viz, the beneficial rule.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Complete usufructuary mortgage presupposes the restoration of land to the transferor either by redemption or by efflux of time.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Bangladesh Vs. HajiAbdul Gani Biswas and others, 1BLD(AD)8</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 50 C.W.N. 578;(1910) AC 220 (223); (1857)6 H.L. Case 61(106); 661. A. 50 —Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section— 95A</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Usufructuary mortgage</strong>—A transfer of a holding by way of an out and out sale with an agreement to recovery or whether the transferor receives from the transferee any consideration and the transferee acquires the right to possess and enjoy the usufruct of such holding etc. for a specified period in lieu of such consideration, shall notwithstanding anything contained in the documents relating to the transfer, be deemed to be a complete usufructuary mortgage for a period not exceeding 7 years.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Asmatunnessa and others Vs. Serina Beguin and others, 1BLD(HCD)350</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—96 (3)(a)</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Pre-emption</strong> — Deposit of consideration—If application for pre-emption is made within the period of limitation and the consideration money is also deposited in Court within the period of limitation, it shall be deemed that the deposit has been made while making the application for pre-emption.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Md. Mafizuddin Sarkar Vs. Md. A. Jabbar Akhand, 1BLD (HCD) 486</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Pre-emption by a Hindu Widow</strong>—Preemption—Cosharer—A Hindu widow having life interest in a holding is a cosharer tenant of the holding and is entitled to pre-empt transfer of land of the holding.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Rai Kishori Saha Vs. Bharat Au Sardar and others, 2BLD (HCD)1l9</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—96</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Pre-emption—Application for preemption by contiguous landholder</strong>—Preemptor’s land contiguous to some of the plots</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">transferred, but the plots transferred are coii tiguous to each other and in a compact block— Pre-emptor entitled to pre-empt all the plots transferred—Pre-emption is allowed to help consolidation and amalgamation of holdings.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Haji Tajamal All Vs. Abdus Sattar and others, 3BLD (AD) 6</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 31 DLR (AD) 88; 32DLR (AD)54-- Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section —96</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Pre-emption</strong>—Application for pre-emption filed before the registration of the kabala in question was complete—Application premature—Prematurity can be cured if at the time of the trial the kabala was registered, otherwise prematurity would remain—When the question of prematurity was raised only at the appellate stage and registration was complete during the pendency of the appeal, prematurity held cured at the appellate stage.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Lebu Miah Vs. Ganesh Chandra Nath and others, 3 BLD (AD)57</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 31 DLR(AD) 118 — Cited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section — 96 (10)(a)</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Transfer to co-sharer by inheritance</strong>— <strong>not pre-emptible</strong>—Transfer to a co-sharer whose interest in the tenancy accrued by inheritance cannot be pre-empted—Even if the father of such cosharer acquired interest in the tenancy by purchase he is a cosharer by inheritance—Transfer to such a cosharer by inheritance is immune from pre-emption.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Abdul Haque Miah and another Vs. Abdur Rashid and others, 3BLD(AD)103</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Pre-emption—</strong>Pre-emption cannot be refused on the ground that a sub-tenancy has been recorded in S.A. Khatian when the document mentions the land by CS. Khatian and C.S. Plots.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Jaynal Abedin Molla Vs. A liar Rahman and others, 3BLD (AD)105</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Sectlon—96</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Hindu Widow</strong> —Right to claim preemption — During the period of her life time a Hindu widow is a complete owner and co sharer of any property or holding in question with the right to claim partition and consequently she has the right to claim preemption—Hindu Women’s Right to Property Act, 1937(XVIII of 1937), S.3</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Rai Kishori Saha Vs. Md. Motaleb Mi and others, 3BLD(HCD)</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section–96</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Pre-emption</strong>--Omission to record a finding that pre-emptor is a person to whom transfer by pre-emption can be made as envisaged under section 90 S.A.T. Act cannot be a ground for dismissal of the case.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Shahidur Rahman Molla and others Vs. Abdul Halim Molla &amp; ors., 3 BLD (HCD) 89.</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 13DLR 338; 2IDLR 599; 29DLR 153: 26DLR 93: IBLD 121; 1BLD(AD)280— Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—96</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Defect of party</strong>—No such objection specifically raised by the pre-emptee in written objection—Defect of party disclosed in evidence —Pre-emptees not entitled to take advantage of the same. The case cannot fail as the parties are not on contest as to defect of party.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Skahidur Rahrnan Molki and others Vs. Abdul Halim Molla &amp; ors., 3 BLD (HCD) 89.</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 31 DLR(AD)88— Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—96</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Pre-emption</strong>—Reconveyance of the land under pre-emption before filing the case if defeats right of pre-emption--If the land in question is reconveyed to the original owner before the starting of the proceeding for preemption, the right to pre-emption does not exist.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Ramesh chandra Barman and others Vs. Naresh Chandra Barman and others, 3 BLD(HCD)99</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 29DLR 229; IBCR. 27—Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—96(2)</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Pre-emption case</strong> —Omission of a necessary party is fatal to pre-emption case—Respondent No. I being a co-sharer was a necessary party in the pre-emption proceeding— Failure to make her a party in the proceeding has vitiated it—The mere fact that her name was not disclosed did not absolve the preemptors of their mandatory duty to impleaci her by ascertaining necessary particulars.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Jalaluddin Fakir Vs. Shahjahan All Molla and others, 4BLD(AD)27</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 33DLR(AD)l 13—Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section— 96</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Question of benami in a pre-emption case</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Benami transaction—Question of benami nature of the disputed kabala cannot be gone into and determined in a proceeding for preemption—But if a pre-emption is sought to be resisted on the ground that no transfer took place under the relevant kabala in that the vendor did not part with possession but simply made a show of transfer, then such a transaction may be looked into.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Ash win Kumar Karmaker being dead his heirs Vs. Han Mohan Shil and others, 4BLD (AD)29</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 51C.W.N.644; 6DLR589; 45C.W.N. 658; 16DLR(SC) 155—Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Sction—96(2)</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Waiver of right of preemption</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Question of waiver of right to preemption—The appellant was impleaded both as an opposite party and as a petitioner and though these two parties were the same persons, they were impleadèd separately—On his death exemption from substitution was sought and granted in respect of the opposite party, but no exemption was sought for and granted in respect of the petitioner—In this circumstances, it is difficult to conclude that the heirs of the appellant would not have claimed rateable pre-emption if substituted— The provision of making parties being mandatory, waiver of right to pre-emption cannot be presumed on a hypothetical ground that heirs of the appellant would not have claimed preen-lption.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Abdul Hamid Bhuiyan and others Vs. Dengua Mia, 4BLD(AD)32</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section— 96</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Right of pre-emption</strong>—Whether such right is extinguished by subsequent reconveyance to the vendor—Since the right of preemptibn accrues on the transfer of a holding the vendee cannot defeat the pre—emption right by taking the plea that the land has been reconveyed to the vendor when he is still in possession of the same—Sham transfer or colourable agreement will not stand in the way when the case of pre-emption is made out— Though the reconveyance had been effected but the vendee is still in possession and therefore the right of pre-emption subsists.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Md. Sukur Au Vs. Sree Suresh Chandra Barman and others, 4BLD(AD)219</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section — 96(4)</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Rateable Pre-emption</strong>—Pre-emptor is cosharer by purchase—Pre-emptee purchased lands of the holding by two different kabalas both being executed on 21.1.75 and registered on 17.12.77, registration Nos. being 24655 and 24656—Pre-emptor filed case for preemption of the kabala with registration No. 24656—Pre-emptee claimed rateable preemption as a co-sharer by purchase by virtue of the kabala with registration No. 24655— Pre-emptee is a co-sharer and entitled to rateable pre-emption.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Md. Riazul Karim Vs. Mst. Shirin Begum, 4BLD(HD)135</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 9DLR 258; 35DLR(AD)182—Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section— 96(4)</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Formal application for rateable preemption—</strong>According to section 96(4) a cosharer tenant including the transferee could apply to seek rateable pre-emption--No formal application for rateable pre-emption is necessary—Prayer for rateable pre-emption in written objection is sufficient.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Md. Riazul Karim Vs. Mst. Shirin Begum, 4BLD(HCD)135</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 5DLR254—Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section— 96</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Doctrine of us pendens</strong> —Its applicability in a pre-emption case—The right of preemption, in a case of the present nature, is not absolute but is subject to the agreement for reconveyance—If the land has already been reconveyed during the pendency of the preemption case the doctrine of lis pendens can- not come to the rescue of the pre-emption— Transfer of Property Act, 1882 (VI of 1882)S.52.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Serajul Haque and others Vs. Ahmed Husain and others, 4BLD(HD)194</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 35DLR(AD)225; I 3DLR287—Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section — 96(2)</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Necessary parties</strong>—All co-sharers by inheritance, recorded or not recorded, are necessary parties in a pre-emption case and this is mandatory—The requirement of law will be frustrated if some co-sharers are not made parties in the case.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Zainul Abedin Vs. Syed Hashmatullah and others, 4BLD(HCD)272</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 28DLR(AD)5: 33DLR(AD)l 13; 21 DLR262—Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section-96 </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Partial preemption</strong>—Whether the preemptor whose land is not contiguous to the entire land of the transferred plot is entitled to pre-empt the entire land without depositing the actual value—He may pre-empt only that part of the land transferred to which his land is contiguous unless the land transferred is a compact block of area—There is no evidence regarding extent of contiguity of the preemptor’s land sought to be pre-empted or as to which of the pre-emptors land is contiguous to the said land and whether it is a compact block or divided into well demarcated separate plots—For determining the extent of con-tiguity between the lands concerned and actual value of the lands sought to be preempted the case should, be sent back on remand.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Masood (Mashood) Ali Vs. Mosaminat Samira Banit and others, 5BLD (AD)70</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 31 DLR(AD)88; 32DLR(AD)54: I977BSCR397; 34DLR(AD)2 17—Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section— 96(4)</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Limitation for filing application for rateable pre-emption</strong>—Whether a transferee from contiguous owner is to file such application within two months mentioned in section 96(4) of S.A.T. Act, or he can file the case beyond that period—Such a transferee must come within the period of limitation applicable to a transferee co-sharer tenant— When the contiguous land owner is bound by the period of limitation. a transferee from this category cannot be left free to seek ‘preemption whenever he likes.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Adeluddin Kha,z being dead his heirs: Abdur Rahinan Khan and ‘others Vs. Md. Shahjahan Mb (Minor) and others; 5BLD (AL)82</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Scction—96</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Question of title in a pre-emption case</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Whether the Court can enter into investigation regarding title of the vendor in such a proceeding?—When entire consideration money has been deposited with a prayer to pre-empt only half of the land whether it can be said to be a case of partial pre-ernption— When the prayer in the application for preemption is for apart only of the entire land the Court is not required to make the deduction that prayer must be read in respect of the whole—the Court cannot enter into investigation regarding title of thevendor in the case.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Hatem Au Mollah and others Vs. Hayet Khan and others, 5BLD(AD)183</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—96</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Pre-emption</strong>--Whether transfer to a co-sharer by purchase is premptible by a ‘contiguous land holder—If a land has been transferred to a co-sharer and when no other co-sharer has claimed pre-emption, the transfer is immune, by necessary implication to preemption, by a contiguous land holder.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Md. Azimuddin Pramanik and others Vs. Sree Satya Narayan Prainanik and others, 6 BLD(AD)98</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 6DLR 130—Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section— 96</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Right of Pre-emption</strong>—A mere decree in a suit for specific performance of a contract does not confer right of pre-emption</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Whether a person obtaining a decree for specific performance of contract for sale and before execution and registration of the sale deed is a co-sharer in the holding relating to the decretal land—Respondent is claiming to pre-empt on the ground that he became a cosharer by virtue of a decree which he obtained in his suit for specific performance of contract—His status , as, a co-sharei would have been established if he obtained a registered kabala in pursuance of the decree—Since he did not obtain the kabala as yet he is not a cosharer in the holding.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Mst. Maleka Khatun and another Vs. Abid Au and others, 6BLD(AD)137</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—96</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Amendment of pre-emption application</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Whether amendment of pre-emption petition making a new claim on the basis of contiguous ownership will change the nature and character of the case specially when it is barred by limitation—No amendment is allowed where its effect will take away any legal right accrued to the other party by lapse of time or if the amendment introduces a totally new and inconsistent case—The appellant claimed pre-emption either as a co-sharer or as a tenant holding land contiguous to the land transferred —This was necessary because the respondent took the plea that on the basis of a mutation case a separate khatian had already been created —In the present case no legal right has accrued to the pre-emptee—Once an amendment is made the amendment will relate back to the date of institution of the case.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Sree Shushil Ranjan Dutta Vs. Al-haj Moulvi Idris Mia, 6BLD(AD)221</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: BSCR (1979) 135; PLD1948 (P.C.) 73; 15DLR(SC) 120—Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—96</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Admission in pleading</strong>—Whether a party making such admission is bound by it—The pre-emptors in the application for pre-emption stated that they mutated their names by separating the jama by filing separation case — Whether the pre-emptors are bound by such admission—Admission is no doubt a strong evidence against its maker but it is also open to him to adduce evidence to show that it is not in fact an admission but is the result of bonafide mistake of fact —All important questions as to separation of jama and payment of rent separately have not been decided by the Courts below—Determination of this question is necessary for deciding the pre-emption case.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Be gum Khodeza Akhter Vs. Hajera Khatun and others, 6BLD(AD)161</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—96(4)</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Functus officio</strong>—Whether the Court is functus officio and cannot extend time to deposit money for rateable pre-emption—The trial Court while allowing rateable preemption directed that in case the appellant failed to deposit money within two months his application for rateable pre-emption ‘shall stand dismissed—The order being capable of automatic operation it became final when the default occurred—The trial Court rightly refused extension of time on the ground that it became functus officio.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Abdul Hadi Bepari Vs. Safaruddin Mondal and others, 6BLD(AD)332</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Seetion—96(6)(b)</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Rateable pre-emptionad justment of deposit</strong>e—Whether the Court can direct to adjust the amount to be deposited for rateable pre-emption in favour of the transferee from the amount deposited by the pre-emptor in his favour—Deposit’ for rateable pre-emption by a subsequent claimant being a transferee, the Court may in its discretion exempt a transferee—pre-emptee from making the deposit and to adjust the amount due from him against pre-emption money already deposited, if a prayer is made to the Court in appropriate time.’</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Abdul Hadi Bepari Vs. Safaruddin Mondal and others, 6BLD(AD)332</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—96</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Withdrawal of part deposit by some pre-emptors</strong>—---Withdrawal of part deposit by some of the pre-emptors who decided not to proceed with the case and deposit of the said amount by the remaining pre-emptors whether can be allowed by the Court—In any case the contesting pre-emptors cannot be non-suited for the steps taken by the non-contesting preemptors—The contesting pre-emptors cannot be blamed and made to suffer for withdrawal from the case by the non-testing pre-emptors —The pre-emption case when filed was legally instituted with full deposit—The Court is not powerless to allow intermediary steps required to be taken by any party to maintain the pre-emption proceeding which was legal and valid when instituted.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Md. Jamiluddin and others Vs. Md. Alimuddin and others, 6BLD(HCD)32</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—96</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Question of sale or exchange?</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In a pre-emption proceeding the question whether the transaction by the purported sale under pre-emption is sale or exchange can be decided—Whether evidence can be adduced to prove that the document is not what it purports to be?—When the disputed kabala is between stranger to the document in question and a party thereto there is no bar in leading oral evidences to prove that the document in question is not what it purports to be but when it is between the parties to the document such evidences are not admissible—There is no error of law in holding that the transaction is an exchange and not a sale and as such exempted from pre-emption—Evidence Act, 1872 ( 1 of 1872), Ss. 91 and 92.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Brindaban Das and another Vs. Ershad Au Mondal, 6BLD(HCD)85</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 26DLR(SC)59; 35DLR(AD)230; I 7DLRI 5; AIR. 1958(SC) 448—Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—96</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Right of Pre-emption</strong>—Acquiescence and estoppel—When the pre-emptor negotiates the sale under pre-emption or the facts are such that his acquiescence can be safeI’ concluded, the doctrine of estoppel comes into full play—His conduct will be a bar even though he files his application for pre-emption in a statutory right.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Moulana Abdul Karim Vs. Nurjahan Begurn and others, 6BLD(HCD)125</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: A.i.R. 1968(SC)933; PLDI96I(SC) 436(444); 22DLR 449: A.I.R. 1928(PC)190 AIR. 1925 (Lahore)57; A.I.R. 1947 (Oudh) 81; A.I.R. 1951 (Nagpur) 451; AIR. 1950 (Madhaya Bharat)85—Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—96</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Reconveyance during pre-emption proceeding</strong>—Whether right of pre-emption subsists even after reconveyance of the property to the vendor after filing the case but before final order of pre-ernption?—Pre-emption right is not a right in the property but a right of substitution in place of the vendee—Jt is a right to he substituted in place of the vendee— If the final order cannot be made under sub-section (7) of section 96 of the S.A.T. Act for any reason the pre-emptor does not acquire any interest in the property sold—The section takes for granted that the right of pre-emption and the sale giving rise to cause of action will subsist till the final order is made—If the preemptor’s interest in the holding is lost or the sale is rendered non-existent the proceeding for pre-emption becomes infructuous—There is no prohibition for reconveyance of the property to the vendor during pendency of preemption proceeding—After such reconveyance right of pre-ernption is lost.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Md. Abbas Ali Vs. Md. Osinan Au and others, 6BLD(HCD)130</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 29DLR 153; 1 B.C.R.(AD)l70; 35 DLR 79; 29 DLR 229: 1 B.C.R. 27; 35 DLR (AD) 225: AIR. 1958 (SC) 838; l.L.R. 7 All 665; ISDLR 317;—Cited</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—96</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Sub division of holding</strong>—After accrual of pre-eniption right sub-division of holding does not nullify the right of Pre-emption— Separate holding has been created in the name Qf the stranger—purchaser by way of mutation ?—Whether sub-division of the parent holding by mutation will create a bar for the exercise of right of pre-emption by the cosharer of the parent holding—For determining the rights of parties in a pre-emption case the original holding is to be conceived of as an unbroken unit, including the transferred portion despite its sub-division made after the transfer in question— Once the right of preemption has accrued to a co-sharer in a holding it cannot he defeated by subsequent sub-division of the holding, unless the transfer itself is nullified or the interest of the preemptor in the parent holding is extinguished before the final order is made on the preernption petition.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Raisuddiiz Molla and others Vs. Md. Golam Wahed and others, 6BLD(HCD)180</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: I B.C.R. (AD)194; 33DLR(AD)323; 26DLR(SC) 58: AIR. 1958(SC)838: I.L.R. 7 (All) 775—Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—96 (b)</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Pre-emption—Deposit of money</strong>—Coappli-cants obligation to make deposit of money when arises?—He is not required suo motu to deposit the money on his own computation— Until an order is made by the Court determining the amount to be paid by the coapplicants the consequences provided will not come into play.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Himaizghsu Bikash Singha Vs. Mvi. Sirajul islam and others, 7BLD(HCD)423</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section— 96</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Single application for more than one transfers—</strong>Whether one app licati on for preemption of land transferred by two kabalas is maintainable—li is not the requirement of law that a pre-emptor is to file separate application for each transfer—The lower appellate Court committed an error of law in hol-ding that a single application was not main-tamable n view of the provisions of the Code of Civil Procedure—Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 (V of 1908), Or. 2 Rs. 2 and 3.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Sree Jitendra Nath Howlader Vs. Sree Bi,cweswar Howlader and others, 8BLD (HCD)421</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 23 DLR 68—Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—96</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>‘Knowledge’</strong>—Determinant for knowledge to take a pre-emption proceeding—The pre-emptors initial knowledge that the plot in question was sold would not help him in a bid to file a pre-emption case—Knowledge as referred to in the Act means and includes a definite and complete knowledge in order to file a petition for pre-emption.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Abdul Sattar and another Vs. Osimuddin and others, 8BLD(HCD)197</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 29DLR 178—Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section — 96(7)(6)</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Subsequent transferees’ right to deposited money</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Deposit made with pre-emption petition</strong>—Subsequent transferees’ entitlement to the money in deposit—After the application for pre-emption, the property was again transferred and the petitioners having stepped therebyinto the shoes of the pre-emptee, they are permitted to withdraw the consideration and statutory money compensation deposited in the case,</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Abdul Sattar and another Vs. Osimuddin and others, 8BLD(HCD)197</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 35 DLR(HC)238.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section— 96</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Defect of party</strong>—Consequence of failure to implead a co-sharer in a pre-emption proceeding—Nurul Islam being a co-sharer in one of the plots of the khatian was certainly a cosharer in the holding in question—Failure of the pre-emptors to implead him in the application for pre-emption is a serious defect of party since impleading of a co-sharer, whether by inheritance or by purchase, is arnandatory provision of the law—The omission pointed out at the earliest point of time having not been supplied, the order of the High Court Division restoring the trial Courts order allowing pre-emption is not sustainable in law.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Sultan Ahmed and others Vs. Akhtaruzzaman and others, 10BLD(AD)23</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section— 96(3)(b)</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Pre-emption—Deposit of balance consideration money</strong> —Question of making deposit with statutory compensation within the specified period and after enquiry by the Court as to the amount to be deposited—When the pre-emptor prayed leave to deposit the balance consideration money with the statutory compensation the pre-emptees opposed the prayer—This showed they were trying tO frustrate the very pre-emption proceeding— The trial Court rightly granted the prayer; because the pre-emptor and the Court accepted the proportionate valuation of the land as pointed out by the pre-emptees themselves.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Selina Begum and another Vs. Mofizul islam and others, 10BLD(AD127</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section— 96</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Right of pre-emption accrues on completion registration</strong>—When registration is compulsory, the date of accrual of right df pre-emption is not the date of execution of the deed of sale or any earlier date or the date of presentation for registration but the date on which the deed of sale is registered and the title effectively passes—Cause of action for pre-emption accrues on the date of registration of kabala where registration is compulsory.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Abdul Motalib Vs. Imam Au Mollah and other BLD(AD)160</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 13DLR889: 17 DLR 365; 17 DLR 231; 20 DLR 355; 21 DLR 599; 31 DLg(AD) 118; 34 DLR (AD)220; BCR 1982 (AD) 87; 9DLR 258; 40 DLR (AD)75—Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—96</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Pre-emption</strong>—knowledge—Pre-emptor seek-ing pre-emption of case land—Trial Court refused pre-emption on the ground of lirnitation—.Appellate Court reversed the finding of the trial Court—In revision High Court DiviSiOn declined to interfere with the question on finding of fact—Appellate Division approving the stand of High Court Division dismissed the appeal holding that this being a finding purely of facts does not warrant interference in revision. The High Court Division rightly refused interference.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Sona Mia Vs. Abdul Khaleque, 10BLD (AD)209</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section— 96</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Accrual-of right topre-emption Limitation for</strong>—In case of pre-emption the date of registration of the document by which transfer of the property takes effect gives rise to accrual of the right of pre-emption— The sale deed in the present case was presented for registration on 2.12.75, but in fact it was registered on 24.10.79 and the pre-emption case was filed on 13.2.80—So finding by the appellate Court that the case was barred by limitation cannot be sustained.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Md. Golarn Mostafa Mridha Vs. An jut Ali Molla and others, 10BLD(HCD)252</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 33 DLR 254; I7DLR (Dac)365; 21 DLR(Dac) 588; 3:1 DLR(AD)1 I I;—Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section— 96</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Application of section 14 of Limitation Act in pre-emption case</strong>.—Pre-emption petition filed two years prior to the date of registration of the deed under pre-emption--.Dismissed on the ground of immaturity—delay of long 13 months caused in filing second petition for pre-emption—Petitioners prosecuting previous proceeding diligently and in good faith—wrong advice of lawyer—Petitioners are entitled to claim the benefit of section 14(2) of the Limitation Act in computing the period of limitation— Limitation Act, 1908 (IX of 19081, S. 14(2).</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Faizer Rahinan and others Vs. Atiar Miah,nud Shaikh and others, IOBLD (HCD) 401</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section— 96</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Legislative intent</strong>—The clear intention of the legislature was to confer a right of preemption holding-wise. A distinct right has been conferred in respect of a distinct holding.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Birendra Nath Chakraborty Vs. Subal Chandra Biswas and others, 108LD(HCD) 424.</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 26 DLR93; I9DLR 659: I4DLR 796 (Dacca); 103DLR 283—Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Sections—116 and 117</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Sub-division of a joint tenancy—</strong>Subdivision is permissible only on the application of one or more co-sharer tenants— Notice is a must to the parties concerned in cases--of amalgamation, consolidation and sub-division—No proceeding for sub-division of -a joint tenancy can be taken without any application by a tenant and notice to all the parties concerned.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Md. Khairullah Bhuiyan Vs. A,nena Khatun and others, 2BLD(HCD) 72</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: 17 DLR384; 16DLR77—Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Sections—116 and 117 (1)(a)</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Amalgamation and consolidation of holdings</strong>—Revenue Officer competent to pass such order suo motu—Payment of rent at the old rate even after amalgamation and consolidation cannot set at naught the process which was duly made and acted upon—Wheli order of amalgamation has been passed by the competent authority and in accordance with law its validity cannot be challenged in the preemption proceeding—Prima facie the order was a valid one, its validity cannot be chalenged- for a collateral purpose—The civil Court while dealing with an altogether different matter cannot ignore the order passed by a competent Revenue Officer.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Md. Khairuilah Bhuivan Vs. Haji Nurul Alam Chowdhury, 3BLD (AD)179</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. 33DLR(AD) 309: 33DLK(AD)323; 51 C.W.N. 644—Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—117</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Lis pendens</strong>— The expression ‘otherwise dealt with in section 52 of T.P. Act covers sub-division of holding—Mutation of holding during the pendency of pre-emption proceeding comes within the mischief of doctrine of us pendens—Such mutation will not bar the right of pre-emption—Transfer of Property Act, 1882 (IV of 1882), S. 52: Non Agricultural Tenancy Act, 1949 (XXIII of 1949), S.24.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Md. Abdur Rouf and others Vs. Ahmuda Khatun and others, 1BLD (AD)269</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—117(i)</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Mutation without notice to cosharers</strong>—Statutory requirement of notice upon co-sharers before effecting mutation of holding is mandatory and mutation of holding without notice to a co-sharer isnot binding on the co-sharer.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Md. Abdur Rouf and others Vs. Ahmuda Khatun and others, 1BLD (AD)269</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref: (1967) I9DLR(SC)36;—Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—143</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Revenue Officer-not a Court</strong>— Whether a Revenue Officer dealing with mutation proceedings is a Court— Whether cognizance of an offence by a Magistrate without a complaint in writing by the Revenue Officer for committing forgery in respect of a document produced before- him legal—The Revenue Officer holding mutation proceeding does not act as a Court within the meaning of section 195(1) Cr. P.C—There is no bar for the Magistrate in taking cognizance of the case in the absence of any complaint from him—State Acquisition and Tenancy Rule, 1955, Rules 22-25; Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898 (V of 1898) S. 195 (1)(C).</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Idris Ali and others Vs. The state, 6BLD (HCD) 7</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ref. AIR. 1950 (SC)188; 8 CLR 330 at page 357: 1931 AC. 276; PLD 1956 SC (md) 65; PLD (1957) (SC) (Pak)91; 26 DLR 157; 27 DLR 388: 20 DLR (Dhaka) 1019; A.I.R. 1926(PC)lO0; 9DLR(WP) (Lahore) 40; PLD I 973(SC)6 19:—Cited.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—143 A</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Record of rights</strong> —rectification of—Material question in deciding such a case—An application under section 143A is not a suit for declaration of title but is a proceeding for rectification of mistakes in the record of rights prepared on the basis of possession in the land in question—The scheme of the section shows that possession is the material question.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>The Assistant Custodian, Enemy Property (L &amp; B) Tangail, Vs. Bholanath Guha and others, 4BLD (AD) 159</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section — 146</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Board of Land Administration</strong>—Section 146(1) shows that the general power of superintendence and control over all Revenue Officers is vested in the Board of Land Administration and not in the Government. Moreover, section 146(1) vests the Board of Land Administration with Administrative control over the Revenue Officers and by no means empowers it to revise the order passed by the Revenue Officers under the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Saifur Rahman Vs. Govt. of Bangladesh and others, 10 BLD (AD) 286.</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Sections—147, 148, 149 and 150</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Appeal, Revision and Review</strong>—The powers of appeal, revision and review are in sections 147 to 150 of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Section 147 of the Act provides for preferring appeal against the orders of the Revenue Officer and this section shows that the appellate authority is the Collector, when the order is made by a Revenue Officer subordinate to the Collector, Commissioner of the Division, when the order is made by the Collector of a District within the division and the Board of Land Administration, when the or- der is made by the Commissioner of a division. There is no other authority under section 147 to whom an appeal can be preferred.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Section 148 of the Act provides for the period of limitation for an appeal under section 147 of the Act.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Section 149 provides for revision of an order passed by a Revenue Officer. Under this section similar to an appeal, the Collector, the Commissioner and the Board of Land Administration have been vested with the power of revision against the orders of the Revenue Officers. Section 149 does not empower the Government to revise, rescind or cancel any order passed by a Revenue Officer.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Section 150 of the Act provides for review of an order by the Officer himself who passed the order.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Saiftir Rahman Vs. Govt. of Bangladesh and others, 10BLD (HCD) 286</em></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—151</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Limitation</strong>—Pre-emption under section 96 of State Acquisition and Tenancy Act— Limitation—Pre-emptor entitled to exclusion of ttrne of proceeding bonafide prosecuted in a Court without jurisdiction—Limitation Act, 1908 (IX of 1908), Ss. 14 and 29.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Md. Abdul Majid and others Vs. Serina Begum and others, 1BLD (HCD) 350.</em></strong><span id="pastemarkerend"></span></p></div></div>
1226	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">STATE OWNED MANUFACTURING INDUSTRIAL WORKERS (TERMS AND CONDITIONS) ACT, 1974</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  2 BLD (HCD)141.</p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  1974</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  STATE OWNED MANUFACTURING INDUSTRIAL WORKERS (TERMS AND CONDITIONS)</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p align="center" style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: center;"><strong><u>STATE OWNED MANUFACTURING INDUSTRIAL WORKERS (TERMS AND CONDITIONS) ACT, 1974</u></strong></p><p align="center" style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: center;"><strong><u>(X OF 1974)</u></strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section—3</strong></p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Agreement with workers</strong>—The validity of—State-owned Manufacturing Industrial Workers (Terms and Conditions) Act. 1 974 and its subsequent amendment fixed the wages for spool packers—An earlier agreement with them fixing their wages has then lost its force—Labour Court’s order directing payment of wages under the agreement is without lawful authority.</p><p style="margin-right: -.2in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>M/s. carpeting Jute Mills Ltd. Vs. Chairman, Khu Inn Labour Court and others, 2 BLD (HCD)141.</em></strong></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
1227	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">SUCCESSION ACT, 1925</h2>
